headline: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1982; Energy
abstract: Gasoline prices in the U.S. have dropped 2 cents to 3 cents a gallon in less than a month because of the worldwide oversupply of crude oil. Further reductions, analysts say, are all but certain.  Since last April, the national average price of gasoline has dropped by about a nickel, to $1.35, according to Platt's Oil Price Report, a trade publication. The decline in pump prices is in marked contrast to the near-tripling between 1973 and last April. (Page A1.)   China opened its offshore waters to foreign oil companies for exploration and production, beginning a new phase in its economic cooperation. Peking is seeking quick development of an energy source that it hopes will supply fuel for decades. Bids were invited from 46 companies from 12 countries. In all, 23 American companies were said to have expressed interest. (D1.)

headline: 13 DIE IN COLD AND STORMS IN NORTHERN EUROPE
abstract: Snowstorms and frigid air gripped Britain again today with no warming trend in sight. The death toll from the unseasonal cold spreading across northern Europe rose to at least 13.    In Britain, after one of the coldest nights on record, the police warned drivers to stay off the highways unless ''absolutely necessary.'' Snow and ice made dozens of roads in Wales impassable, and hundreds of cars were abandoned in snowdrifts up to 20 feet deep.

headline: FOR TURKS, COFFEE BREAK RETURNS
abstract: Turkish teahouses can become coffeehouses again with the ending of a four-year ban on coffee imports.  The decision to allow imports of coffee and 12 other banned items was announced several days ago by Minister of Trade Kemal Canturk as a sign that some economic gains have been made in Turkey. The import ban was imposed at a time when Turkey was forced to spend its hardcurrency earnings on oil products.

headline: G.N.P. MILESTONE: $3 TRILLION
abstract: Last Dec. 11, some of the big news of the day was: The Security Council picked a new Secretary General of the United Nations; Argentina's President was ousted by the military junta; the House approved a foreign aid bill.   Some of the small news was: A Norwegian ship broker was sentenced to 20 years for a grain scam; American Tourister laid off 40 people; Grumman snared a $71 million Air Force contract.   Nowhere in the next day's papers, though, was there any coverage of the fact that at 11 A.M. on Dec. 11, the country's gross national product crossed the $3 trillion mark.   To be fair to all those who missed it, no one knows for sure that the big moment occurred at 11 on the 11th. It could have been an hour earlier, or a day later, or two weeks before, when you had your hands full with a dinner party for eight. G.N.P. is tough to get a fix on.

headline: NORTH KOREANS' GUERRILLA TRAINING WORRIES SOUTH
abstract: A dozen deafening drills were turned off at a Seoul subway construction site so that the foreman could make himself heard.   The foreman, Cho Myung Chae, who said his gang was ''making one yard a day'' at one of the 84 construction sites where work is proceeding on a second subway line, recalled tunneling of a different kind that he did three years ago.   He was one of a team from a South Korean engineering group that cut an interception tunnel going north to meet an ''invasion tunnel'' built by North Koreans under the demilitarized zone.

headline: NOMINEE FOR PRETORIA POST BACKS 'PEACEFUL CHANGE'
abstract: Herman W. Nickel, President Reagan's nominee to be the United States Ambassador to South Africa, told a Senate confirmation hearing today that he favored ''peaceful change'' in southern Africa, but his support of Reagan Administration policies in the region drew criticism from two church-related groups.   The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is expected to vote on Mr.  Nickel's nomination Tuesday.  Mr. Nickel, a former Time magazine correspondent and a onetime member of the board of editors of Fortune magazine, said revolutionary change in the region would provoke a ''major crisis for our allies and ourself and risk turning Africa into a theater of confrontation for the major powers.''   He said a policy of ''constructive engagement,'' using American economic involvement as a means of influencing South Africa, was the preferred way of insuring peaceful change in the region.

headline: FUNDS FOR NEW LAKER VENTURE
abstract: An agreement has been reached that could provide Sir Freddie Laker with the financing he needs to begin another lowfare, trans-Atlantic airline service, his new partner, Roland W.  Rowland, announced tod ay. But the new venture might have some problems getting off the ground.   The new company, Mr. Rowland said, would be a 50-50 venture involving an initial investment of up to $35 million by Lonrho Ltd., of which Mr. Rowland is chairman, and the purchase or lease of five McDonnell-Douglas DC-10's. That would be about one-third the number of planes operated by Laker Airways when it went into receivership last week with debts of over $500 million.

headline: DONATIONS AND LOSSES: SOME RULES LIBERALIZED
abstract: Taxpayers who contributed to their alma maters last year, saw their basement playrooms destroyed by a flood or attended school to further their careers may be able to pare their taxes by itemizing deductions. Last year, the new tax law also granted a retroactive break to parents who adopted hard-to-place children in 1981, permitting them to deduct some of their adoption-related expenses for the first time, and new court decisions liberalized the rules for theft and casualty losses.   Among other things, the courts approved a theft claim filed by a woman who had paid a divorce fee to a lawyer who had falsely told her he had obtained her divorce, and granted similar casualty deductions to taxpayers who did not seek reimbursement of their losses from their insurance companies.   Charitable contributions are one of the most common itemized deductions. But starting in 1982, even taxpayers who do not itemize will be able to subtract a certain portion of their donations (the limit is $25, or 25 percent of the first $100 in contributions by singles or ma rried persons filing jointly).

headline: Washington Watch; Oil-Price Effect On Recovery
abstract: WASHINGTON SKIDDING oil prices are cheering Reagan Administration economic analysts, who are convinced that what have already been significant savings in energy bills represent a major plus for economic growth.   The falling oil prices ''are the ace in the hole for the recovery we expect to be under way in the second half,'' said one Reagan planner, who added that the impact could be equivalent to a tax cut in spurring consumption. The decreases lie, in part, behind the forecast of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan that the economy will come ''roaring back'' after sharp declines in the fourth quarter of 1981 and first quarter of this year.   Officials here consider it unlikely that the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which have just tried to revive their cartel at an emergency meeting in Vienna, can put into effect a scale of production cuts sufficient to arrest the slide. The oil ministers agreed last Friday to cut output by about 700,000 barrels a day

headline: SOVIET GENERALS DESCEND ON NEW DELHI
abstract: Led by Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the 73-year-old Soviet Defense Minister, 16 senior Soviet officers arrived here to affirm the Soviet-Indian relationship as obviously as possible.   Officially, both Indian and Soviet spokesmen described the visit - the first by Marshal Ustinov to any non-Communist country - as a show of amity and good will. The Indians, however, have sought to characterize the visit as just another in a series of exchanges that will not endanger Indian claims to following an independent foreign policy, while the Soviet visitors, arriving in such strength, were indicating their interest in at least maintaining their position as India's chief arms supplier.   ''The successful cooperation in the field of defense between the two countries serves both the national interests of India and the Soviet Union as well as the interests of strengthening of universal peace and security,'' Marshal Ustinov said on his arrival.  ''Indo-Soviet relations are developing steadily,'' added the Defense Minister, who is also a member of the Soviet Politburo.

headline: No Headline
abstract: To the Business Editor:   The old ad age that ''the more things change, the more they stay the same,'' applies well to Professor MacAvoy. In criticizing the Business Roundtable's recent statement on corporate responsibility, Professor MacAvoy stepped into Milton Friedman's shoes as the defender of another hoary adage, ''The business of business is business.'' Professor MacAvoy goes on to criticize the statement's lack of specificity in how to make the difficult trade-offs among the demands of these groups. That may be a fair criticism; but in asserting that corporate concern ''with community needs and problems'' as well as with ''the interest of society at large'' exceed a company's responsibilities, he ignores the necessary complexity of ''enlightened self-interest,'' flies in the face of current political realities, and runs smack into the Reagan Administration's drive to get the private sector to take up some of the slack caused by Federal budget cuts.

headline: Other Business; HOWARD RUFF'S NEW TUNE
abstract: When Howard Ruff sings does anyone listen? At $9.95 a shot, he hopes so. Mr. Ruff, better known for run-for-the-hills economic advice, has cut his first album. The adviser, who turns out to be a classical baritone, renders ''I Walked Today Where Jesus Walked'' and ''If I Were a Rich Man,'' among other numbers.  Put out by Mr. Ruff's Target Records, Howard Ruff Sings would make any rock-ribbed American patriate weep. Aside from ''Rich Man'' (from the Broadway musical ''Fiddler on the Roof''), there are ''Climb Every Mountain'' (from ''The Sound of Music''), ''Hymn to America'' and ''My Way,'' a song Frank Sinatra made famous.

headline: SURVEY FINDS ECONOMY STILL WEAK
abstract: A sampling of the opinions of purchasing managers from the nation's industrial companies indicates that the economy remained weak in January. However, the rate of decline slowed, according to the survey, taken by the National Association of Purchasing Management and released yesterday.   Referring to the slower rate of decline, Charles Haffey, chairman of the association's business committee and vice president of corporate purchasing for Pfizer Inc., said, ''The key in January's figures is the rate. The really bad news is employment.''

headline: EAST GERMANS WARMLY GREET JARUZELSKI
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, flew here today for a day's visit.  It was his second trip abroad since he imposed martial law in Poland on Dec. 13, and like his first trip, to Moscow, was ostensibly aimed at bolstering economic cooperation.   General Jaruzelski was given a hero's welcome by the East German leaders, who were among the sharpest critics of liberalization in Poland and who had called repeatedly for a crackdown.   The 10-member Polish delegation was received with full military honors, including a 21-gun salute, at Schonefeld Airport by the East German leader, Erich Honecker, and his associates.

headline: Critics' Choices
abstract: PHOTOGRAPHY The dark, square prints of Robert Giard have an air of quiet menace about them. The people in his portraits do not connect with the viewer in a friendly way.

headline: India Raising Military Outlay
abstract: India's military spending will rise 11 percent to $5.65 billion under the budget announced today for the fiscal year beginning April 1.

headline: U.S. Carrier in Kenyan Port
abstract: The United States aircraft carrier Constellation, which is part of the American naval presence in the Indian Ocean, dropped anchor at the Kenyan port of Mombasa today for a good-will visit, the United States Embassy said. The 60,100-ton carrier is scheduled to remain at Mombasa until Saturday.

headline: SYRIA ACCUSES JORDAN OF KILLING SOLDIER IN RAID
abstract: Syria said today that armed men infiltrated into its territory from Jordan on Thursday and ambushed an army patrol, killing a sergeant and wounding another soldier.   The raiders withdrew under covering fire from Jordanian troops on the Jordanian side of the border, a Syrian Government spokesman said ,according to the Damascus radio.

headline: Former Ambassador to China Talks on Peking-Moscow Ties
abstract: The United States should be careful not to use China's uneasiness with the Soviet Union as a ''counterweight'' in foreign policy, says Leonard Woodcock, a former United States Ambassador to China.   Mr. Woodcock said Thursday that strong cultural and ideological differences between the two Communist countries will keep them from establishing a warm relationship.   He also told a University of Connecticut audience that Taiwan and Chinacould ''find a mutually acceptable political accommodation'' to their differences if left alone.

headline: On Cable Magazine's April Fool's Rumor
abstract: As the April issue of On Cable magazine began to reach subscribers last week, a report spread through the industry that Ted Turner's electronic empire was being gobbled up by NBC. It was sparked by the editor Peter Funt's column Up Front with the headline ''Turner Broadcasting Merges With NBC!''

headline: PROSECUTION OF POLITICIAN STIRS QUEBEC
abstract: An extraordinary outpouring of sympathy has emerged for Claude Charron, the former majority leader of the Quebec Assembly, who was fined last month for shoplifting in a Montreal store. And the incident has brought out all the old tensions that have characterized English-French relations in Montreal.   Mr. Charron resigned his leadership post in the assembly as well as his membership in the provincial cabinet after admitting that he tried to steal a jacket worth $120 from Eaton's. The store is part of a chain controlled by the Eaton family of Toronto and part of a Quebec business establishment dominated by English Canadian interests.

headline: Itel in Accord With Creditors
abstract: The Itel Corporation, an equipment leasing company that filed for protection from its creditors in January 1981, said that it had reached an agreement with representatives of its unsecured creditors on major elements of a proposed reorganization plan.   The proposal provides that senior unsecured creditors and subordinated debt holders would receive a minimum of $654 million face amount of debt securities, preferred stock and cash, plus interest equivalent payments on certain amounts, as well as 79 percent of the stock in the reorganized company.

headline: Pabst Rejects Bid
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company said its board had rejected the previously announced $131 million unsolicited acquisition proposal from C. Schmidt & Sons Inc., a Philadelphia brewer. Pabst said the board had determined the $16-a-share Schmidt proposal was financially inadequate and not in the best interest of Pabst or its shareholders.

headline: DUARTE ALLY SEES SETBACK FOR LEFTISTS
abstract: President Luis Herrera Campins of Venezuela, the Salvadoran's Government strongest Latin American supporter, said today that the large voter turnout in El Salvador Sunday was a rejection of the leftist opposition there.   But he warned that Venezuela would reduce its aid to El Salvador should a rightist coalition reverse the country's policies favoring income and land redistribution.   Venezuela gave El Salvador more than $81 million in economic aid last year, more than the United States, but Mr. Herrera's warning may indicate a parting of the ways with the Reagan Adminstration. Reforms 'a Condition for Peace'   ''One condition for peace,'' Mr. Herrera said of any new government, ''is that they maintain the social reforms. Our plan is to cooperate with all democratic processes except those that signify a retreat, which could negate the possibility of peace.''

headline: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Consumer installment debt fell $173 million in December as Americans paid off more than they borrowed for the first time since July 1980, the Federal Reserve Board reported. It said credit extended for new purchases declined 2.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted $26.87 billion. The figure was seen as new evidence that t herecession was worsening as 1981 ended. (Page D1.)   President Reagan's budget request was attacked by members of both parties as Administration officials began their formal presentation of the proposal to Congress. Senate Republicans indicated they would rewrite the budget, voicing interest in a Democratic plan to place a partial freeze on Federal spending and tax cuts. (A1.) Mr. Reagan, continuing his Middle Western swing, used some of the harshest language of his Presidency in defending his budget. (A1.)

headline: Chrysler Talks On Unit's Sale
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation is reported near an agreement to sell its tank-building unit, but one of the three companies said to be bidding said yesterday it had dropped out.   Sources had identified the bidders as the General Dynamics Corporation, Teledyne Inc. and the LTV Corporation.

headline: Tendler Turns Phibro Toward New Objectives
abstract: With the acquisition of Salomon Brothers, David Tendler, the 43-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Phibro Corporation, continues to lead his company rapidly into new avenues of diversification.   The new Salomon division of Phibro was formed in a manner for which Mr. Tendler is well-known: quickly, swiftly and secretly.

headline: Briton in Arctic Trek Has a Narrow Escape
abstract: The leader of a two-man British expedition trying to circle the globe by the two poles narrowly escaped death in the Arctic Ocean and the team lost some equipment, organizers reported today.   A support plane delivered fresh supplies to Sir Ranulph Fiennes and his associate, Charles Burton, and they are scheduled to resume their journey to the North Pole, 400 miles away, Tuesday.

headline: THOUSANDS MOURN A 'MARTYR' IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Bearing the coffin of a white trade union organizer who died in detention and the flag of the outlawed African National Congress, a cortege of more than 1,000 blacks and whites wound its way slowly for about four miles today through downtown Johannesburg and its white suburbs.   In the South African context, where demonstrations against white minority rule are almost automatically proclaimed to be ''riotous assemblies,'' it was a startling sight - almost certainly the largest display of black political feeling to have been seen in the white areas here since the Congress movement was forced underground in 1960 by a banning order.   The police, carrying riot equipment, were stationed along the route, but the procession was allowed to proceed, in defiance of laws that make it a crime to show support for a banned organization. When it came within half a mile of the segregated white cemetery where Dr. Neil Aggett was to be buried, the casket was removed from the hearse and carried in the front rank of the marchers who strode in front of a convoy of about 17 buses.

headline: Around the World; Marcos Changes Mind On Communist Party
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who was quoted last week as saying that it was legally possible for the Communist Party to take part in the political process if it renounced violence, said today that his ruling party was not prepared to allow the party to become formally accredited.   Mr. Marcos told reporters that the Communist Party had to renounce its avowed objective of overthrowing the Government by violence, join elections and receive at least 10 percent of the vote before it could be accredited.

headline: U.S. PLANS PROTEST ON POLAND AT MADRID TALKS
abstract: The United States is planning several measures, including a prolonged recess of the Madrid talks on East-West cooperatio n, to demonstrate its opposition to the crackdown in Poland, Administration officials disclosed today.   The Madrid conference is scheduled to resume on Feb. 9. The United States is urging the Western allies to adopt a plan under which the conference would concentrate for a week to 10 days on Western charges of Soviet breaches of the 1975 Helsinki accords, then would recess until September or October.   It would make no sense for the West to negotiate new agreements at Madrid, American officials said, while the Soviet bloc was violating existing accords.

headline: IN THE SHADOWS OF MADISON AVENUE
abstract: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Andrew Feinberg writes on advertising in New York. By ANDREW FEINBERG   I t's a well-known practice on Madison Avenue. An advertising agency buys a television program and sells it to a station, not for cash, in some instances, but for air time for commercials. The time is then entered into what's called a time bank, usually in a computer. Then, from the time bank, the agency sells its clients the time for their commercials.   The practice is known as bartering, and some barter deals are relatively straightforward. A variation called the tie-in barter, however, often finds the agency using its considerable leverage on the station to make the deal work. It might go something like this: Take the show and you'll get 40 percent of our business in your market. Reject it and you may suffer. Although agencies deny it, their critics say that their tactics are often coercive and unethical.

headline: Red Brigades Terrorists To Go on Trial Today
abstract: Sixteen Red Brigades terrorists charged with the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier go on trial Monday in a heavily protected courthouse two miles from where the general was abducted.   Eight of the terrorists accused of taking part in the kidnapping, including five captured in the Italian police raid on the ''people's prison'' where General Dozier was held 42 days, are expected to be present. The other eight are still at large and will be tried in absentia.

headline: AWACS ACCORD IS DENIED BY SAUDI
abstract: Saudi Arabia denied today that it had signed an agreement with the United States on conditions governing the use of the five United States Awacs surveillance aircraft to be delivered to the Saudis in 1985.   The Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, made the denial to the Arabic daily Asharq al-Awsat in response to Western press reports that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger had negotiated such an accord during a recent visit to Riyadh.

headline: AUTHOR CALLS ARMS SALES A MAJOR POLICY TOOL
abstract: A newly published book contends that the sale of military weapons and equipment has become the major instrument of foreign policy for both the Western powers and for the Soviet Union.   The book, commissioned by the Council on Foreign Relations and written by a senior research fellow of the Council, Andrew J. Pierre, is entitled ''The Global Politics of Arms Sales.'' It was published by the Princeton University Press.   Mr. Pierre takes a less disapproving stance than some earlier writers did about the steadily increasing scale of arms sales by the major industrial powers to the developing nations.

headline: G.M. TO GET $500 MILLION FOR EDIFICE
abstract: The General Motors Corporation moved a step closer yesterday to selling its New York City office building, through a private financing deal that would garner the cash-short No.1 auto maker $500 million.   G.M. granted an option to Corporate Property Investors to buy the 50-story office building, at 767 Fifth Avenue, in 1991 and the Manhattan-based real estate concern agreed to provide the auto maker with $50 0 mil lion in return for 10 percent, 10-year notes from G.M.   C.P.I., founded in 1971, is privately held, with both American and foreign investors. It owns New York City properties, and such major regional shopping centers as Lenox Square in Atlanta, Burlington Mall in Boston and Roosevelt Field on Long Island.

headline: Colombia Holds 3 in Shooting Of 2 American Drug Agents
abstract: The police said they had arrested two Cubans and a Briton today in connection with the kidnapping and shooting here last Tuesday of two American drug enforcement officers.

headline: POLISH WORKER TELLS OF STREET BATTLES IN GDANSK AT TIME OF THE CRACKDOWN
abstract: A 20-year-old worker from Gdansk arrived in Warsaw today and provided an account of the street fighting there in the days after the imposition of martial law Dec. 13. The authorites have said that more than 300 people were injured in the fighting and have admitted one death.   The worker, who is now a courier for a resistance movement, said that an underground involving several hundred people had already formed on the Baltic Coast but that it was not planning to engage in open activity until the spring.   Following are excerpts from a three-hour interview with John Darnton, The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, in the worker's own words but arranged chronologically. Special to the New York Times   WARSAW, Jan. 14 - A 20-year-old worker from Gdansk arrived in Warsaw today and provided an account of the street fighting there in the days after the imposition of martial law Dec. 13. The authorites have said that more than 300 people were injured in the fighting and have admitted one death.

headline: ERNST & WHINNEY SUED BY U.S. ON TAX ADVICE
abstract: The Justice Department charged today that Ernst & Whinney, one of the nation's ''Big Eight'' accounting firms, was advising its clients to classify business property falsely to reduce their taxes.   The department, in a civil suit filed in Atlanta, sought a court order directing the company to stop offering its ''investment tax credit study'' service and to turn over to the Internal Revenue Service the names of all clients who have received it.   Ernst & Whinney's chairman, Ray Groves, in a statement released by Harold Wolfson, a spokesman, called the Government's suit ''unwarranted and misplaced'' and said the firm's investment tax credit advice ''was not deceptive.''

headline: Washington Watch; Regan's Fight With the Fed
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Federal Reserve is still Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's bete noir. And the former Merrill Lynch chairman still doesn't know whether he can get the nation's central bank off his back.   When the Treasury Secretary went after the Fed this summer - in an effort to get its chairman, Pa ul A. Volcker, to loosen his grip on the money sup ply - the chairman ignored the Secretary. To make matters worse , the top economists in Treasury, the Council of Economic Advi sers and the Office of Management and Budget also supported Mr.  Volcker.

headline: WHITE MOTOR CITES HUGE LOSS
abstract: The White Motor Corporation, the ailing truck manufacturer that has been trying to reorganize after filing a bankruptcy petition last year, announced yesterday that it lost more than $300 million on operations and the sale of assets during the 15-month period ending March 31, 1981.   The losses leave White - once a billion-dollar-a-year maker of heavy-duty trucks, forklifts and farm equipment - with a negative net worth of nearly $70 million and very little prospect of ever restoring itself into a viable manufacturing concern, as it had hoped to do when it filed its bankruptcy petition in September 1980.   An official at the Cleveland-based corporation said that because of the downturn in the economy and the truck-building industry, and the loss of many key managers during the past 15 months, it was likely that White's remaining assets would eventually be liquidated to pay off as much of its debt as possible. The likelihood that the company would be revived or that its stockholders would receive anything for the nine million outstanding shares was ''very bleak,'' the official said.

headline: Mitsui-Iran Deal Cited
abstract: Mitsui and Company Ltd. has signed a contract to import 150,000 metric tons of fuel oil, worth about $23 million, from the National Ir anian Oil Company, the Japanese news agency Kyodo reported today. Mitsui will also shortly conclude a contract to e xport chemical products, such as synthetic resin materials, to Iran in exchange for the fuel oil, Kyodo reported.

headline: RIYADH'S MARKETS REFLECT ITS PAST AND FUTURE
abstract: To visit this city's souk is at once to wander into A rabia's exotic past, glimpse its future and to sense theoften confusi ng present linking the two.   Hundreds of gold bracelets are coiled like small snakes in stall after stall in the gold souk. Nearby, workers sort through bales of sweetly fragrant incense and spices from the Far East. On one corner, an old Saudi man sharpens scissors on a decrepit manual machine while pulsating Arabic music blares from a radio.

headline: FINNISH LEADER, IN MOSCOW, VOWS TO MAINTAIN CLOSE TIES TO SOVIET
abstract: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland pledged today that his nation would continue to pursue a policy of friendly relations with the Soviet Union.   On his first visit to the Soviet Union as head of state, Mr.  Koivisto told Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, at a Kremlin banquet that he would unflaggingly follow the path mapped out by his predecessor, President Urho Kekkonen.   Mr. Koivisto took over in January from Mr. Kekkonen, who in 25 years as President built up close ties, based on a neutral foreign policy, between Finland and the Soviet Union.

headline: AMERICANS DOMINANT IN TECHNOLOGY
abstract: AMERICAN businessmen talk these days about new technology as the trump card in international competition. Confronted with a competitive onslaught based in part on advancing technology in Japan and, to a lesser extent, Western Europe, they are plunging resources into research and development.   Consultants and academics are flooding business journals with reports on the strategic implications of technology and how to manage it. Still, although France, West Germany and Japan have joined the United States to make up what John Harris, president of the Technology Management Group at Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a consulting group, calls technology's ''big four,'' technology experts agree that over all, the United States has never lost the position it assumed during the 1940's as the world's leader in new technology.

headline: Pabst Dissidents Seek More Shares
abstract: Shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company, led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor, have mailed proxy materials as part of their plan to gain control of the brewer. The group is dissatisfied with the current management, and has accused the board of indecisiveness in the face of severe financial problems.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 11 A.M.

headline: ALTAMIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

headline: Economic Scene; How to Avoid A Depression
abstract: THE job of avoiding a depression and setting the economy back on a course of stable growth cannot be achieved by some ''quick fix.'' It will require a balanced combination of policies commanding broad national support.   A plan to reduce the huge prospective deficits -a key element in the strategy for relieving the pressures on monetary policy and reducing interest rates - needs bipartisan support in Congress and genuine White House cooperation. This is likely to require a willingness on the part of the President to change the budget and tax priorities, to ease the burdens so heavily concentrated on the poor and the ''working poor,'' to scale down oversized tax cuts and to shape a military policy that relies less on ''throwing dollars at problems,'' and instead serves a comprehensive and coherent national security strategy, which has been lacking.

headline: Patents; Bed Sheet Enhances Patients' Comfort
abstract: A top bed sheet that provides space underneath for comfortable accommodation of the user's feet was patented this week for the Sleep Knit Corporation, New York. According to Sidney M. Weiss, who was granted patent 4,308,626, an initial version, made of soft, stretchable cotton, is currently in use by more than 200 hospitals, including several in New York.

headline: RETAIL CHIEF NAMED AT BANK OF AMERICA
abstract: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, has grouped together its worldwide retail banking and consumer-service activities under one officer, James B. Wiesler, a 54-year-old executive vice president. Mr. Wiesler will be responsible for all of the San Francisco-based bank's present and future retail functions in California, the rest of the United States and overseas.   Largely because of difficulties in consumer operations, earnings of the BankAmerica Corporation, the bank's corporate parent, fell 47 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981 and 31 percent for the full year.

headline: Weinberger Supports Efforts To Protect Salvadoran Junta
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today backed Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s view that the United States must do ''whatever is necessary'' to prevent the overthrow of the American-backed junta in El Salvador.

headline: SOVIET PENTECOSTAL IS VISITED IN HOSPITAL
abstract: American officials today were allowed to visit the Pentecostal who was hospitalized after a hunger strike at the United States Embassy. They said she had resumed eating solid foods and appeared in good spirits and health.   The visit by the Americans, Dr. John Schadler, the embassy physician, and James Curt Struble, a consular official, was the first since the Pentecostal, Lidiya Vashchenko, 30 years old, was moved to a Soviet hospital from the embassy on Saturday after a monthlong fast during which she drank only tea and juices.

headline: Gas-Powered Ford Vehicle
abstract: The Ford Motor Company introduced a twopassenger car that burns natural gas and can be refueled at home.  There are no plans to produce the car.

headline: U.S. Chief Named At Triumph-Adler
abstract: Triumph-Adler, the West German-based international business equipment manufacturer, has established Triumph-Adler North America to bring together its American units under one umbrella and has named Robert R. Hagy president and chief executive officer. Among the components in the American operation -with temporary headquarters in Hartford, but moving next month to nearby Windsor - are Royal Business Machines, the Pertec Computer Corporation and McBee Loose Leaf Binders.   Triumph-Adler was acqured in 1979 by Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, from Litton Industries of the United States for $440 million. It was Volkswagen's first major diversification, but the new subsidiary has turned out to be a major headache for the auto manufacturer. It lost $38 million in 1980 and its deficit last year has been estimated at more than $100 million. Analysts attributed the losses to poo r management decisions. It is not known if the American units are als o losing money because Triumph-Adler does not disclose profitabillit y figures for its various operating units.

abstract: To the Business Editor: I heartily applaud and endorse the suggestion of James S. Tisch in ''Reading the Stock Tables'' (Feb. 7) to list the closing price and price change before the name of the stock.

headline: Mortgage Rates Rise
abstract: The average interest rate on 30-year home mortgages rose to 17.30 percent for the week ending Jan.8, up from 17.04 percent in the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today in its weekly primary mortgage market survey. The rate applies to single-family home mortgages with a 20 percent down payment. David Andrukonis, an economist for the mortgage corporation, said that the mortgage rate average rose steadily through 1981, to a peak of 18.63 percent on Oct.9.

headline: Borden Net Rises 25.4%
abstract: Borden Inc., a diversified food and chemical concern, said yesterday that its earnings for both the final quarter and all of 1981 rose to record levels despite a slight drop in sales.

headline: Investing; FEAR A FLOOD? HOW TO BUILD YOUR ARK
abstract: CRASH: It's a chilling word, and the thought that the economy might s ink into something akin to the 1930's experience has provoked a s pasm of apprehension across the country in the past few weeks.  From corporate board rooms to brokerage trading rooms, the fears are that: The Federal deficit will require so much debt capital that an economic upturn will never get under way; towering interest rates will lead to major bankruptcies; falling prices for commodities and real estate will snowball into a deflationary collapse; and the high unemployment and idle capacity plaguing the auto and home-building industries will spread nationwide.  There are any number of reasons to doubt this scenario. One is that depression anxiety is a natural psychological response to any deep recession. Also, as every contrary thinker knows, economic events that receive a lot of advance publicity often turn out to be duds.  Remember when gold was going to go to $3,000 an ounce, oil to $55 a barrel?

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Company News; AT AILING BRANIFF, SACRIFICES HAVE BECOME PART OF THE JOB
abstract: Making sacrifices to help keep Braniff International from failing is nothing new to the airline's employees.  Since 1979, Braniff has lost a total of $335 million, and many of the troubled company's remaining employees - the ranks have been thinned by furloughs, layoffs and attrition - seem convinced that, without their concessions, they would have been out of work long before now.   A year ago, the employees agreed to a 10 percent pay cut, and this week they had to defer receiving half their paychecks.  They are not exactly happy about it. In fact, some said they fear that the airline is just playing them along, saving whatever it can with the knowledge that it is going to collapse soon.

headline: Advertising; New Shop Seeks Its Own Niche
abstract: TWO former leaders of the Needham, Harper & Steers creative department in New York, Lois Korey and Allen Kay, have opened their own advertising agency with $6 million in billings.   The proprietors of Korey, Kay & Partners, which has offices in the Empire State Building, last Friday explained what will set their agency apart from the field.   It is being positioned as a shop for entrepreneurs and an agency that, although a corporation for legal reasons, will conduct itself like a partnership. No corporate titles will be made public.

abstract: The Administration cautioned Congress that lawmakers would have to bear the responsibility if the President's budget were not approved and the economy faltered as a result. In issuing the warning, David A. Stockman, the budget director, said there were few acceptable alternatives to the President's budget plans. (Page A1.).

headline: Article 159890 -- No Title
abstract: David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles real estate developer and investor who put together the deal earlier this year under which Occidental Petroleum bought Iowa Beef, has now made a $375 million offer for the Cannon Mills Company, the nation's seventh-largest publicly held textile manufacturer.   Cannon announced yesterday that it had received an unsolicited acquisition offer, for $40 a share, from the Pacific Holding Corporation, a company owned by Mr. Murdock. Following a board meeting, Cannon announced that the proposal would be referred to the company's financial advisers. However, analysts said that they did not expect Cannon to accept the offer.

headline: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
abstract: TOKYO Japan's unemployment problem is one that other industrialized nations wish they had. Its 2.1 percent jobless rate is far lower than elsewhere, and it is extremely stable. The yearly peak was 2.2 percent, reached in 1978, when this oil-poor nation was in the throes of adjusting to high-cost energy.

headline: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board will continue to pursue a tight monetary policy this year, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed's chairman, said in presenting his annual monetary targets to Con gress. Mr. Volcker said spending cuts and tax increases to reduce pro jected Federal budget deficits were crucial to recovery. However, h e did not directly criticize President Reagan's projected budget deficits. (Page A1.)   Mr. Reagan, in his first Economic Report to Congress, said he was trying to break with past practice and create a strong, noninflationary economy in which the private sector played the dominant role. (A1.) The Administration based its optimistic forecast on the belief it had dealt with the major economic problem of the last decade, the mixture of economic stagnation and high inflation.  (D1 9.)

headline: Death Sentences for 5 Approved by Mubarak
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak today approved death sentences for five Moslem militants and jail terms for 17 others convicted in the Oct. 6 assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.   A Defense Ministry statement said the convicted men would be officially informed of Mr. Mubarak's decision on Sunday and would have 15 days to appeal to the Egyptian President for mercy.

headline: Canada Expansion By Telecom Unit
abstract: Northern Telecom Canada Ltd., a unit of Northern Telecom Ltd., announced a $40 million expansion program in Calgary, Alberta, to manufacture electronic telephone systems and other business communications equipment.   The project includes a new $13 million plant and a $27 million investment in manufacturing facilities and equipment. Construction of the plants is scheduled to start in March, with first production expected in early 1983.

headline: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF IN FEBRUARY
abstract: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to foreshadow economic trends, declined three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the 10th monthly drop in a row and another sign that the recession is not yet over, the Commerce Department reported today.   Any ''pronouncement of the end of the recession is a little premature,'' said Robert Ortner, the department's chief economist.  ''I do not believe the recession ended in January, February or March, and we do not yet have any hard evidence that it is about to be over.''   Mr. Ortner said that he still expects an economic recovery to begin by the third quarter, ''but then the recovery may fade with these interest rates so high.''

headline: Reagan Opens Energy Unit
abstract: President Reagan issued an executive order today declaring the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation in business, making it possible for the agency to begin supervising two large oil shale projects in Colorado.   The corporation had been a key element of Jimmy Carter's energy policy when he was President.

headline: CYPRIOTS GREET PAPANDREOU WARMLY
abstract: Andreas Papandreou arrived here today on the first visit by a Greek Prime Minister to Cyprus and pledged that his Government would give top priority to promoting ''a fair solution'' to the Cypriot problem.   ''I have come to assure you that both the Greek Government and the Greek people are giving and will continue to give their undivided support for the Cyprus people's struggle for freedom and independence,'' Mr. Papandreou said in an emotional speech on arrival at Larnaca Airport.   He emphasized that Cyprus must be free from occupation troops, a reference to the Turkish forces that have occupied the northern part of the island since 1974.   Mr. Papandreou was given an enthusiastic welcome by Greek Cypriots, who form more than 82 percent of the island's population.

headline: Wilkinson Unit Names a President
abstract: K. Douglas Martin, 41 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of Wilkinson Sword Inc., the United States unit of Wilkinson Sword Group Ltd., the big British razor blade and cutlery manufacturer. The position is a new one and corresponds with the transfer of the American company's headquarters to Atlanta from Berkeley Heights, N.J.   Mr. Martin is also president and chief executive of Scripto Inc., a producer of writing instruments and disposable lighters, also based in Atlanta.

headline: NEW ISSUES SLOWING
abstract: After last week's deluge of new corporate notes and bonds, when 17 issues with a face amount of $1.9 billion were sold, underwriters have scaled back their financing plans this week but warn that the volume could increase if investor demand strengthens.   Last week's supply of new issues was one reason why prices of outstanding issues fell as much as 3 1/2 points to raise yields as much as 40 basis points. Some analysts saw the lower prices as a disheartening sign of limited investor interest, while others were encouraged by the heavy volume and said it was an early sign of growing investor confidence that interest rates and inflation will be lower in coming years.

headline: SCHENECTADY BANK GETS HARTFORD UNIT
abstract: The troubled Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Association, which was merged over the weekend into the Schenectady Savings Bank, began business today as Northeast Savings, a combined Connecticut and New York thrift institution.   Together, the Hartford and Schenectady institutions became the largest federally chartered savings and loan association in New England, with assets of about $1.7 billion.   Federal authorities had been seeking a merger partner for Hartford Savings and Loan after it reported operating losses of $7.3 million, pushing its net worth well below federally required minimums, and after it lost an estimated $10 million in deposits last month following a brief run triggered by news accounts of its problems.

headline: Nicaragua Denounces Honduras Over Arrest
abstract: Nicaragua has protested over the arrest of a Nicaraguan doctor who sought the protection of the Nicaraguan Embassy in Honduras after deserting from a rightist exile band that launches fre quent attacks into this country from Honduran territory.   The doctor, Noel Ernesto Vasquez Gutierrez, 49 years old, who was seized by the police in Tegucigalpa as he was about to board a flight for Managua on Thursday, had earlier told reporters there some 22 Argentines were advising the armed exile groups in Honduras.

headline: Around the World; Pentecostalist in Soviet Calls Off Hunger Strike
abstract: Avgustina Vashchenko, the 52-year-old Pentecostalist who started a hunger strike seven weeks ago with her daughter while they were in sanctuary at the United State Embassy here, said today that she had ended her fast.   She said she decided to call off the protest because her 30-yearold daughter, Lidiya, had safely returned to the family's hometown in Siberia, and she expected authorities to approve the family's application to emigrate to a country where they could practice their religion without harassment.

headline: Virginia Fox Hartley, Ex-State Dept. Aide
abstract: Virginia Fox Hartley, a retired State Department official, died at Georgetown University Hospital Monday of a heart attack. She was 74 years old.

headline: MADISON AVENUE SCANDAL
abstract: The disclosure shook Madison Avenue.  The J. Walter Thompson agency said last week that some $18 million in nonexistent revenues had been fed into a computer at a unit, JWT Syndication, over three years and nine months.

headline: Market Place; Stock Market Called Bargain
abstract: JOHN M. TEMPLETON, an investment fund manager, said recently that there was a 50-50 chance that the Dow Jones industrial average would reach 3,000 in five years - a startling prediction at a time of considerable market distress.   In a telephone interview from his home base in Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas, yesterday, he discussed the stocks he has been buying in his continuing quest for market gains. He mentioned as he always did that the overall market itself did not have to go up for his portfolio to profit if he chose individual stocks with skill. But his portfolio would, of course, do better if a rousing bull market developed, he added.

headline: Japan's Shipbuilding Off
abstract: Foreign orders received by Japanese shipbuilders in 1981 declined 18 percent from 1980, to 5.3 million gross tons, the Japan Ship Exports Association said today. Foreign orders received in December fell 67 percent, to 204,000 gross tons, from the previous December and were down 38 percent from the previous month, the association said.

headline: NICARAGUAN URGES U.S. TO NEGOTIATE
abstract: Nicaragua proposed ''direct and frank'' talks with the United States today to end the crisis in Central America.   Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the coordinator of Nicaragua's junta and chief of state, told the Security Council that the Cuban Government too was ready for ''negotiations without delay.'' Havana, he said, had empowered him to make the offer on its behalf.   The American delegate, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, neither accepted nor rejected Mr. Ortega's proposal, but said she was ''skeptical.'' The Nicaraguan leader's words, she said, did not match his deeds. His very insistence on a Council meeting to ''air baseless charges'' against the United States, she said, increased tensions.

headline: Scottdale to Close
abstract: Scottdale Mills Ltd., which survived the Great Depression without cutting back production or employees, said it is going out of business in April with the loss of more than 500 jobs.

headline: VIETNAMESE SAID TO OVERRUN CAMBODIAN BASE
abstract: An important anti-Communist guerrilla base at Sokh San, in Cambodia's Cardamom Mountains, has been overrun by Vietnamese troops, and thousands of Cambodian civilians have fled across the nearby border into Thailand, Western diplomats here said today.   The number of casualties was still unknown.  The Vietnamese attack on the base area's four isolated villages was reported to have began last Tuesday. By today, between 3,000 and 7,000 Cambodians had poured into southeastern Thailand in the vicinity of the town of Trat, it was reported.

headline: Austrian Gets U.N. Post
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today named Kurt Her@ndl of Austria to become head of the United Nations Human Rights Division.

headline: Business Forum; THE UNSTEADY HAND AT THE FED
abstract: T HE American economy is deep in recession and, in theory at least, a self-correcting process should be at work. The cost of money ought to be falling and cheaper money, in time, ought to pull us out of recession.  There is scarcely an area of the economy that would not benefit from lower interest rates. Lower mortgage rates would revive the housing market after its worst year since 1946. Lower consumer loan rates would tempt people to buy more cars, and so benefit Detroit, which is going through its worst sales period in two decades. Lower bond rates would encourage business to borrow more to invest in the future. And lower rates generally would help the stock market, which has been in the doldrums for years.  That is how it should be. The reality is that interest rates, which fell a little near the end of 1981, are rising again, and what that will do to the economic outlook doesn't bear thinking about.

headline: COLT PLANS TO SELL CRUCIBLE UNIT BY '83
abstract: Colt Industries said yesterday that it plans to sell its Crucible stainless and alloy division operations in Midland, Pa., by the end of this year.   The steelmaking division suffered ''substantial'' losses in 1981 on revenue of about $500 million, Colt said.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Arrives For Talks in Lebanon
abstract: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today and reportedly told Lebanese leaders that he had done everything possible to avert an Israeli invasion of Lebanon. But he is said to have warned that an incident might still touch off an invasion.   Mr. Habib has apparently won a continuation of the seven-month truce between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand sets out on a oneday trip to Washington Friday to try to reduce some of the obstacles to a closer French-American partnership.   Mr. Mitterrand apparently seeks to explore a notion he has held since he took office last May, that France might partly replace West Germany as the political keystone of a reinvigorated Atlantic alliance.   One requisite for such a role is a more active relationship with the United States than France has had of late. But the prospect is still some way off. The immediate task the French President has set for himself is to take up with President Reagan the current strains in the relationship.

headline: Oil Imports Down 28.2%
abstract: Oil imports declined sharply in February, continuing a trend that began in 1979, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.  In its monthly report, the institute said that 4.85 million barrels were imported daily last month, compared with 6.75 million barrels a day in February 1981, a decline of 28.2 percent.

headline: Around the World; Council of Europe As sails Turkish Junta
abstract: The Parliamentary Assembly of the 21-nation Council of Europe rejected efforts today to expel Turkey from the organization, but passed a tough resolution that could ultimately have the same effect.   The resolution accused the Turkish military junta of human rights violations, including the torturing of political prisoners.

headline: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ways to Save the Thrift Industry; Economic Analysis
abstract: The nation's ailing savings industry is approaching the ultimate crunch, and there are a variety of proposals on to how to deal with it.   Figures released last Friday by the New York State Banking Department confirmed the seriousness of the situation. During the fourth quarter, New York City's 34 savings banks alone lost $337 million, with several of the larger banks rapidly running out of reserves.   The situation is similar across the country. Some officials are privately predicting that by year-end as many as 600 failing savings banks and savings and loan associations will need assistance from the Federal deposit-insurance agencies.

headline: TALKS ON LOANS WORRY POLAND
abstract: Poland expects to reach an agreement next month with Western banks to reschedule Warsaw's large loans from these creditors, but the Government here is deeply concerned about the suspension of talks on the debt owed to Western governments, according to a Finance Ministry official.   Zbigniew Karcz, head of the ministry's foreign department, said in a recent interview that without the cooperation of the 16 Western creditor nations, the elaborate plan worked out last year to give Poland breathing space in handling its total debt of $27 billion could collapse.   In response to the imposition of martial law in mid-December, representatives of the creditor nations told Poland that while arrangements for rescheduling the debts due in 1981 could stand, talks on rescheduling this year's debt, under a plan that had been agreed upon in principle, were being indefinitely postponed.   ''I am waiting for the normal situation with Western countries to be restored,'' Mr. Karcz said. ''Every week we wait is lost. It's not a secret that Poland will suffer most. I have said this many times during the talks in Paris. But Western countries will suffer also.''

headline: DENG, GONE 37 DAYS, BACK IN PEKING
abstract: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, emerged today after an absence of 37 days and said that a ''revolution'' was under way to reduce the bloated government bureaucracy.   Mr. Deng, whose last reported engagement here was on Jan. 12, appeared at a meeting and subsequent luncheon with Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian ruler, Foreign Minister Huang Hua and their wives.   In reporting Mr. Deng's reappearance, the New China News Agency said that he had acknowledged ''speculation abroad about his nearly one month's rest in other parts of the country.''   In an evident refutation of rumors about a power struggle, he was quoted as having said that China was enjoying ''unprecedented stability.''

headline: FINNS VOTING IN PRESIDENTIAL CONTEST
abstract: Finns vote Sunday and Monday for the electoral college that will choose their next President amid assurances the country will stick to its official policy of neutrality and friendship with the neighboring Soviet Union.   A heavy turnout is predicted and opinion polls indicate that the country's largest party, the Social Democrats, may win 130 places in the 301-member college. Its candidate, Prime Minister Mauno Koivisto, is favored to win when the college names its choice Jan. 26.   The identity of the successor to Urho Kekkonen, President since 1956, may remain unknown until then. The college will have a completely free hand under the country's Constitution and could, in theory, give the job to nearly any adult Finn.

headline: GOODRICH, B F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: MAJOR IRAQ WITHDRAWL IS THE 2d IN 18 MONTHS
abstract: For the second time in the 18 months since the Iraqi-Iranian war began, Iraq has been forced to make a major withdrawal under heavy Iranian attack. This retreat appears to have aroused fears in Iraq that an Iranian invasion may be near.   The first retreat came last September, when Iranian troops attacking to lift the Iraqi siege of the battered oil refinery city of Abadan forced the invaders to withdraw northward 10 or more miles to positions on the other side of the Karun River. Abadan continued to come under long-range shelling, but the battles at the eastern entrance to the city were ended.

headline: WEYERHAEUSER UP
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 increased 20.9 percent, aided by an exchange of its common stock for long-term debt. Sales were up 3.6 percent.   The Cincinnati-based company said that net income in the second quarter increased to $191 million, or $2.31 a share, from $158 million, or $1.91 a share, in the 1980 quarter. Sales rose to $2.9 billion from $2.8 billion.

headline: Market Place; A Close Look At Servico
abstract: SERVICO INC., which runs Holiday Inns and other motels and hotels, has tried to retire its outstanding shares twice. Now it seems resigned to public ownership, only to find that its shares have languished.   Servico was 8 3/4 bid in the over-the-counter market last Friday.  Yet the company's fans believe its intrinsic worth is several times that. Servico owns 24 of 40 properties outright and has major equity interests in six more.

headline: Platt Leaving Tiffany's March 1
abstract: Henry B. Platt, a great-great-grandson of the founder of Tiffany & Company who g ave up the titles of chairman and chief executive officer last June, announced yesterday that he would retire on March 1 at the age of 58. Mr. Platt had been succeeded as head of the jewelry and s ilverware retailer and producer after five months in thepost by David W. Mitchell, chairman of Avon Products Inc., the cosmetics and fragrance producer that acquired Tiffany in 1979 for $104 million in stock.   ''I feel I've made my record here at Tiffany,'' said Mr. Platt, who has been vice chairman since relinquishing the top job. ''I have my goals and my style. It speaks for itself.''

headline: HAIG OPPOSES CONTINUAL PRESSURE ON EUROPE OVER SOVIET GAS DEAL
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that, despite differences with the Western Europeans over a natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union, the United States should not use the Polish crisis as an excuse to pressure them to cancel or cut back on the project.   At a news conference in Madrid before flying here for talks, Mr.  Haig stressed the importance he attached to Western unity in the face of the military crackdown in Poland. He seemed to suggest that agreement within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was more important than pressuring individual members of the alliance into adopting sanctions against the Soviet Union.   ''Never before has there been such unanimity of views within the NATO alliance,'' Mr. Haig said. ''First, with respect to the true nature of events in Poland; second, with respect to the culpability of the Soviet Union in these events and, third, with respect to concertion of effort and policy in reaction to these events.''

headline: EXPERT SAYS FIND DISPUTES HISTORY OF POMPEII
abstract: Archeologists have recently found the remains of about 20 people who died in the fire and lava that flowed from Mount Vesuvius onto Pompeii and Herculaneum 1,903 years ago.   Digging in this populous suburb of Naples, in whose confines ancient Herculaneum lies, the searchers unearthed two groups of skeletons, perfectly preserved to the eye but brittle to the t ouch.   One group contained about eight human skeletons and the skeleton of a horse, which apparently crushed its rider.  The bones of other people were scattered nearby. Prof. Giuseppe Maggi, the archeologist in charge of excavations in the Vesuvius area, said in an interview that he thought the victims in that group might have been borne away by a tidal wave an d returned, already dead, by the succeeding undertow.

headline: Around the World; Red Brigades Issue A Statement on Dozier
abstract: The Red Brigades today issued their fourth communique on the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier.  Journalists who found the statement said it did not set any conditions for his release or give any information about his fate.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Cutting the Budget   As Congress starts packing for its Easter recess, differences over the Administration's 1983 budget remain unresolved. Congressional and private analysts agree that some concessions from the White House are probable.

headline: BEHIND THE BOTTOM LINE: HOW EMHART ADDS UP ITS YEAR'S WORK
abstract: On the second floor of the low-slung world headquarters of the Emhart Corporation, the consolidation department fanned out behind mustard-colored partitions. Fluorescent tubes gleamed. Men and women huddled over Formica desks, wearing down pencils. The desks were laden with spread sheets and computer printouts, enough paper to start a mill.   To judge by the zeal of those working on it, a project was going on that seemed to be on the order of a NASA moon mission. An Emhart functionary, in fact, calculated that some 120 Emhart units would have three people apiece assigned to it, working 10 to 12 hours a day, six days a week, for 12 straight weeks.   Without even getting into the crunching work carried out by computers, by the legal staff, by messengers, by publicity hands, he came up with the fact that this project will consume 180 man-years of labor.

headline: Bobbie Brooks Inc.  Appoints President
abstract: Maurice Saltzman, 63 years old, will step down as chief executive officer of Bobbie Brooks Inc., a leading women's apparel concern that he co-founded in 1939, around May 1, the end of the fiscal year, the Cleveland-based company announced. Although he will continue as chairman, Mr. Saltzman will be succeeded as president and chief executive officer by Lawrence Halpern, 47, currently president of the corporation's Bobbie Brooks division.   Bobbie Brooks filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Jan. 15. Shortly afterward it entered into a factoring arrangement with the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation, whereby Meinhard will advance funds to the garment maker against invoices.

headline: SOME BEVERLY HILLS GLITTER IS PAWNED
abstract: -When Don Clark, a Los Angeles area insurance adjuster, needed "just a quickie loan," he brought his wife's fur coat to the Beverly Loan Company.  In return for the full-length back mink for which he had paid $3,500 five years ago, Mr. Clark received $500 and a pawn ticket.   Three months later, Mr. Clark revisited the firm's Beverly Hills office. With a stack of crisp bills, he repaid the loan plus an additional interest charge of $25, and redeemed the coat, which had been kept in cold storage.

headline: First Interstate Has Fall in Net
abstract: The First Interstate Bancorporation reported yesterday that fourth-quarter net operating earnings declined 6.8 percent, to $63.3 million, from $67.9 million in the comparable period of 1980. On a per-share basis, earnings dropped to $1.55 from $1.70.   First Interstate is the nation's eighth-largest banking company, with total assets of almost $37 billion.  J.J. Pinola, chairman, attributed the decline primarily to the ''exceptionally strong fourth quarter a year ago.''

headline: Two Guys Chain Ended
abstract: Vornado Inc., the Garfield, N.J., company that operates the Two Guys discount store chain, said it had closed its last 12 stores as part of a plan to become a real estate development company.

headline: STIHL: A WORLD WIDE FAMILY BUSINESS
abstract: Andreas Stihl, founder of the world's largest chain saw manufacturer, did not want his daughter to go into the family business. Like most German men of his generation, Mr.  Stihl looked askance at women in business.   That was in 1969. Judging by the scarcity of women executives in West Germany even today, this attitude seems to persist.  But Mr. Stihl's daughter, Eva Mayr-Stihl, overcame her father's misgivings. After studying languages and economics at Munich University, she joined the marketing department of the family enterprise, and now she is the company's executive vice president and chief financial officer.

headline: Lufkin Profit Increases 55%
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. reported that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 increased 55 percent, to $4.2 million, or 36 cents a share, from $2.7 million, or 29 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

headline: Iran Oil Sales To Japan Fall
abstract: Japanese imports of crude oil from Iran may continue to decline, stopping after April when current delivery contracts expire, industry sources said here today. No Japanese importer or refiner has renewed expiring contracts since December, they added.

headline: Of Prices...
abstract: To the Business Editor: As a customer of ''Cohose,'' as we still call it, for the last 20 years, since the iron pipe rack and bare bulb days, I was pleased to see ''Fleeing Brooklyn, He Makes It in Cohoes'' (March 7).   If Mayor Koch is elected Governor, I am sure he will be pleasantly surprised by the quality and selection available to him in the men's department.

headline: Economic Scene; The Value Of Deficits
abstract: RAILING against big deficits is currently fashionable, and that is hardly surprising. The gargantuan deficits looming ahead for the 1980's scare liberals and conservatives alike.   But while the fight is waged to reduce those deficits, it is important not to forget that deficit spending can also be useful, particularly in an economy as weak as this one.   Most economists say the 10 percent cut in personal income tax rates scheduled for July 1 - and this year's deficit spending in general - will be a critical element in pulling the economy out of recession.

headline: BRITISH JOBLESSNESS TOPS 3 MILLION FOR FIRST TIME
abstract: The British Government announced today that unemployment in January passed three million for the first time. The news touched off a fresh storm of criticism of the economic policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.   ''Above three million'' proclaimed the Standard newspaper tonight in big black type. In the House of Commons, Mrs. Thatcher was greeted this afternoon with shouts of ''resign.''

headline: 2 UPSTATE THRIFT UNITS ARE MERGED
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday merged the troubled Western New York Savings Bank into the Buffalo Savings Bank, creating the state's third-largest thrift institution, with assets of $5.5 billion. The merger became effective at 11:59 last night.   All of Western's deposits and mortgages automatically were assumed by Buffalo Savings at the time of the merger.  Western had 220,000 depositors and held 18,576 mortgages, accordi ng to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. Western' s total assets amounted to $1 billion, and its deposits, $875 million .

headline: OFFICIAL AT A.T.& T. STRESSES NEW LINES
abstract: When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a change in its upper management organization last week - placing its four most senior officers in charge of overall corporate planning and giving each of five executive vice presidents responsibility for a distinct business segment - attention was focused on Charles Marshall.   Mr. Marshall, a 52-year-old former president of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, was appointed an executive vice president, effective Feb. 1, after serving as A.T.& T. vice president for only about three months. He will be in charge of ''Baby Bell,'' the name that many use to refer to the Bell subsidiary that will be established to handle operations in unregulated businesses.

headline: HOUSE PANEL VOTES BILL ON CABLE TV LIMITATIONS
abstract: The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would broaden the rights of television stations and producers to control use of their copyrighted programs by cable television systems.   The bill, adopted on a voice vote, would allow television stations to claim exclusive regional rights, not currently permitted the stations, for broadcast of syndicated programs.   As part of an agreement between the broadcasting and cable television industries, the legislation would overturn a March 12 decision by a judge in United States District Court in Syracuse, subjecting satellite and microwave-broadcast systems to full copyright liability for television shows they beam from one area to another.

headline: British Ford To Cut Prices
abstract: The Ford Motor Company, the only profitable major auto maker in Britain, said today that it was cutting prices by an average 4.5 percent to narrow the gap between domestic prices and those on the European continent.   Sam Toy, chairman of the company's British division, said the reductions, which take effect on April 1, would help the company meet its target of capturing 35 percent of the British market in new cars.

headline: Oil Find Off Norway
abstract: The Norwegian state oil directorate today confirmed reports of a major oil and natural gas find in the North Sea. Industry sources said further drilling in the Norwegian sector would be needed before the extent of the find, in the Hod Field, was known. Norway currently produces about 531,000 barrels of oil daily.

headline: HAIG CALLS TAIWAN A 'DIFFICULT ISSUE' IN TIES WITH CHINA
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has said that ''extremely sensitive discussions'' are under way with Peking over the Taiwan issue and that he is ''not in a position to predict the outcome.''   American officials previously said that talks were going on over the United Excerpts from interview, page 12. States' decision to continue arms sales to Ta iwan, something Peking regards as infringing on its sovereignty. But Mr. Haig's remarks, in an interview in his office Friday, seemed to indicate concern for future relations not voiced previously.   ''It would be counterproductive to go into details, because things are at a delicate stage, but speaking candidly, some diffi cult issuesare involved, '' he said. ''We are making a major effort to bridge these differe nces. I will be just as frank when I tell you I am not in a position to predict the outcome.''

headline: HOW A CHRYSLER DEALER SURVIVES
abstract: PLYMOUTH, which stands on six and a half acres of grass and asphalt on a corner near the East-West Expressway here, has been owned by A. Coolidge Elkins since 1951. He took the business over from his father, who became a Chrysler dealer in 1926 after selling everything from Overlands to Stanley Steamers since 1918.   Elkins stands well away from ''automobile row,'' a service road just off of the main highway where most of Durham's other 13 automobile dealerships are found. But its 42,000 square feet of space make it the second-largest dealership in town, and it holds 10 percent of the automobile sales market in the Durham area, Mr. Elkins estimates.   Dealerships, these days, are a threatened species. The National Automobile Dealers Association reports that 900 of them went out of business last year and 1,650 the year before. There are now 25,700 dealers, while back in 1972 there were 30,100.

headline: FAMILIAR FACE TO GHANAIANS
abstract: Some months ago, in one of his reflective moods, Jerry John Rawlings acknowledged to a friend that one of the things he regretted about his 112 days in power two years ago was giving up the leadership of Ghana to the elected civilian Government of President Hilla Limann.   He was disappointed in Mr. Limann's lackluster performance, Mr.  Rawlings said to the friend, and he feared that his mistake had resulted in worsening economic and political conditions in Ghana through what he charged was the corruption of the Limann administration.   Three days ago, the 34-year-old former air force pilot moved to rectify his ''mistake'' by seizing power for the second time in two years in a military coup that toppled Mr. Liman n's Government.   The speculation among Western and African diplomats is that this time Mr. Rawlings will be less inclined to yield power quite so rapidly or readily as he did in September 1979. At that time, Mr.  Rawlings said recently, he just might have been ''naive, perhaps even too eager to believe that elected Ghanaians would necessarily slog hard to make a success of government.''

headline: German Prices Up 0.2%
abstract: The federal statistics office said today that final figures showed that Germany's cost of living index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in the month to mid-February.

headline: Lionel and 2 Units In Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: The Lionel Corporation, a diversified producer and retailer of electronics equipment and toys, announced yesterday that it and its wholly owned subsidiaries, Lionel Leisure Inc. and the Consolidated Toy Company, had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.   The company previously reported that it expected to report a loss for the year ended Dec.31, 1981, because of a disappointing Christmas selling season in its toy supermarket operations and high interest expenses.   In the first nine months of 1981, Lionel lost $12 million on revenues of $166.9 million. In the corresponding period in 1980 the company lost $4.4 million on sales of $129.2 million. Earlier this month, Lionel omitted its regular quarterly dividend of 5 cents.

headline: WALL STREET'S NEW SUPERBROKERS
abstract: CAN Sears, Roebuck & Company, the new owner of Dean Witter Reynolds, sell stocks with socks? Will Shearson Loeb Rhodes, one of Wall Street's liveliest, most acquisitive firms, be stifled by its marriage to solid old American Express? What about that broker from the Bache Group, immortalized in television ads as a hard-boiled hustler who neither eats nor sleeps? Can he be turned on by selling life insurance policies for the Prudential Insurance Company? And what can Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's pre-eminent securities trader, get out of its new owner, the Phibro Corporation, a master commodities trader?   It was just under a year ago that the first of these mergers - the union of Prudential and Bache - shook the granite facade of Wall Street. Subsequently, several giants of other industries abruptly installed themselves as major forces in the securities business because they had read the same signals: The traditional businesses of banks, insurance companies, retailers, stock brokers and consumer lenders were breaking down and would give way to large, widely diversified purveyors of financial services. When once there was a single superbroker - Merrill Lynch - now there are five. Even the giant Bank of America bought discount broker Charles Schwab & Company, and the Bechtel Group absorbed Dillon, Read & Company.

headline: REINING IN THE SAUDI ECONOMY
abstract: If this country's political leaders had to run for office, they could easily point to their record in fighting inflation.   Since 1975, when inflation was running over 35 percent, the rate plummeted to just over 10 percent in 1977, and has been held under 5 percent in the four years since. Government spending has held steady for three years running. And economic growth has averaged 21.4 percent a year since 1975.

Dozier today arrested a fugitive suspected leader of the Red Brigades and 10 others believed to be members of the terrorist organization, the authorities said.   The arrests came during dawn raids on three hide-outs on the outskirts of Rome, the police said.

headline: 1,000 Afghans to Go to U.S.
abstract: One-thousand Afghan refugees in Pakistan will be given permission to go to the United States this year, a spokesman for the United States Consulate General said here today.

headline: Mobile Cuts Credit Line
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had sharply reduced a credit agreement it established last year with a group of banks, to $1 billion from $6 billion.   ''We have decided that we didn't need the credit,'' said a spokesman for the oil company, which entered into the agreement last June, shortly before it became embroiled in a bidding war for Conoco Inc. The credit was maintained during Mobil's bid for the Marathon Oil Company late last year.

headline: RIGID DEFENDER OF APARTHEID
abstract: The English-language press has long ridiculed him as ''Dr. No'' because of his inflexible resistance to any easing of the racial code that the world knows as apartheid.   But Dr. Andries Treurnicht, a former dominee, or minister, in the Dutch Reformed Church with an earned doctorate in philosophy, has battled against the heresy that white power, which he prefers to call ''white self-determination,'' can survive a little racial mixing in the social or political spheres.   In recent years, as spokesman for the unrepentant right wing of the governing National Party and the party's leader in the crucial Transvaal Province, he has waged a rear-guard action against the cautious policies for change of Prime Minister P.W. Botha that has repeatedly brought the two men to the brink of an open break. When that break finally came this week, shattering the unity of an Afrikaner movement that has dominated white politics for 33 years, Dr. Treurnicht was forced into a corner he had always managed to avoid.

headline: U.S. Ends Mercedes Antitrust Suit
abstract: The Justice Department today abandoned an antitrust suit against Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc., saying it had decided not to oppose the company's requirement that dealers sell only company-supplied replacement parts.

headline: U.S. Lifts Cap On Mortgages
abstract: In a discouraging signal for the nation's depressed housing industry, Government officials said today that they are raising the ceilings for federally insured home loan rates.   Officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development said the department's Federal Housing Administration will, beginning Monday, insure single-family home loans with interest rates up to 16.5 percent - up from the current 15.5 percent.   Loans insured by the Veterans Administration will follow that lead.
