headline: TRYINNG TO RESOLVE THE PRODUCTIVITY ISSUE
abstract: Stipulating that more investment is necessary - but perhaps not sufficient - to put the nation's economic productivity back on a growth path, Representative David R. Obey, a liberal Democrat from Wisconsin, held hearings last week to survey what else should be done.   Witnesses offered a number of ideas over three days. The thrust of their testimony and the questions by Mr. Obey and other members of a House Budget Committee task force was that productivity was a manyfaceted thing not susceptible to easy definition, diagnosis or rehabilitation.

headline: WIENERWALD TO SELL MOST RESTAURANTS
abstract: Two-thirds of the worldwide Wienerwald chain of 1,550 restaurants will be sold as franchises in an attempt to improve the liquidity of the Wienerwald Group, according to its finance manager, Kurt Lichtenstein.   The executive said today that the need for cash arose after some of the restaurant's creditors became ''a little disturbed.''

headline: Canadian Pacific Unit Names Chief Executive
abstract: Robert W. Campbell, 59, will become chief executive officer of Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., one of Canada's major industrial and natural resource companies, on April 29, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Campbell has been chairman and chief executive officer of PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd., a Canadian Pacific subsidiary, since 1971.   Mr. Campbell, who was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment on his appointment, is described by one colleague as having been one of a handful of obvious contenders to succeed Ian Sinclair as chief executive officer of Canadian Pacific.   Described as a ''very direct man -someone who doesn't beat around the bush,'' Mr. Campbell led Calgary-based PanCanadian during years in which it was the largest single contributor to Canadian Pacific's net income.

headline: U.S. ACCUSED BY SALVADORAN
abstract: A leading Salvadoran opposition figure, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, blamed the Salvadoran junta and the United States Government today for prolongation of the civil war in El Salvador, saying that the guerrilla-led opposition had been ready for months to negotiate a peace settlement.   ''But so long as there is no dialogue, it is logical to expect the war to continue, before, during and after next Sunday's elections,'' he said at a news conference here. ''The actions we see now merely reflect the growth in the revolutionary movement.''

headline: France Reaffirms Plan To Rebuild Iraqi Reactor
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson reiterated today that France would rebuild the Iraqi nuclear reactor destroyed by Israel last year. He added that Paris was taking steps ''to insure an exclusively peaceful utilization of the reactor.''

headline: OFFICIAL SHIFTS ROLE IN U.S. SEA-LAW DELEGATION
abstract: A key official in the United States delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference, who has been under attack on charges of conflict of interest, said today that he was temporarily leaving his Washington law office.   The official, Leigh S. Ratiner, said he was leaving his position as counselor to the delegation to serve as its deputy chairman until the conference session ends on April 30, and that he is taking a leave of absence from his firm.   ''There are no conflicts,'' Mr. Ratiner said in an interview, He said the change of roles was intended to save the Government money and, ''as the conference begins and my role is more visible, I felt that it would be better if I became an employee'' rather than ''an independent contractor.''   The head of the delegation, James L. Malone, said: ''I don't think there will be any conflict of interest with Mr. Ratiner under this arrangement. I wanted to make it clear there will be no conflict. I don't think there's a conflict whatsoever.''

headline: British Ford Layoffs
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had laid off 4,000 workers at its Halewood plant.

headline: DATA GENERAL STOCK DROPS $10 A SHARE
abstract: A flurry of selling sent the stock of the Data General Corporation plunging $10 a share yesterday in response to the minicomputer maker's announcement that its second-quarter earnings will fall well below earlier expectations.   The stock, which opened late because of an imbalance of sell orders, finished the day at $33.75 a share.  Wall Street analysts had been predicting earnings for the fiscal quarter ending March 13 in the area of $1 a share, although Data General, of Westboro, Mass., said late Wednesday that it will earn less than the 83 cents a share it had reported in the comparable quarter last year.

headline: HOUSING STARTS ROSE IN FEBRUARY
abstract: The housing industry revived slightly last month, with housing starts rising 6.5 percent from January's level, to an adjusted annual rate of 953,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.   Government and private analysts attributed the February gain largely to the fact that builders had simply delayed some construction for one month - especially in the Northeast - because of the extremely cold January weather in many parts of the country.   Even with the February upturn, housing starts remained at a level that one industry spokesman called ''terribly depressed'' by the standards of recent years. In January 1981, for example, housing starts were at an annual rate of 1.66 million.

headline: TRADERS AWAIT MONEY DATA
abstract: Institutional buyers of fixed-income securities continued to avoid long-term bonds last week and this - more than any other factor - added to the downward pressure on prices.   The price of long-term Government bonds, typified by the 14 percent's of 2011, fell 4 points (or $40 for $1,000 of face value) during the week. Prices of tax-exempt issues slipped another point or so, despite some buying by bond funds catering to small investors. Corporate issues were down about a half point for the week.

The problem in their country is just a matter of training, the soldiers said, looking up and down the mall to see if they were being observed. When we return, they said, the trouble will come to an end.

headline: Agricultural Problem Seen
abstract: Despite current surpluses, United States agricultural markets may face serious pressure in the future because of demands from domestic consumers and foreign buyers and the use of crops for fuel, according to a report released today.   The report, by the National Planning Commission, a private, nonprofit research organization, warned of a potential confrontation between domestic consumers and export buyers.

headline: DELIVERY IS BEGUN OF ELECTRONIC MAIL DESPITE OBJECTIONS
abstract: The United States Postal Service, after years of delay, today began its electronic mail service for commercial users, in the face of criticism and court action.   Called E-COM, for electronic computer-originated mail, the new service provides high-volume commercial customers the ability to transmit messages to post offices, computer to computer, for final delivery by first-class mail anywhere in the 48 contiguous states in two days or less. More than 100 companies and institutions have signed up to obtain the service.   Postal Service officials said they would wait a full 24 hours before assessing the service's first day of operation.  Karen Uemoto, director of the E-COM service, said today that volume is expected to reach 20 million to 30 million pieces in the next year, and the growth should make it possible to recover capital costs of about $40 million in five years.

headline: Technology; A.T.T.'s New Computer Net
abstract: WHEN the American Telephone and Telegraph Company expands into new unregulated businesses - by dint of the proposed settlement of the Federal antitrust suit or by legislation or by an order of the Federal Communications Commission - its first offering is likely to be the Advanced Communications Service, a computer-to-computer communications network.   The A.C.S. illustrates many of the issues surrounding A.T.& T.'s entry into new markets. It is an example of the technological development that has made the notion of a monopoly restricted to plain telephone service untenable - namely, the merging of computers and communications. It illustrates the difficulties of distinguishing ''basic'' service, which merely transmits data unchanged, from ''enhanced'' services, which manipulate the data in some way.

headline: Tass's U.N. Office Invaded
abstract: Seven Ukrainian Americans, chanting ''Freedom for the Ukraine'' and demanding the release of Ukrainian political prisoners in the Soviet Union, today invaded the United Nations bureau of the official Soviet press agency Tass.

headline: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PAPANDREOU AND THE MILITARY: FROM ANIMOSITY TO COURTSHIP
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, once seen as a staunch opponent of Greece's traditionally rightist military, has courted the loyalty of the armed forces by appointing a new leadership, offering economic inducements and pursuing a nationalistic foreign policy.   The seriousness with which Mr. Papandreou regarded the military could be seen after his election victory in October, when he kept the Defense Minister's portfolio for himself and paid almost daily visits to the armed forces' headquarters, where he also has an office. Since then he has entrenched his position by replacing the armed forces' leadership and a few dozen other senior officers and by granting military personnel substantial improvements in the conditions of service.   Further, the Socialist leader has made it clear that he no longer intends to pull Greece out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a move that, it is widely believed, would be strongly opposed by the military.

headline: OPEC'S LOSS OF MASTERY
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has always been an ungainly sort of club. Besides occasionally going to war against one another, members have engaged in the lesser indiscretions of privately cheating on official prices to raise sales while publicly accusing their fellows of exactly the same behavior.  In a particularly memorable flourish, one member (Iraq) distinguished itself by kidnapping the oil minister of another member (Iran) in 1980.   Nonetheless, few onlookers, particularly the consuming countries that have found no way to counter the organization's 11-fold rise in crude oil prices over the past eight years, had seriously doubted OPEC's effectiveness.

headline: World Oil O utput Off 6 % in 1981
abstract: World oil production in 1981 declined by a record year-to-year amount - 6 percent - because a recession in Western consuming countries restricted economic growth and high oil prices spurred conservation, a leading oil journal said yesterday.   World oil reserves rose 3.42 percent, or 22.2 billion barrels, to 670.7 billion barrels last year, with the entire gain occurring in the non-Communist world, the Oil & Gas Journal said.   At the same time, world oil output dropped 6 percent, or 3.57 million barrels a day, to 55.9 million barrels a day in 1981, the Oil & Gas Journal said.

headline: C.D.C., A CANADIAN CURIOSITY, BUILDS AND EMPIRE
abstract: TORONTO ''T HEY'RE a heads-up outfit,'' said David Schulman, an analyst with Geoffrion Leclerc Inc. ''But ...'' ''I think they're very good,'' said Ira Katzin, an analyst for Pitfield Mackay Ross Ltd., ''I'm very confident in the management of the company. But ...''   ''They're really quite brilliant,'' said Michael Graham of Dominion Securities Ames Ltd. ''But ...'' They were all talking about the Canada Development Corporation, one of the world's most curious companies. A hybrid holding corporation for Canada's Federal Government and perhaps 50,000 private Canadian investors, C.D.C. has labored in quiet obscurity from the second floor of an old abandoned department store here to craft a diversified, international industrial empire that today has almost $8 billion in assets.   For a decade C.D.C. has pretty much gone its own independent corporate way seeking ''to expand, widen and develop opportunities for Canadians to participate in the economic development of Canada,'' according to its legislative mandate, often to the chagrin of its principal owner, a Federal Government run by politicians.

headline: LA MAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Alpine Geophysical Corp. said it had acquired Precision Products of North Haven, Conn., for about $3 million, including $2.8 million in cash and debentures and 50,000 shares of Alpine common stock.   * Arvin Industries said its board had authorized the purchase of up to $7.5 million of the company's common and preferred stock.   * Boise Cascade Canada Ltd. said it would shut its pulp and paper mill in Kenora, Ontario, for at least eight days starting March 7 because of sluggish demand.

headline: Lockheed Gain by 1985 Seen in C-5 Deal
abstract: If the Lockheed Corporation ends up with a contract to produce 50 more C-5 Galaxy transport planes as recommended by the Defense Department, it would help the company eventually build up employment at its division in Georgia and contribute to profits by about 1985.   Wall Street analysts who follow the company, such as Wolfgang H.  Demisch of Morgan Stanley & Company, however, see no windfall from the order, which he said might eventually tot al about $5.2 billion for 44 of the planes.   ''It's a nice piece of change,'' he said, but he added that he did not expect it to lead to high profits since the company did not allow itself much of a margin in the amount that it plans to charge the Government.

headline: South African Plan On Sharing of Power Divides Ruling Party
abstract: Twenty-three members of South Africa's ruling National Party rebelled today against Prime Minister P.W.  Botha's support of a plan to allow nonwhites a role in government.   The action appeared to threaten the unity of the white-minority party, in which a right wing has long opposed attempts to modify the country's racial segregation policies.

headline: SOME IN POLAND WIN ACQUITTAL, BUT NO ONE CHEERS
abstract: Room 224 of the Warsaw courthouse was packed today with people sitting in the aisles and on the window sills when the defense lawyer began his summation.   In the dock were three workers, charged with instigating a strike at the Warsaw steel mill shortly afer martial law was declared Dec.  13.   How, said the defense lawyer, could workers be punished for breaking a law against striking that had only just been proclaimed and that they were not familiar with? The history of Poland, he said, was the story of one war after another - an allusion to the constitutional ''state of war'' that provided the legal basis for martial law. Depriving people of their human rights was in some respects worse than war, he said as the crowd began t o cheer. The judge, Andr@zej Lewandowski, ordered the courtroom doo rs closed, to silence the people in the corridor.

headline: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRODUCTIVITY
abstract: To the Business Editor: I suggest that Mr. Henrici create a third plot showing the output per dollar of wages retained (that is, after tax income to the worker). I haven't done this, but I wonder whether it just might show that the productive worker is in reality receiving less per unit of real output, while the enterprise is receiving no more, simply because the nonproductive (read ''government,'' or, if you must, ''public'') sector is drawing more.   This, of course, is not a productivity curve, but it does cast some light on the idea that ''...in the long term the employee's share of gross product remains fairly constant, which seems reasonable.'' ANDREW J. LYKE Newton, Conn., March 11, 1982

headline: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israel Reports Capture Of Squad of Terrorists
abstract: Israel's military command tonight announced the capture of an Al Fatah terrorist squad after a 52-hour pursuit. Two of the three gunmen who had infiltrated from Jordan were said to have been wounded in an exchange of fire at a hideout near Tiasir, a village two miles east of the Jordan River.

headline: TWO VISA DISPUTES ANNOY AND INTRIGUE INDIA
abstract: The award of a United States entry visa to an Indian advocate of Sikh separatism and the denial of a Soviet visa to an Indian Communist who holds the Order of Lenin have raised indignation and speculation here in the last week.   The Government's anger was aroused by news that Jagjit Singh Chauhan, the chief spokesman for a movement that advocates a separate homeland for the Sikh religious minority, had been allowed to enter the United States from Canada.   Foreign Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao summoned the United States Ambassador, Harry S. Barnes, last weekend to convey the extreme disappointment of the Indian Government that Mr. Chauhan had been allowed to enter the United States despite an earlier notification by India that his passport was no longer valid. Mr. Rao reportedly expressed surprise that in light of the American Civil War support could be given to an avowed secessionist.   United States officials here and in Washington notified the Indian Government that although Mr. Chauhan's entry had originally been blocked, the objection to his entry was waived on humanitarian grounds because he told United States immigration officials that he was going to Houston for treatment of a heart problem.

headline: RATES MOVE SLIGHTLY HIGHER
abstract: Short- and long-term rates rose slightly yesterday as dealers said they remained uncertain about the near-term future of interest rates.  Demand of large institutional investors for United States Government and corporate notes was weak, and dealers said the day's price declines resulted largely from speculative activity.   ''Actually, I think the market showed remarkable strength given all the news that one would have expected to cause prices to fall,'' one dealer in the Treasury market said.   Among the developments that analysts said would normally cause lower prices and higher yields in the credit markets were the increase in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to around 13 3/8 percent and Federal Reserve sales of Treasury bills for its own account and that of a customer.

headline: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PUT A CONCERT IN YOUR POCKET
abstract: To see it is nothing special.  Sized no larger than a carton of cigarettes and weighing only one pound, the Casio VL-Tone has a keyboard, a calculator face and several buttons on its surface.  To hear it is something else.

headline: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: French Rightist Paper Admits Misuse of Picture
abstract: A senior editor of the right-wing French newspaper Figaro said today that the paper had ''erroneously'' used a four-year-old photograph of blazing corpses in Nicaragua to illustrate a report on what it said was a Nicaraguan massacre of an Indian tribe in neighboring Honduras.   The French satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaine charged last week that the photograph had been misused and today Henri Christian Giraud, news editor of Figaro's weekly color magazine, said ''a deplorable mistake'' had been made.

headline: VISA DISPUTE IMPERILS U.S. MEXICO TIES
abstract: A decision by the Reagan Administration to cancel the temporary immigrant visas of tens of thousands of Mexicans living in the United States has provoked loud protests in Mexico and is threatening the first storm in relations since President Reagan took office.   The Government has recalled its Ambassador to Washington, Hugo B.  Mar gain, who will brief President Jose Lopez Portillo and Foreign Minister Jorg e Castaneda de la Rosa on the controversy this week.  Mexican labor groups have also asserted that the Immigration and Naturalizatio n Service is planning ''mass deportations'' of Mexicans in the United States.   So far, however, both the Reagan and Lopez Portillo administrations have been careful not to let the problem grow into a major crisis.  ''The issue, as presented publicly, has been blown out of all proportion to the real facts,'' the American Ambassador, John Gavin, insisted last week. The Mexican Government said it had been assured there would not be ''massive deportations or roundups.''

headline: NL Gives President Added Post of Chief
abstract: Theodore C. Rogers, the 47-year-old president of NL Industries, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective May 1. He will succeed Ray C. Adam, 62, who will continue as chairman.   NL, with headquarters in New York and sales last year of almost $2.5 billion, is in the petroleum services, chemicals and metals businesses. Formerly known as the National Lead Company, the corporation is no longer involved in the lead field; As Mr. Rogers noted yesterday, ''We like to say that we got the lead out.''

headline: F.C.C. Ready to Issue Cellular Radio Orders
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission, after more than 13 years of deliberations and delays, plans to issue final orders as early as this week authorizing a new form of mobile telephone service called cellular radio, according to senior officials in the agency.   The decision to proceed, which was uncertain until last week, ends speculation that the new service may be delayed further by last month's proposed antitrust settlement between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.   An important provision of the commission's plan to start cellular radio, which was affirmed in December, sets aside half of the business for telephone companies and leaves the rest for other kinds of companies, which will have to compete among themselves for permits to operate their own services. System Improves Voice Quality   In the cellular system, made practical by computer technology, localities are divided into small geographic units, or ''cells,'' each served on a two-way basis by their own receivers and low-power transmitters, using different radio frequencies. Special switching equipment makes it possible for a call made from a moving vehicle to be handed off automatically from cell to cell, from frequency to frequency, without interrupting the conversation. It is designed to provide vastly improved voice quality for small, portable, wireless telephones for home and personal use, as well as in automobiles.

headline: REAGAN EXPECTED TO BACK MORE AID FOR SALVADOR JUNTA
abstract: Despite reports of a large-scale massacre of civilians by Government troops in El Salvador, President Reagan is still expected to certify that the Salvadoran security forces are making a ''concerted and significant effort'' to respect human rights.   Spokesmen for the State Department and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said they expected the legal certification document to be sent to Congress on Thursday, paving the way for continued United States assistance to El Salvador.   Military and intelligence officials, meanwhile, said that the flow of small arms from Nicaragua to anti-Government forces in El Salvador continued at a steady rate in recent months.   The certification on human rights is required by the Foreign Assistance Act, approved last month. The President must submit documentation within 30 days of the date that the law was enacted, and at six-month intervals for two years, in order for $25 million in military aid and $40 million in econom ic assistance to be sent to the military- civilian junta in El Salvador. But the act does not give Congress the right to challenge the accuracy and validity of thefindings in t he President's certification.

headline: Backer & Spielvogel Ends Tie With Bon Jour
abstract: Backer & Spielvogel and Bon Jour International have ended their relationship, according to a staff memo circulated yesterday at the agency. The account, which came to the shop last May 1, once billed $6 million.

headline: NEW CURBS ON ENTRY INTO U.S. ANGER FILIPINOS
abstract: The screening, put into practice because illegal immigration has become a serious problem, is aimed at determing whether the applicant is a geniune tourist who will return home.  Despite the screening, hundreds of Filipinos on temporary visas disappear upon reaching the United States.   American efforts to halt such practices have led in recent weeks to a complaint by the Philippine Government over the treatment of its citizens at United States points of entry.  A letter of protest sent through the United States Embassy here to the State Department by Foreign Minister Carlos P. Romulo has demanded an explanation for the "discriminatory acts committed by United States immigration and customs officials."

headline: ATI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARMIES OF JOBLESS YOUTHS MARKING TIME IN CHINA
abstract: If there is enough for her to do, Sun Fang goes each weekday to a small backroom workshop to sit with other young women around a cramped table assembling plastic toy automobiles under the harsh glare of a fluorescent light.   The pay of $35 a month is decent by Chinese standards. But the work is tedious and, worse, it is temporary for Miss Sun, a quiet 23-year-old who has been unable to find a permanent job since leaving school in 1976.   Miss Sun was supposed to join more than one million other young people from Shanghai sent to work in the countryside during the Cultural Revo lution, but her parents did not want her to go. Those young people who were allowed to return got first priority in employment. N ow the emphasis has shifted to those who have left school since 1978, so Miss Sun has been overlooked.

headline: DOW UP 6.09
abstract: Stock prices moved higher yesterday in a performance that Wall Street analysts described as a fairly typical response to the market's recent weakness. However, several issues sustained losses in the takeover sector.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.09 points, to 836.66. On Monday and Tuesday, reacting to investor worries over rising interest rates and prospective record budget deficits, the Dow plummeted more than 20 points. Tuesday's closing at 830.57 marked the lowest finish since 824.01 last Sept. 25.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: ARABS ASSAIL MITTERRAND TRIP
abstract: France came under sharp criticism in the Arab world today for the visit to Israel by President Francois Mitterrand. There were calls here and in Saudi Arabia for a reappraisal of Arab relations with the French.

headline: SAUDI BANKS FOR WOMEN THRIVING
abstract: In the male-dominated society of Saudi Arabia, religion, government, business, finance and the media are the almost exclusive preserves of men. In tradition and still largely in fact, women are expected to hide behind a black veil and stay at hometo rear the c hildren who represent the future of this thinly populated kin gdom.   Despite their inferior social status, however, Saudi women have plenty of money - an estimated 30 to 40 percent of the hundreds of billions of dollars of private wealth in this country - and the Koran guarantees them personal control over it.   As a result, banks run by women and catering solely to women have begun to spring up in the major cities of Saudi Arabia. This is an unusual development in a country governed by strict interpretations of Islamic fundamentalism.

headline: POLISH AIDE ACCUSES U.S. OF 'IMMORALITY'
abstract: A top adviser to Poland's military leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, bitterly accused the United States today of ''attempting to recolonize Western Europe politically'' and of practicing ''the utmost immorality'' in withdrawing Poland's fishing rights in United States waters.   In contrast, the adviser, Wieslaw Gornicki, had high praise for what he saw as the more sympathetic positions toward Poland of some Western European nations, particularly West Germany.   Mr. Gornicki, a former journalist, emphasized that he was neither a member of nor a spokesman for the Military Council running Poland.  Singling out President Reagan for criticism, Mr. Gornicki accused him of ''using food as a weapon to punish our nation.'' He added, ''Never have sanctions been applied with such harshness and brutality.'' Referring to the fishing rights, he said: ''What were we going to do with the fish? Turn them into tanks and guns? It just means people in lines for a longer time.''

headline: Marshall Field S ues Icahn Group
abstract: Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago-based retail chain, said it had filed suit against Carl C. Icahn and 11 individuals and companies, charging that their purchases of more than 14 percent of Field's common was illegal. Last week, Icahn and affiliated companies said that they had increased their holdings to 14.7 percent of Field's common.

headline: Article 192508 -- No Title
abstract: Purex Industries said late yesterday that its directors had approved an a greement in principle for the acquisition of Purex for $31.50 a share by a privately held company to be formed by Gibbon, Green, Van Amerongen, an investment banking firm in New Yo rk City that specializes in leveraged buyouts.   The acquisition would involve payment of $406 million in cash, based on the company's 12.9 million outstanding shares.

headline: Your Money; Vast Changes For Estates
abstract: ONCE, before the inflation of the last two decades, estate planning was a subject only for the very wealthy. Now, some people have found that they are accumulating more wealth than they imagined and need to know the complexities and tax consequences of transferring their estates to their survivors.   ''Inflation has done well by a lot of people,'' said Isaac W.  Zisselman, a senior partner of Young, Kaplan, Ziegler & Zisselman, a law firm specializing in probate, tax and financial planning. ''They should consider what they really are worth and analyze the kinds of money they ultimately will control.''

headline: BONN BANKING CHIEF IN U.S. AS DIPLOMAT
abstract: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of West Germany's central bank, the Deutsche Bundesbank, is in the United States in an unusual role - as a diplomat seeking to reduce some of the strain in relations between the Governments of the two countries. He explained at a breakfast interview yesterday that for many years he had had excellent relations with America's financial leaders, so he hoped that his visit could achieve its purpose.   Considering that Arthur F. Burns, formerly Mr. Pohl's counterpart at the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, is now United States Ambassador to West Germany, a political trip by a central banker seems somewhat less unusual than it might have two years ago.

headline: BROCKWAY GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN PROPOSAL ATTACKED AS A 'BLUEPRINT FOR PRESS CONTROL'
abstract: The English-language press today assailed a proposal that journalists be registered by a body with the power to bar them from writing articles for any publications in South Africa.   ''This is a blueprint for Government press control,'' The Cape Times declared, reacting to a draft law drawn up by a judicial commission of inquiry. The commission contended that a Soviet-inspired ''total onslaught'' on the South African racial system was able to exploit the relatively free press the country has now.

headline: British Car Production
abstract: Auto production by British manufacturers rose to a provisional 75,000 units in December from 66,000 in November and 57,000 in December 1980, the Departme nt of Industry saidtoday.

headline: OFFICIAL IN POLISH CENTRAL COMMITTEE RECONSTRUCTS THE EVENTS OF DECEMBER
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by the authorities there since Dec. 14.   In a reconstruction of events from Dec. 13, when martial law was imposed, to the end of the year, a well-informed Communist Party source said on Jan. 1 that Lech Walesa had been persuaded to make an appeal to Solidarity members on the day of the crackdown to give up open resistance, but that the move was blocked by the Roman Catholic Church.   The church intervened and urged the Government not to press for such an appeal on the ground that this would undercut Mr. Walesa's credibility as a leader and make it difficult for him to play a ''useful'' role in the future, the party source said.   The source, who holds an important position in the Central Committee, said that he had no first-hand knowledge of events surrounding Mr. Walesa's house arrest, but had spoken to some of the principals involved, including the Minister for Trade Union Affairs, Stanislaw Ciosek.

headline: SOVIET BOOKLET ATTACKS U.S. ARMS POLICY
abstract: The Soviet Defense Ministry has printed an elaborate booklet on United States military strength in which it argues that the Reagan Administration's strategy is to develop the country's nuclear forces to the point that ''a pre-emptive strike'' against the Soviet Union becomes possible in this decade.   This charge is the keystone of a document that marks the most sophisticated effort yet to persuade public opinion in the United States and Western Europe that the Reagan Administration's arms buildup is a threat to peace.   While Mr. Reagan and his aides have premised increases in the American military budget on the need to counter what they say is a Soviet bid for military superiority, the Soviet booklet declares that it is the United States that seeks ''world dictation.''   ''Soviet military doctrine has been and is based on the principle of retaliatory, that is, defensive actions,'' the booklet says. By contrast, it says, ''the agreed schedule of Pentagon plans for building up strategic offensive armaments and deploying anti-missile and space defense systems is timed to complete the development of a so-called first-strike potential in the 1980's.''

headline: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan May Tax Gains on Bonds
abstract: In a move apparently aimed at curbing purchases of zero-coupon, deep-discount Eurobonds, Japan's Finance Ministry is considering imposing a tax on capital gains, it was reported today.   Sources said the possibility of the tax was being raised as a warning to Japanese investors against purchases of the zero-coupon issues - most of them offered in the international markets in the last few months by United States corporations shut out of their own credit markets by high interest rates.

headline: Second of two articles.
abstract: Israel has reportedly warned that it would react with force if Egypt broke agreements on Sinai. Page A4. By LESLIE H. GELB Specia l to the New York Times   WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 - The dominant fact of life in the Middle East is Israeli military superiority, and the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin intends to preserve and use that superiority to maintain the political status quo in the region through the 1980's.   Since there is little the Arab nations can do about this situation on the battlefield, they are gearing up to carry their struggle for the Palestinians and the return of remaining occupied territories to Washington. And, for the first time, Arab and Israeli leaders alike see potential vulnerabilities in American support for Israel.

headline: FAMILY PLASTIC ENTERPRISES ABOUND DESPITE ALL THE GIANTS
abstract: The top floor of the Garfield Manufacturing Company's warehouse is furnished with long schoolhouse-style oak desks, overhanging fluorescent lamps and the portrait of the company's founder, Frederick Bauer, an immigrant from Germany.   Amid this homey mom-and-pop atmosphere, Mr. Bauer's son runs a small plastics business that supplies parts to such corporate giants as the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Western Electric Company.   To most consumers, plastics are synonymous with chemical monoliths such as the Dow Chemical Company or the Union Carbide Corporation - enormous companies with enormous factories that churn out material found in everything from telephones to dashboards.   Actually, however, the companies responsible for some 60 percent of the nation's 37 billion pounds of plastic production are small shops run by entrepreneurs who often began with nothing more than a vat, a molding machine and an empty garage.

headline: Advertising; Benefits Of Network Affiliation
abstract: AN agency network is an amalgam of shops from various markets that helps the small or medium-sized company compete with the giants.  As the words from Longfellow's ''Hiawatha'' go, ''Union gives strength.'' That was the topic yesterday as Harold A. Shoup, president of Carr Liggett Advertising, Cleveland, met with Robert E. Drinkwater, for two years president of the 50-year-old National Advertising Agency Network, which contends it is the largest and oldest of the eight that are listed in Standard Directory of Advertising Agencies.

headline: A.T.&T.'S NEW CHALLENGES
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Co. settlement with the Justice Department will provide grist for business school case histories for years to come. It is a nearly perfect case - one that raises many issues, is filled with uncertainties and for which there are no clear-cut answers.   While the settlement generally wins praise as being in the best long-term interest of AT&T, the business school view is that the transformation of the company from a giant that thrived in a monopoly setting to a mere mortal moving into a tough competitive arena will require changes that strike at its corporate heart.   And how the AT&T case - probably cases, since the settlement raises enough issues to keep many case writers busy -is taught in the nation's business schools could well affect how the next generation of business leaders views the breakup of the largest company in the world.  AT&T recently agreed to give up its local telephone operations to enter such previously prohibited fields as data processing, communications between computers and sales of related equipment.

headline: Round 3 on the Roundtable
abstract: To the Business Editor: Although Milton Friedman remains a lively presence in our midst and in occasional television re-runs, he has apparently already been reincarnated in the person of the Yale economist, Paul W. MacAvoy.  In his ''The Business Lobby's Wrong Business'' (Dec. 20), Professor MacAvoy echoes Professor Friedman's classic declaration that, ''The social responsibility of business is to increase its profits,'' and takes to task the members of the Business Roundtable for their recently published ''Statement on Corporate Responsibility.''   According to Professor MacAvoy, the Roundtable statement is fatally flawed by its implication ''that the large corporation is a political entity ... rather than an economic organization.'' The fact is that Mr. MacAvoy's comments are themselves invalidated by a failure to comprehend the contemporary scene.

headline: Brunswick Unit Target of Offer
abstract: The American Home Products Corporation said it would begin buying Brunswick Corporation stock now that a Federal court had cleared the way for its $425 million purchase of Brunswick's coveted medical unit.   Meanwhile, in Los Angeles, the Whittaker Corporation said it was dropping its $318 million offer for a controlling interest in Brunswick, ending a sometimes acrimonious battle between the two companies.

headline: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: British Jobless Drop
abstract: Unemployment in Britain fell slightly this month but stayed above the 3 million mark, the Department of Employment reported today. It said that the February total to date was 3.04 million, down 25,700 from January. The figure represented 12.6 percent of Britain's 24 million work force, compared with 12.7 percent in January.

headline: REAGAN PROMOTES 2 AT STATE DEPT.
abstract: President Reagan named two career specialists in European affairs today to the second and third ranking positions in the State Department.   The President announced that Walter J. Stoessel Jr. would become Deputy Secretary of State and that Lawrence S. Eagleburger would be Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. The appointments are subject to Senate confirmation.   Mr. Stoessel, 61 years old, is a former Ambassador to West Germany, Poland and the Soviet Union and has been serving as Under Secretary for Political Affairs since the beginning of the Reagan Administration. His promotion to Deputy Secretary marks the first time a career Foreign Service officer has held the No. 2 State Department post since 1945.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEWFOUNDLAND VOTE: OIL ISSUE
abstract: Premier A. Brian Peckford of Newfoundland has called an election next month, two years before the end of his term, to strengthen his position in the province's continuing dispute with the Canadian Government over control of offshore energy resources.   With negotiations broken down for more than a month, Mr. Peckford, who was elected in 1979, said Monday that he would take the issue to an election on April 6 in which he is favored to win. Mr. Peckford said today that he had offered a proposal to the federal Government that contrasts with the settlement Nova Scotia was persuaded to sign two weeks ago.   There is much more at stake than political differences in the Newfoundland dispute, because exploration has turned up proven reserves of some 2 billion barrels of oil, with hopes of more, whereas only gas has been found thus far off Nova Scotia. There is currently a gas surplus in Canada.

headline: CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Home Products Corp. said its tender offer to acquire up to 14.2 million shares of Brunswick Corp. common stock had drawn 24.5 million shares.   * American Medical Affiliates said Unicare Services Inc. had agreed to acquire substantially all of American Medical's nursing home assets for more than $57 million.

headline: CHRYSLER LOST $66.9 MILLION IN 4th QUARTER
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss of $66.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1981 and a loss of $475.6 million for the entire year, somewhat less than most analysts had forecast.   Chrysler was the last of the domestic automobile companies to report its financial results for 1981, the second consecutive year of dismal sales and earnings for the once-vibrant industry. Its fourthquarter loss was far less than the $235.1 million that the nation's third-largest auto manufacturer lost in 1980's fourth quarter.   The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company, the American Motors Corporation and Chrsyler reported a combined loss of $1.34 billion, although G.M. earned a slight profit of $333 million.  The losses were far less than in 1980, primarily as a result of costcutting measures rather than an increase in car sales. All four companies reported losses for 1980, and these totaled more than $4 billion.

headline: Company News; S. & P. DEBT RATING ON FORD LOWERED
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the debt rating of the Ford Motor Company and its financing subsidiary today, saying ''the timing and magnitude of a recovery in U.S. auto sales is increasingly uncertain.''   Ford recently reported a loss of $1.06 billion for 1981.

International Harvester said initial deliveries of the trucks will start in March. The length or value of the contract was not disclosed.

abstract: The Ford Motor Company said it would enter a joint program with privately held Polimotor Research Inc. to develop and perhaps manufacture a plastic car engine by the late 1980's.

headline: Woman, 59, Is Elected The President of Malta
abstract: Agatha Barbara, 59 years old, was elected President today, the first woman to hold the office.

headline: Exxon in Alaska
abstract: The Exxon Corporation expects to double or triple the $3 billion it has invested in Alaskan projects by the end of the century, Randall Meyer, president, told the Anchorage Chamber of Commerce. He said 21 percent of Exxon's net investment through 1981 has been in Alaskan operations. If the large resource estimates on Alaska made by the National Petroleum Council prove accurate, the oil industry could spend nearly $300 billion, in 1981 dollars, during the next 40 to 50 years for Alaskan oil and natural gas development, he said.

headline: Soviet Warns Europe on Trade
abstract: The Soviet Union cautioned Western European countries today against any moves to join the United States in sanctions imposed on Moscow after the military crackdown in Poland.   In an article in Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, Foreign Trade Minister Nikolai S. Patolichev wrote:   "Those countries that give in to pressure exerted from the other side of the ocean may pay for this with the loss of their positions in our foreign trade.

headline: Advertising; 'Jersey' Tag Confining For G.& M.
abstract: WHEN they first started their agency in New Jersey five years ago, Ron Gianettino and George D. Meredith just wanted it to be the best agency in the state. After a while that was no longer a sufficient goal, so it w as a changed to the ''biggest'' New Jersey agency. Now they feel tha t the New Jersey tag is too confining.   Dissatisfaction with the status quo, it's what has made America great.  Actually, the president and executive vice president and creative director, respectively, of Gianettino & Meredith of Mountainside have never worked for an agency outside the state, but have out-of-state clients.

headline: BAKER HAS DOUBTS ON TAX RISE
abstract: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today it seemed unlikely that President Reagan would accept his recommendation for increasing some excise taxes.   Senator Baker, in a televised interview, expressed support for enacting ''a minimum corporate or business tax,'' but offered no details. Senate aides said the Administration would make no such proposal, but had begun to indicate it would not oppose such legislation if there were a Congressional majority for it.   Making the case for increases in some Federal excise taxes to shrink the Federal budget deficit, Senator Baker said, ''It's intrinsic in the position of the Republican Party and the position President Reagan has taken and I have taken over the years that we fight deficit spending.'' With respect to excise taxes, however, he said President Reagan ''may be leaning against that decision.''

headline: A JAPANESE REPORT PREDICTS DOMINANCE IN G.N.P. BY 2000
abstract: By the year 2000, the value of goods and services produced by each person in Japan will have surpassed that of the United States by more than 20 percent, according to the forecast of an advisory council to the Japanese Government.   In a preliminary report subm itted to the Government Sunday, the high-level ad visory group predicted that by the turn of the century, Japan's per c apita gross national product will be $21,510, a level almost two an d a half times greater than the $8,940 recorded in 1980.   In contrast, the report predicted that the per capita gross national product in the United States will be $17,600, a 69 percent increase from $10,420 in 1980.

headline: THE ACQUISITIONS THAT HAVEN'T PAID OFF
abstract: Not so many months ago, billion-dollar takeover offers were sweeping Wall Street. Among the biggest targets were the natural resource companies and in the culmination of a decade-long infatuation with minerals, the pursuers, for the most part, were oil companies.   In little more than a week's time last year, Standard Oil of California offered $4 billion for Amax, in vain it turned out, and Standard Oil of Ohio handed over $1.8 billion for Kennecott. In other notable battles, Du Pont outbid Mobil and the Seagram Company for Conoco, and U.S. Steel picked up Marathon Oil with Mobil, again, the loser. Seagram, awash with cash with the proceeds from its sale of Texas oil and gas properties, offered $2 billion plus for St. Joe Minerals but lost again, this time to the Fluor Corporation.   Were all those billions worth it? For Du Pont and U.S. Steel, the answer awaits further developments of the great oil glut. But in the other big arena of natural resource acquisitions - metals - the oil company acquirers would have done better by buying more oil or shares in a money fund. Oil, over the last eight years, has proven a handsome investment, delivering a 17 percent annual rate of return on shareholders equity while minerals have averaged only a little more than half that. And last year, mining was, at best, only marginally profitable.

headline: JAMES RIVER, AMERICAN CAN IN DEAL
abstract: The James River Corporation has tentatively agreed to buy certain paper-making operations of the American Can Company for about $420 million in cash and stock, American Can said yesterday.   The move is the latest in a series of acquisitions by James River.  Under the preliminary accord with James River, American Can would receive about $330 million in cash and the remaining $90 million in James River common stock or preferred stock exchangeable into James River common.   The transaction would give American Can 21 percent of the voting stock in James River, a leading producer of specialty paper products.  ''On balance, I think it's positive for American Can if and when the deal with James River is consummated,'' said Cornelius W.  Thornton, who follows American Can for the First Boston Corporation.  ''The amount of cash they're getting from James River, added to the amount they would get should they sell their timberlands, should give them around $600 million to $700 million. This would allow them to get into the financial services business in a meaningful manner.''

headline: 2 OF STEEL GIANTS IN WEST GERMANY AGREE TO MERGE
abstract: Two of West Germany's largest steel companies agreed today to merge their steelmaking activities in a new joint venture that would form Europe's second-largest steel company.   Krupp Stahl and Krupp Sudwestfalen (steelmaking subsidiaries of Fried. Krupp) and Estel-Hoesch Werke (West German arm of Estel, the Dutch-German steel company) jointly announced their intention to merge their steelmaking, steel-finishing and other activities in a new company in which Krupp Stahl and Estel-Hoesch will hold equal shares. Krupp Sudwestfalen, whose activities complement those of Krupp Stahl, is by far the smaller of the two subsidiaries.

headline: TURKEY WARNS GREECE ON AEGEAN MOVES
abstract: Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu accused Greece today of trying to establish ''faits accomplis'' in the Aegean region, and warned that Turkey ''will not hestitate to equally retaliate.''   ''It should be clearly known that Turkey will not accept any 'faits accomplis' likely to affect her rights and interests in the Aegean,'' Admiral Ulusu said at a news conference.   Asked whether Turkey would extend its territorial waters in the region or consider such a Greek move a ''cause of a war,'' the Prime Minister said: ''No, no. Of course we don't mean that. We don't increase our territorial waters' limits. I hope the Greek Government understands what we mean.''

headline: Top Parties in Zimbabwe To Discuss a Merger
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today th at the country's two main political parties would meet soon to discu ss a possible merger as a prelude to declaring Zimbabwe a one-party s tate.   The merger would include his own ruling Zimbabwe African National Union and the Patriotic Front Party of his former rival and present coalition partner, Joshua Nkomo.

headline: PRETORIA PREMIER DEFEATS HIS RIVAL
abstract: Prime Minister P.W. Botha overcame a challege to his leadership of the governing National Party by its extreme right wing today and effectively ousted his chief rival from the party hierarchy.   The rival, Dr. Andries P. Treurnicht, entered a hall belonging to a wing of the Dutch Reformed Church here this morning as leader of the National Party in the country's wealthiest and most populace province, the Transvaal. When he emerged six hours later, he had been stripped of his membership in the party's executive committee and politically humiliated on a motion of confidence that affirmed Mr.  Botha's right to interpret party policy on key racial issues.   The vote on the motion was lopsided, 172 to 36, and it meant that the party machinery in the crucial province had been wrested from Dr. Treurnicht's control. The Prime Minister has given dissident party members until Wednesday to reverse their stand on the confidence motion taken here today and in the parliamentary caucus two days ago. If they fail to do so, they will be expelled from the party.

abstract: Baker International, an American oil company, is raising a 10-year, zero-coupon Eurobond for a nominal $225 million, one of the lead managers, the Goldman Sachs International Corporation, said Friday. Priced at 24.70 percent, the bond yields 15.01 percent annually, it added.

headline: Texasgulf Sale
abstract: The Canada Development Corporation said it had completed the $1.85 billion (United States) acquisition of Texasgulf Inc.'s Canadian mining and minerals operations. As previously reported, C.D.C.  swapped its 35 percent interest in Texasgulf plus $521 million in cash to acquire the Canadian assets, which inclu de the huge Kidd Creek mine in northern Ontario. The agreement was part of an agreement under which Societe Nationale Elf A quitaine of France acquired the non-Canadian assets of Texasgulf in mid-1981.

headline: COST SQUEEZE ON OIL REFINERIES
abstract: Caught between crude oil prices that just won't come down fast enough and refined product prices that just won't stop coming down, oil refiners across the United States are slowly but inexorably being squeezed out of business.   Barely a week goes by without some independent ''tea kettle'' refiner or major oil company announcing that it is closing down all or a portion of a refinery because it is no longer possible to sell products at a profit in the shrinking, but still viciously competitive, oil market.   Some refinery operations are being suspended in the hope that the good old days will eventually return. Others are being dismantled and sold piece by piece to the highest bidder. Still others are simply being boarded up because it is too costly to do anything else with them - steel monuments to the passing of the growth era for United States oil consumption.

headline: Oldsmobile Plans To Lay Off 1,000
abstract: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation, the principal employer in the Lansing area, said it would lay off 1,000 workers over the next month.

headline: PARTIES IN ISRAEL UNITE IN OPPOSING ARMS FOR JORDAN
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, backed by all of Israel's major political parties, appealed publicly to President Reagan today to reject Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's proposal to sell advanced weapons to Jordan.   Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Begin presented an array of statistics on what he called ''the mighty, almost unimaginable flow of sophisticated weaponry reaching the Arab states from both the East and the West.'' This arms buildup, he contended, jeopardizes Israel's qualitative military edge over the Arabs, which President Reagan has pledged to maintain.   Parliament then approved, by a vote of 88 to 3, with 6 abstentions, a resolution expressing ''deep concern'' over Mr. Weinberger's proposal, which, it said, ''poses a serious danger to Israel's security.'' The only opponents were members of the Communist Party.

headline: PRODUCERS DENOUNCE A TAX RISE
abstract: Proposals being debated within the Reagan Administration to increase Federal excise taxes on gasoline, liquor and tobacco have raised a gale of protest from many manufacturers of those products, mild objections from retailers who sell them and a nod of approval from private economists.   Liquor and cigarette producers argue that raising taxes on their goods would dampen sales, in some cases severely enough to offset the revenues gained from the higher levy. As for oil refiners, they say that a rise in the excise tax on gasoline would accelerate the trend toward conservation but would have little or no immediate effect on sales.   The outlook remains unclear. The Senate majority leader, Howard H.  Baker Jr., says it seems unlikely that President Reagan will accept his recommendation for raising some excise taxes. (Page D3.)

headline: Washington Watch; Finding Where Buck Stops
abstract: WASHINGTON THE runaround. It's a practice of just about all Federal departments and agencies. You have a specific problem. One bureau can't handle it, suggests another, which suggests still another, and at the end of the line you still can't find the person with the answers.   A major reshuffling is now under way within the Government conglomerate known as the Commerce Department. The avowed purpose is to establish exactly where the buck stops. The unit selected for revamping is the department's International Trade Administration, which oversees much of the nation's foreign trade effort.

headline: AUSTRIAN LOAN TO SOVIET
abstract: A group of Austrian banks has announced an agreement to lend the Soviet Union $596.6 million over the next two years at low interest rates, at a time when Moscow is known to be suffering from an acute shortage of convertible currency.   The agreement comes in the wake of a NATO ministerial decision to suspend economic cooperation with Moscow, including bank credits, until martial law in Poland is ended.   The Austrians intend to use the loans to raise their exports to the Soviet Union, shrinking their increasing trade deficits with Moscow.  Trade with all of Eastern Europe accounts for roughly one-fifth of Austria's total trade, but in 1980 that trade tipped into deficit for the first time since 1963.

headline: SILICON PRAIRIE, TEXAS
abstract: DALLAS SOME business people here like to describe this city's diversified economic base as recession-proof, but it's probably safe to assume that none of them work in the electronics industry. After years of spectacular growth, 1981 and the first quarter of 1982 proved a rude awakening for many of the best-known names in technology-related industries, and there are no immediate prospects of a sudden turnaround.   ''The small companies that developed a product to fit a particular niche generally did well, but the more broad-based, undifferentiated ones really had their problems,'' said Mark Jordan, a special-situations analyst for the Houston-based brokerage firm of Rotan Mosle.   Yet, most observers see a bright future for the Texas electronics industry, which is based in the Dallas-Fort Worth area called the ''Silicon Prairie'' and has outposts in Austin and San Antonio. A study by the University of Texas anticipates that sales for the industry within the state by 1990 will quadruple its 1978 level, outpacing the nationwide growth. The study, which was issued last year, used the latest available figures.

headline: New Forecast On Building
abstract: Construction activity this year may be slower than anticipated because of the recent rise in interest rates and the deeper-thanexpected recesssion, an industry group said yesterday.   The McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said that building contracting this year is expected to total $165.3 billion, about $4 billion less than the level predicted five months ago.

headline: 10 Policemen Killed in Brazil
abstract: A box of dynamite exploded in a state police barracks today, killing 10 troopers and a civilian. The police said the explosion, described as accidental, took place in a remote jungle outpost near this city in western Brazil.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: In its new economic scenario for the fiscal 1983 budget, the Reagan Administration is finally acknowledging that its commitment to a restrictive monetary policy imposes limits on its goals for economic growth.   This acknowledgment, which is reflected in reports of preliminary forecast figures and in interviews with Administration officials, illustrates the monetarist influence in top circles of the Administration. But it has created problems for the Administration by forcing it to face traditional economic strictures rather than standing pat with what many economists think are the unrealistic tenets of the Administration's supply-side economics.   The recognition that monetary policy imposes a ceiling helped unravel the President's earlier promise of a balanced budget by 1984. It also has forced the Administration to face up to a string of record budget deficits in the future and threatens its hopes for strong economic growth after the recession.

headline: RAILWAY 'BATTTLE OF GIANTS' SET
abstract: The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it had approved the merger of the Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway, setting the stage for what the agency's vice chairman said would be ''a battle of giants.''   The other giant that Reginald E. Gilliam Jr., the vice chairman, alluded to in an interview was created by the I.C.C. in November 1980 when it approved the merger of the Chessie System and Seaboard Coast Line Industries.   That created the CSX Corporation, a railroad with 26,452 miles of road serving nearly every state east of the Mississippi except those in New England. Now, after 15 months of deliberation, the I.C.C. has given birth to another huge Eastern carrier with 17,860 miles of road serving substantially the same states as the CSX.

headline: WITH SALVADOR'S REBELS IN COMBAT ZONE
abstract: El Salvador's political and military leaders call them ''terrorists'' and blame Communist subversion for the war here. United States officials agree with what those leaders say: that Cuba and Nicaragua are supplying weapons, training and men.   But the peasants and their leaders here in the province of Morazan, where the anti-Government movement is the strongest, contend that theirs is an indigenous revolution spawned by decades of political and social injustice. The revolution, they say, is being fought primarily by peasants who were born and raised in the areas where they are fighting.   For two weeks, this reporter walked and lived with the guerrillas in the northern part of Morazan, roughly an area stretching from midway between Perquin and San Francisco Gotera to the Honduran border, in an attempt to get answers to some of the questions about the movement.

headline: Bloom Gets More Libby
abstract: The Bloom Agency in Dallas, which already has assignments from Libby, McNeil & Libby, is getting a few more million in billings as the Chicago company removes all of its assignments from Tatham-Laird & Kudner in its home town. The new business is for beverages, pumpkin, produce products and new products.

headline: CHINA REPORTED UNYIELDING ON TAIWAN ARMS ISSUE
abstract: Deng Xiaoping, China's leader, told a prominent American businessman today that there was no room for compromise with the United States on the issue of American arms sales to Taiwan.   His comments during a meeting with the businessman, Armand Hammer, followed the publication of a Chinese magazine article this week that quoted Mr. Deng as saying that Peking was ''well prepared'' to downgrade diplomatic relations with Washington if it had to.   At the same time, the Chinese Government today rebuffed the offer made on Wednesday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to improve Chinese-Soviet relations, asserting that Moscow would be judged by its deeds and not its words.   The Chinese statement ignored Mr. Brezhnev's pointed assertion that Moscow had always recognized Peking's claim to sovereignty over Taiwan.

headline: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress he still had doubts about President Reagan's economic program. He said that even if budget deficits were held within current projections, there would be some question whether a sustained recovery was possible. He advised further spending cuts, possibly in the military sector, or deferring the last year of Mr. Reagan's tax cut. (Page D11.) G.O.P. Congressional leaders told the President that his 1983 budget proposal was dead and that they would draft an alternative with the Democrats. (A1.)   The nation's leading banks reduced their prime lending rates by half a point, to 16 1/2 percent. Several bankers and economists predicted the prime would drop further in the coming week. Bankers attributed the move to declining rates in the money markets, where they obtain funds for their own use. (D1.)

headline: West German Ship Saves Refugees From Pirates
abstract: The crew of a West German rescue ship saved 99 Vietnamese ''boat people'' from the hands of pirates after a sea chase in the Gulf of Thailand, a refugee aid organization reported today. A spokesman for the privately sponsored Com mittee of Emergency Doctors said a boat with 124 refugees on boar d left Vietnam last Thursday, but it was boarded by pirates who s hot to death 14 of the boat people.

headline: MYSTERY OF THE MISSING FILIPINO ATHLETE TAKES ON A POLITICAL TINGE
abstract: The mystery over the disappearance of a prominent athlete after dining with a daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos went into a second week today, with the father of the missing man again accusing the Philippine leader of involvement.   Ricardo Manotoc, a Manila realtor, said his 32-year-old son Tommy was ''possibly being held captive'' for having secretly married Imee Marcos, 26, in the United States in December after divorcing his first wife in the Dominican Republic in October.   The father's charge, made in an interview, followed a statement by Mr. Marcos over the weekend that Tommy Manotoc presented no problem to the Presidential family since he was still the husband of Aurora Pijuan, a former international beauty contest winner whom he married in 1971. Divorces are not recognized in this predominantly Roman Catholic country.

headline: MORE THAN 60 OTHERS ARE INJURED
abstract: Fire raged through the top two floors of a 10-story tourist hotel today, killing at least 32 people and injuring more than 60, fire officials said.   It was the worst fire in Japan since a November 1980 blaze killed 45 people in the resort town of Kawaji.  One of the dead was Kim Tae Dong, 63 years old, a former South Korean Communications Minister who was leading a 17-member delegation to a management conference here, Korean Embassy officials reported.  Two Americans were among the injured in the blaze at the Hotel New Japan.

headline: Company News; Coal Port Halted
abstract: The Savannah Coal Port, a jointly owned development enterprise, announced suspension of construction on its coal storage and shipping facility on Hutchinson Island at Savannah, Ga. The port unit is owned by Elk River Resources Inc. and Harbert Coal Terminals Inc., a subsidiary of the minerals subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the Amoco Minerals Company. A spokesman for Harbert Coal Terminals said the company would probably seek partners for its interest in the port before construction on the facility was resumed.

headline: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
abstract: Interest rates declined yesterday, reducing the yield at the Treasury's auction of new three-year notes to 14.63 percent, well below the 14.9 percent yield that was estimated a day earlier.   Although lower yields and increased prices for notes and bonds are often a sign of increased investor demand, many credit market participants said that yesterday's drop was engineered by traders and speculators and was not based on an inflow of orders from institutional buyers, such as pension funds, banks, insurance companies and investment advisory concerns.   ''At 14 7/8 percent, or even 14 3/4 percent, we would have had a lot of orders for the three-year note,'' said one dealer in Government securities, ''but at these lower yields, I have to assume the issue was bought on emotion by traders and speculators.'' Popularity Cited   William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at the Bank of NewYork, said th at the $1.353 billion of noncompetitive purchases for the three-yea r issue showed its popularity among individuals and smaller insti tutions. Even so, he added that ''the Street pushed the market to the point where lower yields eliminated a lot of interest by institutio ns.''

headline: Police Kill 4 in India At Political Clash
abstract: Four people were killed when policemen opened fire to break up clashes between supporters of India's opposition Janata Party and the ruling Congress Party today in Ahmadabad, 275 miles north of Bombay, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.   The agency said that all four of those killed belonged to the Janata Party and that 13 others were wounded.  The clashes took place in a sugar factory after the two groups began fighting during an annual general meeting of the factory, the agency said.

headline: SPAIN NAMES NEW MILITARY CHIEFS AFTER REMOVING FOUR TOP LEADERS
abstract: The Spanish Government announced the appointment today of new armed forces chiefs after suddenly relieving the nation's four top military men of their commands only hours before.   The Defense Ministry said Thursday night in announcing the shake-up that it was convenient to carry out the change before Spain embarked on lengthy negotiations connected with its entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, possibly in the spring. Three of the replaced officers are 65 years old and due to retire soon.

headline: Pabst Dispute Hearing Set
abstract: A state administrative hearing has been scheduled for Feb.23 into possible violations of Wisconsin law by a Minneapolis businessman and his associates seeking control of the Pabst Brewing Company.   Richard Malmgren, Commissioner of Securities, who has authority to review the conflict under the Wisconsin Corporate Takeover Law, said Thursday: ''I anticipate that representatives of both parties will appear voluntarily.

headline: SALVADOR PEASANTS PRAISE LAND POLICY
abstract: Officers of an organization representing peasants in E l Salvador praised the Government there this week for ''positive at titudes'' toward the troubled land-redistribution plan and for accep ting policy recommendations from the group.   The group, the Union Comunal Salvadorena, which says it speaks for more than 100,000 peasants, had told Jose Napoleon Duarte, the country's President, in December that ''the failure of the agrarian reform process is an immediate and imminent danger.'' It reported the murder of more than 90 peasant leaders then and estimated that as many as 25,000 farmers had been evicted from their newly acquired land, some by right-wing gangs and some by Government security forces. Favorable Picture of Duarte Given   In a four-page lett er dated Jan. 25 two off icers of the union gave a generally favorable picture of President Du arte and some other members of the civilian-military junta and sa id that a number of the peasant group's recommendations had been acce pted. While the letter did not repudiate the gloomy findings of the December report, it outlined a series of promises by Government o fficials to overcome problems arising from lethargic bureaucracy a nd widespread brutality.

headline: German Bankruptcies
abstract: West German bankruptcies during November totaled 1,063, up 50.4 percent from a year earlier, the federal statistics office said today. Company bankruptcies climbed 67.9 percent, to 816; insolvencies of private individuals totaled 247. Bankruptcies in the first 11 months totaled 10,460, the agency said, up 25.7 percent from the similar 1980 period.

headline: Shell Group Posts Decline
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies said today that earnings fell 19.3 percent last year because of the worldwide slowdown in economic activity and depressed demand for petroleum products.   Net income for the year fell to the equivalent of $3.43 billion, from $4.25 billion in 1980, converting the pound at its current exchange rate.

headline: MARCOS SON-IN-LAW ISSUES AN APOLOGY
abstract: A Philippine athlete who vanished Dec. 29 after secretly marrying a daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos apologized on radio and television today because his family had accused the Marcos family of complicity in his disappearance.   Tommy Manotoc, a 32-year-old amateur golfer and professional basketball coach, made the apology by twice reading a letter to the President at a news conference arranged by Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile. The news conference was held hours after the Government announced that he was rescued from ''armed terrorists'' Monday in a mountainous area 55 miles east of Manila ''usually dominated'' by the Maoist insurgent group known as the New People's Army.   ''I understand,'' Mr. Manotoc's letter said, ''that many names have been maligned and that your honor has been questioned. This I would want to rectify for the sake of the country and the Filipino people which you lead.''

headline: WALESA SAID TO SET TERMS FOR TALKS
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.   Sources with knowledge of Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, said yesterday that he had set pre-conditions for negotiating with the Government.   One was that the talks be on neutral ground. He has also reportedly demanded that the rest of the 18-member union presidium and three advisers be present.

headline: Tandy Net Grows 28.8%
abstract: The Tandy Corporation, which runs the Radio Shack stores, reported today that earnings in its fiscal second quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 28.8 percent to $70.26 million, or 68 cents a share, from $54.56 million, or 53 cents a share, a year before. Sales climbed 19 percent to $638.3 million from $534.3 million.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Andersen Group Inc., Bloomfield, Conn., has named Ernest P. Hodur president of Andersen Laboratories.   * Dollar Savings Bank has made Felix J. Christiana senior vice president.

headline: C.I.A. CHANGES SPY OPERATIONS TO ADD SECURITY
abstract: United States intelligence-gathering activities are increasingly being conducted under the cover of private commercial organizations rather than diplomatic missions, according to senior intelligence officials.   The officials said the change was made to tighten security after the loss of sensitive documents when the United States Embassy in Teheran was seized in 1979, Secret Contacts Disclosed   The officials said this new procedure, initiated by William J.  Casey, director of Central Intelligence, resulted from the intelligence community's concern over the public disclosures of secret contacts with Iranian officials and of detailed American assessments of the Iranian situation that followed the takeover.   The documents were obtained by Iranian militants when they seized the embassy on Nov. 4, 1979. They were subsequently published in Iran in a 13-volume series of paperback books, copies of which have now reached newspapers in the United States.

headline: Sales Decline At 2 Japanese Auto Makers
abstract: The Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's leading auto makers, said today that their 1981 exports, domestic sales and production all fell from the previous year.   The companies attributed the declines to economic stagnation in Japan and overseas and the Japanese Government's agreement to restrict e xports in an attempt to ease trade frictions.

headline: Around the World; 2 Refugees Begin a Fast At Embassy in Moscow
abstract: Two of seven Siberians who have lived as religious refugees in the United States Embassy since 1978 have begun a hunger strike to protest the failure to resolve their plight, a relative of the two Siberians said today.   ''It's amazing that two countries that rule the world between them can't resolve the question of our family,'' said Lyuba Vashchen ko, 29years old, on e of seven Pentecostal Siberians who sought refuge at the embassy i n June 1978.

headline: ARAB OIL MEETING SET
abstract: Arab oil ministers will consult here over the weekend on a possible date and site for an emergency OPEC meeting to discuss the worldwide oversupply of oil and tumbling crude oil prices, Algeria's oil minister, Belkacem Nabi, said today.   Sources said the meeting here might be expanded to include representatives of non-Arab members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Indonesia's oil minister, Dr. Subroto, might fly here for the discussions, the sources said. Mr. Nabi, who will be chairman of the meeting here of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries made no mention of Dr. Subroto or other non-Arab oil ministers.

headline: Market Place; Orange Groves And the Future
abstract: LAST week's frigid weather didn't much change the prospects of the Florida orange juice companies. Even before the temperature plunged, neither of the two companies offering investors a pure play was doing well.   American Agronomics, the larger of the two, achieved a turnaround a while back, but it has not done as well lately. The other one, Orange-Co Inc., is not universally regarded as well managed. With the price of the stock well below its underlying value, however, the company may have potential as a takeover candidate.

headline: ECONOMISTS VOICE DOUBTS ON BUDGET
abstract: Several conservative economists who are members of President Reagan's Economic Advisory Board expressed reservations today about various aspects of the President's 1983 budget, particularly the projected deficits.   The economists supported Mr. Reagan's decision not to seek tax increases now to shrink the 1982 budget deficit but some suggested that Congress would be prudent to raise revenues next year. One possible way mentioned was reducing or stretching out the 10 percent cut in personal income tax scheduled for July 1, 1983.   Among those expressing their views in separate comments were Paul W. McCracken, who was chief economic adviser to President Richard M.  Nixon; George P. Shultz, who served Mr. Nixon as Treasury Secretary and budget director; Charls E. Walker, who was Mr. Nixon's Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, and Herbert Stein, who also advised Mr.  Nixon.
