headline: Freighter Sinks Off Japan
abstract: An 11,400-ton Panamanian-registered freighter sank in rough seas off Japan today. The Maritime Safety Agency said all 33 crewmen, from Hong Kong, Taiwan and Indonesia, were rescued by a Japanese fishing boat.

headline: BELL PLANS TO OPEN 2 COMPUTER CENTERS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it was creating two computer centers to provide planning, programming and data processing services for a new subsidiary.   One of the data centers will be established in Orlando and employ about 1,000 workers with an annual payroll of about $36 million, officials said.

headline: WONDERS OF THE FIELD
abstract: AMONG the wonder machines that the technological revolution of the l ast 15 years has produced for medical diagnosis are the following: CAT scanners: The CAT (computerized axial tomography) uses a c omputer and X-ray beams to produce a cross-sectional image on a s creen that looks as if the person undergoing the scan were cut into l ayers. CAT scans reveal details often impossible or difficult to seei n ordinary X-rays.

headline: G.M. Calls Plant Report 'Premature'
abstract: A spokesman for the General Motors Corporation labeled as ''premature'' published reports that plants in Baltimore and Linden, N.J., are the most likely to assemble small cars should G.M. enter a joint agreement with Toyota.   ''It's way too premature,'' William H. Noack said. ''We've only acknowledged that we're talking with Toyota.'' Today's Baltimore Sun quoted an unidentified auto industry source as saying the two plants are the top candidates.

headline: HUNT TRUST PLANS SALE OF OIL SITES
abstract: The Placid Oil Company, which is owned in trust for members of the Hunt family of Dallas, has agreed to sell some of its oil and gas properties for $410 million in cash to the Petro-Lewis Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Petro-Lewis, a Denver company that acquires, develops and operates oi l and gas properties for itself and others, said it would pay Pl acid $347 million and Hunt family interests about $63 million.  Pe tro-Lewis expects to complete the transaction this month.

headline: RENOVATION PLANS READY FOR ARCHIVES IN 'VILLAGE'
abstract: An unusual arrangement, reached after six years of negotiation among government agencies, community groups and a private developer, has cleared the way for the long-awaited renovation of the Federal Archives Building in Greenwich Village.   The $52 million renovation by the Teitelbaum Group, a consortium headed by David M. Teitelbaum, will convert the empty 10-story building at Christopher and Washington Streets into a mixed-use structure combining space for retail shops and areas for community groups on the lower floors with space on the upper floors for 354 cooperative apartments.   The landmark Federal building has several imposing features: its size and dominating block-square bulk; its total interior space of 670,000 square feet, which is about an acre a floor, and its redbrick facade, done in the 19th-century Romanesque revival style that evokes a mixture of romanticism and practicality.   But now the most important fact about the building is its own future -and the effect its redevelopment will have on the changing western edge of Greenwich Village.

headline: Addendum

headline: U.S. WEIGHS PIPELINE STRATEGY
abstract: President Reagan heard arguments from his chief advisers today on whether to take a hard line with the European allies to prevent construction of a pipeline to carry Siberian natural gas to Western Europe, but he put off a decision, Administration officials said.   According to these officials, Defense Secretary Caspar W.  Weinberger made clear his view that if sanctions against the Soviet Union over the situation in Poland were to have any credibility, the allies would have to be told firmly that the United States would oppose the use by European companies of licenses from American concerns to produce components for the pipeline.   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported to have stressed that although the pipeline was contrary to Western interests, it would be counterproductive to try to block it now. He was said to have counseled that it was more important to prevent an open rift in the Western alliance than to take strong action over the pipeline project.

headline: MRS.
abstract: Mark Thatcher, the son of the British Prime Minister, was found alive and well today in the Sahara, along with his French co-driver and mechanic. The three disappeared six days ago while taking part in the punishing Paris-to-Dakar motor rally.   His father, Denis, who flew to Algeria Wednesday to take part in the search, confirmed that Mark, who is 28 years old, was safe.  Earlier, the official Algerian press agency reported that an Algerian Air Force plane had spotted Mr. Thatcher, his co-driver, Anne-Charlotte Verney, his mechanic, Jean Garnier, and their car.  They were seen standing by a tent near the settlement of Tindert, about 250 miles southwest of Tamanrasset in southern Algeria, where a search headquarters had been set up.

headline: U.S. STEEL WAITS TO CLOSE MARATHON DEAL
abstract: By midnight tonight - unless the Supreme Court stops the clock in response to Mobil's emergency petition - the United States Steel Corporation will be free to buy a controlling interest in the Marathon Oil Company, thus ending the biggest takeover battle since Du Pont's $7.6 billion purchase of Conoco last summer.   U.S. Steel cautiously declined to com ment on its apparent success, and outside t enants at the company's headquarters in downtown Pittsburgh sa id that, despite some evidence of stepped-up activity, there did not appear to be any sign of victory in the air.   Andy Staursky, a spokesman for the company, said that David M.  Roderick, chairman of U.S. Steel, was ''out of town on other business'' both Monday and yesterday and was not available for comment.   The Supreme Court did not act yesterday on Mobil's petition to block the U.S. Steel purchase of Marathon.  The Bankers Trust Company, U.S. Steel's official paying agent in the Marathon tender offer, said that it was making tentative plans to start the paperwork as soon as the midnight deadline passes so that it can begin delivering checks to Marathon's stockholders, in person and by mail, on Monday morning.

headline: Real Estate; Upper-End R esidential Developer
abstract: AT one time or another, Charles Shaw has been an active bui lder in 13 cities. In no one place is he the biggest developer, or the most notable. But he is a major figure in commerci al real estate development, and he has several substantial p rojects in his portfolio, including the Museum Tower, the lu xury condominiums being built on top of the new wing of the Museum of Modern Art on West 53d Street. The Museum Tower is a joint venture w ith the Leon D.  DeMatteis Construction Corporation.   Mr. Shaw, who bases his operations in Chicago, has a fondness for expensive, unusual residential buildings such as the Lake Point Tower, a 70-story residential complex on Chicago's lake front that is supposed to be the tallest residential building in the world.

headline: INDIAN MIGRANTS TO MIDEAST FACE MANY PITFALLS
abstract: Thirty-one Indian farmers who said they had been lured to Lebanon by promises of jobs, only to be taken to a guerrilla camp, were rescued last month by the Indian Government, which paid their way home.   But their unhappy experience, which, they said, involved being ordered to fight as mercenaries in Beirut, did not end with their return. They were imprisoned on charges of violating emigration laws.

headline: COMMODORE ADDS HEAD FOR CONSUMER PRODUCTS
abstract: Alan W. Fink, 45, who has spent about two decades selling consumer products, has joined Commodore International Ltd. as the first president of its newly formalized consumer products division.  Commodore is a major manufacturer of computer systems and semiconductor components.

headline: U.S. EXPECTS PROGRESS IN NAMIBIA TALKS
abstract: State Department officials said today that the United States and four other Western nations expected to make progress next week in their efforts to bring about the independence of South-West Africa from South Africa.   The officials said that as a result of intensive diplomatic exchanges in the last several months, the African countries and parties involved in the negotiations to bring the territory, also known as Namibia, to independence seem to be in agreement on the principles for the elections to a constituent assembly and for the constitution itself.   Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, will represent the United States at talks in Bonn on Monday and Tuesday with envoys from Britain, Canada, France and West Germany. These five nations are known as the contact group and have been trying to find a formula in negotiations with South Africa, black African nations and the various political factions inside and outside the territory.

headline: Angola Accuses Pretoria Of Stepping Up Raids
abstract: Angola accused S outh Africa today of attacking Cuban troops deep inside the countr y and of stepping up the conflict with long-range air raids.

A Petersen spokesman said that the plan was to continue the two publications, with the newly acquired one concentrating on on-street trucks and the old one on off-road vehicles. The acquisition brings to 14 the number of specialty monthly magazines Petersen publishes.

headline: 2 Banks Raise Prime to 16 1/2%
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank and Marine Midland Banks yesterday raised their prime lending r ate a quarter of a percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent, afte r holding out for a week with a smaller increase than the rest of t he industry.   Other big banks had increased their prime rate to 16 1/2 percent from 15 3/4 percent last Tuesday.

headline: Mexican Oil Plan Reported
abstract: The Mexican Petroleum Institute has recommended that Mexico elimi nate its ceiling s on exports of crude oil and natural gas so that funds can be rais ed for industrial development, Petroleum Information Internatio nal reported today in its latest edition.   The weekly newsletter, published by an A.C. Nielsen Company subsidiary here, said the Mexican Government agency's report was likely to generate considerable controversy in Mexico because the national energy program, adopted scarcely more than a year ago, limits exports to 1.5 million barrels of oil and 300 million cubic feet of gas daily.

headline: REAGAN'S ANTITRUST EXPLOSION
abstract: WITH last week's historic developments in suits against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the International Business Machines Corporation, the attention of antitrust-policy watchers snapped back toward the Justice Department and its antitrust enforcer, William F. Baxter. Until the Friday announcements, however, it had been the Federal Trade Commission and its new chairman, William C. Miller 3d, in the spotlight with the Mobil and U.S. Steel bids for Marathon Oil.   Indeed, in unexpectedly lively matches, the Reagan Administration is bouncing balls fiercely in both of the antitrust courts available to it.   It is in the F.T.C. court that, almost since Mr. Miller took command in October that one of the biggest and most fiercely contested takeover attempts on record has been waged, the $6 billionplus bids by Mobil and U.S. Steel for Marathon. Big Steel nailed down its victory last week after the Supreme Court refused to hear Mobil's last desperate appeal.

headline: Oil Prices Weaker on Spot Market; Spot Oil Prices Weaker
abstract: Crude oil prices continued to weaken on the spot market this week as supplies remained far in excess of demand and buyers continued to show little interest, market sources said here today.   Many traders left to attend the annual dinner of the Institute of Petroleum in London last Wednesday, which also contributed to the slow trading, the sources said.

headline: Kuwait Offers a P.O.W. Plan
abstract: Kuwait is prepared in principle to be a staging point for families visiting prisoners captured in the Iraqi-Iranian war, a Government spokesman said today. Iraq and Iran announced agreement in principle last month for visits by families of prisoners taken during the 17-month-old Persian Gulf war.

The quake, which struck the northernmost island of Hokkaido, destroyed homes and set off landslides in coastal fishing villages, the police said.

headline: SOVIET FREEZE: EUROPE'S VIEW
abstract: Most Western European governments and military specialists reacted cautiously today to the freeze on medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe announced by Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain quickly dismissed the missile freeze, which concerns nuclear weapons deployed in the European part of the Soviet Union, or west of the Ural Mountains.   Mrs. Thatcher told the House of Commons the decision ignored two facts: ''Firstly, it freezes the total superiority of the Soviet Union in these particular theater nuclear weapons. Secondly, it ignores the fact that the SS-20 missiles can just as well be targeted on this country and the rest of Europe from beyond the Urals as they can this side of them.''

headline: SEARS OFF IN QUARTER; FULL YEAR UP 6.6%
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported yesterday that net income slipped 1.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, while revenues advanced 5.3 percent. It said higher income expense was a major factor.   Sears, the world's largest retailer and now a leading financial services company, said that net income in the latest three months slipped to $333.1 million, or $1.05 a share, from $339.7 million, or $1.07 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues increased to $8 billion from $7.6 billion.

headline: ISRAELI CABINET AFFIRMS POLICIES ON ARAB PROTEST
abstract: As demonstrations continued in the West Bank today, the Government affirmed its policies in the occupied territories, declaring that ''no acts of violence or disturbances of the peace or order will be tolerated.''   In northern Israel, leaders of Israeli Arabs prepared for a general strike and demonstration on Tuesday to demand an end to the Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza and the formation of a Palestinian state. (Page A5.)   Three Palestinian protesters were shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers in Yabed, near the West Bank town of Jenin. An army spokesman said they had attacked a patrol with knives and Molotov cocktails. According to an army statement two of the Palestinians were hospitalized. No soldiers were injured.

headline: IRAQ SAYS JET FIGHTERS FROM ISRAEL VIOLATED AIRSPACE A 2D TIME
abstract: Iraq, for the second time in five days, charged today that Israeli jet fighters had violated its a irspace.   The official Iraqi press agency, monitored here, said two Israeli F-15's flew 36 miles into western Iraq and were chased away over Maqar al-Naam by Iraqi warplanes.

headline: Prospects
abstract: The False Bottom   In coming weeks, signs that the recession may have hit bottom in February are likely to surface, giving the Administration and Congress an excuse to delay action in their dispute over fiscal policy. While acknowledging that a rebound of sorts did occur last month, some analysts say the underlying fundamentals remain unchanged, and that the current recession is still dangerously close to turning into something far worse.   Upcoming reports on retail sales and industrial production, to name two, are likely to show improvement from depressed January levels.  Unemployment rose last month, but remains below 9 percent. And positive oil price developments could give a short-term lift to some beleagured industries, notably the commercial airlines.

headline: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 DROP 31.1%
abstract: The pace of new-car sales by the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers fell 31.1 percent in the first 10 days of March, the steepest decline this year, despite continuing rebate programs.   The Chrysler Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation reported today that they had sold 16,841 cars daily in the nine selling days of the period, compared with 24,460 a day in the eight selling days of the comparable 1981 period. 'Mostly the Recession'   David Healy, an analyst with Drexel Burhham Lambert Inc., attributed the poor sales to the recession, high interest rates and high car price - ''mostly the recession.''   All five major auto makers, including Volskwagen and American Motors, had rebate programs in effect during the period, but they appeared to have had little impact on sales.

headline: Market Place; Datapoint's Gloomy News
abstract: THERE'S a rule of thumb in Wall Street that, once earnings estimates are reduced, they are likely to be reduced again. That is exactly what has been happening with Datapoint. The company's management met with analysts yesterday only to disappoint them further.   Datapoint has been a highflier for years. Its highly regarded line of data processing and communications equipment has made it one of the premier growth companies. But in January, Datapoint's management forecast income of 66 cents a share for the fiscal second quarter ended that month.

headline: SLOW GROWTH HELPS CUT INFLATION IN WESTERN ECONOMIES AND JAPAN
abstract: Inflation in the seven largest non-Communist industrial nations has dropped sharply in the last year as a result of slow economic growth, reduced wage demands and falling commodity prices. Economists expect the downward trend to continue.   By the end of 1981, inflation in those countries had declined to a rate of about 8 percent, compared with 12.2 percent in 1980. In recent months, various private and government economists have been growing more optimistic about the outlook.

In a separate filing, the company said it had also increased its stake in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company to 2,645,300 shares, or 23.84 percent. In its S.E.C. filings, G.& W.  said that both purchases were for investment purposes.

headline: Soviet Reports Appointment Of Deputy Chief of the K.G.B.
abstract: Georgi K. Tsinev has been named first deputy chairman of the K.G.B., which runs the Soviet overseas intelligence operations and internal security force, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.   No formal announcement of the 74-year-old army general's appointment was made.

headline: Reynolds Raises Cigarette Prices
abstract: R. J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette producer, said it will raise the wholesale price for all of its domestic cigarette brands and its Winchester little cigars by $1 per thousand, effective next Tuesday.   Reynolds said the increase would raise the consumer price of a package of cigarettes about 2 cents and 20 cents for a carton.  Reynolds manufactures Winston, Salem, Camel, Doral II, Vantage, More and NOW cigarettes.

headline: RECORD SET ON 30 YEAR U.S. BONDS
abstract: The Treasury sold new 14 percent bonds yesterday at an average yield of 14.56 percent, a record for a new 30-year issue that showed the extreme reluctance of investors to buy long-term bonds even though inflation has subsided.   The high yield for the bonds - up from only 13.9 percent a week ago and 12 3/4 percent in late November -seemed to confirm Wall Street warnings that large budget deficits push up interest rates. Early last November, the Treasury sold similar bonds at a 14.10 percent yield, but since then budget deficit estimates for the fiscal years 1983 and 1984 have expanded sharply.   Despite this, Treasury officials had little choice but to crowd into the credit markets this week with $20 billion of short- and long-term issues that raised about $6.7 billion of new cash. Treasury officials estimated last week that they needed to raise $41.25 billion of new cash this quarter to cover a fiscal 1982 deficit estimated by private analysts and some Government officials at $100 million.

headline: Risdon Picks New Chief

Zimmermann, the 47-year-old president of the Risdon Corporation - a mini-conglomerate with about half of its $160 million volume in cosmetic and specialty packaging -has been appointed to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Christopher H. Buckley, 66, who remains chairman of the company, based in Naugatuck, Conn.

headline: C.A.B. DISCLOSES INQUIRY ON AMERICAN AIRLINES
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that it was investigating complaints that American Airlines may have tried to aggravate a cash-flow crisis at Braniff Airways by tampering with the ticket-clearing process.   William H. Wentz, the board's general counsel, said in an interview last night that it had been reviewing the complaints for about a week. So far, he said, the board had determined that some of the complaints were unfounded while others were impossible to check.

headline: ASARCO APPOINTS NEW CHAIRMAN
abstract: Ralph L. Hennebach, 61 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Asarco Inc., a leading nonferrous metals producer with interests around the world. His appointment will be effective after the annual meeting on April 28.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Three conferences held in Warsaw last week drew a distinct line between the dominant forces in Poland under martial law. Although both the church and the state appealed for unity, the conditions they set augured the opposite.   Presiding stiffly over a surprisingly tame session of the Communist Party's Central Committee and displaying similar control at a subsequent session of the country's Parliament, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski demonstrated that the reins of party and Government were firmly in his grasp, that the free-wheeling political debates of the previous year were over.   He heard solid support for martial law and for his promise of continued severity against violators; he heard only denunciations of Solidarity and the ''extremists'' who he said hijacked its leadership, and he found no disagreement with his program of ''national reconciliation'' along lines that would effectively exclude the indepdendent labor union Solidarity in the shape it had before military rule.

headline: ITALIAN POLICEMEN FREE U.S. GENERAL, WHO IS UNHARMED
abstract: Antiterrorist forces stormed an apartment in Padua and freed Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier today, 42 days after he was abducted by the Red Brigades.   The American general was unhurt and said he was in ''excellent health,'' according to the United States Ambassador in Rome, Maxwell M. Rabb. The general, the highest-ranking American officer serving with NATO in Italy, was taken to an American military hospital in Vicenza, 20 miles from Padua, for an indefinite period of medical observation.   One of his captors was aiming a pistol at the general's head when the squad of 10 special antiterrorist policemen broke into the second-floor apartment at 11:35 A.M. (5:35 A.M. Thursday, New York time), the Italian news agency ANSA quoted the Padua police as having said. One Terrorist Is Wounded   Seized in the raid were five persons, including one or two women, who were described by the police as being members of the leftist Red Brigades. No shots were reported fired, but one of those seized was taken to a Padua hospital with a head wound said to have been caused by a blow with a rifle butt.

headline: Israel Assails Vote in U.N.
abstract: The Israeli Parliament in Jerusalem today rejected a United Nations resolution condemning the annexation of the Golan Heights. The opposition abstained from the vote in Parliament because it was critical of the Government's extension of Israeli law to the area.

headline: BIDDER FOR CANNON SEEMS TO NEAR GOAL
abstract: David H. Murdock has won the approval of family interests in the Cannon Mills Company for his acquisition bid, and thus appears well on his way to gaining control of the 100-yearold concern, textile industry analysts said today.   ''It's a good probability that he will have at least a majority ownership,'' said John Pickler, an analyst with Wheat, First Securities in Richmond.   The takeover would be worth $390 million if Mr. Murdock were to acquire all outstanding shares. He has arranged a financing plan that would effectively enable him to acquire Cannon with loans backed by what analysts regard as Cannon's undervalued assets.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILLER, H, & SONS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Protest by North Korea On War Games Rejected
abstract: The American-led United Nations Command today rejected a North Korean demand that the United States and South Korea stop joint exercises.

headline: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REBELLION ERUPTS IN CENTRAL SYRIA, DIPLOMATS REPORT
abstract: A revolt against the Government of President Hafez al-Assad has been under way for eight days in the central city of Hama, Western diplomatic sources reported today.  About 8,000 Government soldiers were said to have the city under siege.   About 100 Government tanks and artillery pieces have leveled part of the city, according to Japanese businessmen evacuated by Government troops Tuesday night. The businessmen said the bombardment was continuing.

headline: Sony Appeals Videotape Ruling
abstract: The Sony Corporation appealed to the Supreme Court to overturn a far-reaching ruling that could brand three million American families as lawbreakers for using home video recorders to tape television programs.   The ruling last October by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco panicked the home video recording industry by declaring that use of recorders to tape copyrighted TV programs -even for home use - violates Federal law.   ''Rarely has there been a copyright case of greater public, commercial and academic interest,'' Sony's attorneys contended in urging the High Court to review the case.

headline: EARNINGS FORECASTS GO LOWER
abstract: With the economy sinking deeper into recession, economic forecasters are revising their estimates of corporate earnings for the first quarter of 1982, making their gloomy projections even gloomier.   The forecasters said corporate profit margins in the first quarter were being squeezed much tighter than earlier anticipated, as a result of lower productivity, high interest rates, dwindling sales volumes and product prices that are slipping faster than manufacturing costs. The auto, oil and housing industries are expected to lead the earnings retreat, dragging other sectors of the economy closely behind.   ''What is most disconcerting,'' said Gail I. Hessol, vice president for industrial ratings at Standard & Poor's Corporation, ''is that just about any of the industries or companies we deal with have business forecasts that assume a recovery for the second half of 1982. But when we press them, they admit their orders have not picked up this quarter. If there is to be a recovery, they should be receiving the orders by now. I think many of them are quietly reassessing their plans.''

headline: Salvador Policy Protest Is Staged in New York
abstract: A three-hour protest in New York against United States military aid to El Salvador drew a crowd estimated by the authorities at up to 4,000 people yesterday.   The protest, sponsored by the New York chapter of the Committee in Solidarity With the People of El Salvador, began with a rally at the United States Mission to the United Nations and then moved to the Salvadoran Mission.

headline: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARBARA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Smaller Cuts For S.E.C.
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is scheduled to lose 125 staff positions in President Reagan's proposed budget for th e fiscal year 1983, much less than the possible cuts thecommission ha d been facing last fall.

headline: BELL'S PERPLEXED STOCKHOLDERS
abstract: Flush with some inherited money, Ruth Spencer put some of it into American Telephone and Telegraph stock soon after she got out of college. Now retired and a widow living in Terrell, Tex., she still has the stock, but with A.T.& T. splitting up the Bell System, she isn't sure what to do with it.   ''Up to now, Telephone has been plenty good to this shareholder,'' she said. ''I've read every little smithereen I can find, and I've clipped them and marked them and puzzled over them. Certainly, anything that's new is fearful, though I'm glad that that dad-gum suit is settled. I'll tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to keep my stock, but I'm going to watch it like a hawk. Don't think I'm not.''   Every member of the phone company's far-flung family of three million shareholders - from the big pension plans to the short-order cook in Duluth to the widow at poolside in Miami -has been watching A.T.& T. stock with an accountant's keen eye ever since the tumultuous announcement some four weeks ago that the phone system would be broken up.

headline: TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1982; Companies
abstract: An agreement for Coca-Cola to acquire Columbia Pictures in a $750 million transaction is expected to be announced today. The proposal is said to call for an offer of $74 a share in cash and stock for the profitable film company's 10.7 million shares outstanding. The acquisition would be the first major one under Roberto O. Goizueta, who took over Coca-Cola last March. (Page A1.)   Chase Manhattan's fourth-quarter earnings almost doubled, rising to $135.6 million. Continental Illinois reported a 35.7 percent increase in its net operating earnings. (D3.)

headline: NORTH KOREAN LEADER PLANS HUGE FETE FOR SON
abstract: Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, is preparing a lavish celebration of his 70th birthday next month to pave the way for his son's succession to the leadership, according to South Korean intelligence sources.   Mr. Kim, who has led North Korea since 1945, has already delegated much authority to his 40-year-old son, Kim Chong Il, the intelligence sources said. The high point of the mammoth birthday ceremony on April 15, they said, will be the public appearance of the son at his father's side in front of an audience of 100,000 that will include dignitaries from China, the Soviet Union and the third world.   ''Almost the entire North Korean Cabinet is in orbit right now,'' said a spokesman for the South Korean Agency for National Security Planning, an intelligence group. ''They are traveling in Africa, Central and Latin America and elsewhere, seeking to drum up support.'' The sources said that the ministers were offering to charter aircraft to bring guests to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, if they could not otherwise afford to travel.

headline: EQUALITY IN MARRIAGE AT NABISCO BRANDS
abstract: PERFECT symmetry rules the board room of Nabisco Brands, the food giant created last July from the merger of Nabisco and Standard Brands. Housed between walls of glass, 26 directors - 13 from each company - sit at an exceptionally large, square table. Side by side are the chairman and chief executive, Robert Schaeberle, formerly head of Nabisco, and the president and chief operating officer, F. Ross Johnson, formerly head of Standard Brands.   Nor does the symmetry end in the board room. No senior manager has left the merged company, and the lineup of the new team reads like a Chinese menu: one from column A (Nabisco), one from column B (Standard Brands).   The new company, with sales last year of $5.8 billion, ranks as the nation's fourth-largest food processor, behind Dart & Kraft, Beatrice Foods and General Foods. It is also, by all accounts, a most successful venture as mergers go. ''We keep using the word 'logical,' '' said Mr. Schaeberle during an interview at the midtown Manhattan headquarters of the Nabisco Products division -formerly the international headquarters of Standard Brands.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chemical Bank has named as vice presidents William B. Cornfield, Mary Ellen Travis, Reginald P. Smith, Thomas J. Rizzo, G. Harrison Houston 3d, Kenneth H. Ringel, Deborah Gerard Adelman, James A. Capo and Timothy T. Gannon.   * Fedders Corp. has appointed Thomas A. Oravetz president and chief executive officer of its Fedders Automotive Components Company and Joseph Terpak to the new position of vice chairman of the division.   * Filmways Inc. has appointed Robert P. Schwartz senior vice president-administration.

headline: TURKEY CONCEDES TORTURE DEATHS, REPORTS IT IS PROSECUTING OFFICIALS
abstract: The Government acknowledged today that 15 people had died of torture since the military takeover on Sept.12, 1980, adding that other reports were being investigated.   The Government spokesman, Ilhan Oztrak, announced that nine security officials had been convicted and sentenced in three of the torture cases and that 12 other cases were before the courts. He did not say what the sentences were.

headline: AEICOR INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CITIBANK GROUP TO GET THE PINEHURST RESORT
abstract: Pinehurst, the luxurious golfer's resort, rises out of the arid sand hills of south-central North Carolina like some desert oasis. Without warning, the bleak scrub brush landscape gives way to emerald fairways and vaulting pines.   And with a turn off Route 1 from Raleigh, one leaves behind the real North Carolina of struggling tobacco farms for a fantasy land of stately villas, a country village, and almost painfully consistent good taste.   Whether Pinehurst's tasteful traditions can survive is the present question. Documents are expected to be signed shortly to turn over the 87-year-old resort from its corporate owner of 12 years to an eight-bank consortium, led by New York's Citibank, which hopes eventually to resell it. The transaction involves assets of Pinehurst, valued at about $31 million, and an assumption of the corporate owner's $73 million debt.

headline: Dow Declines 2.86, to 830.57
abstract: Stock prices continued to slip yesterday on the heels of Monday's sharp drop. Still hanging over the market was investor concern about interest rates and the Reagan Administration's projected record budget deficit.   The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 830.57, down 2.86 points. A day earlier, it tumbled 17.60 points and crashed through a support zone around 840 on the charts.

headline: C.A.B. ALLOWS CARRIERS TO RETURN TO FARE TALKS
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board today extended the authority of United States carriers to take part in conferences aimed at restoring a fare-setting mechanism for North Atlantic routes.   The vote, which gave the airlines immunity from antitrust charges until March 15, came with a provision that European governments accept much greater pricing flexibility on the North Atlantic routes.    Daniel M. Kaspar, director of the agency's Bureau of International Aviation, disclosed to the board today that the 21 members of the European Civil Aviation Conference - the heads of Europe's civil aviation authorities - had agreed to work toward a C.A.B. proposal that would establish ''tariff zones'' within which airlines could adjust prices without g overnment approval. Fi nal agreement is being sought by the end of February.

headline: SATURDAY, MARCH 27, 1982; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan is no longer committed to the budget he submitted last month and is ready to negotiate basic changes in it to reduce the projected deficit, according to Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor. His remarks were regarded as the most openly conciliatory sign so far in the budget dispute with Congress. (Page 1.)   The foreign trade deficit shrank sharply in February, to $1.2 billion from $5.1 billion in January, the Commerce Department reported. It said the value of oil imports had plunged and that the current recession had helped reduce imports at a faster pace than in any month since the 1975 recession. Nevertheless, the department warned that the year's deficit could approach $42 billion. (38.)

headline: Batten, Barton Adds Spearmint
abstract: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn's Chicago office has added Wrigley Spearmint to the other brands of chewing gum it advertises for the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company.

headline: Your Money; Settling Fights With Brokers
abstract: MR. X was in a tizzy. On the advice of his broker, he invested $3,000 in options to buy and sell stocks and promptly lost $1,153.  Mrs. Y was in a funk. Her broker made one trade after another in her $137,000 account, running up the amount she had to pay in commissions and losing $3,000 on poor investments.   Mr. X and Mrs. Y complained to the companies that employed their brokers. Mr. X said: What do I know about options trading? I relied on the broker's word that it was a safe investment. Mrs. Y asserted that her account was being ''churned'' to earn commissions for the broker.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Officials Accused by Nyerere Of Being Corrupt and Greedy
abstract: President Julius K. Nyerere has accused Tanzania's bureaucracy of being corrupt and greedy, The Sunday News, a Government-owned newspaper, reported.

headline: IN SALVADOR, CITY ENDURES 5 DAYS OF WAR
abstract: Rebel forces attacked this provincial capital last Friday in their strongest military operation in two and a half years of civil war. Most previous guerrilla attacks had been against soldiers defending small, isolated villages.  Hitand-run raids on larger cities rarely lasted more than a few hours.   But for five days there was intense fighting in the streets of Usulutan, the country's fourth largest city, which rests in a rich agricultural valley between volcanoes and the Pacific Ocean. During that time, residents were pinned inside their homes without electricity and water, unable to get food.

headline: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLES PUBLISH LIMITS ON UNION ACTIVITIES
abstract: The Polish Government published proposals today for the future of trade unions that would guarantee their independence, but curtail the use of strikes and prevent them from becoming a political movement.   The proposals, prepared by the Government's Committee for Trade Unions and published in major newspapers, declared as their aim the prevention of a return to the kind of officially manipulated unions that existed before the 1980 agreement that gave rise to the independent Solidarity union, But the proposals, which were carried Sunday by P.A.P., the Polish press agency, also ruled out a return to the ''opposition and destructive force'' that the document said Solidarity became.   One of the Solidarity leaders still at large, Zbigniew Bujak, who headed the Warsaw local, said in a recent interview that he might agree to revive Solidarity with limited goals and restricted strike rights, but he indicated that he would demand that the union maintain its structure organized both by regions and by crafts. This was rejected by the Government paper released today.

headline: MAJOR EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Thais Jail a Jersey Woman
abstract: Candice Lee Carpenter of Oakland, N.J., was sentenced to 25 years in jail today for her attempt to smuggle seven pounds of heroin out of Thailand last September.

headline: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Javits Bids Allies Hold More Top-Level Talks
abstract: Terming the ''disharmony'' among the NATO countries ''our greatest weakness,'' former Senator Jacob K. Javits urged yesterday that meetings among the top leaders of Western nations become a regular and institutionalized element of diplomacy.   Mr. Javits, in a speech to a joint meeting of the Foreign Policy Association and the Council on Foreign Relations at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York, deplored what he said was the absence of ''effective consultation'' among the countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, especially at times when a swift response to Soviet actions is called for.

headline: LOUISIANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RCA Dividend To Be Cut 50%
abstract: The RCA Corporation, parent of the NBC television network, said yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend in half to reduce costs and improve its financial position.   The reduction, to 22 1/2 cents a common share, marks the first cut in the company's payout since it began paying dividends in 1937, Thornton F. Bradshaw, chairman, said.

headline: Talking Business with Loucks of Baxter Travenol Ambulatory Patient Care
abstract: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., a Deerfield, Ill., supplier of products used in intravenous feeding and therapy, in the treatment of kidney disease and in blood treatment, recently reported record operating results for 1981. It earned $150.6 million, up 18 percent from 1980, on sales of $1.5 billion. Earnings per share, up for the 27th consecutive year, were $2.15, after a 2-for-1 stock split.   Vernon R. Loucks Jr., Baxter's president and chief executive officer, in a recent interview, discussed how the company had positioned itself to benefit from pressure on hospitals to cut costs. Mr. Loucks, a Yale graduate and former Marine officer who holds an M.B.A. from Harvard, served as a senior management consultant with George Fry Associates before joining Baxter Travenol in 1966 as assistant to the president and chief executive officer. He has since held senior positions in the company's domestic and international operations.

headline: IT WAS TOUGH MEDICINE, BUT G.D. SEARLE BREATHES EASIER NOW
abstract: SKEPTICISM and trepidation abounded at G.D. Searle & Company when Donald H. Rumsfeld took charge in 1977 as president and chief executive. There was trepidation because he was known as an ax man.  There was skepticism because Mr. Rumsfeld had no corporate business experience, whatever the number of top Government posts he had held, and he was also an outsider - the first non-Searle to head the company in its 90-year history.   ''He's tough-minded,'' said Arthur M. Wood, a Searle director and former chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company. ''Searle knew that it would be taking some risks in bringing him on.''   The doubts about Mr. Rumsfeld have long since dissipated and employees have little to fear for now. Searle's earnings on continuing op erations have climbed an average of 17 percent a year, and Searle re ported last week that 1981 earnings on continuing operations ju mped 29 percent, to $130.9 million, on sales of $942.3 million (alth ough an accounting adjustment and losses from discontinued operation dropped the net to $98.7 million).

headline: TAYLOR RENTAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: T.W.A. Cuts Fare to Coast
abstract: In an effort to fill up more seats in the coach section of its planes flying the transcontinental routes, Trans World Airlines said it had lowered fares and relaxed some of its restrictions on its Super Saver fares.   Effective immediately, T.W.A. said that the one-way Super Saver fare from New York to Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego was reduced to $169 during the day and $149 at night.

headline: Warsaw Accuses Group Of Armed Resistance
abstract: The Polish Government today accused opponents of organizing an armed resistance movement that it said was involved in killing a policeman, assaulting soldiers and stealing arms.   The military prosecutor's office said some of the nine people being investigated in the slaying last month of a police sergeant were suspected of belonging to what it termed an armed criminal organization called the Armed Forces of Underground Poland.

headline: OCCIDENTAL NET UP 35.5%
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum C orporation reported yesterday that strongearnings gain s by its coal division offset declines in oil and gas earnings and helped lift 1981 fourth-quarter earnings by 35.5 percent. Reve nues advanced 40.6 percent.   The diversified Los Angeles-based concern said that net income in the latest three months rose to $187.1 million, or $1.72 a share, from $138.1 million, or $1.65 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues increased to $4.47 billion from $3.18 billion.

headline: Around the World; Moscow Hunger Striker Said to Be Deteriorating
abstract: A Pentecostalist on a hunger strike is in deteriorating condition at the American Embassy and will soon be handed over to the Soviet Union for treatment, a United States spokesman said today.   The transfer of Lydia Vashchenko to a Soviet hospital was described as ''imminent'' by the embassy official, and an embassy source said it would probably take place Saturday.

headline: U.N. RESOLUTION ON GOLAN
abstract: Following is the text of a resolution on the Israeli annexation of the Golan Heights that was vetoed by the United States today in the Security Council:   THE SECURITY COUNCIL, RECALLING its Resolution 497 (1981) dated 17 December 1981, HAVING CONSIDERED the reports of the Secretary General contained in document S/14805 dated 21 December 1981, S/14805/Corr. 1 dated 23 December 1981 and S/14821 dated 31 December 1981,   CONSIDERING that the Security Council in its Resolution 497 (1981) decided that in the event of noncompliance by Israel it would urgently meet ''to consider taking appropriate measures in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations,''   BEARING IN MIND General Assembly Resolution 36/226 B of 17 December 1981, RECALLING General Assembly Resolution 3314 (XXIX) of 14 December 1974, which defines an act of aggression as ''the invasion or attack by the armed forces of a state of the territory of another state, or any military occupation, however temporary, resulting from such invasion or attack, or any annexation by the use of force of the territory of another state or part thereof,''   DETERMINING that the continued occupation of the Syrian Golan Heights since June 1967 and its annexation by Israel on 14 December 1981 constitute a continuing threat to international peace and security,   ACTING in accordance with the relevant provisions of Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations, 1. STRONGLY CONDEMNS Israel for its failure to comply with Security Council Resolution 497 (1981) and General Assembly Resolution 36/226 B (1981);   2.

headline: Around the World; Iranian Ends Syrian Visit With No Gains on Iraq
abstract: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Vellayati of Iran flew home today after three days of talks that produced no sign of progress toward ending the Iranian-Iraqi war.

headline: Tobin Says Fed Imperils Recovery
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board's tight-money policies - and not the Administration's huge budget deficits -threaten to ''stop a new recovery before it gets very far,'' James Tobin, who was awarded the 1981 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, said yesterday in New York.   Professor Tobin said the Fed could relax its monetary stance without rekindling inflation if its action were coupled with measures to reduce Federal deficits.   He proposed eliminating a 10 percent cut in tax rates scheduled for July 1983, reducing defense spending plans by $10 billion a year, imposing $10 billion in ''windfall profits'' taxes from a decontrol of natural gas prices and raising another $10 billion by closing unspecified tax loopholes.

headline: Nigerian Heads World Court
abstract: The 15-member International Court of Justice today elected Taslim Olawale Elias of Nigeria to be its president. Judge Elias, 67 years old, had been acting president and succeeds Sir Humphrey Waldock of Britain, who died in August.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: After its rapprochement with the United Automobile Workers fell apart last month, the General Motors Corporation chose a familiar route to counter dismal sales. It announced plans to close three plants indefinitely in March, including its Chevrolet and Cadillac plant here, and throw another 7,000 employees out of work.   The breakdown in talks and the subsequent layoffs caught many labor relations specialists off guard. General Motors had won high marks for improving morale and productivity on the factory floor since the last big recession in 1974. Its worker participation programs, which in general give employees more responsibility on the assembly line, have been widely copied.   Moreover, many management specialists had pointed to G.M. as an example of how a large American manufacturer is meeting Japanese competition by reducing labor tensions and improving products.

headline: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Suriname Holds Coup Figure
abstract: Suriname announced today that soldiers had captured the army lieutenant who led an attempted coup last week against the leftist Government of Lieut. Col. Desie Bouterse. The Government said Lieut. Surinder Rambocus was captured Wednesday but did not comment on reports he had been wounded.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM TESTIMONY BY HAIG BEFORE HOUSE PANEL
abstract: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s testimony today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:   Vietnam-Salvador Parallel   I think much has been done to suggest there are strong parallels between the American approach today to Salvador and to Vietnam some years ago. I think this is a terrible distortion of reality and one which overlooks a number of fundamental differences.   First and foremost is the difference with respect to the strategic importance of Central America as a region and the member republics of the region to the United States today. That region is our fourth largest trading partner; one-half of our oil moves through the waters of the Caribbean and the canal. Roughly one-half of our global trade goes through that region. As a nation, we've been plagued recently to the tune of one and a half million undocumented illegal entries to the United States in 1980. All of this underlines the strategic importance of the Central America region. From the standpoint of military capability, at a time of conflict, it would control the flow of our logistic support for our half a million Americans positioned forward in Europe to maintain the defense of those assets, let alone the importance of our ability to defend Western Europe at large.

headline: 2 Iranians Said to Escape Assassination Attempts
abstract: Iran's police chief and a religious leader escaped separate assassination attempts in Teheran, Iran's official press reported today.

headline: Business Conditions; RAISING MONEY ABROAD
abstract: Paced by a sharp increase in Canadian placements, activity in international bond markets rose 24 percent last year, to $47.7 billion, according to a survey by Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm.   High interest rates in Canada, strong credit demand stemming from rising government deficits and a wave of company takeovers were the major reasons why Canadian debt offerings in international markets more than tripled in 1981, to $10.5 billion, from levels a year earlier.

headline: Baltimore Canyon Plans
abstract: A division of the Zapata Corporation has acquired interests in five adjacent nine-square-mile tracts about 70 miles southeast of Atlantic City in the Baltimore Canyon Trough, Barney White, a spokesman for the company, said today.

headline: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNEXPECTEDLY, MRS. THATCHER'S FORTUNES BRIGHTEN
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's chances of winning the next general election, which were considered almost nonexistent three months ago, appear to be improving.   In a season of subtle but significant changes in the tenor of British politics, Mrs. Thatcher and her resolutely cautious policies no longer seem quite so embattled. This week a London bookmaker went so far as to install her Conservative Party as a narrow favorite to win the election, which is expected in the spring of 1984.   The most important development has been a slowing of the momentum of the new Social Democratic Party, which burst upon the British political scene just a year ago with tremendous force, and which won its most notable victory late last year when Shirley Williams captured the previously Conservative seat at Crosby, near Liverpool, in a by-election.

headline: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: More Britons Are Seeking Better Life Abroad
abstract: ''We want a better life,' ' Moirag Knowles said as she explained why she and her fiance had d ecided to move to Australia. ''It's quite tough here and it's g etting tougher.''   Her fiance, Kim Sharpley, an auto mechanic, added, ''I've not had a wage rise in three years.'' Battered by recession and depressed by a pervasive British malaise, more and more Britons are leaving, convinced that fresh opportunities lie elsewhere and that Government cutbacks, particularly in public spending, have caused the quality of life to deteriorate.

headline: Holly Sugar's Shares Plunge
abstract: Holly Sugar Corporation stock plunged $11.25 a share in consolidated trading yesterday to $47.75. Wall Street professionals attributed the drop to the vagueness of a Wednesday announcement by Michael S. Buchsbaum, chairman of the company, that he was ''giving consideration'' to forming a group to buy Holly for ''approximately'' $65 a share.

headline: Potlatch Layoffs
abstract: The Potlatch Corporation, a major producer of lumber and paper products, said it would shut three Idaho plants and lay off 600 workers because of a continuing severe downturn in the housing market. The latest cutback, effective next Monday, raises to nearly 1,200 the number of Potlatch employees on indefinite layoff in the state, the company said. Its total payroll in Idaho is normally about 5,000, Potlatch said.

headline: Dr Pepper Net Rises by 9.1%
abstract: The Dr Pepper Company, the soft-drink maker, said today that it earned $7.2 million, or 35 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1981, 9.1 percent more than the $6.6 million, or 33 cents a share, in the comparable period in 1980.

headline: El Paso Pipeline
abstract: The El Paso Natural Gas Company, a unit of the El Paso Company, said it had filed for an additional 250 million cubic feet of pipeline capacity from the Anardarko and Arkoma Basins in Oklahoma.

headline: BRANDT WARNS FRENCH POLITICIANS
abstract: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt was bitterly critical today of the French response to the Bonn Government's attitude toward the Polish crackdown.   At a news conference this morning, Mr. Brandt, chairman of the Social Democratic Party, accused French politicians of using the situation in Poland as a ''big stick'' to assail their domestic political opponents.

headline: McCall's Ad Director Takes Gannett Position
abstract: Joseph R. Welty, 52-year-old vice president and advertising director of McCall's magazine, is leaving to become vice presidentadvertising of USA Today, Gannett's proposed national newspaper.

headline: Portuguese on Greek Visit
abstract: The Portuguese Prime Minister, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, arrived today for a two-day official visit and talks with Greek leaders on Portugal's bid to join the European Economic Community. Greece became the tenth member of the Common Market in January 1981.

headline: Cannon Holders Accept Share Offer
abstract: The major stockholders in the Cannon Mills Company, who own 27 percent of the 9.4 million shares outstanding, said they had agreed to sell their stock to the Pacific Holding Company, which is owned by David Murdock, the Los Angeles financier.   The shareholders, apparently responding to a revised offer made late Wednesday by Mr. Murdock, are the trust fund set up under the will of Charles A. Cannon, the Cannon Foundation and the Cannon Charitable Trust.

headline: BASIC SHIFTS IN CONSUMPTION CITED
abstract: The energy crisis, the source of so much personal discomfort and national anxiety during the 1970's, has eased materially. Almost every day brings new announcements of price reductions for gasoline as world oil prices slide. And supplies - barring an upheaval in the Middle East - appear increasingly available.   ''I'm not going to say the energy crisis is over,'' says James B.  Edwards, the Secretary of Energy, ''but we are certainly heading in the right direction. Our dependence on oil imports is at the lowest level in 10 years.''   The situation is such that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to approve at a meeting in Vienna on March 19 production cuts of a million barrels a day or more, the equivalent of daily output in Texas.

headline: G.E. OFFERS DATA LINK TO IMPROVE AUTOMATION
abstract: The General Electric Company yesterday introduced a data transfer network intended to allow communication between computers and automated factory equipment.   If the system performs as G.E. expects and is widely adopted, it would represent a major development in the drive to improve manufacturing productivity through automation.   Sharing information through such a network should increase the productivity of automated equipment. For instance, it would become possible to use data developed when a computer designs a new part to quickly program the machines that will make the part.

headline: Business Forum; WHY THE MICROBE MAKERS GOT STUNG
abstract: JUST a year or so ago, there were skeptics who said that all you n eeded to start a biotechnology company was a venture capitalist, a m icrobiologist and a mouse. But that didn't stop investors from b idding up stock prices almost threefold and providing the capital n eeded to expand the emerging biotechnology industry by an order of m agnitude.  In 1981, the five leading biotechnology companies - Genentech, Cetus, Bethesda Research Labs, Genex and Biogen - enjoyed aggregate revenues of almost $100 million, reflecting an annual growth rate of well over 150 percent since 1976.  But today, Wall Street's enthusiasm has given way to serious reappraisals, and stock prices of the genetic engineering companies have tumbled. Over the past year, Genentech fell from a high of almost $90 a share to $30.25, while Cetus has dropped to $10.25 from nearly $30.

headline: SCOTT PAPER, HAMMERMILL UP
abstract: Two major Pennsylvania-based paper companies - the Scott Paper Company of Philadelphia and the Hammermill Paper Company of Erie - reported higher sales and earnings in the last quarter of 1981 and for the year compared with 1980 results. Scott Paper   For the final quarter of last year, Scott Paper reported a 39.8 percent increase in net income, to $48.8 million, or $1.16 a share, compared with $34.9 million, or 89 cents a share, on fewer shares in the 1980 period. Sales for the quarter rose to $598.3 million, or 14.3 percent ahead of the $523.6 million in the 1980 period.

headline: ALLRIGHT AUTO PARKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HONEYWELL PROFIT DOWN 26.9%
abstract: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter, depressed by a loss at a French subsidiary, fell 26.9 percent from the year before while revenues increased 9 percent.   Honeywell, a major producer of information-processing systems and control systems for environmental, industrial and aerospace applications, said that net income in the latest three months dropped to $103.2 million, or $4.49 a share, from $141.2 million, or $6.28 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues increased to $1.57 billion from $1.44 billion in the preceding year.

headline: Big Rise Seen In '81 Cotton
abstract: The 1981 cotton crop is expected to exceed 15.7 million bales, 41 percent larger than the drought-reduced 1980 harvest, the Agriculture Department said today.   The latest estimate - based on surveys made around the first of the year - is up 1 percent, or about 164,000 bales, from indications in December, officials said.

headline: DILLINGHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: CENTRAL NATIONAL BANK (CHICAGO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: Iran Cuts Oil Price for Second Time
abstract: Iran told buyers today that it had cut its crude oil prices by a dollar a barrel for the second time this month as a world glut continues to alarm the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, OPEC, industry sources said.   Iran, struggling to increase war-restricted exports in a buyers' market, said it would sell its light crude at $32.20 a barrel compared with $34 for similar-quality Saudi light, the OPEC benchmark crude.   Iran cut a dollar from its price on Feb. 5 but failed to attract customers.  Market analysts say there is a risk that unilateral price cuts among the 13 OPEC members will undermine the group's whole pricing structure, already put under severe strain by a plunging spot, noncontract market.

headline: Around the World
abstract: An Algerian diplomat was found slain today after he was reportedly abducted last night from his home here.

headline: Reagan Is Challenged By Maryknoll Leaders
abstract: Leaders of the Maryknoll missionary orders have challenged President Reagan's decision to certify that the human rights situation in El Salvador has improved. In a statement issued Tuesday, the Rev. James Noonan, superior ge neral of the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers, and Sister Regina Mc Evoy, vice president of the Maryknoll Sisters, said increased mi litary aid to El Salvador ''will serve only to further the violencedo ne by the security forces of El Salvador against their own pe ople.''

headline: High Salvador Officer Slain in Rebel Ambush
abstract: The Defense Ministry has announced that a high-ranking army officer was slain in a guerrilla ambush Thursday near San Felipe, 50 miles east of the capital.   The officer was identified as Lieut. Col. Mario Azenon Palma.

headline: HAMILTON INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: An Air Fare Newsletter To Help Keep Score
abstract: Louis Van Leeuwen and Marshall Barrett, who had worked together at Van Leeuwen & Partners before it went under, have been inspired by the airline fares war and the stadium sales message, ''You can't tell the players without a scorecard,'' to create a scorecard for fare discounts.   It is, indeed, called the Airfare Discount Bulletin, and is available from their office at 733 Summer Street, Stamford, Conn.  06901, for $20 a year.

headline: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.E. Plans Layoffs In Kentucky Plant
abstract: The General Electric Company said that it would lay off up to 1,700 production workers at its Appliance Park manufacturing complex here on Feb. 8.

headline: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kuwait's Scottish Stake
abstract: The Bank of Scotland said today that the Kuwaiti Government now holds 9 percent of its stock, following the recent purchase of 35,000 shares. Barclays Bank, the largest shareholder, owns 34.8 percent.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American International Group Inc. has named James T. Howe to the newly created position of vice president-bank relations, and Frank Filipps as treasurer.   * Colgate-Palmolive Co. has appointed Robert J. Haig executive vice president and chief operating officer of its Princess House Inc. in North Dighton, Mass.   * CPT Corp., Minneapolis, announced that Dean F. Scheff, chairman and chief executive officer, was assuming the additional responsibilities of chief operating officer following the resignation of G.R. Holland as president and chief operating officer.

headline: Market Place; Mutual Funds And I.R.A.'s
abstract: TAXPAYERS picking among alternatives as they decide how to capitalize on the expanded Individual Retirement Accounts are in some cases turning to mutual funds that ignore tax considerations as irrelevant.   Basically the new I.R.A. rules allow up to $2,000 in sheltered income for an employed individual. Workers already covered by employer pension plans are now also allowed t o have I.R.A.'s   Banks and mutual fund organizations and private money managers are all vying for a share of the new I.R.A. market, estimated to have a $50 billion potential.   In the early years of I.R.A.'s, individuals used savings accounts for the most part, but lately many have turned to money market funds. Others are seeking the potential of common stocks purchased through mutual funds.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview given by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to The New York Times on Friday:   CHINA Q. Despite the decisions on not selling advanced jets to Taiwan, the Chinese still seem to be hammering away on the question of Taiwan and infringements on their sovereignty. How do you see Chinese-American relations developing? Are they deteriorating as the Chinese press seems to make out?   A. I think our first principle is to recognize we highly value good relations with China. That is our policy, and I think also you have to make the point that a great deal has been achieved over the decades since the Shanghai communique, in which I myself was intimately involved, and that we are determined to do all we can to preserve these achievements.

headline: PEAVEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Rich and Poor Nations Are Urged to Negotiate
abstract: The Brandt Commission called today for immediate global negotiations between rich and poor nations on ways to rescue the poorest countries from the effects of the worldwide recession.   The commission, an independent panel of 15 world statesmen and economists headed by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, said in a statement that negotiations under United Nations auspices ''will need very positive initiatives and political will to overcome inertia and obstacles.''

headline: Retrenchment At Datapoint
abstract: The Datapoint Corporation, the minicomputer company, said it was freezing wages for its 9,000 employees, eliminating 230 jobs by closing a Waco, Tex., manufacturing plant and scaling back operations at a California development center.   Harold E. O'Kelley, chief executive, blamed sluggish sales and other ''adverse economic conditions'' affecting the electronics and technology industries.

headline: TIMES OF LONDON GETS BACKERS
abstract: A group of British investors promised today to ''insure the survival'' of The Times of London as an independent newspaper, but did not extend the offer to the daily's sister publication, The Sunday Times.   ''Were The Times to collapse next week, we would step straight in,'' said David Dimbleby, a broadcaster and publisher of neighborhood weeklies.

headline: Eagleburger Wins Approval
abstract: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved President Reagan's choice of Lawrence S. Eagleburger to be Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. Mr.  Eagleburger, a career Foreign Service officer, has most recently served as Assistant Secretary for European Affairs. In his new post, he will be the No. 3 official in the State Department. He succeeds Walter J. Stoessel Jr.

headline: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.B.M. CASE CHALLENGER CITES POLICY CONCERNS
abstract: Philip N. Stern, 55, whose ''friend of the court'' motion to challenge the dismissal of the antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation was granted last Friday, thinks that his involvement in the matter goes right along with his other interests on public policy issues.   ''A significant interest of mine over the 30 years of my adult career is the vigor and integrity of antitrust enforcement,'' said Mr. Stern, a philanthropist and heir to a Sears, Roebuck & Company fortune, from his Washington, D.C., office. ''This is obviously one of the leading antitrust cases and a precise continuation of the interest I've had in my professional and philanthropic career.''

headline: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONTINENTAL AND ALLIED TO BUY SUPRON
abstract: Moving further into the oil and gas business, the Allied Corporation and the Continental Group announced yesterday that they had agreed to buy the Supron Energy Corporation of Dallas on a 50-50 ba sis for $35 a share, or $714 million in cas h.   In response to a question about the price, an Allied spokesman, Christina Pagano, said that the announced price represented only the 20.4 million shares in public hands.   Donald J. Donahue, vice chairman of Continental, said in a telephone interview that executive stock options would also be purchased, lifting the price to over $775 million. Will Assume Debts   He said that the two companies would also assume Supron debts of $50 million to $55 million, thus making the overall price some $825 million.   The Allied spokesman later said that the $825 million figure was ''O.K .'' More than h alf of the funds to pay for the company would come directly from Supron's own oil and gas production, Mr. Donahue said.  In a statem ent announcing the terms, Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman of A llied, and S. Bruce Smart Jr., chairman of Continental, said that an Allied subsidiary would first buy Supron and then transfer Supr on's oil and gas properties to an Allied-Continental partnership.

headline: Japan Car Exports
abstract: Japan's vehicle exports in the fiscal year 1982, which begins in April, will not rise from the current year's figure, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. It said it could not give any definite export forecast because the export environment in the United States and West Europe, its major markets, was uncertain. Japan exported about 2.3 million cars to the United States in the 1981 calendar year.

headline: HISTORIC A.T.&T. SETTLEMENT AS SEEN BY THE PARTICIPANTS
abstract: Seventeen directors assembled in the dark, wood-paneled board room of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Dec. 16. They listened quietly as Charles L. Brown, the chairman, presented a report that would lead to the dismemberment of the largest company in the world and to reshaping of the telecommunications industry.   Talks with the Justice Department about a possible settlement of its seven-year-old antitrust lawsuit against A.T.& T. were ready for a critical stage, Mr. Brown said. The chairman described what he felt should be the company's objective: to divest itself of the 22 Bell System operating companies, which provide most of the nation's local telephone service, in return for a free hand at competing in data processing, computer communications, equipment sales and other lucrative fields, previously prohibited.

headline: BONN OFFICIAL URGES NATO TALKS TO SORT OUT DIFFERENCES
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, reflecting his Government's concern about a seeming deterioration in relations with the United States, proposed today that the foreign ministers of the Atlantic alliance meet periodically for informal talks about their political differences.   The idea, he said after a meeting with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., is modeled on the practice being followed by the foreign ministers of the 10-nation European Economic Community, who meet in seclusion twice a year.   ''This makes for better understanding,'' Mr. Genscher said.  A State Department spokesman later said that ''the United States shares Foreign Minister Genscher's interest in improving consultation within NATO.'' He said the proposal would be given ''careful consideration.''

headline: DISCLOSURE POLICY IS STUDIED
abstract: A House committee raised questions today about the adequacy of Securities and Exchange Commission disclosure rules.  Cited as a case in point was the S.E.C.'s handling of an investigation into disclosures by th e Mobil O il Corporation of the relationship of William P. Tavoulareas, Mobil 's president, to a Mobilaffiliate that employed his son.   At the hearing, some members of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations and witnesses from the S.E.C. generally agreed that the disclosure rules needed to be altered and that the Mobil case illustrated some of the reasons.   The issue confronting the S.E.C. in the Mobil case was the adequacy of the company's disclosure of the father-son relationship, not any questions about the propriety of the relationship itself.

headline: POPE CALLS FOR IMPROVED TIES WITH JEWS
abstract: Pope John Paul II urged Christians today to overcome the ''misunderstandings, errors and even offenses'' that Christians of the past have inflicted on Jews.   ''The terrible persecutions suffered by the Jews in various periods of history have finally opened many eyes and wrought up many hearts,'' the Pope said. ''Christians are on the right path, that of justice and fraternity, in trying, with respect and perseverance, to join with their Semitic brothers around the common heritage, so rich for all.''   The Pope was addressing a group of about 40 churchmen and lay leaders who met here for three days in the first gathering of a commission that was formed in 1974. A body under the jurisdiction of the Vatican Secretariat for Christian Unity, its task is to study the improvement of religious relations between Roman Catholics and Jews.

headline: Phibro Names President Of Phillip, a Subsidiary
abstract: The Phibro Corporation, the nation's 14th-largest nonfinancial company last year with revenues of $25.1 billion, has simplified its organization chart by converting its Phillip Brothers unit from a division to a subsidiary. And At the same time, it named one of its key executives, Thomas D. O'Malley, 40, as president of the new subsidiary, an international trading organization for some 150 commodities.

headline: KODAK SHOWS NEW DISK CAMERAS
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced a line of cameras that use a film disk instead of conventional roll film. The new products are intended to secure the company's position as the dominant force in amateur photography for the rest of the decade.   Foreshadowed in patent drawings and research disclosures during the past few years, the introduction included no surprises but was still impressive, according to industry analysts.   The disk cameras are ''the biggest innovation in amateur photography since the cartridge-loading Instamatic was introduced 19 years ago,'' Walter Fallon, the company's chairman, unabashedly told reporters gathered at the Plaza Hotel yesterday. The meeting was one of eight news conferences the company held around the world.

headline: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pakistani Regime Seizes 480 Suspected Foes
abstract: The authorities have arrested about 480 suspected members of an organization that wants to overthrow the military Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, Interior Minister Mahmoud Abdullah Haroon said today.

headline: U.S. Reaction
abstract: A dministration offici als said today that theyhad not yet seen the details of the policy ch anges announced in Tokyoand would issue a formal reaction when the fi nal package was conveyedto foreign governments.

headline: FURTHER DIP IN DOLLAR IS FORECAST
abstract: The dollar is likely to continue its recent slow decline against other major currencies during 1982, but will still remain high by historic standards, bankers and economists agree.   They also believe that 1982 may lay the foundations for a major decline in the dollar's value if, as some forecasters expect, the United States begins to record large international payments deficits while West Germany and Japan resume posting their traditional surplusses.   Whether this drop develops depends on several unknowns, including the depth of the economic slowdown in the United States, events in Poland and whether American interest rates turn sharply higher again as the economy recovers.   Between October 1980 and last August, the American dollar reversed almost 10 years of steady decline in value against other major currencies, rising some 30 percent against the German mark and by 13 percent against the Japanese yen, according to calculations by the Morgan Guaranty Trust.

headline: Around the World; Dublin Car Bomb Injures Irish Forensic Expert
abstract: Dr. James Donovan, Ireland's top police scientist and a witness against I.R.A. guerrillas, was seriously injured today when a booby-trap bomb exploded in his car, the police said.

headline: NATIONWIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; Turning Nuclear Waste Into a Cable for Burial
abstract: A nuclear waste disposal system invented by H. Richard Leuchtag, a research physicist in Galveston, Tex., includes combining the waste with glass components, then melting it and forming it into a cable.

headline: Westinghouse Venture
abstract: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it would form a 50-50 joint venture in Japan with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in June 1982 to produce core parts of gas circuit breakers for use in power plants.
