abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BELL PARES BORROWING FOR 1982
abstract: Charles L. Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that the Bell System would be able to reduce its planned external financing needs by at least $500 million during 1982 because of the weakening economy and the resulting drop in demand for new telecommunications construction.   Speaking to an overflow gathering of the New York Society of Security Analysts, Mr. Brown also announced that for the first time in A.T.& T.'s history, it would turn to the Eurobond market to raise$400 million in seven-year debt securities to meet part of its total capital requirements for the coming year.   In discussing the upcoming divestiture of A.T.& T.'s 22 operating subsidiaries, as a result of the settlement with the Justice Department of its antitrust suit, Mr. Brown reiterated the company's commitment to spinning off the local telephone companies in sound financial condition.   He said A.T.& T. plans to provide funding so that the operating companies ''will be able to avoid new issues of long-term debt between now and their divestiture.'' Moreover, A.T.& T. will assume existing debt obligations of local operating companies, if necessary, to preserve their credit worthiness, he said.

headline: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * C. Dayton Titsworth joins Korda Rand Levine as executive vice president-management and Jack Robson as senior vice president, creative director.

headline: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Northwest Sets Stock Purchase
abstract: Northwest Industries said that its directors have authorized a cash tender offer to buy back five million of its common shares at $75 a share, or a total of $375 million. The company's stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 73 3/8, up 1 1/2 points.

headline: WEINBERGER VOWS SUPPORT FOR SEOUL
abstract: After touring a segment of South Korea's front line today, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger returned to Seoul and renewed the Reagan Administration's commitment to South Korean security.   Mr. Weinberger, on the second stop of a trip through Japan, South Korea and the Philippines, flew by helicopter to the heavily fortified demilitarized zone that divides this peninsula. He had lunch with G.I.'s of the Second Infantry Division and inspected one of their outposts facing North Korea.

headline: DIPLOMATS SAY HAVANA WANTS WIDE U.S. TALKS
abstract: Cuba is ready to discuss all aspects of the situation in the Caribbean basin with the Reagan Administration, diplomatic sources said today, but it will not withdraw support for Salvadoran rebels as a condition for such negotiations.   The sources said that was the essence of the message delivered last weekend by President Fidel Castro through Mexico's Foreign Minister, Jorge Castaneda de la Rosa, to a special State Department envoy, Gen. Vernon A. Walters, who had held a secret four-hour meeting with the Cuban leader early this month in Havana.   The sources added that Mr. Castro was pleased by his meeting with General Walters, who is a former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, and was hopeful that it would be followed by further negotiations with the Reagan Administration. Cuba Prefers Wide Talks   ''The Cubans say that no arms have gone from Cuba to El Salvador for the past 14 months, but they can't assume an obligation to stop aiding the guerrillas if this problem is seen in isolation,'' a knowledgeable Western diplomat said. ''They argue that the situation would be different if the United States stopped arming the Salvadoran junta or peace talks began in El Salvador.''

headline: SCM Assails Import Prices
abstract: Smith-Corona, the only maker of portable electric typewriters in the United States, today asked the Government for help against Japanese competitors' pricing practices.   Representative Gary A. Lee, Republican of upstate New York, said he and officials of the SCM Corporation, which owns Smith-Corona, had asked Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige to enforce the laws against dumping - the sale of imports in the United States for less than in the country where they were made.

headline: MOVIE SYSTEMS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Hotpoint To Symon, Thomas
abstract: SYMON, THOMAS & HILLIARD has been assigned General Electric's Hotpoint appliance account, which will be especially rewarding if and when Hotpoint decides to do some consumer advertising.   Hotpoint, which is getting only trade advertising support, has something in common with James W. Thomas, president and Columbia, S.C., native, and Anthony T. Hilliard, executive vice president and a one-time London lad. All were at Compton Advertising before coming to Symon, Thomas.

headline: AN INFORMER HELPED F.B.I.'S AGENTS TRAP SOVIET ARMY ATTACHE
abstract: The arrest of a senior Soviet military attache last weekend came after the Federal Bureau of Investigation arranged for an informer to pass to him what the Russian was led to believe was a sensitive document, a high-ranking Government official said today.   The official said F.B.I. agents were on the scene when the informer handed the document to the diplomat in a shopping center in suburban Washington.   The attache, Maj. Gen. Vasily I. Chitov, was detained by bureau agents and later declared persona non grata and expelled.  Although General Chitov's arrest and expulsion became known Thursday, it was not until today that it was disclosed that the F.B.I. used an informer to trap the Soviet diplomat.

headline: Venezuela Cuts Price Of Some Oil
abstract: Venezuela lowered the prices of its heavier grades of crude oil by $2.50 a barrel yesterday, according to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, putting the prices of those oils at $18.90 to $26.50 a barrel.   The move matches a $2.50 reduction by Mexico last month on similar grades of oil and seemed to be another indication of depressed prices among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: KAISER STEEL CUTS ITS EMPLOYEE COSTS
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, which announced last week that it lost $513.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, said today that it had cut executive salaries by 10 percent and instituted a wage freeze for all salaried workers.   It also will change medical and vacation benefits for all salaried employees throughout the company.

headline: Despite Woes, JWT Retains Buy Signal
abstract: The headline in the Feb. 9 Research Digest of the Dean Witter Reynolds brokerage, reads, ''JWT Group (JWT/NYSE) Advertising Campaign for New Kodak Camera Should Keep Bright Earnings Picture.''   In what follows, Fred Anschel, a securities analyst, pictures the J. Walter Thompson parent's stock as undervalued and projects ''1982 earnings of about $4.50 per share.''

headline: THE GREAT REPRESSION
abstract: HOW to describe the underlying condition of the American economy? Short-term, it is obviously in a recession that started last fall; but this is the second recession since 1980, the third since 1975, and many economists believe that, even if recovery begins in the second half of this year, a fourth recession is just around the corner. It's been a long sequence of recessions and weak, aborted expansions.   Is this, then, a depression we are in? Looking backward, the term seems too strong. The economy has been stagnating, not collapsing. If the roof were to fall in later this year, or next, it could become a depression, but the odds are still against it.   Call it repression - a chronic state of underemployment and industrial slack that has dogged the economy for the greater part of the past decade, a condition brought on by repressive actions of governments in the industrial world to cope with inflation, energy shortages and currency disorders.

headline: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China to Issue New Bonds
abstract: China will issue $2.4 billion in Treasury bonds this year to raise funds for economic development and encourage saving, the official New China News Agency reported today.   Despite political and economic conditions, the agency said, ''the financial situation is still difficult and insufficient funds for China's economic construction remains a problem.''

headline: Webb Account Moves To Lewis & Gilman
abstract: O.K. Monopoly fans, the powers that be in the Del Webb Claridge Hotel and Hi-Ho Casino, at the corner of Boardwalk and Indiana Avenue in Atlantic City, have opted to move its advertising account from Fifer Advertising in Newtown Square, Pa., to Lewis & Gilman in Philadelphia.   The assignment is for advertising, public relations, marketing, market research and sales promotion, everything.

headline: FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEXICO'S MIDDLE CLASS TURNS TO DISCO AND BURGERS
abstract: Long before its official opening this month, crowds began flocking from all over this sprawling, overcrowded metropolis to a new amusement park on the wooded outskirts of Mexico City to enjoy a form of leisure until now available only north of the border.   Costing $30 million and spread over 70 acres, Adventure Kingdom is the first such park to be built in Latin America, this time around the geographical theme of six international villages, though peppered with the usual restaurants, shops and mechanical games.   Its instant popularity was no surprise. Every year, tens of thousands of Mexicans travel to the United States for the exclusive purpose of visiting Disneyland in Los Angeles or Disneyworld in Orlando, Fla. The demand for this kind of entertainment was just waiting to be tapped.

headline: A UTILITY'S PROBLEM IN SELLING INSURANCE
abstract: Along with the Christmas mail this past season, 200,000 Maryland residents received a sales brochure for small amounts of life insurance - known in the trade as burial insurance, to cover one's final expenses.   The promotion was unusual because it was sponsored by a subsidiary of the Washington Gas Light Company, a regulated utility serving Maryland and Washington.   In recent years, there has been a trend among such investor-owned utilities to diversify, but they have generally restricted expansions to energy-related activities.   In a recent survey of its 200 member utilities, the Edison Electric Institute found that 82 companies had recently started 286 nonut ility business ventures. Most investment s were in such areas as fuel exploration, real estate and energy cons ervation, but some utilities are employing their assets more dir ectly.

headline: MESTA MACHINE NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Putnam B. McDowell, 57, has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Mesta Machine Company. As chairman, he succeeds John D. Iversen, 69, who retired.

headline: ISRAEL AGAIN SHUTS WEST BANK SCHOOL
abstract: The leading Palestinian university in the Israeli-occupied West Bank was ordered closed today for two months by the Israeli military government, an army spokesman announced today.   The announcement followed two days of disturbances outside the university of Bir Zeit, north of the town of Ramallah, and the arrest of 50 demonstrating students and faculty members.   The army spokesman said stones had been thrown at army vehicles during the protest. No injuries were reported.  It was the second time in four months that the university had been closed by Israel. Classes resumed Jan. 4 after a two-month closure ordered by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon in November in the wake of student protests against the installment of a civilian administrator to handle education and other matters previously handled by the army.

headline: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: P.L.O. CLAIMS ROLE, THEN ISSUES DENIAL
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization today first claimed, then denied, responsibility for a grenade attack that killed an Israeli soldier.   The initial claim promptly raised fears here that Israel might carry out its threat to invade Lebanon in retaliation for any guerrilla raid.   The claim was made in the afternoon by the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, one of the more radical of the eight guerrilla organizations under the P.L.O. and was followed by a series of contradictory announcements.

headline: Hewlett Drops Computer Price
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced that it had reduced prices up to 21 percent on its personal office computer and introduced a new model capable of handling more information at a faster rate than its previous models.   The company said that it had cut the price on the HP 125 personal office computer model 10 by 21 percent, and on model 20 by 19 percent.

headline: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BISHOP CALLS POLES 'SICK' WITH ANGER
abstract: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic primate of Poland, said today that Poland was ''sick'' and that its people were ''overcome by anger'' at events in their country.   To an emotional congregation in the Church of St. Stanislaus in downtown Rome that filled every available space inside and in the courtyard, the head of the Polish hierarchy said:   ''We are confident that, with God's help, we will be able to explain to ourselves the reasons for our anger, in a dialogue, and not by force. Poland must not become an arena of bloody confrontation. No one must be allowed to manipulate our wrath, because the people want to shed this illness of rage all by itself, and emerge all in one, and healed.''

headline: SALVADOR'S REBELS BID REAGAN ACCEPT A NEGOTIATED SOLUTION
abstract: In an open letter to President Reagan, the five commanders of El Salvador's guerrilla movement have called on the United States to change its policy and accept a negotiated solution to the civil war.   The letter, which was made available here, was delivered to the White House today. In it, the guerrillas suggested talks between the Salvadoran junta, which has United States support, and the guerrillaled opposition ''without preconditions by any of the parties to the conflict.''

headline: AIRLINE DEREGULATION LOSERS
abstract: Anne Thi@beault is not one of the millions of Americans who benefited from Federal deregulation of the airline industry. Instead, Mrs. Thibeault said, she is one of deregulation's victims - and deserves restitution.   For nearly a decade, Mrs. Thibeault worked as a reservations clerk at Air New England, a once-bustling commuter airline based in Boston. In October of last year, Air New England shut down, blaming deregulation for its troubles. Mrs. Thibeault and 400 others were thrown out of work.

headline: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: British Railways Shut For 4th Day in a Week
abstract: Britain's state-run railways were shut down today for the fourth day in just over a week as 20,000 engineers began a 48-hour strike for a pay raise that they say they were promised.   But management says the 3 percent increase that the engineers had expected on Jan. 1 was linked to a commitment to improve productivity, in particular by accepting flexible work schedules.

headline: BankAmerica Note Offering
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $500 million of zero-coupon notes.   The notes are designed primarily for purchase by Individual Retirement Accounts, Keogh plans, Individual Retirement Account rollovers, pension plans and certain other investors not subject to Federal income taxes, it said.

headline: Canada Unit to Get 58% Stake in Savin
abstract: The Canada Development Corporation will acquire a 58 percent stake in the Savin Corporation, a marketer and manufacturer of copiers, under an agreement signed yesterday by directors of both companies, Savin said.   Under the proposal, Toronto-based Canada Development will buy 8.3 million shares of newly issued and treasury Savin common stock for $40 million cash, plus a noninterest-bearing note for $35 million.

headline: SOVIET REPRISALS ON AFGHANS CALLED FIERCE
abstract: Armed resistance to the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan is continuing, but on a smaller scale than that reported by the insurgents, and Soviet forces appear to be responding with a much heavier hand, according to United States and British analysts.   As the Soviet occupation enters its 27th month, Moscow appears to be combining the tougher retaliatory policy with an extension of its economic ties with the Government of President Babrak Karmal.   Leaders of insurgent organizations in Pakistan, the land to which two and a half million Afghan refugees have fled since the Soviet Union intervened in late December 1979, continue to report gains against the Soviet forces, which are now estimated to number 90,000.  But the Soviet retaliations have been fierce.

headline: Bid for Cannon Has 72% Reply
abstract: David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles financier who controls the Pacific Holding Corporation, said that his offer of $44 a share for the stock of Cannon Mills Inc. had attracted 72 percent of the textile manufacturer's shares.   Mr. Murdock, who owned 5.1 percent of the stock before the offer, said that 6.75 million shares had been tendered as of 5 P.M.  Wednesday.

headline: NEW ORDERS UP BY 0.9% IN FEBRUARY
abstract: Orders for new manufactured goods rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, to a seasonally adjusted $158.59 billion, the first gain since November, the Commerce Department reported today.   However, the report noted that nearly all of the growth was in orders for military hardware.  Robert Ortner, the department's chief economist, said that ''the economy still looks weak.'' The report also said that total shipments of manufactured goods increased in February - for the first time since last June. The shipment gain was 1.7 percent, to an adjusted $159.7 billion.

headline: Other Business; A CHICKEN IN EVERY WOK
abstract: According to Leslie Watt, president of the Watt Publishing Company in Mount Morris, Ill., the great frontier for special interest magazines is China. So the company has made a foray into the Far East with a magazine that serves a $10 billion-a-year market in this country and an expanding market abroad. The market is poultry, and the magazine is Poultry International.

headline: Other Business; TRADE: IT'S THE SAME OLD TUNE...
abstract: Over the years, as the United States and Japan have talked about Tokyo's burgeoning trade surplus, their comments have taken on a pattern as predictable as that of the ritual tea ceremony.   Back in August of 1977, the United States Ambassador to Tokyo, Mike Mansfield, warned Japan that the $5 billion American trade deficit with Japan the previous year was a ''disturbing figure'' and ''provides much ammunition to the advocates of protectionism in the United States.''   In 1978, this message came from James R. Jones, Democrat of Oklahoma: ''The time for negotiations has long passed...unless the trade imbalance is substantially reversed in the next several months, there will be protective measures added to a number of legislative items in 1979.''

headline: WOODSTREAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Article 201069 -- No Title
abstract: An executive of the Ford Motor Company said today that the company would post a loss ''slightly in excess of $1 billion'' when it officially reported its results for 1981 in a few days.   Peter J. Pestillo, the company's vice president for labor relations, made the disclosure in response to an inquiry from the United Automobile Workers union. Ford is engaged in talks with the union to exchange assurances of greater job security for wage and benefit concessions.

headline: KENYA'S ASIANS WORRIED OVER ATTACK BY PRESIDENT
abstract: Many of Kenya's 100,000 Asian residents are expressing concern and bewilderment over the recent charge by President Daniel arap Moi that some traders and businessmen among them are ruining the nation's economy through corrupt practices.   Ever since the President made the charge and threatened to deport those found guilty of hoarding or smuggling currency, some Government officials have been privately trying to assure Kenya's Asians, who are mainly of Indian and Pakistani background, that they will not encounter discrimination.   But leading Asians here say the President's statements, made in a speech Feb. 6 to a group of municipal officials, added to Asian feelings of insecurity that were growing before he spoke. Some say one result could be a quickening of Asian emigration and of the flight of Asian capital.

headline: THE I.M.F.'S IMBROGLIO IN AFRICA
abstract: NAIROBI, Kenya IN three African countries in less than a year, there have been strikes, or demonstrations, or riots, all pointing to an unlikely villain: the International Monetary Fund.   The fund, after all, is the major source of outside financing for an area that A.W. Clausen, president of the I.M.F.'s sister organization, the World Bank, has described as ''by far the poorest part of the world's economy.''   Opposition to the fund - and, by habits of thought in this area, to the United States, holder of the largest voting block in the fund - centers on charges of imperialism. More particularly, it comes in reaction to the increasing readiness among multilateral and bilateral aid donors to take African governments to task over their economic performance. It is a trend that seems reinforced by the Reagan Administration's stress on the ''conditionality'' of development assistance.

headline: FOR ROSSIGNOL, IT'S STILL UPHILL
abstract: NO one has to sport ''Think Snow'' bumper stickers in this Alpine community in southeastern France. This is the home of Rossignol skis, the world's biggest manufacturer of skis, and a large portion of the 20,000 people who live and work here think of little else but snow.  They think about it even more when there isn't any, which was pretty much the case in the last three years. What's more, the snow drought extended from the Alps to Vermont and the Rocky Mountains in the United States. Worldwide sales of skis decreased by 13 percent in the 1980-81 season, and the drop was centered in the United States and Canada.   Consequently, Rossignol is in trouble. Not terminal trouble, according to its president and founder, Laurent Boix Vives, but trouble enough to put the company in a serious bind for at least another year - even if this winter, at last, there's a surfeit of snow in some areas. ''It's snowing everywhere,'' Mr. Boix Vives said in an interview in his office here a few days ago. ''Obviously, we are very happy. Unfortunately it is not going to help us right away.''

headline: COMMODITY PRODUCERS' TOUGH LIFE
abstract: However wretched their economic lots were in 1981, the poorer countries that supply much of the world's exportable raw materials can expect even worse conditions this year. Most commodity prices that the third world receives today are only slightly above their 1976 dollar levels, but the value of the dollar has shrunk to 55 cents since then.   Even if the global economy recovers in 1982, the poorer nations cannot expect prices of their raw-material exports to rebound until the following year at the earliest. Meanwhile, the third world's foreign debts continue to soar.

headline: Former Reagan Aide Picked to Head SIPC
abstract: James G. Stearns, a former member of President Reagan's Cabinet when he was Governor of California, has been selected as chairman of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, the nonprofit organization that provides up to $500,000 in insurance for each stockholder's investment held at brokerage firms.   The White House said that it plans to nominate Mr. Stearns to the seven-member board of directors of the corporation, which Congress established in 1970 to protect investors from losses when stockbrokers go bankrupt. If the Senate confirms Mr. Stearns, the President will also designate him as chairman to succeed Hugh F.  Owens, 72, who is resigning after eight years in the post.

headline: No Headline
abstract: MUBARAK DISMISSES EGYPTIAN CABINET   CAIRO, Jan. 2 (By WILLIAM E. FARRELL, Special to the New York Times) - President Hosni Mubarak dismissed the Egyptian Cabinet today, named a new Prime Minister and ordered him to form a new government.   The new Prime Minister is Ahmed Fuad Mohieddin, a 55-year-old politican and radiologist who has been in Egyptian public life since the time of the late Gamal Abdel Nasser.   Until today's move by Mr. Mubarak, Mr. Mohieddin was First Deputy Prime Minister. The post of Prime Minister was held by Mr. Mubarak, who inherited it when he succeeded President Anwar el-Sadat after Mr. Sadat was assassinated as he watched a military parade on Oct. 6.

headline: French Aide in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France arrived in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, tonight at the start of a twice-postponed trip to discuss military cooperation, the official Saudi press agency said.

headline: TOP POLISH PRELATES MEET WITH POPE
abstract: Three leaders of Poland's Roman Catholic Church reported to Pope John Paul II today on their stalled effort to mediate between the Polish military rulers and the suspended independent trade union Solidarity.   The meeting at the Vatican was held soon after Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of Poland, and the two other churchmen arrived from Warsaw. It was their first meeting with the Pope since martial law was imposed in their homeland on Dec. 13 and Solidarity was suspended.

headline: CHROMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HAIG FEARS EXILES FROM LATIN AREAS MAY FLOOD THE U.S.
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told the nation's governors today that the United States might be flooded with refugees if radical trends in El Salvador and other countries were not stopped.   White House officials said Mr. Reagan's Caribbean speech to the Organization of American States was set for Wednesday and that the President was leaning toward accepting Mr. Haig's advice that he stiffen the address with stern warnings to Cuba. The officials say the speech is still being worked on, but that as of this morning, Mr. Reagan intends to assert that this country will do what is ''prudent and necessary'' to protect El Salvador and other states to prevent ''other Cubas'' from arising. Details of Reagan Speech   The major portion of the speech still deals with proposals to grant trade and investment concessions to the area to boost the economies of the countries in the region as well as with an emergency request to Congress for $300 million or $350 million for this fiscal year, the exact sum still not having been decided.

headline: Corning Glass Ratings
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday lowered its senior long-term debt rating of the Corning Glass Works to double A-minus from double A and assigned a double A-minus rating to the proposed $100 million, 7 percent debentures due 2007. The debt rating service said that the company, based in Corning, N.Y., ''has been and continues to be subject to cyclical influences.'' Standard & Poor's said the company's A-1 plus commercial paper rating was being maintained.

headline: ITALIAN TELLS HOW DOZIER WAS FREED
abstract: The head of the provincial government in Verona, which is conducting the inquiry into the abduction of Brig.  Gen. James L. Dozier, said Saturday that the police were not certain before the rescue that that the general was being detained in the apartment from which he was freed on Thursday.   The provincial leader, Peppino Gnisci, said in an interview at his office that the police had at best a 75 percent certainty that they would find the general and his captors when they burst into the apartment, their guns ready and protected by bulletproof jackets.   Mr. Gnisci declined to be specific about how the authorities had obtained the information that led them to the successful rescue but said that all the relevant indications had come from people arrested after General Dozier's kidnapping on suspicion of having links with the Red Brigades terrorist group.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: The White House withdrew the nomination of a longtime supporter of President Reagan, William R. Van Cleave, as chairman of the General Advisory Committee of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency today.

headline: ROBINSON'S NEW TARGET FOR HIS SHEARSON UNIT
abstract: Wall Street expected fireworks when James D. Robinson 3d, the quietly dedicated chairman of American Express, and Sanford I. Weill, the hard-driving chairman of Shearson/American Express, faced each other across the boardroom table.   But six months have gone by since the $900 million acquisition of Shearson Loeb Rhoades by American Express and, as far as anyone can tell, the only fireworks have been directed at the competition--chiefly Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

headline: 4 FEMALE GUERRILLAS FLEE IN ITALY AS COMRADES BOMB PRISON WALL
abstract: Four women suspected of b eing terrorists escaped from the Rovigo women's pr ison today after accomplices outside blasted a hole in the pri son wall, tossed them machine guns and kept guards at bay with auto matic fire, authorities said.   A passer-by was killed and six others wounded by the blast, which sent masonry flying 100 yards and blew out windows of nearby buildings. The police said three or four accomplices had been involved in the breakout.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski appears to be firmly in control of th e military council, the Government and the demoralized Communist Par ty, Western diplomats and knowledgeable Poles believe.   Although his style is less than dictatorial and he has not fashioned the image of an activist leader in the public consciousness, the 58-year-old general has achieved a position of power unparalleled in postwar Poland.   The only comparable figure over the last 36 years is Wladyslaw Gomulka, the party leader who rose to power as a reformer in 1956 and who was dismissed, an embittered conservative, after workers' riots in 1970. Mr. Gomulka, who is now terminally ill, was praised as ''a great son of the Polish nation, an ardent internationalist and a Communist'' in an editorial today in Trybuna Ludu, the main Communist Party newspaper. The occasion was the 40th anniversary of the founding of the Polish Workers' Party, the predecessor of today's Polish United Workers' (Communist) Party.

headline: INSTALLMENT DEBT FALLS $173 MILLION
abstract: Consumer installment debt fell $173 million in December, as Americans paid off more than they borrowed for the first time since July 1980, another recession period, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The big decline in buying on credit -including an expected new drop in auto loans - was further evidence that the current recession was worsening as 1981 ended. Earlier reports had shown sluggish sales, quickly falling production and rapidly rising unemployment during that month.

headline: OUTLOOK FOR THE REVITALIZATION OF HARLEM
abstract: As the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development prepared to award 12 of the many brownstones it owns in Harlem, Anthony B. Gleidman, the agency's commissioner, kept telling reporters that the lottery's most significant point was the ''message'' being sent to private financial institutions.   Noting that all of the 2,059 entrants in Tuesday's lottery had to have an annual income of $20,000, he declared: ''We've established the fact that there are thousands of middle-income families within and outside of Harlem who want to live and own property here. Now we can go to the banks, the insurance companies and the pension funds and say: 'Look at this. This means you can safely invest in housing in Harlem.' ''

headline: MONETARISM IN BRITAIN
abstract: LONDON IN the heady days just after her ascension in May 1979, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher proclaimed loudly and widely her faith in the notion that strict control of a single monetary statistic would go a long way toward producing less inflation and more economic growth.   Early this month, in a few sentences tucked into the middle of the 108-minute budget address by Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Conservative Thatcher Government in effect buried that ''monetarist'' strategy. Henceforth, Sir Geoffrey said, a variety of monetary statistics would be monitored within broad target bands.   Similarly, Mrs. Thatcher early on moved to ease the burden of income taxes to encourage savings and investment, a change consistent with what became known in the United States as supply- side economics. But she also raised taxes on consumption. Partly as a result of this, and the Government's monetary policy, the inflation rate jumped to nearly 23 percent and the practices of supply-side economics have receded.

headline: Five Agencies Seek Sears Apparel Account
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company has announced t he names of the five agencies that will be considered for its $30 million consolidated apparel adver tising account. They are Foote, Cone & Belding, which had one-third of the apparel business, as well as the automotive and recreation bu siness; the Leo Burnett Company, which has Sears's Allstate Insu rance; N.W. Ayer; Needham, Harper & Steers, and Tatham-Laird & Kudner.

headline: Business Conditions; DISTRESSED ALUMINUM
abstract: With demand from once-strong customers like automobile manufacturers and home builders still at depressed levels and the once-bouyant overseas markets drying up, these are difficult times for aluminum producers.   Although some analysts expect business to pick up in the second half, if current trends hold, 1982 could be the third consecutive year of declining production and shipments.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CANADIAN TAR SANDS: HOPE AND CHALLENGE
abstract: The thick muskeg, now frozen, rests on 50 feet of clay and rock in Northwestern Canada. Beneath that geologically mixed cover lies a vast mass of black sand with an untapped energy potential. Whether the potential will be realized may depend on the outcome of a meeting Wednesday in a distant board room.   Canada's newest Alsands project, a $13.1 billion effort to help bring this country closer to energy self-sufficiency, now appears seriously threatened by a series of economic, political and technical problems.

headline: KEMP SAYS FED FOSTERS JOBLESSNESS
abstract: Representative Jack Kemp today blamed the Federal Reserve Board's monetary policy for the nation's economic slowdown and high unemployment. The New York Republican said President Reagan should try to get the Fed to change its stance instead of asking Congress for higher taxes.   Mr. Kemp, an advocate of the supply-side economic theory, appeared on a television interview program, NBC's ''Meet the Press.'' He said that, at a meeting with the President Monday, he would argue against raising taxes. Some Administration officials are urging tax increases to cut budget deficits.

headline: Zimbabwe Finds Arms Cache
abstract: Security forces searching for illicit hoards of arms have found another cache of munitions in the province of Matabeleland, the police said today. A spokesman said the dump, with more than 36,000 rounds of small ammunition and 124 rockets, was hidden in a forest 100 miles north of Bulawayo.

headline: Owens-Illinois Drops
abstract: Owens-Illinois Inc., a major glass producer, sai d today that earnings for the fourth quarter of 1981 declined to $ 30.5 million, or $1.02 a share, from $37.9 million, or $1.28 a share , in the comparable period in 1980. Sales were also downfor the quart er, totaling $928.1 million, compared with $977.8 million.

headline: Air Deliverer Officer to Quit
abstract: Arthur C. Bass, vice chairman and former president of the Federal Express Corporation, will resign from the company's active management on May 31, the air freight company announced today.   Mr. Bass joined the company in 1972 and was president from 1975 to 1980 when he became vice chairman and head of the company's advance projects and research group.

headline: Renault Output to Rise
abstract: Renault, the French state-owned auto maker, plans to produce 2.5 million vehicles a year by 1985, compared with 1.81 million in 1981, its new chairman, Bernard Hanon, told a news conference Friday.

Douce, president and chief operating officer, said that the company was ''prepared to resist effectively any acquisition attempt that we judge to be contrary to the best interests of our shareholders, our employees and the general public.''

headline: CADILLAC FAIRVIEW SHIFT AN 'ORDERLY TRANSITION'
abstract: E. Leo Kolber, 53, who has long been associated with the Bronfman family, which owns 35 percent of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, has been promoted to chairman and chief executive officer from vice chairman.   He succeeds John H. Daniels, 54, who stepped down to vice chairman of North America's largest publicly owned real estate developer, with headquarters in Toronto, ''to insure an orderly transition.''   At the same time, the company said that it intends to withdraw from the land and housing business. ''The business doesn't meet what the company has determined as its present objectives,'' Cadillac Fairview said, ''and the company sees its future in the investment part - office buildings and shopping centers.''

headline: ALLIES DISCUSS MORE CURBS ON SALES TO SOVIET BLOC
abstract: The Reagan Administration began two days of talks with its NATO allies and Japan today on tightening curbs on the sale of strategically valuable goods to the Soviet Union and its Communist allies.   The talks, which could have a major impact on East-West trade, are taking place in secrecy at a meeting of the Coordinating Committee on Export Controls. The committee maintains a list of strategically sensitive items that the allies have agreed not to export to any Communist-controlled buyers. The committee brings the list up to date about every three years.

headline: INVENTORIES CUT 0.4% IN DECEMBER
abstract: American businesses reduced their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today. Government analysts saw the drop as a sign that companies were trying to fight their way out of the recession, but some private economists were more cautious in interpreting the data. The drop in inventories held by manufacture rs, retailers and othersnearly kept pace with a sales drop of six-ten ths of 1 percent in December, leaving the closely watched invento ry-to-sales ratio for the month at 1.49, the same as in November. T he ratio represents the number of months needed to liquidate inventor ies on hand at the prevailing sales pace.

headline: Soviet Jew Is Seized In Red Square Protest
abstract: An 18-year-old Soviet Jew was seized in Red Square today when he held up a sign demanding permission to migrate to Israel, witnesses said.   Friends of the protester identified him as Mikhail Tsivin of Leningrad.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * General Host Corp. said it had purchased 140,500 shares of its common stock, or 2.8 percent of the total outstanding, for $10 a share, or $1,405,000.   * MCI Communications Corp. said it had reached an agreement to provide interconnecting long-distance service to users of the Sugar Land telephone system in the Houston area.

headline: SUPREME COURT RETAINS SUIT ON ASBESTOS
abstract: In its latest action involving the flood of liability suits against manufacturers of asbestos products, the Supreme Court today kept a major category of those lawsuits alive by permitting them to remain in Federal court. Without comment, the Court turned down an appeal by the Johns-Manville Corporation and other manufacturers of asbestos products from a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond. That court allowed five former workers at the Newport News shipyards, who had been exposed to asbestos on the job as long as 42 years ago, to maintain their suit against the company in Federal court.   Had the court of appeals accepted the companies' argument that there was no basis for Federal jurisdiction and the case therefore belonged in state court, the workers' suit would almost certainly have been dismissed under the Virginia statute of limitations. Like many states, Virginia requires that lawsuits be filed within two years of exposure to a harmful substance.

headline: THE COMPANY THAT STOPPED DETROIT
abstract: IN every direction, as far as the eye can see, the unmistakable imprint of Japan's largest auto maker is evident in this city that fittingly bears the company name.   More than 35,000 of the Toyota Motor Company's 48,000 employees worldwide work here, 150 miles west of Tokyo. Rows and rows of lookalike houses that Toyota provides for its married workers at cutrate prices form a kind of corporate Levittown.   Company dormitories can house 20,000 bachelors and another 1,500 units are available for unmarried women workers. Then, too, there is the company stadium that seats 30,000, the company baseball fields, the company gymnasiums, the company swimming pools, company tennis courts, even company sumo rings.

headline: Stocks of Oil Slip in Japan
abstract: Japan, which imports almost all its crude oil, reduced its stocks of crude and petroleum products slightly last year because of a steady decline in domestic demand, the Ministry for International Trade and Industry said today.   The oil industry and the semiofficial Japan National Oil Corporation had 463.5 million barrels in storage at the end of 1981, down 1.2 percent from 468.9 million a year earlier, the ministry said.

headline: Users' Praise Of Permalens
abstract: According to John H. Williford, vice chairman of Cooper Laboratories, Palo Alto, Calif., one of the conditions for assigning the Permalens account to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners was the assurance that Jerry Della Femina himself would write the copy.   As it turned out, the agency chief executive noted, most of the copy came right off the tongues of contented - yea, ecstatic - users of the Permalens.

headline: Mexican Bus Strike Ends
abstract: Bus service in Mexico City returned to normal today after a wildcat strike by bus drivers caused weekend disruptions. Negotiators ratified an agreement to end the strike in the Department of Labor Sunday. The main points of contention remain to be resolved after a referendum to determine which union will represent the drivers.

headline: MARRIOTT GINO'S BID BACKED BY BOARDS
abstract: The boards of directors of the Marriott Corporation and Gino's Inc. have approved Marriott's $48.6 million cash tender offer for all of Gino's common stock, the companies announced.

headline: Market Place; Food Stocks: A Close Look
abstract: THERE'S a saying in Wall Street that new group leadership - the stocks to own for the next upswing - develops in down markets. If that holds true this time, it seems abundantly clear that energy, technology and precious-metal issues, which once served as inflationhedge favorites, are not destined to lead the ultimate parade to higher prices.   Food-processing stocks, on the other hand, have been performing uncommonly well, along with such sectors as soap and electric utilities. These groups represent the sort of defensive investments that people often make in times of extreme market conservatism. In fact, on the theory that the best offense is a good defense, some analysts expect food securities to continue to perform well in the next market cycle.

headline: Harper's Tries Program With Travel Agents
abstract: Those intellectual subscribers to Harper's magazine, especially those who like to travel, are going to feel so lucky when their favorite magazine includes a postage-paid card that will allow them to request additional information from any travel advertiser.

headline: U.S. Warns Nicaragua Over 'Alien Influences'
abstract: President Reagan told Nicaragua's new Ambassador to the United States today that the sacrifices of the Sandinist revolution must not result in a new dictatorship in Central America.   Mr. Reagan, in a letter accepting the credentials of Francisco Fiallos Navarro, warned Nicaragua against the ''consequences of inviting alien influences and philosophies in the hemisphere.''

headline: Purchasing Agents Cite Deeper Slide
abstract: The deeper slide into the recession foreseen in November by purchasing agents at many of the nation's leading industrial companies materialized in December.   New orders, production and employment all continued November's decline, according to the December ''Report on Business'' of the National Association of Purchasing Managers.   ''For new orders and production, it was the worst performance since June and July of 1980,'' said Charles T. Haffey, vice president of corporate purchasing at Pfizer Inc. and chairman of the association's business survey committee.   ''The employment picture has not been so poor since the first few months of 1975, which was the end of a major recession,'' he added.  However, he noted that the December rate of decline for the orders, production and employment indicators was not so steep as those of the previous few months.

headline: Advertising; Who Tops Ad Agency Mergers?
abstract: TED BATES/WORLDWIDE, fifth largest throughout the globe among American agencies, is very eager to be known as the agency that made the biggest acquisition in agency history.   It briefly had that title after it acquired Campbell-Mithun in 1979 only to lose it to the Interpublic Group of Companies, which earlier had won it by acquiring Campbell-Ewald in 1972 then rewon it by buying SSC&B and part of the worldwide Lintas operation.   Earlier this month the William Esty Company, the 16th-largest American agency, announced that it had merged with Ted Bates for the ''largest merger'' in history. Actually it was an acquisition, and since both are privately held companies, one cannot verify their numbers. Bates is reporting 1981 billings of $1.4 billion, which, of course, has nothing to do with the acquisition size. But Esty's size does, and it announced that its billings for the year were $575 million.

headline: Credit Market; MONEY SUPPLY UP $700 MILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday announced a $700 million increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Jan.  13 - a surprising development to analysts who had expected a decline of about $4 billion to offset some of the previous week's large, $10.2 billion increase.   Short-term interest rates rose sharply after the Fed's announcement, as traders quickly decided that the Fed had little choice now but to combat excessive money supply growth by making credit scarcer in the banking system, thereby driving up interest rates.   Some economists were more circumspect, however. They said the recent increases in short-term rates were evidence that the Fed was ''leaning'' against rapid money supply growth without yet undertaking an outright tightening of monetary policy that would send interest rates higher during a recession, possibly endangering a recovery.

headline: JAPAN TO LET DOW RAISE $100 MILLION
abstract: - The Dow Chemical Company has received permission from Japan to raise nearly $100 million in their capital markets, the largest such transaction by a foreign firm to date, a U.S. official said today.   John R.S. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in an interview that the Dow deal resulted from talks between U.S. and Japanese officials concerned about the difficulty of raising funds across national boundaries.

headline: MASSEY-FERGUSON LOSS IS NARROWED IN QUARTER
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially beleaguered farm equipment producer, reported yesterday that it lost $73.5 million in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Jan. 31, less than the company had expected and substantially less than it had lost in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.   The Toronto-based company said that its deficit in the latest three months had narrowed from a loss of $81.4 million in the first fiscal quarter in 1981 and included a provision of $10.4 million for unusual costs and a foreign-exchange loss of $8.4 million. In the 1981 quarter, the company had a foreign-exchange loss of $16.9 million.

headline: PATHMARK OPERATOR SELECTS A PRESIDENT
abstract: Leonard Lieberman, 53 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Supermarkets General Corporation, the operator of the Pathmark supermarket chain in the Northeast. He succeeds Herbert Brody, 67, who continues as vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Woodbridge, N.J., company.

headline: POLISH MODERATES FACING CHALLENGE
abstract: The Central Committee of Poland's Communist Party will meet this week for the first time since martial law was declared Dec. 13, the Polish press agency P.A.P. announced today.   Although apparently intended as a demonstration that the party had not ceded its ''leading role'' in the country's affairs to the military, political sources said the session could witness a clash between moderates who came to the fore before martial law was imposed and a revitalized group of hard-liners.   The Government, meanwhile, outlined guidelines for the future of Solidarity. A statement said the union should abandon political ''ambitions'' and strikes should be used only as the ''ultimate measure.''

The new agreement, which complements an existing $160 million credit line, will extend to November 1893. The original credit line extends to January 1989, and about $65 million has already been borrowed under it, the company said.

headline: NICARAGUANS SAY INCURSIONS PROMPTED INDIANS' EVICTION
abstract: The Sandinist Government, which has been sharply criticized for forcibly removing some 10,000 Miskito Indians from land along the Honduran border earlier this year, is maintaining that the evictions were necessitated by growing incursions into northern Nicaragua by armed exile bands.   ''We had no choice but to move the Miskitos,'' said one top Sandinist commander, who asked not to be quoted by name. ''Look what's happening now. It was not an ideal solution, but we couldn't risk having the counterrevolutionaries agitating among them anymore.  Unfortunately, we had to find a military solution before a political solution.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Armco Inc. said that it had increased its share of Oregon Metallurgical Corp. stock to 80 percent of the shares outstanding.   * Camelot Industries filed suit against Vista Resources, seeking an injunction to halt Vista's unsolicited conditional tender offer to purchase 650,000 Camelot shares.   * Computer Communications has been awarded a court judgment of $5 million from Codex Corp., a subsidiary of Motorola Inc., for a wrongful termination by Codex of a joint marketing and development agreement with Computer Communications. The latter has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since late 1980.

headline: Personal Finance; HOW TO DEDUCT A NIGHT ON THE TOWN
abstract: A S tax time approaches, so does deduction da y, and with it the question of handling the entertainment expens es that are major items for professionals and for business executives with entertainment bills that are not reimbursed by their compan ies. The watchwords, taxexperts stress, are ''be sure you can prove i t.''   The rules about tax-deductible entertaining were little affected by former President Carter's famous attacks on the ''three-martini lunch'' and left unchanged by last year's tax act. But a revenue-hungry Government is sharpening its collection process, the cost of underpaying taxes is soaring, and last week, the Internal Revenue Service said it would soon be auditing twice as many returns as it has in recent years. While three years is the normal limit for an audit, the I.R.S. can go further back in some cases - and it recommends that you keep your records for at least six years.   ''Substantiation, is the biggest problem with deducting entertainment,'' said Barbara Weltman, an attorney who helps compile ''J.K. Lasser's Your Income Tax,'' an annual tax manual.

headline: Pope Prays for 'Stable Peace' And 'Liberty' for Guatemala
abstract: Pope John Paul II devoted a major part of his sermon today to Guatemala, praying for ''stable and secure peace, liberty and justice'' for ''that tormented country.''   Addressing the usual Sunday noontime crowd of tourists and pilgrims in St. Peter's Square, the Pope lamented ''the fratricidal struggle'' that he said was suffocating ''the just and legitimate aspirations for a civilian, peaceful coexistence and orderly progress.''   ''Many times,'' he said, ''the bishops of Guatemala have expressed their profound concern over the insecurity that afflicts the life of the nation.''

headline: BRITISH TAKE A NEW STEP ON ULSTER HOME RULE
abstract: The British Government is beginning a new initiative aimed at bringing a measure of home rule to Northern Ireland.   In recent weeks the Government has taken important steps on several fronts, including increased cooperation with Dublin and new efforts to bring together the various political factions in the province. On Wednesday, announcing an 8 percent increase in the planned level of public spending there, James Prior, the British Cabinet minister responsible for the province, said the increase demonstrated the Government's commitment to Northern Ireland, and he added pointedly:   ''I hope this will be reflected in the cooperation that the Government receives in seeking to bring about greater stability, and in the long-term political responsibility.'' A Show of Displeasure   But the problem of reconciliation that Mr. Prior faces was reflected in the fact that just two weeks ago, when he invited the province's Members of Parliament in for a meeting to discuss the new economic package in advance, most of them stayed away, in a show of displeasure with the Government.

headline: LATIN BORDER AREA BECOMES VOLATILE
abstract: The marshy, undeveloped Miskito Indian region on the Caribbean coast has become the focus of Nicaraguan fears of an exile invasion and Honduran alarm at a Nicaraguan military buildup.   Nicaragua has accused Honduras and the United States of promoting a separatist movement among Nicaraguan Miskitos and encouraging armed bands of Nicaraguan exiles to make incursions.   In response, Nicaraguan troops have removed 8,000 to 10,000 Indians from border areas. In announcing the arrest of 100 dissident Miskitos on Feb. 3, the Managua Government said 60 Nicaraguan soldiers and Miskitos had been killed by rightist exiles in recent weeks.

headline: DARK DAYS FOR PLANE MAKERS
abstract: This prosperous prairie town thought it had given ''recession proof'' its true meaning. Situated where the Middle West meets the Sun Belt, Wichita breezed through the turbulent 1970's without a slump, thanks to its booming aviation and oil drilling industries.   As for more recent times, Wichita's unemployment rate in January was only 4.5 percent, about half the national average. The current economic slump, it seemed, was also passing Wichita by.

headline: BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPLIT ON U.S. POLICY SEEN AT E.E.C. TALKS
abstract: West European leaders appeared seriously divided over the best response to the world economic crisis and the strains it is producing in their relations with the Reagan Administration at the start of the Common Market's semiannual meeting today.   As a result, the 10-nation community, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, is unlikely to be able to present a cohesive view on world economic problems when the leaders of its four biggest members, West Germany, France, Britain and Italy, meet with President Reagan and the Prime Ministers of Canada and Japan at the Western economic meeting in Versailles, France, next June.   Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Britain's Conservative Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, both took a firm stand against mounting pressure from the Common Market's Executive Commission and several smaller governments to move to policies intended to stimulate economic growth. These policies, which include higher government spending, would be aimed at bringing down Europe's soaring unemployment rate.

headline: NEW YORK REGION CATCHING UP IN THE TECHNOLOGICAL RACE
abstract: WHILE several widely scattered areas of the nation have been winning the race to development of high-technology industry, the New York metropolitan area has not been left at the gate. Beginning quietly in the early 1970's, the area's growing technology complex has helped to transform the economic profile of Long Island and the developments are on the verge of moving into New York City itself.   In just in the last six years, hundreds of small- to medium-size companies engaged in highly sophisticated scientific research and manufacturing have cropped up on Long Island, from the New York City line almost to Riverhead. No one, not even economic-development specialists, is sure how many enterprises there are because no two people have the same definition of high technology. But no one disputes that companies engaged in avionics, semiconductors, microcircuitry and other ventures on the cutting edge of new technology have found a home in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

headline: DETERMINING INCOME AND TAX EXEMPTIONS
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service takes an expansive view of income, and requires that just about everything from bartered goods, salary and wages to lottery prizes and even kickbacks be reported on a tax return. But new provisions in the law double the amount of di vidend income that i nvestors can exclude on their 1981 returns, and allow people to she lter their interest income in two new ways. The general rule is that taxpayers must include all payments for services rendered, including such items as severance pay, union strike benefits and under-the-t able commissio ns. Gambling victories must be reported (losses can be deducted as a n itemized deduction, but only up to the amount of winnings), and s o must illegal income such as embezzled funds. Alimony and separate maintenance payments are considered income, but child support paym ents are not.   Taxpayers must also list a certain portion of their income from investments, such as stock dividends or interest on bank savings accounts. The amount and type of investment income that can be excluded this year has been liberalized as a result of the 1980 Windfall Profit Tax Act.

headline: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

headline: LISTING DEDUCTIONS: THE RANGE IS BROAD
abstract: One step in preparing tax returns that many people enjoy is completing Schedule A, where the costs of ever ything from straightening a child's teeth to the sales tax on a new car can be itemized and deducted. Last year the courts approved deductions for everything fr om hair transplants for a prematurely bald man to the cost of whisk y prescribed by a doctor to relieve angina pain. A wide variety of medical expenses, ranging from vitamin pills prescribed by a doctor to prosthetic devices for patients recovering from mastectomy, are deductible as long as the cost exceeds a certain level. The rule is that an individual can claim only those expenses that exceed a ''floor'' for total medical expenses of 3 percent of his or her adjusted gross income.   But half of all medical insurance premiums, up to a maximum of $150, can be deducted regardless of whether the taxpayer qualifies for other medical deductions. (The other half is treated as an ordinary medical expense and is subject to the 3 percent floor.) Medicine and drugs are also deductible, but before they can be added to other medical bills subject to the 3 percent floor they must first be reduced by 1 percent of the taxpayer's adjusted gross income.

headline: POPE MAKES PLEA FOR POLISH UNION
abstract: Pope John Paul II, in his strongest and most explicit call for the survival of Solidarity, said today that the union had become an integral part of the ''heritage of the workers of Poland and of other nations.''   To make his meaning quite clear, the Pope used the Polish word ''Solidarnosc'' five times in his New Year's address, even though the rest of it was in Italian.   As he spoke from the window of his apartment, young people in St.  Peter's Square held up huge banners with the words ''Solidarity'' in both Polish and Italian; others, some standing on the shoulders of their companions, waved dozens of large gold and white Polish flags.  The Pope was interrupted by fervent applause several times from the crowd of about 50,000.

headline: More Auto Layoffs
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced plans for further plant closings next week. G.M. said it would double car plant closings to six, increasing temporary layoffs to 18,700.

headline: Grumman's President Named Chairman of Flxible Bus Unit
abstract: In a move to strengthen its money-losing Flxible bus subsidiary, the Grumman Corporation assigned its secondhighest executive to Flxible today and said that it was restructuring another subsidiary that makes fire trucks, ambulances and yachts, among other products.   Flxible's new chairman is Joseph G. Gavin, 61 years old, who has been president and chief operating officer of Grumman since 1976. He will retain those posts. Mr. Gavin, who was the head of Grumman's lunar module program in the 1960's, has worked at Grumman throughout his career.

headline: ISRAEL HARDENING ITS STANDON VISITS
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin was reported today to have said that he would not visit Egypt until President Hosni Mubarak came to Israel and included Jerusalem in his itinerary.    Mr. Begin's remarks, made at a meeting of the Jewish Agency's board of governors on Monday and confirmed today by one of his aides, appeared to reflect a rise in tension two months before Israel is scheduled to return the last part of Sinai to Egypt.   Mr. Begin was understood to have said that Mr. Mubarak's reluctance to visit the contested city of Jerusalem, which Israel regards as its capital, was unacceptable.   ''We cannot accept a guest who will demonstrate against Jerusalem,'' Mr. Begin was quoted as having said. He added that Israeli-Egyptian ties would be stronger if President Anwar el-Sadat, who was assassinated in October, were alive.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: A LONGER RECESSION In his press conference last week, President Reagan tried to calm the Financial markets by voicing strong support for the Federal Reserve's tough money policies.  While Mr. Reagan's intentions were good, analysts say his perception of the source of Wall Street's skittishness is misplaced.   The Fed's credibility has rarely been higher in financial markets.  What worries money men is the future course of fiscal policy.  By refusing to budge on current budget priorities, Mr. Reagan said littler that would dispell those doubts.

headline: American Can
abstract: The American Can Company said that about 4.56 milllion of its shares were tendered under an offer made Jan. 12 to buy back 2 million of its shares. The company said it had accepted for payment 2.2 million shares, including about 93,000 shares tendered by odd-lot holders, and had elected not to accept any additional shares.

headline: THE CURSE ON CIGARS
abstract: BARRE, Pa.  ''W HAT this country needs,'' Representative James L.  Nelligan told Congress late last year, ''is a good five cent cigar ... and no excise tax.'' Maybe so, but evidently that is not what the country wants. Cigar sales today are at their lowest point since 1930, when people first began keeping track. They are down 42 percent from the 1964 high point of 9 billion cigars sold. Authorities on the subject say nothing is going to revive the market before this decade is out. And it is in the lower price ranges that the blight is felt most.  The American Cigar Company in nearby Mountaintop, Pa., producers of Anthony y Cleopatra, Roitan and La Corona cigars, reports sales are declining annually by about 10 percent.  The General Cigar Company, owned by Culbro and makers of Robert Burns, White Owl and Gold Label cigars, announced on Nov. 19 - which happened to be National Smokeout Day - that in June it would shut down the plant near here, its largest, laying off 300 employees. It plans to concentrate operations at a smaller automated plant in Phillipsburg, N.J.

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1982; International
abstract: Two banks downgraded their loans to Poland to ''nonperforming assets.'' The two, Marine Midland of New York and Fidelity of Philadelphia, were the first Western banks to announce such an action. They still expect the loans, which were well below $100 million, to be paid, however. Many American bankers believe that Poland's large debt does not constitute a threat to the soundness of the international banking structure. (Page D1.)   Daniel K. Ludwig is reported to be giving up his billion-dollar development project in the Brazilian Amazon. A group of banks, insurance companies, contractors and investment houses are to take over the project, one of the largest ever financed by one person.  (D1.)

headline: Business School Dean Appointed by Columbia
abstract: John C. Burton, 49, a former Deputy Mayor of New York City and chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been appointed dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business in New York, effective July 1. He succeeds Boris Yavitz, 58, who has been dean since 1975 and who will become the Paul Garrett Professor of Public Policy and Business Responsibility.   A certified public accountant, published author and sports fan, Mr. Burton has been a Columbia professor since 1962. During his five years of city and Federal service, from 1972 to 1977, he was on leave from the faculty.

headline: Pabst Plans to Buy Pittsburgh Brewing
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company, which is engaged in a battle to prevent Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis financier, from taking control of the company, announced yesterday that it has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, a small but profitable regional brewer.   Under the agreement, Pabst, the nation's fifth-ranked brewer, will pay in common stock the equivalent of $7 a share for the 1.1 million outstanding common shares of Pittsburgh Brewing, or a total of about $7.7 million. The transaction will be a tax-free reorganization and is subject to the approval by the board and shareholders of Pittsburgh Brewing and the execution of a definitive agreement.

headline: Israeli Diplomat Warns Of Move Into Lebanon
abstract: Israel's new Ambassador to the United States warned today that Israel could be forced to take military action in southern Lebanon, declaring ''I would almost say it's a matter of time.''   The Ambassador, Moshe Arens, said Palestinian forces were still building up arms in the area, endangering the Israeli population in northern Israel, despite a cease-fire arranged with American help last July.

headline: People
abstract: * Howard S. Plisstner named director of advertising for Omni magazine.   * Robert A. Cohen, former publisher of The New Republic, has been elected publisher of Technology magazine.

headline: Personal Finance; THE FUNDS THAT DON'T PAY DIVIDENDS
abstract: G IVEN the lackluster performance of the stock market this past year, another kind of equity mutual fund would seem to be the last thing anybody needs. Yet several funds, some new and some older, have an interesting twist: They are structured to minimize taxes by reinvesting income and by never paying dividends.   Called tax-managed funds, they concentrate on utility stocks. The funds are completely different from those that specialize in taxexempt municipal bonds except that they share a common goal of reducing taxes.

headline: BENDIX MOVE SPURS RCA STOCK ACTIVITY
abstract: Investors, sensing a takeover bid for the RCA Corporation, propelled trading in RCA stock to the most active spot on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, although some Wall Street analysts cautioned that they did not believe RCA would become a takeover target any time soon.   In a surprise development announced Monday evening, the Bendix Corporation disclosed that it had purchased ''for investment purposes only'' more than 5 percent of RCA's voting stock and that it had ''no present plans'' to buy more than 9.9 percent of RCA's shares. In a blistering reaction, announced soon afterward, RCA said the purchase was ''not welcomed.''   Responding to the Bendix announcment, trading in RCA stock soared to 1.3 million shares, ending the day at $20, ahead only 62 1/2 cents. If Bendix, which has not identified the period during which it bought RCA stock, were to have acquired its shares at yesterday's closing price, the stake would be worth about $75.4 million. Bendix stock rose by 62 1/2 cents, to $52.125, in moderate volume of 63,800 shares.

headline: British Pay Up 10.8%
abstract: The average pay of British workers rose 10.8 percent in the year ended Jan. 31, the Government said today.  Inflation was at a 12 percent annual rate in January.

headline: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT'S WATCHDOG
abstract: William Francis Baxter, an assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division of the Justice Department, was on a skiing vacation in Utah until late this week.  But from out West, he followed the last-minute, secret negotiations for a settlement of the historic antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A Justice Department attorney served as a courier, delivering documents to him in Utah. He was in constant contact with his office by telephone to check on the status of the case against the International Business Machines Corporation, which the Justice Department dropped today.   That ability to combine diverse activities illustrates the way in which Mr. Baxter practices the ''efficiency'' principles that he preaches as a conservative economist.

headline: Markets
abstract: Several leading banks reduced their prime lending rates by half a point, to 16 percent. It was the lowest level for the prime in three months, and hopes rose in banking circles that interest rates would continue to fall. One forecast was for a 14 percent rate within 30 to 45 days. Chase Manhattan also reduced its residential mortgage rates by a quarter point. (Page A1.)   Stock prices plunged in active trading as worry over the weakening economy mounted. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped below the 800 level for the first time in almost two years, closing 11.89 points lower, at 795.47. Analysts predicted a further decline in the Dow, to between 760 and 780 over the next few weeks. (D1.)

headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.4 BILLION
abstract: The basic measure of the nation's money supply declined by a modest $1.4 billion in the week ended Dec. 30, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday, reversing a similar upswing in the previous week.    A number of bankers and economists said that the small decline indicated that the Federal Reserve would continue to keep a tight rein on the money supply and that, as a result, short-term interest rates would not decline despite new evidence of a deepening recession.   ''My best guess for the immediate future is that short-term rates will be flat,'' said Jay N. Woodworth, vice president and economist of the Bankers Trust Company. ''Considering the economy, these rates should be expected to fall.'' Mr. Woodworth and most other economists cited the Government's report yesterday that the unemployment rate jumped to 8.9 percent in December on an annual basis, up from 8.4 percent in November.

headline: Soviet Expected to Rule On Pentecostals' Visas
abstract: Soviet officials are expected to rule by late March on emigration applications of Lidiya Vashchenko and other family members living in Siberia, a sister said today.   Lidiya Vashchenko, four other family members, and two other Pentecostals dashed past Soviet guards into the United States Embassy here in 1978.

headline: Texaco Is Said By Honduras To Curb Fuel
abstract: A Honduran official has accused Texaco Inc. of causing a gasoline shortage in an attempt to force the Government to approve a tripling of gasoline prices.   Texaco, the country's only petroleum refiner, announced Monday that it had run out of crude oil. In three days, 4,500 of the 5,000 gasoline stations in Honduras have closed, unable to refill their pumps. Long lines of automobiles have formed at stations still open, and the Government has sent inspectors to check consumer complaints that some fuel was watered down.

headline: A Chrysler Closing
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would close a Detroit plant that boxed parts for shipment overseas because the company had sold off its European, Far Eastern and South American manufacturing operations.

headline: ISRAEL'S POLICY ON SYRIA TALKS
abstract: Israel has asserted that its annexation of the Golan Heights has not changed its willingness to negotiate with Syria over territory seized in the 1967 war.   Israel's position was spelled out in a report issued today by Kurt Waldheim, the outgoing Secretary General.

headline: EGYPT'S CHIEF TURNS FROM DIPLOMACY TO ECONOMICS
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak has completed his first international tour as Egypt's leader and is ready to tackle what he has labeled his chief priority - restructuring Egypt's economy.   Mr. Mubarak arrived in Egypt Monday night after a 10-day trip that took him to Rome, the Vatican, Paris, Washing ton, London, Bonn and Vienna. Egyptian officials, the Egyptian pres s and several diplomats here praised Mr. Mubarak's handling of the tr ip, a view also evident in the press coverage at his various stops.

headline: CINCINNATI MILACRON CHOOSES PRESIDENT
abstract: Clifford R. Meyer, 58 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the country's leading manufacturer of machine tools with close to $1 billion in sales last year. As president, he succeeds James A.D. Geier, 56, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company.

headline: Around the World; U.S. Declines Comment On Accusation in Pravda
abstract: The United States Embassy declined to comment today on the Soviet press accusation that a large group of American spies had been working under the guise of diplomats in Moscow.   Privately, embassy sources described the accusation in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda as ''old stuff.''

headline: Creditor Plan For Cooper-Jarrett
abstract: Cooper-Jarrett Inc., a trucking concern now operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said that Judge Vincent Commisa in Federal Bankruptcy Court had approved a debtor-in-possession creditor arrangement between the company and the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Almost every party to the troubles in Central America is now saying that it is prepared to negotiate with its adversaries. But according to accounts by Administration officials and Latin American diplomats, there is far less going on than meets the eye, at least for the moment.   On the surface, it looks like all of the parties are preparing for serious bargaining: revelations of a high-ranking Administration emissary meeting secretly with Fidel Castro in Cuba last week, a Nicaraguan leader saying today that his Government and Cuba would negotiate immediately with Washington, the American Ambassador to El Salvador on Wednesday underlining the Administration's willingness to see direct negotiations commence between the new government there and the Salvadoran guerrillas, the Venezuelan President speaking on the same day of rethinking policy toward El Salvador after Sunday's elections, and more. A Willingness to Negotiate   With all of this diplomatic pressure and activity, and with growing domestic opposition to the Reagan Administration policy toward Central America, the speculation was bound to grow that President Reagan had to be looking for a way out. And under the circumstances, no one could exclude the possibility that all this may be the necessary posturing that often precedes serious negotiations.

headline: U.N. Chief Welcomes Move
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar welcomed Leonid I. Brezhnev's announcement today of a freeze in deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe. A United Nations spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said the Secretary General ''welcomes every new initiative enhancing the possibility of a meaningful agreement'' on arms control.
