headline: CHAIRMAN OF UNIROYAL TO RESIGN
abstract: Uniroyal Inc., the nation's fourth-largest tire and rubber company, announced yesterday that David Beretta, its 53-year-old chairman and an employee for almost 30 years, would resign on Feb. 28 ''to pursue business interests.'' Joseph P. Flannery, 49, president and chief executive officer, will become chairman as well.   Uniroyal called Mr. Beretta's departure a retirement. Yanis Bibelnieks, a spokesman for the corporation, said that an employee was eligible for retirement from the company when his age and years of service totaled at least 80.

headline: A Deadline Passes For Times of London
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's deadline for voluntary layoffs to prevent the closing of The Times of London and its sister paper, The Sunday Times, passed today without an agreement with the union, company officials said.

headline: GENERAL AMERICA OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israelis Start to Remove Equipment From Sinai
abstract: Seven weeks before the deadline for their evacuation of Sinai, the Israelis started today to remove equipment from the prosperous desert farms they set up there.

headline: YEN SAGS, AGGRAVATING TRADE PROBLEMS
abstract: In recent weeks, Japanese Government officials have watched with growing concern as rising United States interest rates have weakened the yen, threatening to intensify Japan's trade problems.   Today, in trading described as extremely hectic, the yen's value fell to a six-month low of 241.10 to the American dollar, compared with Friday's close of 237.55.   ''The hoped-for appreciation of the yen has not occurred,'' said Masaru Yoshitomi, chief economist of Japan's Economic Planning Agency. ''The reason is the high interest rates in the U.S., which are the result of the policy mix of the American Government - a tight monetary policy and large projected Federal deficits.''

headline: Bomb Kills 3 in Nicaragua
abstract: A bomb planted inside a piece of luggage exploded tonight at the Managua airport, killing three people and wounding three others, the Government radio station said.  It said the luggage had been unloaded from a Salvadoran airliner that arrived from El Salvador.

headline: MOBIL BIDS BURGER HALT U.S. STEEL
abstract: With time running out, the Mobil Corporation asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today to block the United States Steel Corporation's $6.2 billion takeover of the Marathon Oil Company.   But it appeared that Mobil will not hear Justice Burger's decision until only hours before U.S. Steel is free to begin buying Marathon's shares - at 12:01 A.M. Thursday. Well over 51 percent of the shares have already been tendered to U.S. Steel.   Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, asked Chief Justice Burger this morning to freeze the takeover fight until the full Supreme Court could hear Mobil's formal appeal for a review of the lower court antitrust rulings that have stopped the giant oil company from proceeding with its own $6.5 billion bid for Marathon. The Chief Justice did not respond to Mobil's petition before the Court closed today.

headline: SOVIET JOINS CZECHOSLOVAKIA AND HUNGARY FOR WAR GAMES
abstract: Soviet, Czechoslovak and Hungarian troops plan joint maneuvers in western Czechoslovakia this month, the Czechoslovak press agency reported today.

headline: WARNING ON BANK DECONTROL DISPUTE
abstract: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, warned today that there may not be any action on bank deregulation in Congress this session if the banking and securities industries cannot resolve their differences.   In testimony before a Senate banking subcommitee, industry officials disagreed sharply on a Reagan Administration proposal that would let bank holding companies handle a variety of underwriting activities.   While nearly all who testified urged enactment of legislation that would deal with the deregulation of financial services institutions, there was little agreement on how this could be achieved. And chances that the issue of bank entry into the underwriting field might be resolved in Congress this session appeared diminished.

headline: Lebanon Premier in Riyadh
abstract: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan of Lebanon arrived in Saudi Arabia today at the start of a Persian Gulf tour for talks on the worsening situation in his country. He was quoted by the Saudi Press Agency as saying at Riyadh airport that the main aim of his trip was to explain ''the dangers facing Lebanon and the challenges which are imposed on it by the Israeli enemy, which daily threatens to occupy south Lebanon.''

headline: Kayser-Roth Deal
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries said that its Kayser-Roth Corporation unit signed an exclusive licensing agreement with Jonathan Logan Inc. Under the agreement, Kayser-Roth becomes the sole licensee of women's clothing sold under the Jonathan Logan label. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Gulf and Western said the primary customer for the merchandise will be t he K Mart Corporatio n

headline: CRUCIAL POWER PLANT DECISION
abstract: In a Seattle board room today, two troubled nuclear power projects that have consumed billions of dollars in borrowed funds may be ordered terminated. If so, that action will reverberate through the nation's municipal bond market.   What could shape up is a test case on the ''take and pay'' provisions that obligate municipalities to repay all borrowings even if the revenue-generating project for which they were intended is not completed.   If terminated, the 88 West Coast utilities participating in the two projects - No.4 and No.5 of the Washington Public Power Supply System -may be left having to repay some $2.25 billion in principal payments and some $4.75 billion in interest with no power plants to generate either electricity or revenues.

headline: Mrs. Thatcher Predicts Allies Will Back Actions on Poland
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain predicted today that the European allies would approve joint action to protest military rule in Poland, but she said it might take a ''slightly different'' form than the sanctions imposed by President Reagan.   She made the statement in an interview with the BBC on the eve of a NATO meeting in Brussels to discuss the Western alliance's response to developments in Poland. Mrs. Thatcher did not say what action she expected.

headline: McLouth Steel
abstract: The McLouth Steel Corporation said that its board of directors had decided to seek permision from Judge George Woods of Federal Bankruptcy Court to continue to use its cash collateral beyond this Friday and for as long ''as possible.'' Last week, lenders to the steel company, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, said that as of Friday they would stop financing McLouth and would call in the company's $112 million of loans.

headline: Ulster's Chief Justice Survives Guerrilla Attack
abstract: Irish nationalist guerrillas tried today to assassinate Northern Ireland's top judge, Lord Lowry, firing four shots at him, but missing as he was getting out of his car at Queen's University.

abstract: To the Business Editor: "The Supply Side of PUblishing" (Jan. 7) was most informative.  However, the critique on the "deduction-stretching suggestions of some of the how-to books" omitted one final bit of advice.  When you're deducting the price of the book from your income tax, don't mention the title.  PAUL A. BAUER President, Bauer Industries Inc.  Mineola, N.Y., Feb. 10, 1982

abstract: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said it is reducing production at its Arvida, Quebec, smelter by 43,000 metric tons a year because of depressed sales and the need to balance production and inventory.

headline: FARMERS IN POLAND PRESSED ON GRAIN
abstract: The Polish Government, conceding the existence of a drastic shortage of bread and flour, announced measures today that are designed to force farmers to sell grain to the state.   The measures stopped short of outright compulsory deliveries, a system used in the 1950's and 1960's, but they appeared to be a step in that direction.   At the same time, the Polish Conference of Bishops said it had sent a letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, on what it called ''the very complicated situation in the country.''   The content of the letter was not disclosed, but the Roman Catholic Church has become increasingly critical of martial law and of the arrests, detentions, and forced loyalty oaths that accompanied it.  The bishops also drew up a pastoral letter to be read in all churches and they declared Feb. 2, the feast day known as Candlemas, a day of special prayer for Poland.

headline: Auto Sales Drive Set
abstract: The auto industry is planning a midwinter marketing campaign around new model introductions in hopes of cashing in on a major sales recovery forecast for 1982, a trade publication reported today.   According to Ward's Auto Wor ld magazine, in dustry leaders generallybelieve that the recovery forecast by many an alysts, combined with the 10 percent personal income tax cut on Jul y 1, will unleash consumer demand for new cars next year.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SALVADORAN LETTERS DISPUTED   SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 14 (UPI) - Ambassador Deane R. Hinton of the United States said yesterday that letters o ffering information about an American r eporter who disappeared a year ago had been sent by extortionists .   Mr. Hinton said American officials had investigated the letter relating to John J. Sullivan, a free-lance reporter missing since Dec. 28, 1980, and concluded that they were attempts at extortion.

headline: Advertising; Changing At the Top At D'Arcy
abstract: THE pair of copywriters-turned-ad moguls arrived very early yesterday morning at the spanking new Madison Avenue offices of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, a worldwide operation with more than $1 billion in billings. There was much to do.   The bigger man, who is also the younger, was H.G. Bay Jr., 44 years old and known to the advertising crowd in Detroit as Hal. He capped a meteoric rise at the agency by becoming president and chief executive on Jan. 1.

headline: PRIVATE FOOD AID FROM U.S. TO POLES RESUMES
abstract: A private group announced today that it had begun the first American shipment of food to Poland since martial law was imposed last month.   The group, Food for Poland, said that about 20,000 gallons of dairy products had left Provo, Utah, by truck and would be sent by ship to Gdansk to be distributed by church officials in Poland. Fortnightly shipments of food and clothing to Poland ceased when the military crackdown began Dec. 13.

headline: U.S. OFFERS PHOTOS OF BASES TO PROVE NICARAGUA THREAT
abstract: The Reagan Administration made public today aerial reconnaissance photographs that intelligence officials said proved Nicaragua, with Cuban and Soviet assistance, was assembling the largest military force in Central America.   The Administration asserted that the military buildup posed a threat to Nicaragua's neighbors and had upset the military balance in the region.   Charging that Nicaraguan leaders had lied about the extent of the military growth, Adm. Bobby R. Inman, the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, said: ''It's time to get some concern in this country about their military buildup. It's vastly beyond any defensive need.''

headline: 5 Irish Nationals Are Arrested by U.S.
abstract: Immigration officials said today that five Irish nationals were arrested over the weekend for attempting to enter the United States from Canada to purchase weapons.   Immigration officials said the five, including three who were landed immigrants in Canada, were stopped at the Whirlpool Bridge in Lewiston, N.Y., just north of Niagara Falls, late Saturday night.

headline: F.T.C. HEAD MAY END REVIEWS OF ADS
abstract: James C. Miller 3d, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that he might ask Congress to exempt advertisers entirely from a fairness standard now used by the F.T.C.  to protect consumers from what it considers harmful advertising, especially on television.   Two years ago, when the agency was investigating television advertising directed at children, Congress prohibited the F.T.C.  from issuing any industrywide rules on fairness in advertising.  However, it permitted the agency to continue scrutinizing the fairness of individual advertisements.   Under this authorization, the agency has reviewed such commercials as those showing children in potentially dangerous situations that the agency felt might be imitated by young viewers. In one case, for example, the agency objected to a proposed TV commercial that showed a child using an electrical appliance near water without adult supervision. The commercial was dropped.

headline: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOND YIELDS AT RECORD LEVELS
abstract: Yields on long-term tax-exempt bonds were at record levels yesterday, but dealers said that investor demand remained modest despite the widespread availablity of revenue bonds yielding more than 14 percent and high-grade general-obligation issues yielding more than 12 percent.   ''After dropping sharply Monday, prices stabilized yesterday, but there is still a dearth of institutional buyers in our market,'' one dealer in tax-exempts said. The strongest demand for tax-exempts has been from individuals, dealers said, with banks and casualty insurance companies inactive and seeming to prefer short-term maturities when they do buy.   Thomas Coyle, a vice president at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said, ''We keep seeing good retail cash, especially from individuals who sold bonds at a loss for tax purposes late in 1981 and are now reinvesting their money.''

headline: U.S. TELLS OFFICER WHO CARRIED RIFLE TO LEAVE SALVADOR
abstract: A senior United States military adviser has been ordered to leave El Salvador as a result of having violated American regulations restricting the weapons that advisers are permitted to carry with them on training missions.   At a news conference at the United States Embassy, Ambassador Deane R. Hinton announced that Lieut. Col. Harry Melander, an Army officer who has been in El Salvador for more than four months, would return to the United States next week.   In Washington, a State Department spokesman said that the order to Colonel Melander had been given by Mr. Hinton in his capacity as President Reagan's representative in El Salvador.   In another development, a Salvadoran judge freed one of six former National Guardsmen held in the 1980 deaths of four United States churchwomen and ordered the others held for further investigation.  (Page 18.)

headline: BankAmerica Post
abstract: Daniel W. Costello has been named executive vice president in charge of the real estate division at the BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank holding company, the bank disclosed yesterday. Mr. Costello, 52 years old, was recruited from the American Express Company, where he was senior vice president in charge of real estate and general services. At BankAmerica, he will manage a $2 billion global real estate portfolio. Mr. Costello succeeds Raleigh DeBow, a senior vice president who resigned last year,

headline: Albanian Said to Name A New Prime Minister
abstract: Enver Hoxha, head of the Albanian Communist Party, was reported today to have nominated First Deputy Prime Minister Adil Carcani to succeed Prime Minister Mehmet Shehu, who reportedly committed suicide last month.

headline: Trade Publications In Antitrust Action
abstract: American Business Press, the association of trade publications, has filed a complaint with the Justice Department seeking an investigation into whether the proposed purchase on Wednesday of Production Magazine by the National Machine Tool Builders Association violates the Clayton antitrust act.

headline: WHITTAKER IN NEW BID ,
abstract: The Whittaker Corporation, blocked earlier this month in its attempt to take over the Brunswick Corporation and its Sherwood medical products division, is seeking to buy another medical company.   Joseph F. Alibrandi, president and chief executive, said at the company's annual shareholders' meeting today that Whittaker was conducting ''serious discussions'' regarding acquisitions with four companies with sales of $50 million to $400 million a year. He declined to identify the companies.

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Up
abstract: The 117 magazines that are members of the Publishers Information Bureau had a 3 percent increase in ad pages in January over the same month last year, with a total of 8,143, up a fraction of a page less than 200 pages. Ad revenues, thanks to increased rates, rose $24.1 million, or 13 percent, to $211.2 million.

headline: Broker Loan Rate Up
abstract: The Bankers Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it had raised its broker loan rate by a full percentage point, to 15 1/2 percent, from 14 1/2 percent, effective immediately. The rate, which is considered to be a reliable indicator to future changes in the prime lending rate, ranges from 15 to 15 1/4 percent at other major banks.

headline: Bonn Young Democrats Back Nuclear-Free Zone
abstract: A national convention of a political youth group closely allied to the Free Democratic Party called today for a nuclear-free zone in Europe and for the resignation of Bonn's Minister of Economics, Otto Lambsdorff, a Free Democrat.

headline: Dow Up on Higher Volume
abstract: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after showing modest declines in the three previous sessions. President Reagan's State of the Union Message on Tuesday night exerted ''little impact'' upon the market, according to Lee H. Idleman, research director of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.   ''The speech was most notable,'' Mr. Idleman said, ''in that the President did not propose any taxes, because he has to engineer an economic recovery fairly soon.''

headline: MAGNUSON CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
abstract: Joseph L. Hitt, chairman of troubled Magnuson Computer Systems, resigned unexpectedly, the company announced today.   Charles R. Cole, 50 years old, a director of the company since 1980, was named to replace Mr. Hitt temporarily as acting president and chief executive. Paul H. Magnuson, 38, reassumed the chairman's post.

headline: British Back Canada Charter
abstract: A bill to give Canada final control over its own constitution was approved by the British House of Commons tonight by a vote of 177 to 33. The measure, which was requested by the Canadian Government, now goes to the House of Lords and the Government hopes to pass it into law in the next month.

headline: Itel Payment Data
abstract: The Itel Corporation of San Francisco, a marketer and leasor of transportation and computer equipment, said that preliminary information on its January operations, filed in accordance with Chapter 11 bankruptcy requirements, showed that its unrestricted cash balance decreased by about $9 million, to about $287 million, as of Jan. 31. The company said it had made secured debt and lease payments in January of $11.6 million, compared with $4.5 million in December.  It noted that the amounts paid in January include the retirement of $9.2 million of secured obligations.

headline: CENTRAL AMERICANS CALL PARLEY
abstract: Leaders of five Central American nations called an unexpected meeting within hours of President Reagan's speech on aid to the Caribbean region, Costa Rica's Foreign Ministry said today.   Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Panama and Honduras agreed to attend the meeting Saturday in San Jose, Costa Rica, but Guatemala refused to participate after learning that Nicaraguan officials would be present, the Foreign Ministry said.

headline: Volkswagen Names Financial Officer
abstract: Rolf Selowsky, 51 years old, has been named chief financial officer of Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, whose sales and profits slipped sharply last year. Mr. Selowsky will succeed Friedrich Thomee, who stepped down last October.   The resignation of Mr. Thomee, 61, preceded by a little more than a week the departure of Toni Schmucker, Volkswagen's chairman, who resigned for health reasons, leading to a major management shift at the company. Carl H. Hahn, formerly head of Continetal Gummiwerke, the rubber company, was appointed to replace Mr. Schmucker.

headline: POLISH OFFICIAL SAYS ECONOMIC OUTLOOK IS NOT GOOD
abstract: A Polish Government economist said today that the Government was having difficulty repairing Poland's paralyzed economy.   Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, in declaring martial law Dec.  13, said that a chief goal of the military takeover and the suspension of the Solidarity trade union was to restore the economy.   Warsaw authorities had promised that liberalizations begun after the formation of Solidarity would continue after the economy started to improve.   But the Government official in charge of economic reform, Wladyslaw Baka, in an article in the Communist Party newspaper Trybuna Ludu, said the economic outlook was not good. He told the Polish people that American economic sanctions were to blame and implied that sanctions would prolong military rule.

headline: SKIPPER WHO WAS ATTACKED DENIES AIDING FILIPINO REBELS
abstract: The captain of a Japanese tanker attacked by Philippine fighters at sea on Jan. 15 said here today that Philippine Government suspicions that his ship carried ''terrorists'' and $10 million worth of arms and explosives for anti-Government guerrilla forces in the Philippines were unfounded.   Captain Hideo Takakuwa, skipper of the 5,306-ton chemical tanker Hegg, also denied charges by made Monday by the Philippine Foreign Minister, Carlos P. Romulo, that he failed to fly a flag and ignored repeated warnings to stop.   ''We did not carry arms or guerrillas,'' Mr. Takakuwa said, ''that is absurd.''

headline: Prime-Time TV Plan Is Explained by ABC
abstract: The ABC-TV Network, which announced last January that it would increase its nightly commercial availability on prime time by one minute a night, told its affiliates last week how it plans to phase it in.   In the first year, beginning in September with the new season, a maximum of seven 30-second spots will be available each week for the network and two a week for affiliated local stations.

headline: Tarrytown G.M.'s 2-Week Shutdown

headline: Volvo Robot Plan
abstract: Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, intends to begin producing industrial robots in a leased plant near Detroit, state officials said. The plant will manufacture ''guided driverless vehicles'' to carry parts between robots in automobile plants, Robert Berg, an aide to Gov. William G. Milliken, said. Mr.  Berg said that the Swedish auto maker hopes to employ 200 to 300 workers and have annual sales of $100 million at full production.

headline: Alfa Layoffs
abstract: Alfa Romeo, the second-largest Italian auto maker, laid off 30,000 workers and closed its factories for three weeks to reduce a growing inventory.

headline: E.E.C. Hints Of Recovery
abstract: The European Economic Community appears to be emerging from the current worldwide recession, according to statistics and a survey released today by the E.E.C.  Commission.   The community's provisional industrial index rose to 118.5 in October, up five-tenths of 1 percent from the corresponding month of 1980, after a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, the first since mid-1980, the Commission said.

headline: Midland-Ross Net Off
abstract: The Midland-Ross Corporation, the world's largest maker of industrial heat-treating furnaces and railroad car couplers, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 41 percent from a year earlier, to $5.5 million, or 45 cents a share, from $9.4 million, or 80 cents a share. Sales for the three-month period were $231.1 million, down slightly from $231.8 million a year earlier.

headline: Market Place; Ad Agencies' Stock Outlook
abstract: ADVERTISING agencies may appear as homespun enterprises to the American public, but they contain a strong international streak. In fact, ''International'' is literally the last word in the name of such publicly owned companies as Ogilvy & Mather, BBDO and Doyle Dane Bernbach.   The sense of global endeavor is also apparent in other corporate names. There is, for example, the Interpublic Group, the world's largest ad ag ency, and the JWT Group, which owns the J. Walter Thompson agen cy. There is a saying in the advertising business that ''JWT coloniz ed South America shortly after Columbus.''

headline: AT SOVIET FUR AUCTION, CAPITALISM REIGNS SUPREME
abstract: With a few bangs of a gavel here recently, a pokerfaced Soviet official started a process that should culminate sometime next winter when a small number of wealthy women take turns before furriers' mirrors, nod their approval and step into the street with coats valued at $75,000 to $100,000 apiece.   The sales may be made in New York, Dallas, Tokyo or a few other cities. But if the fur is white-bellied lynx or silver-haired black sable it will probably have come under the hammer in a neo-classical building here called the Fur Palace, where a trade as old as Russia itself rolls forward at a series of fur auctions held three times a year.   The setting is a Stalinesque building of the late 1930's that boasts Corinthian columns and reeks of mothballs, but the officials of Soyuzpushnina, the Soviet trading company that celebrated its 50th anniversary last year, are strictly contemporary when it comes to getting the market price for their wares.

headline: Market Place; Whittaker Bid For Brunswick
abstract: THE Whittaker Corporation's efforts to acquire the Brunswick Corporation might seem counterproductive to people who admire the way Whittaker has streamlined its operations by getting rid of 89 businesses. Whittaker began dropping lines in 1970, but investors did not take much notice until the end of the great bear market.   The nadir for Whittaker shares came in December 1974, when the price touched 1 1/8. Later they climbed, reaching their peak of 50 7/8 last year. Anyone investing $10,000 in Whittaker at the 1974 bottom could have collected dividends since 1978 and could have sold out at the mid-1981 top for $500,000. Whittaker closed yesterday at 31 7/8.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Microsystems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has named Richard C. Joy a vice president-research and development.   * Atlantic Bank of New York has appointed Chris G. Lazarides an executive vice president, and John C. Rakkou a vice president.

headline: 3 Poles Defect in Canada
abstract: The first mate of a Polish freighter, his wife and child applied for political asylum in Canada today in this port on the St. Lawrence River. Pawel Urbanska, 3O years old, his wife, Lydia, also 3O, and 3-year-old Mickal ''will probably be granted asylum,'' an immigration official said.

headline: Marathon Merger Prospects; Marathon Merger Vote
abstract: A leader of dissident Marathon Oil Company stockholders conceded today that the group probably had insufficient votes to block the $6.2 billion merger between Marathon and the United States Steel Corporation.   But the group's investment consultant, James H. McElroy, said the dissidents were studying an Ohio law that gives them ''appraisal rights'' that could result in their obtaining a higher price for their shares. The dissidents complain they are not receiving enough money for their stock.

headline: Trade Deficit Recorded for 4th Quarter
abstract: The United States recorded an $85 million deficit in its balance of payments accounts with foreign countries in 1981's fourth quarter, but still finished the year with a $6.6 billion surplus, the biggest surplus since 1975, the Government reported today.   Many Government officials contend that the $85 million gap in the fourth quarter - the first after five consecutive surpluses - could be a harbinger of an overall deficit in 1982. They said a stronger dollar and reviving economies overseas make it likely that there will be a deficit of as much as $10 billion in 1982, possibly even challenging the record 1978 deficit of more than $14 billion.

headline: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: City Investing Net Rises 8.3%
abstract: The City Investing Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 increased 8.3 percent, to $23.6 million, or 64 cents a share, from $21.8 million, or 59 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues increased 7.2 percent, to $1.49 billion, from $1.39 billion.

headline: I.R.S. WINS ON TAX STRADDLES
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service has won a legal battle to prohibit the use of commodity futures straddles to postpone tax liabilities, but the victory appears to be largely symbolic because the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 banned the use of commodity tax straddles anyway.   The United States Tax Court, upholding the position that the I.R.S. has taken since 1977, ruled Monday that commodity tax staddles were solely devices to avoid paying taxes, rather than business deals aimed at making profits, and prohibited the use of paper losses on such transactions as tax deductions.   A typical tax straddle today would involve, say, the purchase of a 1982 silver futures contract and the simultaneous sale of a 1983 contract. If prices dropped, then losses on the current year's futures would be applied against taxes due by April 15, 1983, while the gains on the futures that were sold short would square the straddlers' accounts with their brokers. Also, the gain on the 1983 futures could be offset by another straddle.

headline: PROFITS FALL AT 3 OIL COMPANIES
abstract: Citing poor earnings in refining operations, the Exxon Corporation, the Standard Oil Company of California and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), three of the nation's six largest oil companies, yesterday reported earnings declines for the last quarter of 1981.   The declines, compared with the last quarter of 1980, ranged from 4.5 percent at Standard of Indiana to 20.5 percent at Exxon.  However, Exxon's figures reflected a large accounting loss because of currency transactions.   ''The figures are telling you that the refining business is still under pressure, especially overseas,'' said Constantine Fliakos, an industry analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. In most refining markets, demand from retailers of petroleum products or industrial users remains too weak for the companies to raise their prices or to operate refineries at volumes high enough for real efficiency.

headline: Aide Says Iran Will Continue Rationing of Essential Goods
abstract: Iran will continue to ration essential goods, including food and fuel, in order to save hard currency, Iran's Minister of State for Executive Affairs said today.   The official, Behzad Nabavi, said in a Teheran radio interview that the supply and currency shortages were ''normal'' considering Iran's 16-month-old war with Iraq and the ''economic war imposed on us by the United States and its allies.''

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN AIDES ' SLIP BLAMED FOR DISPUTE ON TAX EXEMPTIONS
abstract: The Reagan Administration's political embarrassment over the restoration of tax exemptions to segregated schools stemmed from a breakdown in communications on the President's staff, according to White House officials. They say this lapse caused new personal tensions within his triumvirate of senior advisers.   Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said today that he was the only adviser among the Big Three who knew more than one or two days ahead of time that the Justice and Treasury Departments planned to end the Government's 11-year ban on tax exemptions for private schools that practice racial discrimination.   Other White House officials said that Mr. Meese's two colleagues, James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, and Michael K.  Deaver, the deputy chief of staff, were angry that he did not warn them about the policy change that produced last week's controversy over the Administration's racial attitudes.   Mr. Meese said in an interview that Treasury officials told him Dec. 28 that they and officials of the Justice Department wanted to abandon the Federal court-ordered ban on such exemptions. But Mr.  Baker did not find out until the night of Jan. 6 that the Justice and Treasury officials planned to announce the new policy Jan. 8.

headline: People
abstract: * Frank C. Perkins has joined Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as an executive vice president.

headline: Polish Grain Crop Up
abstract: Poland's 1981 grain crop of 20 million tons was up 11 percent from 1980 but still fell well short of demand, an agriculture newsletter, Agra Europe, reported today. The newsletter said that Poland would have to import 7 million tons of grain to meet demand. It added that meat shortages last year were ''only partly offset'' by imports, which in the first nine months of the year ''reached the unprecedented level of 101,000 tons, 19 times more than during the same period in 1980.''

headline: R.J. Reynolds Bond
abstract: R.J. Reynolds Industries is raising a 10-year, zero-coupon Eurobond for a nominal $400 million through its overseas finance unit, bond market sources said here today. The bond is priced to yield 14.64 percent and will provide $102 million, excluding commissions, they added. The Dillon, Read Overseas Corporation is lead manager.

headline: HAMILTON BROTHERS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MINE IN SPAIN IS CRIPPLED BY PRICE SLUMP
abstract: Less then three years ago, King Juan Carlos and Alfonzo Escamez, president of Banco Central and a friend of the monarch, opened a vast open-pit metals mine near here. At the time, the project was hailed as the model investment of the post-Franco era.   As the dignitaries rolled into Aznalcollar - a low, whitewashed town of 5,000 not far from Seville -out-of-work rural laborers gathered at the roadside shouting, ''We want jobs.''   They got them. But now, following the collapse of metal prices, the mine, which was financed by the bank and lies astride what is believed to be the richest pyrite ore vein in Western Europe, is being shut down by its operator, Andaluza de Piritas.

headline: Poland Arrests a Priest On Charges of Slander
abstract: A Roman Catholic priest has been arrested and put on trial for a sermon that was said to slander the Government and Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, a Government spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Jerzy Urban, denied a West German newspaper report that the Government planned a major crackdown on the Catholic Church and a roundup of priests, and he said the Government did not seek a confrontation.

headline: U.S. FIRM ON PACT WITH ISRAEL
abstract: The United States remains unwilling to reopen a strategic cooperation agreement with Israel because of its annexation of the Golan Heights last month, the State Department said today.   But in a written statement in reponse to reporters' questions, the department said, ''We hope for a restoration of a spirit of partnership, which would include consideration by each of the broader policy interests of the other.''   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is scheduled to meet in Tel Aviv later this week with Prime Minister Menachem Begin.  Today's statement was issued after Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger said in an interview that it was Israel who had suspended the memo of understanding, which he and the Israeli Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, signed on Nov. 30. The memo outlined general terms for United States-Israeli cooperation to counter threats by the Soviet Union in the Middle East. Details were to be worked out later.

headline: Odds Favor Tax Cheats, Panel Told
abstract: An increase in tax fraud and unintentional errors may be costing the Treasury more than $70 billion a year, but the odds that cheaters will be caught are slimmer this year than ever, Government officials told Congress today.   The General Accounting Office complained before a House panel that enforcement efforts by the Internal Revenue Service are not keeping up with the increase in the number of income tax returns filed each year and with tax cheats.

headline: BIG BANKS' EARNINGS ARE MIXED
abstract: Eight major American banking companies yesterday reported fourthquarter net operating income that ranged from spectacular to disappointing.   Citicorp, for example, the nation's second-biggest bank holding company, reported that its income before securities transactions rose 126 percent compared with the fourth quarter of 1980, while earnings of the BankAmerica Corporation, the largest, plunged 47.4 percent.   In general, banks in New York and Chicago reported sharp upswings in their fourth-quarter earnings, while those on the West Coast showed declines.   Much depended on how individual banks were poised to take advantage of the decline in interest rates during the fourth quarter. For example, at times during the quarter, the prime lending rate on which banks base the interest charged to customers was as much as four percentage points higher than the interest rate paid on big certificates of deposit.

headline: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Excerpts from remarks, page A5.
abstract: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, arrived here today to an effusive welcome and a strong endorsement from Leonid I. Brezhnev.   Mr. Brezhnev and five members of the Soviet Politburo waited in biting cold at Vnokovo Airport to welcome General Jaruzelski on his first trip outside Poland since he launched the military crackdown there 11 weeks ago.   After being kissed by Mr. Brezhnev on both cheeks and after reviewing an honor guard, the Polish leader drove into the capital with the Soviet leader along a route lined for miles by crowds waving Polish and Soviet flags and hoisting portraits of the two leaders. Feted at Kremlin Dinner   After several hours of talks, General Jaruzelski and his delegation were feted at a Kremlin dinner at which Mr. Brezhnev applauded the ''timely measures'' taken by the Polish leaders to defend Communist rule. Mr. Brezhnev also emphasized the ''identical understanding of current and coming tasks'' that he said had marked the talks here.

headline: DURABLE GOODS ORDERS UP
abstract: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods rose 1.6 percent in December, the second moderate gain after a 9.8 percent plunge in October, the Commerce Department reported today.   Robert Dederick, the department's Assistant Secretary for Economic Affairs, called the report ''additional evidence that the end of the recession is approaching.'' Private economists were not that sure.

headline: AMERICAN BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CALLERS SAY DOZIER HAS BEEN KILLED
abstract: Anonymous callers who said they spoke for the Red Brigades told the newspaper La Repubblica tonight that Brig. Gen.  James L. Dozier had been slain and that his body could be found in a secluded spot about 30 miles from Pescara on the Adriatic coast.   But hours later, the Italian police reported that they had not found a body.  The calls were received at the newspaper's main office in Rome and at its Milan bureau.  About the same time, the American general's kidnappers made public a purported transcript of part of his interrogation by a ''people's court.'' According to the transcript, whose authenticity could not immediately be verified, General Dozier, who was kidnapped from his home in Verona on Dec. 17, told his captors little more than the stages of his military career.

headline: U.S. MISSIONARY SLAIN OUTSIDE GUATEMALAN SCHOOL
abstract: A 37-year-old American missionary from Wisconsin was killed outside his school in western Guatemala by four unidentified gunmen, United States Embassy officials here said today.    The officials said the assassins, who wore hoods, fired submachine guns from a speeding car.  The victim, Brother James Arnold Miller of the Christian Brothers order, was the third American churchman to be slain in Guatemala in seven months. He had been doing missionary work in Central America for nine years, first in Nicaragua and in Guatemala since last year.

headline: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADORANS' U.S. CAMPAIGN: SELLING OF REVOLUTION
abstract: A few minutes before midnight, the two guerrilla leaders from El Salvador and their Mexican host broke off the conversation and switched on the video recorder.   The opening scenes from the NBC News ''Today'' show flashed on the screen, recorded earlier from a widely available cable television link to the United States. As Bryant Gumbel and Jane Pauley previewed the program, the two insurgent leaders watched expectantly. Then the event they wanted to see came on, an interview with one of the guerrillas' military leaders, Cayetano Carpio.

headline: STAGNATION IS FORECAST FOR STEEL
abstract: The steel industry is facing an uphill struggle in the new year.  Some analysts believe that steel shipments, already faltering, may decline in 1982 and provoke new layoffs, a sampling of industry opinion shows.   Shipments of domestically made steel have fallen in recent months because of a continued drop in demand from the automotive, appliance and construction industries. In addition, imports since September have taken a record high of about 24 percent of the market.

headline: SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANS ADVANCE
abstract: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which expects to have $14.8 billion available by June to aid sponsors of development projects, today identified 27 applicants from among whom the first recipients of funds would be selected.   The 27, whose projects are situated in 14 states, are those that responded by the Jan.4 deadline to requests by the Governmentsponsored corporation for additional information. Since 63 applications had originally been filed, this suggested that sponsors of 36 either were not yet prepared to carry through their plans or had decided to abandon them. The projects are heavily concentrated in the West.

headline: Banana Pickers End Strike
abstract: About 4,000 banana pickers were expected to go back to work today after reaching an agreement to end a 37-day strike that cost the Standard Fruit Company about $3 million, a company spokesman said.

headline: DOW GAINS 4.29
abstract: The stock market moved slightly higher yesterday in a session marked by gains in special situations and price declines in the airline group.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.29 points, to 827.63.  Volume climbed to 52 million shares from Wednesday's 49.4 million.  MCA Inc. gained 3 3/8, to 51 3/4. The company plans to separate real estate holdings from its various entertainment operations.  Cities Service rose 2 1/4, to 29 3/4, in active trading. The company was often rumored last year as a takeover target and analysts said that rumors arose again yesterday.

headline: PROJECT TO SHIP GAS FROM ARCTIC NEARS APPROVAL IN CANADA
abstract: Less than 1,000 miles from the North Pole lies a rich field of natural gas that, by 1986, is expected to flow to homes in eastern Canada and, indirectly, to increase the supply of gas to the United States.   The Arctic Pilot Project, one of Canada's boldest attempts to exploit its northern resources, is in the final stages of approval, and construction is to begin when the National Energy Board and the Government give the expected green light in midyear.   The project is being proposed by a group of Canadian companies led by the Government-owned Petro-Canada. The other partners are Dome, Nova and Melville Shipping, while Panarctic Oils will produce the gas and TransCanada Pipelines will distribute it.

headline: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRADERS ARE WARY ON MONEY SUPPLY
abstract: Rapid growth in the nation's money supply has created a minor furor in the credit markets, where interest rates have been generally rising since the end of November.   Higher short-term rates are taking a toll on the long-term credit markets. Investor demand there is very weak, dealers say.  Institutional salesmen conclude that buyers are content with shortterm investments yielding higher than 14 percent and are waiting to select new issues from the forthcoming Treasury sales.

headline: AMERICAN SHIPBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN GIVES ITALIAN A STRONG WELCOME
abstract: In ceremonies filled with expressions of American friendship, tribute and gratitude, President Reagan welcomed President Sandro Pertini of Italy to the White House today.   Mr. Reagan used the occasion of Mr. Pertini's nine-day visit to the United States to express the appreciation of Americans for the rescue by Italian policemen Jan. 28 of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, who had been held captive for 42 days by Red Brigades terrorists.   Tonight, General Dozier sat at President Reagan's table and President Pertini sat at another table with Nancy Reagan at a state dinner at the White House. Entertainment was provided by Frank Sinatra and Perry Como.

headline: STOCK TABLES
abstract: To the Business Editor: Daily bond tables, too.  SIMEON H.F. GOLDSTEIN New York, N.Y., Feb. 8, 1982

headline: Around the World; Salvador Rebels Proclaim Capture of Key Town
abstract: Guerrillas said today that they had captured Jocaitique, a town 100 miles northeast of the capital, after a long battle with Government troops. The assertion was denied by a military spokesman.

headline: NEWFOUNDLAND LIGHT & POWER CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: As Ads Come to China, So Do Regulations
abstract: China, which is just beginning to discover advertising, has already decided to regulate it. How's that for learning fast?  According to Business Asia, a newsletter published by the Business International Corporation, China's State Council recently passed legislation that will, among other things, require that indiginous agencies to be licensed by the state and that food and medicine advertising be certified by the public health authorities.   Finally - and this may be going too far - the rules forbid advertising that exaggerates and covers up defects.

headline: National Patent
abstract: The National Patent Development Corporation of New York, a maker of medical and optical products including soft contact lenses, said a Federal court in California had denied a request by Continuous Curve Contact Lens Inc., a Revlon subsidiary, for a stay of the injunction granted by the court Feb. 5 prohibiting Continuous Curve from manufacturing or distributing its Bufilcon soft contact lenses. The injunction is effective in 30 days unless Continuous Curve obtains a stay. National Patent said that the Feb. 5 ruling held that Continuous Curve had willfully and deliberately infringed its patents.

headline: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: City Stores Sale
abstract: The City Stores Company, a major retail concern, announced signing of a previously reported agreement to sell three of its Maison Blanche suburban department stores in the New Orleans area to Goudchaux's Inc., a retail company based in Baton Rouge, La. Terms of the transaction, expected to be completed in February, were not disclosed. The stores will continue to operate under the Maison Blanche name.

headline: IRAN APPEARS TO WIN KEY BATTLE POSITIONS HELD BY IRAQI FORCES
abstract: An eight-day offensive by Iranian forces has apparently pushed the invading Iraqi Army 24 miles back from strategic positions west of this southern Iranian city, battlefield inspections showed today.   The Iraqis have occupied southwestern Iran since October 1980.

headline: Vanity Fair Ad Discount
abstract: Joseph E. Corr Jr., publisher of Vanity Fair, which Conde Nast plans to revive next year, has devised an interesting discount inducement for a certain class of advertiser.   Any company that ran an ad in the original magazine, which was the talk of the chic set from 1914 to 1936, will be offered a 5 percent discount on ads in the new version.

headline: Most Ankara Businesses Shut Because of Pollution
abstract: The Governor of Ankara ordered all industries and businesses to close down until further notice today as pollution rose alarmingly. Only hospitals and bakeries were excluded from the ban.

headline: POLES REACTING TO ARMY WITH MIXED FEELINGS. . .
abstract: The other day a Polish housewife looked out her window and saw three soldiers manning a roadblock, swinging their arms and stamping on the packed snow to try to get warm. She promptly made a pot of coffee and took it to them.   A few hours later, across town, a captain in uniform and a man who looked like a plainclothes security agent barged to the front of the line in the Europejske Hotel restaurant. They demanded, and got, a table instantly while others grumbled. T hese are the people who are going to run Poland, said one young woman with long red hair. The cinkciarz (pe tty thieves).

headline: Japan Research Spending Rises
abstract: Japan spent $23.9 billion on research in the fiscal year 1980, making it second only to the United States in research outlays, the Prime Minister's office reported today.

headline: India Expels Iraqi Aide
abstract: India today expelled an assistant attache at the Iraqi Consulate who shot and wounded the son of the manager of a restaurant in Bombay. A Foreign Ministry official said the attache, Abdul Razzak Khalaf, was ordered to leave India immediately.

headline: DEFENDING THE PRICE OF RUBBER
abstract: Defending the ''blue line'' is John J.  Reidl's specialty.  He doesn't play hockey; he plays the world's rubber market. He is manager of the International Natural Rubber Organization's buffer stock, and thousands of the world's rubber producers rely on him to keep international rubber prices from getting out of hand.   The ''blue line'' that Mr. Reidl defends is the price below which the world's rubber producers begin to suffer the effects of overproduction. At those levels, small-scale rubber growers, whom the rubber organization was established to protect, cannot make a living by tapping their rubber trees.

headline: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BREZHNEV OFFERS DEEP ARMS CUTS IN EUROPE BY '90
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev today proposed a two-thirds cut in United States and Soviet arsenals of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe by 1990.   The Soviet leader coupled the proposal with an attack on the United States policy of linking progress on arms control to other issues, such as the military takeover in Poland.   ''It is madness for any country to build its policy with an eye to nuclear war,'' he said, charging that the United States was avoiding serious negotiations on medium-range weapons and was using ''various far-fetched pretexts'' to put off the resumption of talks on strategic, or intercontinental, nuclear arms.  Elaboration of November Offer   Mr. Brezhnev's proposal for a two-thirds cut in medium-range weapons was an elaboration of a plan he put forward during a visit to Bonn in November. On that occasion, he offered to reduce Soviet forces by ''hundreds of units'' if the United States did the same.

headline: Public Relations Firms Big Gainers for 1981
abstract: Jack O'Dwyer, newsletter editor, who cares enough about how the public relations firms are doing to put out a directory each year on their standings, reports that, although a number of the firms had flat years in 1981, or actual declines, there were a number of winners, too.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: IS SILENT ON CROP
abstract: The Soviet Government issued its annual economic report for 1981 today and it confirmed previous indications of a gloomy year on most fronts.   In a break with precedent, the report, issued by the Government's Central Statistical Administration, omitted altogether the size of last year's grain harvest, suggesting that the figure is so low as to be politically embarrassing.   The report merely said that farmers had struggled with ''extremely unfavorable conditions'' and that ''state resources of grain will insure a full supply of bread and bread products.'' Crisis Over Poland May Be Factor   Among explanations put forward by Western diplomats for the omission of the grain figures was a reluctance to give the United States a propaganda lever at a time of tension, particularly in view of the threat of a new grain embargo in retaliation for Moscow's purported role in Poland's military crackdown.

headline: BUNKER HILL MINING TO END OPERATIONS
abstract: COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, Jan. 20 (AP) - The Bunker Hill Company, a mining complex, will close ''as quickly as possible,'' its owner said today after efforts to find a buyer failed. Bunker Hill had produced 20 percent of the nation's lead, zinc and silver.

headline: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger spent most of last week touring the Middle East trying to strengthen American military ties with the Arab nations and talking about redirecting policy away from Israel.   Other Administration officials, led by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and including some Pentagon officials, are insisting that there is no change in Middle East policy, and especially no redirection away from Israel.   Does this Administration have a policy toward the Middle East? And does it favor one side over the other? Decisions on Ad Hoc Basis   The answer to the first question appears to be no. By all accounts, President Reagan has yet to hammer out the differences between his two Secretaries and formulate a policy. Decisions are made on an ad hoc basis from week to week.

headline: Phelps Dodge
abstract: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it had cut the bond ra ting of the Phelps Do dge Corporation, a major copper producer, to Baa from A because the c ompany's profit margins, cash flow and fixed charge coverage were currently at cyclically depressed levels.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A LAW TO AUGMENT PHONE DEAL SOUGHT
abstract: The proposed settlement of the antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has increased, not lessened, the need for legislation, a key member of the House said today.   Representative Timothy E. Wirth, chairman of the telecommunications subcommittee, said the settlement was fine as far as it went but that it failed to resolve several major issues such as local telephone rates.   Without ''complementary'' legislation to safeguard consumers, the Colorado Democrat asserted, the settlement could lead to an immediate 50 percent increase in local phone rates and a decline in the quality of the phone network.

headline: No Headline
abstract: POLAND'S PRIMATE CITES NEW ARRESTS UNDER ARMY RULE   WARSAW, Jan. 17 (By United Press International) - Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, said today that new arrests were being made under martial law, and he criticized the military regime anew for its campaign to extract loyalty oaths from Poles.   ''We still see a lack of something there, we hear too much about people's sufferings, we hear about more arrests, and there are such a lot of internees who wait to be released to rejoin work, activity and mutual aid,'' the Archbishop told an overflowing congregation of about 5,000 at Warsaw's St. Karol Boromeo Church.   ''Not only those interned, but also many other groups of people suffer because they must or are persuaded to sign declarations that are contrary to their views and their conscience and, what is more, these people are fired from their jobs.'' 'No One Is Going to Help Us!'

headline: Diamonds
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''Selling a Diamond Could Take Forever'' (Feb. 14) was welcome confirmation of a viewpoint I've been expressing since I first started making and marketing my Wellington counterfeit diamonds.   I have been in the counterfeit diamond business since 1966. I believe that our success can be attributed to two very important marketing facts: 1) Diamonds are the most popular of all stones, but not within the price range of most people. 2) A vast number of people are quite aware that diamonds are not a good investment.  MADAME WELLINGTON Washington, D.C., Feb. 18, 1982

headline: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
abstract: * Atlantic Richfield Overseas Finance N.V. is offering $500 million zero coupon notes due 1992 at price of 25.75 percent, to be offered through a Salomon Brothers group.   * Flowers Industries filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 614,853 common shares, to be sold through a Merrill Lynch group.

headline: Bill Is Introduced to Prevent U.S. Moves Against Managua
abstract: The chairman of a House subcommittee introduced a bill today to prevent the Reagan Administration from aiding any clandestine operation against the Sandinist Government in Nicaragua.   Representative Michael D. Barnes, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the Subcommittee on Inter-American Affairs of the Foreign Affairs Committee, said the legislation was intended to prevent an episode such as the Bay of Pigs incident in 1961 in which Cuban exiles tried to invade Cuba.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Financial Corp. said it had increased its stake in the Penn Central Corp. to the equivalent of 16.4 percent, or 4,788,221 common shares, including 325,000 Penn Central common shares purchased between March 8 and March 10 for a total cost of $7.4 million.   * Arvin Industries and McGraw-Edison Co. announced an agreement in principle under which Arvin will buy McGraw-Edison's international metal products division, based in Phoenix.

headline: TIN MARKET SQUEEZE IS EASING
abstract: Tin users, who have anxiously watched the metal's price climb steadily in recent months, are breathing a bit more easily. In recent days, the price of tin has fallen sharply, and dealers now say that the squeeze that was expected to wreak havoc in the tin market as early as the end of this week probably will not occur.   ''It appears that crunch dates and squeezes and such were overplayed,'' said Bruce Leeming, a director of Rudolf Wolff & Company, metals dealers.   Since July, unnamed buyers who are widely thought to have represented a consortium of tin-producing countries had been pushing the price steadilyhigher by amassing a stockpile estimated at 50,000 metric tons or more. The open market price eventually climbed to about $16,700, or 9,000, a ton three weeks ago from $10,200 before the buying began. A metric ton is about 2,204 pounds.

headline: U.S. Dismisses Charge It Delays Soviet Talks
abstract: The Reagan Administration today brushed aside as ''propaganda'' Soviet complaints of needless delay in talks on reduction of strategic arms and said it would not go ahead before it thinks the time is right.   Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, called Wednesday for a quick resumption of American-Soviet talks on limiting strategic, chemical and conventional arms and said the Soviet Union was ready to reach agreements in all three fields.

headline: NICARAGUANS FIND IT HARD TO BELIEVE WARNING THEY'RE FACING WAR AGAIN
abstract: Nicaraguans are responding to the Government's warning of an imminent American-backed invasion with a sense of disbelief mixed with a kind of precautionary panic. Many people here also seem to have suspended judgment on whether the Government's 30-day state of emergency is justified.   In a restaurant here, a young Foreign Ministry official sighed as she lost interest in her food. ''I can't believe it's all going to happen again,'' she said, recalling the 1979 revolution, ''that we're going to have another war so soon.''

headline: Dior-New York Hires A J.W.T. Subsidiary
abstract: Christian Dior-New York, maker of men's and women's clothing, thinks that its advertising needs have outgrown its in-house capability.

headline: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

headline: ARGENTINES DEBATE KILLING 48,000 PENGUINS A YEAR
abstract: A proposal to slaughter 48,000 penguins a year has brought court suits and contradictory statements in Argentina.   An Argentine company has proposed the two-year pilot project as a rational culling of the country's huge penguin colonies to produce protein for food, and many Government officials support the idea.  Argentina has prohibited the hunting of penguins and many other marine animals in its waters since 1974.   Critics of the plan, including most conservation groups, say it is designed to turn penguins into gloves and other luxury leather products that are in great demand on world markets.

headline: Investing;$
abstract: D ESPITE more than a year of lackluster markets and declining trading volume, the commodity futures fund, or pool as it is better known, has become one of the fastest-growing alternate investments around.   The number of pools registered with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission grew to 827 last year, up from 752 in 1980 and 532 in 1979. And many in the industry believe that if unregistered pools were added, the total today would be more than 1,700.   ''It's easy t o understand why investors are attracted to these pools,'' said Jay Klopfenstein, president of Norwood Securities Inc., a Chicago brokerage house that doesn't handle commodities business. ''These investors enjoy the high le verage of the futures market, without worrying about margin calls o r making trading decisions in markets that change from minute to minute. As with securities, the pool investors always know th e maximum amount of capital they can lose.''

headline: General Tire Reports Loss
abstract: The General Tire and Rubber Company, citing a $57.6 million provision for plant closings, said today that it lost $34.5 million in the first quarter of 1982.

abstract: Businessmen broke ranks on President Reagan's fiscal policies. The Business Roundtable, made up of top executives, rejected his proposed budget deficits and was said to have backed a deferral of personal tax cuts.   OPEC plans an emergency consultation this month to discuss price declines. Britain slashed the price of its North Sea oil by $4 a barrel, putting further pressure on prices. The Saudis said they planned to curtail output.

headline: Other Business; BUTTONS UP
abstract: For years, the American button has been on the defensive.  Hi-tech closures such as nylon zippers, snaps, and velcro fasteners closed out many a button maker.  Straight button imports also hurt, as did imports of buttonequipped clothes, which now account for half the apparel sales in the United States. Many a button maker turned into a jobber, or distributor, of imported buttons.

headline: Lukens Plea On Dumping
abstract: The Lukens Steel Company announced today that it had received a favorable ruling from the Department of Commerce regarding its antidumping complaint against the Japan Steel Works.   Lukens said that the Government agency's preliminary findings indicated that the Japan Steel Works had been guilty of selling clad stainless steel in this country at 14 percent less than fair value.

headline: Kaiser Closing 2 More Potlines
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it would shut down another two aluminum potlines because of continued slow demand.

headline: TWO BRITONS RACE THE SUN TO THE NORTH POLE
abstract: Two British explorers are pressing toward the North Pole in a race to get there and off the ice before the spring thaw makes travel impossible.   If they can reach the pole by the middle of April and make it on over the top before the ice melts, they will be able to get back home to England on schedule in late summer, after traveling 52,000 miles in a three-year expedition around the world from pole to pole.   But if they do not, they will have to go back to their base camp at Alert on Ellesmere Island, the northernmost part of Canada's Northwest Territories, and wait until next spring, when there will again be enough ice and daylight for this leg of the journey.   They have already been delayed in recent weeks by a devastating fire at their camp and then by the loss of one of their snowmobiles in the ice.

headline: The Week in Business; CONSUMER PRICES RISE, BUT NOT BY MUCH
abstract: Consumer prices rose just four-tenths of a percent in December, the Labor Department reported. For the year, they were up only 8.9 percent, the lowest annual increase since 1977. The December increase translates to a compound annual rate of 5.2 percent.

headline: Advertising; Taking the Chaos Out Of Co-ops
abstract: THERE'S one thing that retail advertising experts agree on when it comes to co-op advertising. There's a awful lot of it around that is going unspent. That brings them sorrow.  But cooperative advertising budgets are difficult things to administer and most national ad agencies either do not know how to administer them or have no desire to do so. Two, however, maintain specialty units to help manufacturers who have programs: Sawdon & Bess, a subsidiary of Ted Bates/ Worldwide, and W.B. Doner & Company, Baltimore.

headline: POPE TO NIGERIANS: DEFEND THE FAMILY
abstract: Pope John Paul II said mass today for hundreds of thousands of Nigerian Catholics at the outskirts of this city, which was a battleground that changed hands many times during the country's civil war.   The crowd, mostly Ibo tribesmen from this province in eastern Nigeria that briefly seceded to form the independent nation of Biafra, overflowed with enthusiasm when the Pope, on the first full day of his African journey, landed in a helicopter.   The people chanted, danced and waved paper papal flags of yellow and white and Nigerian ones in green and white. The bitter civil war that put down the secession is forgotten, former Biafrans said, and no one referred to it.

headline: General Tire Plant To Close
abstract: The General Tire and Rubber Company announced today it would close its tiremaking operation here within a year. The plant is the last major tire factory in Akron, a city once synonymous with rubber.   M.G. O'Neil, chairman and president of the nation's fifth-largest tiremaker, said only 185 of the 1,018 hourly and 247 salaried employees would be retained at the facility once tiremaking ended.  Earlier, 421 workers were laid off. The retained workers will be involved in rubber mixing, janitorial and mechanical work that will continue at the facility, but they will not make tires.

headline: Texaco Closings
abstract: T exaco U.S. A., a unit of Texaco Inc., said that it would close its refineries in West Tulsa, Okla., and Casper, Wyo., because both have been marginal in operating efficiency.

headline: United States comments, page A6.
abstract: The United States dismissed Leonid I.  Brezhnev's announcement today of a freeze in deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe as ''a propaganda gesture'' designed to leave the Soviet Union free to gain ''unchallenged hegemony over Europe.''   With unusual speed, the Reagan Administration responded within hours to deride the Soviet leader's announcement that he would stop deploying intermediate-range missiles in Europe so long as the United States did not go ahead with plans next year for a new generation of missiles.   Officials said they were concerned that the Soviet proposal for a nuclear freeze would gain support in this country and particularly in Europe where there have been demonstrations against nuclear weapons. A senior State Department official said that the Russians were trying to ''derail'' Western plans for deploying missiles to end the Soviet advantage.

headline: Tax Leasing Is Supported By Executives
abstract: Industry's ability to modernize and create jobs will be severely hampered if Congress yields to ''political hysteria'' and repeals tax-leasing provisions, corporate executives said today.   ''Stop horsing around with the tax laws,'' Charles D. Dickey, chairman of the Scott Paper Company, said prior to testifying before the Senate Finance Committee. ''To now suddenly change the rules for the whole game would be the worst thing for the economy.''

headline: KUWAIT SEARCHES FOR A GULF PEACE
abstract: Kuwait, a small, highly vulnerable nation wedged in between big and powerful neighbors, is dismayed by the new escalation of the Iran-Iraq war and by Iran's rejection of what is seen here as Iraqi attempts to end the conflict through negotiation.   The Iranians launched an offensive last week northwest of Ahwaz, the capital of Khuzistan, and the Iraqis claim to have stopped the advance with a counteroffensive.   Though struggling to keep a facade of neutrality, Kuwait is reluctantly but deeply involved on the Iraqi side.  Kuwait, though supporting Iraq, has not broken diplomatic relations with Iran. This is not the style of the Kuwaitis who are pragmatic and cautious. The Iranian Ambassador here is one of the most active diplomats in town. Food and other nonmilitary supplies for Iran are said to have crossed the Persian Gulf in modest quantities from here.

headline: Grace Chief to Head Federal Study Panel
abstract: President Reagan yesterday announced the appointment of J. Peter Grace, the chairman and chief executive officer of W.R. Grace & Company, as chairman of a new private-sector study group that will report to the President on ways to cut Government operating costs.  The new group will be modeled on a similar one that Mr. Reagan established while Governor of California. It will be called the Private Sector Survey on Cost Control.

headline: NUBIANS SETTLE BY FLOODED HOMELAND
abstract: The man had last seen his Nubian village, Adendan, in 1963, just before it and two dozen other centuries-old settlements were submer ged by the vast artifi cal lake created by the construction of the Aswan High Dam.   He pointed to an expanse of blue water girded by silky sand dunes, and said: ''It was there - the fields, the date palms, the houses with doors opening onto the Nile. All drowned.'' His voice cracked and he walked away long enough to regain his composure.

abstract: Jesuit leaders summoned to a weeklong meeting here were told today that they must curb a trend toward liberalism and follow the Pope's conservative policies.   The meeting was attended by all 86 provincial superiors of the 26,622-member Society of Jesus.

headline: FIELD RISES $1 IN HEAVY TRADING
abstract: Marshall Field & Company stock rose sharply yesterday in hectic trading. Wall Street analysts speculated that a takeover battle for the major Chicago retailer could develop despite Marshall Field's acceptance Tuesday of a $310 million bid by Batus Inc.   Fran Blechman, who follows retailing for the Wall Street firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, remarked: ''We haven't heard any names. But the stock is so strong, it may be implying that there is some other interested company out there.''

headline: A Top Official in India I s Convicted of Extortion
abstract: The Bombay High Court convicted the chief minister of Maharashtra state of extortion today.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: TED TURNER, the pride of Atlanta and the talk of the cable industry, has an advertising card up his sleeve that should double the amount of talk.   It is a $4 million advertising campaign to promote his Cable News Network that will begin next Monday with five pages in each of the three news weeklies in issues dated March 22, costing almost $700,000. That will be followed by a four-page insert in the April 3 TV Guide. The potential readership is 86 million.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Differ Over E.D.S.
abstract: THE Electronic Data Systems Corporation is doing well at a time when some other computer service companies are suffering in the recession.   Yet E.D.S. shares have declined with the rest of the market.  S elling as hi gh as 25 in late December, they closed yesterday at 22, up 3/8.   E.D.S. first became popular with investors as a pioneer processor of Blue Cross, Blue Shield, Medicaid and Medicare claims. Under its flamboyant founder, H. Ross Perot, a former I.B.M. salesman, E.D.S.  enjoyed explosive growth from its beginnings in 1962 until late in the decade.

headline: REAGAN'S SALVADOR RIGHTS REPORT: THE BALANCE SHEET
abstract: Ambassador Deane R. Hinton of the United States told a gathering of Salvadoran business executives recently that there had been ''serious excesses'' in human rights abuses in their country. And a report he sent to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. noted that Government soldiers were responsible for most of the unexplained killings here.   Nonetheless, President Reagan has ''certified'' that the Salvadoran Government has made significant progress in reducing human rights violations - a certification necessary to the continuance of American aid.   The President's certification Jan. 28 would appear to contradict Ambassador Hinton's public declarations and his embassy's report. But most embassy officials defend the President's action, in part because they say there are some indications of a decline in the violence.  They have also disparaged El Salvador's human rights organizations, whose statistics paint a much bleaker picture of the human rights situation than do the embassy's.

headline: AFRIKAANS PRESS GOADS BOTHA ON NEED FOR CHANGE
abstract: ''We are waiting, Mr. Botha, we are waiting!'' That note of exasperation, sounded in an article on the need for effective political change, would have been regarded as part of a dreary ritual if it had appeared in an editorial in one of the opposition English-language newspapers.   But it cropped up just before the white Parliament opened in January in a signed article by Ton Vosloo, editor of an Afrikaanslanguage daily called Beeld. That was a sure sign the vague and sometimes contradictory hints Prime Minister P.W. Botha had been dropping for several years about his plans for change were starting to wear thin with those who had taken them most seriously.   Mr. Vosloo, a 44-year-old former political reporter, is widely held to be running the most vigorous and influential Afrikaans paper in the country. One result is that no South African journalist is thought to have readier access to the Prime Minister. A politician with a notoriously short fuse, Mr. Botha makes sure the communication is not one-way. When he is displeased, Mr. Vosloo gets the message promptly and directly by phone.

headline: CONRAIL: WALL ST. GETS ABROAD
abstract: With its troubled history, Conrail has hardly been a name to bring a glint to the eyes of Wall Street's deal makers. Even so, investment bankers are beating a path to Conrail's door, vying for a piece of business - the Government's sale of Conrail - that could bring some of the highest fees in the history of Wall Street.   ''All of a sudden, investment bankers have been written into a good deal,'' said John M. Fowler, general counsel of the Department of Transportation. ''We have to sell Conrail and we couldn't do so without paying an investment banking house an enormous amount of money.''   Those fees could easily run up to $20 million, according to Mr.  Fowler. That amount, however, is still below the fees that individual investment houses cleared for such celebrated deals as the United States Steel-Marathon merger or the Du Pont-Conoco union. The Conrail fees would come from the proceeds of the sale and would, in effect, be paid by the buyer of Conrail, not by the United States Treasury.

headline: Bonn Military Spending Up
abstract: West Germany said today that it increased military spending by a real 3.4 percent last year. It said that within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization the rate of increase was second only to that reported by the United States.

headline: Seiko and China In Watch Pact
abstract: The Seiko Group, Japan's largest watchmaker, announced it had reached agreement with China to establish a joint venture company in Hong Kong to assemble watches for worldwide export.

headline: Economic Affairs; LEASING: A GOOD PILL FOR SICK COMPANIES
abstract: ''L EASING'' is becoming a bad word, especially when it refers to the provision of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 that removes all restraints on one corporation leasing equipment from another.  Previously, such leases were prohibited if they were undertaken solely to gain some tax advantage. Now they can be freely used as a device for selling tax deductions and investment tax credits whenever a company making a new investment acquires more deductions and credits than it can use against operating profits.  Some free-market conservatives see leasing as a form of welfare for the corporate sector. Alan Greenspan has been quoted as saying that leasing is ''sort of the equivalent of food stamps for undernourished corporations.'' Liberals see it as providing one more tax loophole for rich capitalists. As the need for more and more tax revenues becomes apparent, it is safe to predict that leasing will come under constant attack.

headline: Careers; Counseling Dismissed Employees
abstract: WHILE the recession is deepening, the so-called outplacement business is booming. Outplacement involves professional third-party job guidance for an employee who is about to be dismissed. The employer pays for the service.   James H. Kennedy, who publishes the Directory of Outplacement Firms, estimated that the industry has revenues of more than $60 million annually, with about 82 firms accounting for about 85 percent of the business.

headline: Radio Marti Head Named
abstract: President Reagan today named F. Clifton White, a longtime Republican Party official, to head Radio Marti, the United States broadcasting initiative designed to counter anti-American broadcasts from Cuba. The initiative, named for Jose Marti, leader of the Cuban drive for independence, is expected to get under way some time later this year.

headline: I.R.A. SUSPECT SENT TO IRELAND
abstract: Desmond Mackin, a suspected member of the outlawed Irish Republican Army who was deported from the United States, arrived in Ireland today and was allowed to enter the country unhindered.   Mr. Mackin, a 27-year-old former taxi driver from Belfast, Northern Ireland, is accused of shooting a British soldier in Northern Ireland in 1978.
