headline: NEW I.C.C. RAIL POLICY MAY AID LARGE CARRIERS
abstract: The Interstate Commerce Commission, as part of its program to eliminate unnecessary regulations and increase competition, today dropped a 30-year policy of protecting competing railroads from the marketing strategies of merged railroads, the agency said.   Reese H. Taylor Jr., chairman of the commission, said that the policy change, which has emerged after two years of work, ''means that consolidating railroads for the first time will be in a position to pass along to their customers more of the benefits made possible by mergers.''   The new policy, which puts an end to formulas for distributing business, applies to past mergers, including the huge Conrail system, as well as proposed mergers, Mr. Taylor said. Transportation analysts see the changes as a significant benefit to many large rail carriers and a sharp setback to smaller ones that depend on connecting traffic.

headline: Seal Hunt Protesters Buzzed by Canadians
abstract: Protesters against Canada's annual seal hunt were buzzed by a Government helicopter today when they reached the outskirts of a giant seal herd.   Reporters on the Rainbow Warrior, the ship from which the Greenpeace conservation group is mounting its protest, said a Coast Guard helicopter flew low over a dozen protesters and journalists on an ice floe in the St Lawrence Gulf.   They were walking to photograph a seal when the helicopter flew 30 to 60 feet above them.

headline: President Is Elected At Parker Pen Unit
abstract: Manville D. Smith, 42 years old, has been elected president of the Parker Pen Company's writing instrument group, which is responsible for 31 percent of the corporation's sales and 55 percent of its earnings. He succeeds Willi F. Sieberger, 60, who resigned from the Janesville, Wis., company for personal reasons.   In the seven months since he joined Parker, Mr. Smith said: ''We've been conducting a very profound self-examination. We have to have the ability to respond to what the market requires and, if you will, become a market-driven company instead of a product-driven company.  We're in the process now of identifying the available opportunities.''

headline: Around the World; Bonn's Budget Passes; Gives Military 'Problems'
abstract: The West German Parliament approved an austere 1982 federal budget today that Bonn's Defense Minister, Dr. Hans Apel, said would confront the armed forces with ''serious problems.''   After three days of sometimes heated debate, Parliament voted 262 to 214, with 1 abstention, to approve the $104.5 billion budget, a 3.2 percent increase over 1981.

headline: WALL ST. SETS UP SHOP IN SINGAPORE
abstract: Wall Street, already well entrenched in Hong Kong, is establishing a permanent presence in Singapore.  In quick succession, five brokerage houses - Dean Witter Reynolds, Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Drexel Burnham Lambert, Shearson Loeb Rhoades and an affiliate of the First Boston Corporation - have opened offices in the island nation at the southern tip of Asia's Malayan peninsula.   And now Merrill Lynch International, which has been operating in Singapore for a decade, has decided to almost double its office space there by renting the 26th floor of the 46-story Raffles Tower, still under construction. The building is named after Sir Stamford Raffles, who helped develop Britain's China trade in the 19th century.

headline: Around the World; Carter Calls Protesters At Embassy in Moscow
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter telephoned the United States Embassy in Moscow today in an effort to persuade two Russian Pentecostalists taking refuge there to give up a three-week protest fast. He failed.

headline: A NONUNION TRUCKER'S RISE
abstract: In 1977, Sal Cotta, president of Polar Transport Inc., thought his trucking company had reached a dead end.  Then the Interstate Commerce Commission, over the objections of established carriers, allowed Polar to haul freight for three more companies, giving it a total of nine, on routes mostly on the East Coast. In doing so, however, it warned Polar that as a carrier restricted to serving only certain shippers it had reached the limit of its authority.   ''It was an unwritten rule, when you got up to seven or eight contracts, you generally got no more than that,'' said Mr. Cotta, a short energetic man with a ready smile.   But all that has changed. With the passage of a law in 1980 bringing partial deregulation to the trucking industry, Polar and other companies like it now have much more freedom to expand operations. Indeed, since the signing of the Motor Carrier Act, the I.C.C. says it has approved 91 percent of all applications for broader operating authority.

headline: Whittaker Profit Up
abstract: The Whittaker Corporation, currently engaged in a struggle to acquire the Brunswick Corporation, today reported improved fiscal first-quarter earnings. Whittaker said net income for the quarter ending Jan. 31 increased 23.8 percent, to $18.2 million, or $1.14 a share, from $14.7 million, or 95 cents a share, a year ago. The Los Angeles conglomerate said sales were up 5.9 percent, to $404.4 million, from $382 million.

headline: MAN WHO SUED K.G.B. IS JAILED
abstract: A 36-year-old auto mechanic who sued the K.G.B.  paid for his temerity today when a Moscow court sentenced him to a year in jail for parasitism and forbade him to live in Moscow for five years after he is released.   When the suit came up for hearing in a Moscow court three months ago, the mechanic, Viktor Tomachinsky, said he was the first person ever to bring a civil action against the K.G.B., the secret police.

headline: AILING ECONOMY IS KEY ISSUE
abstract: The people of Ireland voted for a new government today for the second time in eight months. The dismal state of the economy overshadowed the violence in Northern Ireland as a campaign issue.   Opinion polls in the final days of the three-week campaign indicated that the election was so close that none of the parties might gain a working majority in Parliament. Thirteen nationalist candidates from Northern Ireland were believed to have little chance of winning seats.

headline: Interest Rates Move Lower
abstract: Short- and long-term rates declined yesterday as lower financing costs encouraged traders to increase prices for most outstanding debt securities.   Securities dealers said investor buying of notes and bonds was modest, with the exception of the Treasury's new 14 percent notes due in May 1987. Speculative buying by traders continued to fuel higher prices for other note and bond issues, while lower overnight interest rates were the most important reason for lower short-term rates.   By late in the day, the Treasury's three-month bills closed at 11.97 percent, down from 12.27 percent Tuesday, while the 14 percent Treasury bonds due in 2011 closed at 102 7/8 to yield 13.6 percent, up three-fourths of a point.

headline: Coke's Net Rose 10.8%
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its net income rose 10.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, to $106.2 million, or 86 cents a share, from $95.8 million, or 78 cents a share, in the last quarter of 1980.   The Atlanta-based company, which earlier this year agreed to pay $760 million for Columbia Pictures, reported that sales in the fourth quarter fell 1.4 percent, to $1.41 billion, from $1.43 billion in the last quarter of 1980.

headline: BANKS INCREASING FEES FOR LOANS AND SERVICES TO INDIVIDUAL CLIENTS
abstract: Interest rates and fees paid by individuals for banking services are rising dramatically as banks across the country try to make more money on their retail services or reverse losses.   Even as interest rates have declined for big corporations and financial institutions over the past half year, rates have been rising for consumers. Just last week, for example, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced that the interest rate on its credit card loans would rise by 10 percent, to 19.8 percent from 18 percent, effective March 1.   Over all, the effective cost of most consumer-banking services is being shifted from those who maintain large deposit balances to people with smaller accounts, who bankers contend have not paid the full cost of service. And some bankers are questioning whether individuals with only a few hundred dollars of savings belong in the banking system at all.

headline: No Headline
abstract: U.S. SUED ON PLAN FOR POLISH DEBT   WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (By STUART TAYLOR Jr., Spec ial to the New York Times) - A business-oriented legal foundation asked Federal District Judge Oliver Gasch today to bar the Reagan Administration from paying off $71 million owed by Poland to American banks without following required legal procedures.   The Capital Legal Foundation filed papers requesting a temporary restraining order against the Agriculture Department. The foundation said the plan to pay the overdue interest on loans to Poland without requiring the banks to declare Poland in default violated Federal regulations.

headline: Texaco Refinery
abstract: Texaco Inc. said it had advised its 400 employees at the West Tulsa refinery that it was considering closing the facility but that no decision had been reached. Texaco, which operates 11 refineries in the United States and has interests in 60 outside the country, said the Tulsa facility had been operating at 75 percent of its 50,000-barrel-a-day capacity. The company closed a refinery at Lockport, Ill., last March.

headline: U.S. ASSAILED AT UNESCO CONFERENCE ON PRESS
abstract: The United States was criticized at a Unesco-sponso red conference here today for refusing to help finance an internatio nal program intended to improve journalism and communication s in third world countries.   ''How can we explain the continuing indifference and reluctance of some countries to contribute their share to a program that they helped bring into existence?'' asked India's representative, Majarah Krishna Rasgotra.   Delegates from other developing nations also tried to allay United States fears that projects financed by the so-called International Program for Development of Communications would serve to strengthen government control over the news. 'Principle Responsibility'   ''We won't back any project that limits ideological freedom or restricts the role of the private sector,'' said Alejandro Alfonzo of Venezuela, ''but we feel the principal responsibility to develop communications belongs to the state.''

headline: Columbia Official Played Matchmaker
abstract: Karl Eller, the 53-year-old entrepreneur, communications executive and matchmaker of the planned Coca-Cola Company-Columbia Pictures Industries merger from the Columbia side, recalled yesterday his first conversation about the possibility of a deal with Ira C.  Herbert, an executive vice president of Coke. Mr. Eller is currently president of the Columbia Pictures communications division.   ''We've been friends for 25 years, since we were both in the advertising business together,'' he said from his headquarters in Phoenix. ''He was with McCann-Erickson and then went to Coca-Cola, first in advertising and then in marketing. He also went on the board of Combined Communications Company,'' Mr. Eller's former outdoor advertising company that was sold to the Gannett Company for $375 million.

headline: COMMODITY WATCHDOG CRITICIED
abstract: Members of a Senate subcommitee urged today that the states be allowed to take over many of the enforcement powers of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which, they said, has failed to protect investors from deceptive sales practices and commodity-related investment fraud schemes.   Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommitee on Investigations, said that thousands of Americans had been victimized ''by con artists operating under the guise of legitimate commodity investment firms.''    Mr. Roth opened three days of hearings on commodity fraud as new movement appeared under way in Congress to modify the scope of the C.F.T.C.'s regulatory powers.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS TRY TO BLOCK ROAD
abstract: Rebel forces attacked Government military patrols over the weekend near the provincial capital of Usulutan, about 70 miles east of the capital, burning several trucks.    On both sides of Usulutan, which is the country's fourth largest city, the highway is taking on the appearance of an elongated junkyard, littered with charred skeletons of semitrailer trucks and pickups.   Rebels burned seven trucks near a bridge less than a mile and a half east of here Saturday. Three of the trucks belonged to a Guatemalan transportation company and were en route to Nicaragua to pick up supplies.

headline: TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Some $650 million in oil and gas royalties due the Federal Government last year was held back through underreporting by companies operating on Federal lands, a special panel of investigators has found. It said that up to 6 percent of all crude oil produced in the U.S. is being stolen from oil fields and tank farms. (Page A1.) Americans added just $342 million to their installment debt load inNovember, the smallest increase since the sum mer of 1980, the FederalReserve Board reported. It said that while co nsumers took on $27.5 billion in new debt for the month, they paid off $27.16 billion in outstanding debt, a record liquidation figure . (D1.)

headline: Patents; Spacers to Support Vacuum-Filled Panels
abstract: Richard K. Rathmell, a professional engineer in Ramsey, N.J., reports that vacuum-filled building panels offer excellent insulation but are likely to collapse under air pressure.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For the last two weeks, the Reagan Administration has conducted what senior officials acknowledge has been an intense public relations campaign designed to dispel doubts about its policies in Central America. The effort, which has relied heavily on the use of intelligence information, has produced mixed results. Until Friday, officials thought they were making significant headway. Some members of Congress, including several influential committee chairmen, came away from private intelligence briefings saying they were convinced that the Administration had strong evidence to support its charges of Soviet and Cuban involvement in Central America and of Nicaraguan aid to guerrillas in El Salvador.   The public was given a glimpse of the intelligence material when the Administration made public aerial reconnaissance photographs in an effort to show that Nicaragua, with Cuban and Soviet assistance, was assembling the largest military force in Central America.

headline: U.N. CHIEF URGES REAGAN-BREZHNEV MEETING
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar says he believes that a meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, would ease tensions in the world.   In his first interview since assuming the leadership of the United Nations, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said: ''Confrontation is more or less present. That's why a dialogue between Reagan and Brezhnev is so necessary. It would project a shadow on all international problems.''

headline: GOLAN SCHOOL STEIKE IN 4TH DAY
abstract: Israeli Druse teachers serving in the Israeli armed forces unlocked the doors of strike-bound schools in the Golan Heights today as a general strike by 13,000 Druse there entered its fourth day.   Reports from the occupied plateau said no teachers or pupils turned up for classes and the soldiers left after two and a half hours.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The war between Iran and Iraq has dragged for more than 17 months.  There have been some slight shifts in the tactical position in the last six weeks, mostly in Iran's favor. But victory remains distant for either side despite the extravagant claims made by the Governments in Teheran and Baghdad.   The politicization of the war through the involvement of other nations in the region has increased, overshadowing the action along the battlefront.

headline: U.S. TO RAISE TECHNOLOGICAL LEVEL OF PRODUCTS THE CHINESE CAN BUY
abstract: A ranking United States trade official said today that the Reagan Administration hoped to raise the level of American technology that China was permitted to buy.   The official, Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, said that ''we anticipate the technology levels to increase and we're willing to license in a manner that is different from the past.''   The assistant secretary added that the Administration was even willing to permit the export of some items that the Chinese could put to military use. 80 U.S. Companies Represented   Mr. Brady made his remarks at a news conference before he opened an exhibition of American light industry at Peking's exhibition center, where nearly 80 American companies are displaying products worth nearly $4 million.

headline: Around the World; White House Is Happy With Salvador Inquiry
abstract: The Reagan Administration is happy with the recent pace of El Salvador's 13-month-old investigation into the murders of three American nuns and a missionary, Alan D. Romberg, the deputy State Department spokesman, said today.

headline: DON'T PLAY 'GOSSIPMONGER,' POLAND WARNS CLERGY
abstract: Some of the Polish clergy who have been allowed to visit martial law internees came under attack in the official press today for smuggling messages and reports from detention centers.   Trybuna Ludu, the Communist Party newspaper, said representatives of the Roman Catholic Church ''play gossipmonger or mailman,'' giving rise to sensational reports over the American-run Radio Free Europe of mistreatment of the internees. The paper said such activities were ''disloyal and occasionally even harmful, causing friction where it could have been avoided.''   Trybuna Ludu did not suggest that the church's assistance to prisoners and internees, which has included pastoral visits and distribution of food parcels, would be curtailed. On the contrary, the article said the authorities approved of the activities and had allowed the church considerable access.

headline: UNEMPLOYMENT
abstract: To the Business Editor: There is nothing inherently wrong with economic explanations that are gossipy and anecdotal; however Barbara Bergmann's article "Here is Why You Lost Your Job" (Feb. 7), left me with two disturbing impressions.  First, she implies that the inflation/unemployment trade-off is both stable and well known, thus enabling the Reagan team to have selected more prudently the present combination.

headline: SAVIN'S HEAD SEEKS A BENEFICIAL MERGER
abstract: With negotiations under way for the Savin Corporation, a manufacturer and marketer of copying machines, to sell up to 58 percent of its stock to the Canada Development Corporation for $9 a share, E. Paul Charlap, Savin's chairman and chief executive officer, yesterday disclosed some of the background behind the proposed deal.   ''We built a plant in Union, N.Y., to produce photocopiers using the Landa technology for making the highest quality images,'' he said in a telephone interview, referring to the company's new manufacturing process. ''We spent close to $100 million getting the factory on line and will start getting machines out in the summer.  How many businesses can pour this kind of money out of operations?''

headline: Careers; A Need For Fire Experts
abstract: DR. DOUGAL DRYSDALE, a busy teacher from Edinburgh, Scotland, keeps one jump ahead of his class while he writes a basic book on fire dynamics, the subject of a semester course at Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts.   ''I can't type, but I'm writing the book using a dictating machine,'' he said in an interview recently, looking a little harried because he had a deadline to meet. In May, he is to return to Scotland and his regular teaching post, leaving behind a completed textbook in manuscript form that can be used by future classes.

Patent 4,317,036 was awarded Chia Gee Wang, a biophysicist in Millwood, N.Y.   According to the patent, the instrument can direct an X-ray beam at a specimen and display or record its structure.

headline: ...And Service
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''How Not to Beat Last Year's Sales'' (March 14) by Ralph Shaffer hit the nail on the head. Inattentive, discourteous, even rude, sales clerks fail to understand the importance of the satisfied customer, and retailers' mechanization has made it difficult to buy even the necessary items.

headline: PATENTS; A SATELLITE TO CHART THE EARTH; New Whistle Designed To Turn On a Light
abstract: A whistle that turns on a light when air is blown through it received patent 4,314,316 this week.

headline: CUT IN ARMS URGED BY SOVIET GENERAL
abstract: A senior Soviet general said today that the Reagan Administration's arms spending program was ''doomed to failure'' because the Soviet Union would never allow the military balance to shift against it.   The officer, Gen. Valentin I. Varennikov, said the Soviet Union was convinced that both nations stood to gain from weapons limitation and, if possible, ''radical cuts'' in armaments.   General Varennikov, who is a First Deputy Chief of Staff of the Soviet armed forces, spoke at a news conference that offered the first opportunity in years for foreign reporters to put questions directly to a member of the military hierarchy. The occasion was carefully regulated to restrict questions to the American buildup and the Soviet response.

headline: THE NEW LOOK IN MUNICIPALS
abstract: State and local governments, traditionally reliant on long-term bonds to finance long-lived public projects such as sewers and schools, are turning increasingly to new kinds of short-term securities despite the increased financial risks.   The lure of interest rates of around 8 percent for borrowings due in less than a year compared with rates of 12 percent or more for bonds due in 20 or 30 years has overpowered officials' worry that if the short-term rates should rise, their budgets would be badly strained by the higher interest payments needed to renew the loans.   ''The increasing use of short-term borrowing is understandable, but it can very quickly turn into an abuse,'' said Freda Ackerman, director of municipal bond rating at Moody's Investors Service. New York's Crisis Recalled   The tax-exempt bond market still bears the scars of the 1975-76 New York City financial crisis. That was precipitated by the city's inability to continue renewing its short-term notes, which totaled $4.5 billion by mid-1975. In the 1960's and early 1970's, short-term borrowing grew rapidly, but contracted sharply after the city's crisis.

headline: BEHIND THE SLIPPAGE AT MARSHALL FIELD
abstract: A Chicago landmark, the 75-year-old flagship store of Marshall Field & Company, occupies a full block of State Street, its two famous clocks a guide to the carriage trade to which it catered.  Architecturally, it is even more magnificent inside, a six-story well that is surrounded by columned balconies and topped by a Tiffany dome.   But like State Street itself, Marshall Field has long ceased to be the important fashion center of the city, and its balance sheet - tarnished with money-losing acquisitions and debt -has similarly lost its luster. Thus when Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, acquired 29 percent of its stock, Marshall Field was in a position of weakness. Rather than fall under the control of Mr. Icahn, it agreed yesterday to be taken over by Batus, the United States operating group for B.A.T. Industries of London.

headline: Phillips Gas Plants
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company said it planned to more than double the capacity of its natural gas liquids facilities in central Texas.

headline: WEINBERGER, IN JORDAN, DISCUSSES SALE OF U.S. ANTIAIRCRAFT MISSILES
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger completed a brief visit to Oman today, flew to the aircraft carrier Constellation in the Gulf of Oman, and then came here tonight to discuss the sale of air defense missiles and possibly F-16 fighters to Jordan.   A senior official aboard Mr. Weinberger's plane told reporters that the Secretary would continue to resist Jordan's request that the United States patch up relations with Iraq and assist Iraq in its war with Iran.   The official denied that the Secretary's attempts to improve military relations with the three Arab nations on his Middle East trip were intended to send a message to Israe l.   That was unnecessary, the official asserted, because ''it should be clear by now that unilateral actions by anyone will not be tolerated.''

headline: Broken Hill's Net Down
abstract: Australia's largest company, Broken Hill Proprietary, said today that its earnings for the six months ended Nov. 30 fell by 36 percent, to $87.5 million dollars, or about $94.5 million in United States currency, from the first six months of 1980.

headline: PAPANDREOU, DUE IN CYPRUS TODAY, STARTS DRIVE FOR TURKISH PULLOUT
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou says he has started a diplomatic campaign to gain the withdrawal of Turkish troops from Cyprus and break the deadlock over the island.   The Greek leader is to arrive in Cyprus Saturday for a visit that will demonstrate, he says, his Government's commitment to finding a peaceful solution to the Cyprus problem. Greek Cypriots are preparing an enthusiastic welcome for him, but Turkish Cypriots have accused him of provocation and warned that his visit was aimed at disrupting talks between the two communities.   Mr. Papandreou, declaring that the Cyprus issue is really ''an international problem'' that cannot be solved while Turkish troops remain on the island, sketched what he described in an interview as ''a demilitarization plan'' for Cyprus. The proposal, as he talked, seemed to be still in the making.

headline: ISRAELI DOWNED IN '56 PAYS POIGNANT VISIT TO SINAI
abstract: Occupied Sinai, Jan. 27 - On the desert flats not far from the strategic Strait of Tiran, is the bullet-riddled wreckage of an old Mustang fighter plane. The faded outline of a Star of David is still visible on the fuselage. Around the site, low metal posts have been set in the ground to mark this remnant of the 1956 Sinai campaign.   Visitors come regularly along the hard-packed dirt track that leads south from here to the cape where Egyptian artillery once dominated the narrow shipping lane. Buses and open trucks carrying Israeli youngsters on desert camping trips pause while guides and teachers tell the dramatic story of the battle and of the young pilot, Lieut.  Jonathan Etkes.

headline: Reader Comment; ASBESTOSIS
abstract: P ROFESSOR PAUL MacAVOY's article ''You, Too, Will Pay for Asbestosis'' (Feb. 14) points out an interesting problem facing the insurance industry as a result of asbestos litigation. It suggests that the cost for indemnifying claims will ultimately be borne by the American public in the form of higher insurance premiums.  But the true asbestos story is one of asbestos industry fraud and insurance industry incompetence. And the true questions are whether we are dealing with another industry bailout such as Chrysler, Penn Central, or Lockheed. And if so, why the American taxpayer should be asked to pick up the tab for yet another case of corporate mismanagement.

headline: Personal Finance; HOW THEY RATE THE MONEY FUNDS
abstract: IT was bound to happen. Just as the Reserve Fund spawned an industryw hen it set up shop as the first money market fund a dozen years ago,s o William E. Donoghue has spawned an industry in selling informationa bout money funds. Now, a competitior has one-upped Mr. Donoghue by d eveloping a rating system that ranks the money funds in much the s ame way Moody's and Standard & Poor's ranks bonds.   The competitor is the Institute for Econometric Research, a research group and newsletter publisher in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. It has been run since 1975 by Glen King Parker, who previously operated an offshore mutual fund and a private real estate concern.

headline: Silver Futures Prices Decline in Late Selling
abstract: Silver futures prices seesawed at the technical support line of $7 an ounce yesterday, before some late selling pushed prices down.  Brokers said that once some modest carry-over buying from Monday had trailed off, the market seemed to gradually turn bearish.   At the close of New York's Commodity Exchange, spot April futures were down 5.5 cents an ounce at $7.03, while the active and pivotal near-May delivery fell 6 cents, to $7.12. Yesterday's losses only slightly exceeded the gains of Monday.

headline: Sergio Jeans to Altman
abstract: Englishtown Sportswear, which says that last year it put $12 million behind advertising its Sergio Valente jeans, has just assigned its jeans advertising to Altman, Stoller, Weiss, which has not turned out any jeans advertising for three years since Blue Bell moved out with Wrangler. The previous agency was Fischer Lewandowski, Ltd.

headline: ICHAN GROUP ADDS TO STAKE IN FIELD'S
abstract: The Icahn group, aided by a major purchase by a Swiss investor, has raised its stake in the common stock of Marshall Field & Company to 29.3 percent from 23.1 percent in the last week, an amendment to Icahn's 13-D statement disclosed yesterday.   Alan Clore, the Swiss investor, has bought 440,300 Field shares and is one of five individuals who have purchased a total of 610,100 shares, the amendment reported.   The four other new investors are Marvin L. Warner, chairman of both the Combanks Corporation, Winter Park, Fla., and of Great American Banks, North Miami, Fla., and John J. Edelman, B.F. Manko and Robert G. Bushnell Jr., all described as general partners of the Arbitrage Management Company, New York. The new purchases bring the Icahn group's holdings to 3,165,100 of Field's total 10.8 million common shares outstanding.

headline: Daimler to Buy Fr eightliner Credit
abstract: Daimler-Benz, the West German auto maker, said that the Federal Reserve Board had approved its purchase of the Freightliner Credit Corporation, a financing unit for its major American operations.

headline: TRIBUNAL SET UP TO ADJUDICATE U.S.-IRAN CLAIMS APPEARS TO BE BOGGED DOWN
abstract: The international tribunal set up to deal with claims arising from the hostility between the United States and Iran is still hacking its way through procedural thickets, seven months after it began its work and before it has settled a single case.   The nine lawyers who make up the panel have retreated behind a wall of silence, as have the official Iranian and American representatives here. But those familiar with the tribunal's work said it had encountered controversies worse than anticipated when it set out to evaluate thousands of claims worth billions of dollars in what is called the largest and most complicated international arbitration ever conducted.   At one point, the Iranians began to protest bitterly over what they considered prejudicial remarks by Niels Mangaard, a Swede, who is one of three neutral members of the panel. They reportedly accused him of criticizing the execution of judges in Iran, but he is reported to have said he was misunderstood. What he was complaining about, Mr. Mangaard explained privately, was the execution of judgments in Iranian courts, not the execution of judges.

headline: Personal Finance; YOU CAN GET SUED, EVEN AT HOME
abstract: C ASE 1: The house painter assembles his ladder outside your window and climbs up. Suddenly, somehow, the ladder slips and the painter breaks a hip.   Case 2: Your baby sitter slips on a throw rug and breaks an arm.  Case 3: A man repairing your roof lets a bundle of tiles fall to the ground. It strikes a passing neighbor, putting him in the hospital.   As the homeowner, where does your financial responsibility lie?  Are you covered under your standard homeowner's insurance policy? Can you be sued if the workman, the neighbor or the baby sitter are uninsured? Should you have had workmen's compensation insurance?

headline: Europe, Japan May Cut Rate
abstract: Leading West European countries and Japan, apparently abandoning hopes for American action, have agreed to stimulate their economies by reducing interest rates, European monetary sources report.   The countries involved will also try to prevent excessive movements of the dollar on foreign exchange markets.

headline: PROSPECTS DIMMER FOR LOWER RATES
abstract: The path to lower interest rates, if one can be found this year, is likely to be a circuitous one. Credit market participants have to contend with rapid money supply growth that has raised fears of a tighter monetary policy and higher short-term interest rates while record-size Treasury borrowings put upward pressure on longer-term rates.   ''The battle lines between an expansionary fiscal and a highly restrictive monetary policy have now been clearly drawn in Washington,'' Donald Maude, chief financial economist at Merrill Lynch, said in the Feb. 12 Weekly Credit Market Bulletin, ''with no give from either side in prospect over the immediate future.''   Mr. Maude goes on to say that some modest drop in short-term rates is still likely this quarter because the economic recession will inevitably reduce credit demands and money supply growth. However, he concluded that enough problems remained so that the declines ''could turn out to be somewhat restrained and most certainly short-lived.''

headline: SON OF EX-G.M. HEAD ACCUSED
abstract: Thomas Estes, the oldest son of Elliott M.  Estes, the former president of the General Motors Corporation, stood before a Federal magistrate today and pleaded not guilty to charges that he used his family name and false documents to extract millions of dollars from local banks and business associates.   Mr. Estes, who is 43 years old, was indicted earlier this week on 10 counts of fraud and misrepresentation in connection with his financial maneuverings, which he reportedly resorted to in an effort to live elaborately on a moderate income.   His tactics, according to local news accounts, consisted mainly of paying old debts with new, and larger, borrowings, most tied to nonexistent deals. Thomas Estes refused yesterday to answer questions about the charges. His father has declined commented since the beginning of the proceedings.

headline: REAGAN WEIGHS NEW TAX-RISE PLAN
abstract: The Reagan Administration is studying a proposal that would increase taxes and pass on the additional revenue to the states to offset reductions in Federal programs, such as those dealing with welfare, highways and education, top Administration officials said today.   However, one key official, who asked not to be named, said that the details of the proposal had yet to be worked out and that no final decision had been made. One official said, ''We have been circling around the issue but we have not yet hit the target.'' Another official indicated that while the Administration may move ahead with the plan, it may not be included in the budget for the fiscal year 1983, which will be submitted to Congress on Feb. 8.

headline: HEARING SET ON I.B.M. CASE DISMISSAL
abstract: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a court hearing to determine if the dismissal of the Government's antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation should be overturned.   Judge David N. Edelstein, who presided over the long case, ordered the hearing for April 8 in Federal District Court in Manhattan. He acted on a motion by Philip M. Stern, an author and philanthropist, who asked to appear as a friend of the court to question the I.B.M.  dismissal.   The surprise action appeared to raise the possibility of reopening the historic antitrust case, which sought to divide the giant computer company into several units. On Jan. 8, the Government agreed to drop the 13-year-old suit, saying it was ''without merit.''

headline: Market Place; Timber Assets: Luster Fades
abstract: FORESTRY companies are still drawing attention as acquisition targets, but it is the faster-growing companies with relatively little timber, not the more static companies that grow lots of trees, that are thought to be the best buys. For example Potlatch, which is among the more profitable forestry companies when business is good, has to buy 45 percent of its timber. Yet Potlatch is regarded as a takeover candidate.   In short, acquirers are becoming more selective as inflation slows and the dollar becomes more stable, two factors that make assets a less desirable way of holding value.

headline: Around the World; U.S. and South Africa Open Talks on Namibia
abstract: United States and South African officials opened two days of talks here today aimed at pushing forward delicate plans for independence of South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia.

headline: THATCHER CABINET HAS UNION VICTORY
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher won a major victory today in her effort to tame British unions when the coal miners rejected a call by their leadership for authority to call a strike.   Traditionally the coal miners have been perhaps the most aggressive of British unions, and their strikes have demonstrated their power to cripple the nation. They were considered responsible for bringing down the Conservative Government of Edward Heath in 1974.

headline: Small Israeli Opposition Party Is Supporting Begin for Now
abstract: Telem, a small opposition party, has agreed to abstain in a parliamentary budget vote this week, insuring the survival for the time being of the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.   The Government and the opposition parties hold equal strength in Parliament.

headline: Magazine Agencies Watch Gallo Carefully
abstract: The magazine ad directors who are accustomed to getting ad schedules from Ernest and Julio Gallo, the California wine makers, are probably watching the competition for that account as eagerly as the three agencies that are involved.   That is because the company's agency must wait for the TV commercials to be approved by Ernest Gallo before it can create print ads to complement the theme.

headline: Florida Crop Loss Set
abstract: A new report says about 25 percent of the citrus crop, half of the winter vegetable crop and 10 percent of the sugar cane crop were lost in Florida during last week's freeze.

headline: FRANCE TO BUY 51% OF I.T.T.
abstract: France's Socialist Government said today that it would only buy a 51 percent interest in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's French subsidary - enough for control - but would not purchase the entire company, as originally planned.   The decision, which officials said was worked out with the American parent company, means that the Government has backed away from its initial plans to take full control of all three foreign-owned companies on its nationalization list, apparently worried by the high cost of buying them entirely.   According to sources here, the French Government balked at paying the $375 million that I.T.T. originally asked for in cash for its principal French subsidiary, Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, which broke even in 1981 on sales of $300 million after two years of losses.

headline: Ad Writer To Be Honored
abstract: Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, retailing's legendary ad maker who starred at both Macy's and Gimbel's, is being installed in another hall of fame, this time by the American Advertising Federation.

headline: ASBESTOS: THE ARGUMENT FOR A FUND...
abstract: To the Business Editor:   The health effects of asbestos exposure possibly constitute the most enormous occupational disease problem ever to face the United States. It is therefore unfortunate that both Professor Paul MacAvoy in ''You, Too, Will Pay for Asbestosis'' (Feb. 14) and attorney Robert E. Sweeney in ''Asbestosis'' (Feb. 21) concentrated more on finger-pointing and rhetoric than on addressing the main issue - how to provide prompt and equitable compensation for genuinely injured workers and their survivors.   Let us take another look.  First, virtually all claimants in lawsuits against Keene and others are now receiving compensation totally apart from the lawsuits.  People who had been employed in Federal shipyards are receiving compensation through the Federal Employees' Compensation Act. Other claimants are being compensated under state workers compensation laws.

headline: IRELAND TO PICK PREMIER TODAY
abstract: The Irish Parliament will meet Tuesday to select a Prime Minister, with the outcome still uncertain.  Former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey is regarded here as the most likely winner. But some politicians think that Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald might be able to retain the office, which he has held since last June.

headline: U.S. Denies Harassing A Libyan Jetliner
abstract: The Navy today denied a Libyan accusation that F-14 fighters from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy buzzed a Libyan jetliner last Sunday. But it said that planes from the carrier inspected five unidentified aircraft that later turned out to be commercial airliners.

headline: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: Advertising; Agencies Forecast Tough '82
abstract: THIS year could very well turn out better for ad agencies than clients, because the clients, despite the economic crunch, will be forced by competitive pressures to maintain or exceed 1981 advertising levels. Up to a point.   That is the reading one gets from conversations with the heads of the nation's leading ad agencies, who are uniformly looking forward to a ''tough'' year but not a disastrous one. A majority of them are forecasting a break in the second or third quarters.

headline: Market Place; The Attraction Of Filmways
abstract: TO seekers of buried treasure Filmways Inc. is not the disaster its persistent losses in recent years might suggest. The company has assets of substantial value and that helps explain why last month three separate groups expressed an interest in acquiring all or part of this self-proclaimed buyout candidate.   Saul Steinberg's interests went directly to the c ompany with an offer of $31 million along with a loan to rel ieve Filmways' pressing debt in exchange for enough shares to control the company.   Mr. Steinberg is chairman of the Reliance Group, an insurance company whose assets have been employed over time in various purchases of equity interests in other companies, to the alarm of some of their managements. Mr. Steinberg is currently attempting to take Reliance private -controversial here as always.

headline: By David Diamond
abstract: SURVIVOR:IU INTERNATIONAL   PHILADELPHIA John Gilray Christy sat in the headquarters of the IU International Corporation and rattled off the names of the trucking companies that have gone out of business since the industry was deregulated. ''Last week there was Cooper, Jerrett. Last month it was Jones Motor Freight, Johnson Motor Lines,'' he said.

headline: SOVIET STEPS UP EFFORTS TO SPLIT THE WEST ON POLAND
abstract: Faced with a stiffening posture by the Atlantic alliance on Poland, the Kremlin has stepped up a propaganda campaign aimed at persuading Western Europeans that the United States is using the Polish crackdown as a pretext for destroying detente and restoring the ''obedience'' of European nations to America's commands.   The Soviet pronouncements have warned Western Europeans that the cost of following the American lead could be the collapse of the framework of political, economic and cultural ties that have developed with the Soviet bloc under the rubric of detente. There have been warning s that the Soviet Union coul d withhold lucrative economic contracts from European nations that yield to ''American pressure'' over Poland.   The Soviet press has also warned that the ''hysteria'' over Poland is a smoke screen behind which the United States plans to sabotage talks on limiting nuclear weapons. In particular, recent articles have asserted that the Reagan Administration is seeking to poison the climate of East-West relations so that it can disrupt the talks that opened in Geneva six weeks ago on limiting medium-range nuclear missiles.

abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's third largest, reported today that it lost $21 million in the final quarter of 1981 compared with net income of $2.3 million, or 28 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1980.   The company said revenues fell 7.5 percent, to $167.9 million, on 2.7 million barrels sold, from $181.5 million and sales of 3.1 million barrels in the same 1980 period.

abstract: The Allied Corporation announced that its tender offer for up to 16.1 million common shares of the Supron Energy Corporation of Dallas expired at noon yesterday and that it had begun paying for the shares.

headline: SKETCHES OF LEADERS OF SALVADORAN OPPOSITION FACTION
abstract: Salvador Cayetano Carpio Leader of the Popular Forces of Liberation. A legendary figure who is frequently called El Salvador's Ho Chi Minh, Mr. Carpio was born into a poor San Salvador family and entered politics as a labor organizer. He joined the Communist Party at the age of 28, eventually becoming its secretary general, but resigning in 1970 when it refused to take up arms. A decade later, the party followed his example by backing armed revolution. The 62-year-old Mr. Carpio, who has adopted the nom de guerre of Marcial, is considered the most orthodox Marxist-Leninist in the general command and the least enthusiastic over the prospect of a negotiated settlement. Joaquin Villalobos Leader of the People's Revolutionary Army. Born into a middle-class family in San Salvador, the 30-year-old Mr. Villalobos studied economics for three years at the National University of El Salvador before dropping out to join the guerrillas. He became the leader of his group in 1977. Although the People's Revolutionary Army has demonstrated ideological inconsistency, it is the strongest military force among the guerrillas. Mr. Villalobops is considered a skilled military strategist and a political pragmatist.

headline: DEBT CALENDAR IS LIGHT
abstract: This week's calendar of new fixed-income debt offerings will remain light and dominated by several large tax-exempt issues. But dealers said last week that a heavy flow of corporate bonds were being filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   ''If our statistics are correct, this is the calm before the storm of new offerings,'' one dealer said Friday. ''There is a lot of fear that competition for long-term borrowings and interest rates may start moving up in the next few months, particularly if the recession shows signs of bottoming out during the next month or so,'' the dealer said.

headline: By STEVEN RATTNER
abstract: LONDON I T was just a small change, but a symbolic one. In the stolid halls of the Barclays Bank headquarters here, brass letters reading ''Investment Managers Office'' have been removed, replaced by a similar sign nearby that reads ''Large Corporate Division.''   The creation of that new division, the first time big companies have received special attention within the bank, was just one part of a recent major reorganization that was in turn just one part of Barclays' strategy to assure that the bank remains the largest and most profitable in Britain.   Perhaps most dramatically, the bank has substantially added to its presence in the United States. ''We see North America and particularly the United States as one of the few areas of the world where there is change going on in structure, where there are considerable possibilities for foreign banks, where there is deregulation, however far it goes,'' said Peter E. Leslie, an executive director and senior general manager of Barclays Bank International Ltd., one of two principal operating divisions.

headline: CANDIDATE FAVORING NAPALM USE GAINS IN SALVADOR
abstract: The concern of American officials over holding elections amid the violence here is being compounded by alarm that a man linked to that violence may do very well in the voting.   Ambassador Deane R. Hinton told Salvadoran leaders at a diplomatic gathering last week that his main worry had become the unexpectedly strong showing of Roberto d'Aubuisson, a 38-year-old cashiered army officer long associated with coup attempts and paramilitary terror campaigns.   The boyish looking Mr. d'Aubuisson promises to ''exterminate'' the guerrillas within three months of the convening of the new constituent assembly that is to be elected March 28 by putting the country on a war footing and sparing no tactic. ''Napalm is indispensable,'' explained his campaign spokesman, Willi Aleman. 'Civilians Will Be Killed'   The armed forces would be freed of human rights restrictions on their activities and encouraged to invade Nicaragua. ''We don't believe the army needs controlling,'' said Mario Redaelli, the secretary of Mr. d'Aubuisson's party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance. ''Civilians will be killed, war has always been that way.  When the Germans bombed London they didn't tell civilians to get out of the way first, did they?''

headline: No Headline
abstract: This quiet countryside of hills and valleys, wheat fields and olive groves, is pastoral and beautiful. On this fact, both Arabs and Jews agree. But it is the only overlapping quality in the scenes they see from their two perspectives -the Arabs from this tiny village in the valley, the Jews from their settlement of Shiloh on the hilltop.   The Arabs of Turmos Ayya and surrounding villages see themselves as helpless victims of carloads of heavily-armed Jewish militants who terrorize them, with the objective of ultimately taking all their land and driving them out of the West Bank.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
abstract: Q. There is great fascination with El Salvador and th e Caribbean right now. Could you share some idea of what is going to happen in the next few weeks?   A. I think basically our approach has been a clear one from the outset. First, we have to deal with the socio-economic conditions that create the breeding ground for external intervention and subversion. That is our first approach - that's the Caribbean Basin initiative, plus the economic programs, the works we do bilaterally with each of the nations within the region in the area of human rights, internal reform, land reform, sound economic planning.  Secondly, we attempt to assist the nations. We inherited this situation when the Administration came in - the insurgency in Salvador was running rampant, there was a major offensive in January of last year which was defeated by the Government, but which did not eliminate the threat.   We had a period where, because of our emphasis on the subject early last year, we had some decline in the shipment of armaments into Salvador. In the subsequent months, those arms began to pick up again, and they are now at a level which approximates the high point when we came into office.

headline: REBAL CHIEF SAYS VOTE COULD PROLONG THE WAR
abstract: The leader of El Salvador's main opposition coalition asserted today that the elections Sunday had served to restore the power of the local oligarchy and could intensify and prolong the civil war.   The leader, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, also renewed the opposition's offer to negotiate with the army and the new government. ''We are ready to make a serious effort to find a comprehensive political solution,'' he said.   Reached by telephone at his home in Panama, Mr. Ungo, the Social Democratic president of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, sought to play down the importance of the large turnout reported in the elections, arguing that many people had voted ''because an abstention could be read as support for subversion and that was dangerous''.

headline: Refinery Layoffs
abstract: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said it would lay off 298 employees at its refinery in Puerto Rico and suspend operations there by March 15 unless there is a ''significant change'' in the company's prospects. The company, which emerged from Chapter 11 last year, recently lost a major contract to supply refined products to Esso Puerto Rico. Donald D. McCuaig, Commonwealth's chairman and chief executive officer, said that the company would continue to operate a products terminal at its Penuelas facilities after the shutdown.

headline: Gold Margin Raised
abstract: The margin committee of the Commodity Exchange Inc. said yesterday that it had raised the margin requirements for gold futures, effective today. The exchange said the speculative margin will be $1,500, compared with the previous $1,250. The hedge margin will be $1,000 compared with the previous $800.

headline: Union Pacific Plan
abstract: The Union Pacific Corporation said it plans a record capital investment program of $1.3 billion this year, an increase of 36 percent, or $339 million, over 1981. James H. Evans, chairman, said that the the budget includes $1 billion for the Champlin Petroleum Company, $163 million for the Union Pacific Railroad and $63 million for the Rocky Mountain Energy Company. Of Champlin's total investment, $628 million will be allocated for oil and gas exploration, the company said.

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS KILL 201 IN ANGOLA RAID
abstract: West Africa, March 16 (Reuters) - South African troops wiped out a major guerrilla staging post during a cross-border operation in a desolate mountain area of southwestern Angola, officers commanding the raid said today.   The officers said 45 soldiers from an elite unit made up mostly of blacks killed 201 guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization during a seven-and-a-half-hour attack Saturday, while suffering three losses of their own. They recovered large caches of food and arms, the officers said.   Troops from the 32d Battalion, a formerly secret counterinsurgency unit, still held the rocky Cambeno Valley, 14 miles inside Angola, as South African authorities ferried in a small group of journalists and officers by helicopter to view the camp.

headline: Eastern Seeks Braniff Routes
abstract: Eastern Airlines applied today for some of the Latin American routes that Braniff International has agreed to turn over to Pan American World Airways for four years, until Braniff ''returns to financial health.''   The Eastern application indicated a possible contest for numerous routes that Braniff wants to give up temporarily.

headline: FOREIGN INVESTORS TAKE A LOOK BEYOND NEW YORK
abstract: Mix a little myth with a little reality, add a few crucial questions that no one can answer, and New York City looks like a mecca for foreign individuals and institutions who want to invest in real estate.   Olympia & York of Toronto has become one of the largest owners and builders in New York. Many condominium owners in the Olympic Tower on Fifth Avenue are foreigners. Investors from Hong Kong and the Middle East are planning a condominium development in Chinatown. A British group is planning an industrial development in Southampton, L.I.

headline: IN FRANCE, 'A POLICY OF CHANGE'
abstract: PARIS NINE months after Francois Mitterrand was elected President of France with the seemingly impossible mandate of restoring full employment during a world recession, the country's new Socialist leadership is finding its policies bumping awkwardly against the realities of economic life.   Since taking office, the Socialists have moved with surprising speed to put in place the building blocks of their promised ''policy of change'' - an attempt to blast the French economy out of recession with heavy Government spending financed in part by new taxes on the rich and a vast extension of the state-owned sector. The policies run contrary to the cautious, inflation-fighting, enterprise-encouraging policies now favored by other Western nations.    Demand is being stoked through a doubling of the Government's budget deficit, a result of the big rise in public investment spending, higher pensions and an increased minimum wage. The Socialists' economic cornerstone is a plan to nationalize the remaining French-owned private banks and 12 major industrial groups.  Although it was dealt a setback last month when France's supreme legal tribunal, the Constitutional Council, ruled that the original nationalization plan was illegal because inadequate compensation was being offered to shareholders, the Government responded with a plan to pay nearly $1.5 billion in additional compensation and by postponing until next year the nationalization of 22 of the 36 banks on its list while a commission works out a shareholder compensation plan.

headline: Japan Steel Exports Off
abstract: In the face of stiff competition from South Korea, the volume of Japan's steel exports in 1981 fell 4.4 percent from the previous year to about 29 million metric tons, the lowest in recent years, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today in a preliminary report. A metric ton equals about 2,205 pounds.

headline: I.B.M. WILL RENT TIME ON ITS UNITS
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced its re-entry into the remote computer services business.  Under the new service, customers will be able to rent time on I.B.M. computers in Tampa, Fla., and have the use of more than 100 programs stored on those units.   I.B.M. has been out of the services business, called time-sharing, because of an agreement that settled a private antitrust suit against it by the Control Data Corporation. In that 1973 agreement, I.B.M.  transferred its Service Bureau Corporation, which provided such services, to Control Data and agreed to stay out of the business in the United States until 1979. It is no secret that I.B.M. has been anxious to return.

headline: A U.S. ARMS IMPORT CURB ANGERS ALLIES
abstract: Officials at the State and Defense Departments have become concerned that an import restriction that Congress enacted late last year may jeopardize arms cooperation efforts between the United States and its allies.   The little-noticed Congressional amendment, known as the specialty metals clause, prohibits the import of military products containing a number of metals. The amendment has prompted American allies to charge that the United States, which is itself a leading arms exporter, is unwilling to make military purchases abroad.   ''The allies are really upset over this,'' a State Department official said. ''I can't overestimate how much they're upset about it.''

headline: COMMITTEE IN U.S. WORKING ON BEHALF OF LABOR IN POLAND
abstract: Since the declaration of martial law in Poland on Dec. 13, a small group of activists in New York, most of them college students or union members, has maintained an information and lobbying center devoted to publicizing the cause of Polish workers.   The group, known as Committee in Support of Solidarity, has as its avowed goal the dissemination of whatever information on worker resistance that can be obtained from travelers and by monitoring communications within Poland.   ''We want to inform the American public as much as possible about the scope of the situation in Poland,'' Eric Chenoweth, a 22-yearold former Columbia University student and a founder of the committee, said this week.

headline: ABC-TV Holds Its Line On the 30-Second Rule
abstract: In the wake of the announcement by the National Association of Broadcasters that it is suspending all enforcement of its broadcast codes in light of a recent Federal Court antitrust decision, ABC-TV announced that it is holding the line on the point in question - only one product allowed in a 30-second commercial. The judge's ruling would allow more.   The NBC-TV Network said it was reviewing its stand and CBS-TV said it was doing the same and would have a statement in two weeks.

headline: MEAD DEPRESSION DRUG IS APPROVED BY F.D.A.
abstract: The Mead Johnson & Company division of the Bristol-Myers Company announced yesterday that it had received permission from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a new antidepression drug, thus clearing the way for the company's entry into the mental health pharmaceuticals market.   Called Desyrel, the drug was described at a news conference here as a ''new generation'' in depression-fighting substances because it works in a different manner than existing drugs.   Company officials and doctors who have been conducting clinical studies since 1975 said that Desyrel is effective with some victims of depression who do not respond to currently available drugs and eliminates a number of uncomfortable or disabling side effects in many other cases.   Pharmaceuticals are used to treat about 8 million depression victims annually, alone or in combination with psychotherapy, according to Mead Johnson officials. Antidepressant sales totaled about $230 million last year, Mea d Johnson sa id.

headline: MALAYSIAN OFFICIAL, REPORTED KILLED, FOUND ALIVE
abstract: Malaysia's Foreign Minister was found alive in a mountainous jungle today a day after he was reported to have died in the crash of the light plane he was flying.   ''God is great,'' Foreign Minister Mohammed Ghazali bin Shafie said to reporters as he stepped into an ambulance here from a rescue helicopter.   Mr. Ghazali, who is 60 years old, suffered only a minor injury to his right arm. He said he had opened the door and jumped as ''trees came up in front of us'' seconds before the plane crashed into a jungle-covered hill 20 miles northeast of here.

headline: A 'GARDEN' CONVERSION IN BAYSIDE
abstract: ALTHOUGH firm figures are not available, real estate experts agree that in recent years the conversion of garden apartments to either cooperative or condominium ownership has become well established in Queens, the section of New York City where they are most ubiquitous.   According to a 1980 city report, the primary reasons for this, in addition to the growing desire of city residents to own their dwelling units, are that garden apartments are more expensive to maintain as rental units than conventional apartment buildings. They are generally not energy-efficient, and they are often spread over several acres, thus requiring more maintenance workers and higher labor costs.   Undoubtedly, one of the most welcomed - by other neighborhood residents - of these conversions is occurring in the southeast corner of Bayside, Queens, where the Sidney Kalikow Development Corporation is renovating part of the Heather Gardens garden-apartment development into a 179-unit condominium complex.

headline: 2 I.R.A. LEADERS ARRESTED WHILE TRYING TO ENTER U.S. ILLEGALLY
abstract: Two leaders of the Irish Republican Army - in what appeared to be a coordinated effort to reach New York City in time for a fundraising dinner tonight - were arrested in separate incidents last night as each was trying to cross into the United States illegally from Canada, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said.   One of the arrested I.R.A. leaders, Owen Carron, is a recently elected member of the British Parliament who last summer was refused a visa to enter the United States because of his support for violence in Northern Ireland.   Mr. Carron, an unemployed high school teacher who has been identified as a hard-line republican, was elected to Parliament in August to replace Robert Sands, the I.R.A. official who won the seat in April while on a fatal hunger strike in Maze Prison outside Belfast.

headline: PATENTS; Hammer Strikes Twice To Aid the Handicapped
abstract: A hammer for use by handicapped persons has an extra head that can increase the force of a blow. Dr. Boris Schwartz of Hawthorne, N.J., who has other medical-surgical inventions, received patent 4,314,593 this week for the adjustable tool.

headline: Technology; Developing Disk Cameras
abstract: THE new amateur cameras introduced last week by the Eastman Kodak Company have been called ''disk cameras'' because they replace the traditional film rolled inside a cartridge with a 15-exposure film disk that rotates automatically after every shot.   The simple name says nothing about the company's interesting new film and short-focal length glass lens, which made the disk format necessary. Nor does it reflect the improvements in electronics, manufacturing techniques and processing equipment that made the disk concept workable and, according to Kodak's estimates, potentially profitable.   In short, the word ''disk'' does not begin to tell the technological story behind the new cameras. That story is typical of many applied technology developments. The company committed itself to certain concepts. Then it worked simultaneously on several interdependent electronic, optical, mechanical and manufacturing problems that the concepts presented.

headline: SOVIET HAILS FINNISH VOTE AS 'SHIFT TO THE LEFT'
abstract: The result of the Finnish presidential election of last Sunday and Monday was acclaimed in a commentary by the Moscow radio today as a ''clear shift to the left.''   Taking note of the decisive victory by Mauno Koivisto, the Social Democrat who has been Acting President since September and Prime Minister since 1979, the broadcast described the election as a setback for Finland's ''capitalist parties.'' The broadcast said it was expected that good Soviet-Finnish relations would continue.

headline: Campbell to Buy Mrs. Paul's Units
abstract: The Campbell Soup Company said it had agreed to buy certain frozen food business assets of Mrs. Paul's Kitchens Inc. for an undisclosed price. Mrs. Paul's, which had sales of about $124 million last year, markets more than 65 frozen prepared food products.   The assets to be acquired include the Mrs. Paul's headquarters building in Philadelphia and three frozen food plants in Philadelphia and Doylestown, Pa., and Crisfield, Md. The acquisition does not include Arthur Treacher's Fish and Chips Inc., a subsidiary of Mrs. Paul's, any receivables or business assets not directly connected with the frozen foods assets, Campbell said.

headline: Socal, Conoco Swap Holdings
abstract: The Conoco unit of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Standard Oil Company of California said they had traded substantial coal and oil shale properties in a move designed to push each company into a new area of domestic energy resources.   Under terms of the transaction, Socal, as California Standard is known, acquired an inactive coal reserve adjacent to a producing coal mine near Hillsboro, Ill.

headline: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Warning On Gas Plan
abstract: Leading House Democrats introduced a resolution today that warned the Reagan Administration against attempting ''backdoor decontrol'' of natural gas prices.   The resolution by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was seen as an effort to send a warning to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which recently began hearings on several proposals that would sharply increase natural gas prices.

headline: SPLIT WIDENS IN SOUTH AFRICA AS VORSTER BACKS BOTHA FOES
abstract: The split in the governing National Party deepened today as Prime Minister P.W. Botha's predecessor, John Vorster, emerged from retirement to side with the 22 members of Parliament who voted Wednesday against a motion of confidence in Mr.  Botha's leadership.   Until Mr. Vorster's statement in support of the stand taken by backers of Dr. Andries P. Treurnicht, the right-wing party leader in the Transvaal, it seemed that Mr. Botha had the upper hand in what is already the most severe split the formerly monolithic party has experienced since coming to power in 1948.   It was unclear this evening whether Mr. Vorster, whose health has been shaky, was contemplating a return to active politics. He is 66, the same age as Mr. Botha. Although he had to resign as Prime Minister in 1978 under pressure and, later, as ceremonial President because of his implication in a political scandal, he is thought to retain considerable influence and popularity in the party.

headline: Advertising; Showtime And Xerox Campaigns
abstract: A VISIT yesterday to 909 Third Avenue at 51st Street was rewarded with news of two very different advertising campaigns.  One will be aimed at business executives in hopes of selling them the high-technology office equipment of today and the future. It was put on display on the 18th floor by a team from Needham, Harper & Steers and Michael E.G. Kirby, director of corporate advertising and promotion of the client, Xerox.   The other will try to get cable television subscribers to sign up to pay for additional entertainment from Showtime. This campaign was displayed on the 29th floor by Benton & Bowles in the presence of Susan Denison, vice president of the client, which is a joint venture of Viacom International and Teleprompter.

headline: ZIMBABWE ACTING ON MINERALS
abstract: Zimbabwe, which for years has depended on American, British and South African companies to market its mineral resources, is now on the verge of taking over responsibility for the sales itself.   Parliament is expected to pass soon a controversial measure that would set up a Government marketing board to sell all of the country's 40 minerals except gold. Mineral sales account for more than 50 percent of the export earnings of this country, which has been under black rule for 21 months. In 1981 the minerals brought in more than $500 million of chronically short foreign currency.

headline: METEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Eagle Bid for Wien Delayed by C.A.B.
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday denied a request by the Eagle International Corporation for speedy approval of its plans to purchase Wien Air Alaska from Household International Inc. Instead, Eagle was told it must file a formal application for approval of the combination.   Both Eagle International and Alaska International Airlines, which operates cargo flights in Alaska, are owned by Neil G. Bergt, the recently appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Western Air Lines.

headline: Greek Official Will Visit U.S.  For Talks on Military Bases
abstract: Carolos Papoulias, Greece's Undersecretary of Foreign Affairs, will pay a semiofficial visit to the United States next month, during which he will assess American intentions over the forthcoming negotiations on its military bases here, Government sources said today.

headline: A CERAMIC INNOVATOR IN JAPAN
abstract: Kazuo Inamori, the 50-year-old president of the Kyoto Ceramic Company, has a well-deserved reputation as an unconventional man in this convention-abiding nation.   Respecting one's elders and staying with a single company until retirement are the norms in Japan. But as an upstart in his 20's, Mr. Inamori had a disagreement with his boss at the company for which he worked, quit and, in 1959, founded his own company with seven colleagues, a grubstake of $10,000 borrowed from a friend and a strategy: ''In order to survive, we had to do something innovative,'' he recalled during an interview at Kyoto Ceramic's austere headquarters here. ''We had to do what other companies did not or bypassed.''

headline: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; A Paraplegic Is Named Inventor of the Year
abstract: Intellectual Property Owners Inc. announced this week the selection of the Inventor of the Year for 1981. Don Ausmus, the winner, will be honored at a meeting on Feb. 7 in the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va.
