headline: Market Place; Using Debt To Lift Profits
abstract: SHAKESPEARE'S sage advice - ''Neither a borrower, nor a lender be'' - doesn't necessarily apply to corporations. ''History suggests that companies that use debt well will generally record the best share gains once Wall Street sees an improvement in the economy and begins buying stocks aggressively,'' says Donald W. Mitchell, president of the Mitchell Investment Management Company of Cambridge, Mass., which specializes in pension fund investment.   But too frequently, corporations earn less on their debt-financed investments than they pay in interest - especially in a recession.  Thus, investors who expect an equity bull market should consider companies that are able to enhance profitability with debt.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Defeats No-Confidence Motion
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's coalition thwarted an opposition attempt to unseat the Government today because of its handling of the evacuation of Sinai.   By a vote of 55 to 52, the Parliament in Jerusalem rejected a motion of no confidence in the Government by the Labor opposition.

headline: 7 KILLED AND 60 HURT BY 2 CAR EXPLOSIONS AT MARKET IN BEIRUT
abstract: At least seven people were killed and 60 wounded when two car bombs went off within minutes of each other in a crowded seaside shopping district here this afternoon.   Two anti-Syrian organizations took responsibility for the explosions in calls to news agencies here.  The bombs went off shortly after 1 P.M. on the shore road, known as the Corniche, near a row of makeshift, corrugated-tin shops that replaced the city's traditional souk, or market, which was destroyed in the civil war six years ago.

headline: MANHATTAN LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JETERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Output Up, but Short Of Demand
abstract: China has increased production of television sets ninefold, refrigerators by 233 percent and bicycles by 100 percent in the last three years, but is still far from keeping up with demand, the New China News Agency reported today.   China produced 4.8 million television sets in 1981, it said, and by the end of the year there was one set for every two households in Shanghai.

headline: Bahamas Strike Cripples Most Airline Service
abstract: About 4,000 civil servants and communications and airline employees walked off their jobs today in a one-day strike that crippled airline service to most of the Bahamas and left thousands of people without telephone service.

headline: BATUS RAISES OFFER FOR MARSHALL FIELD
abstract: Concerned that its price for Marshall Field stock was too low, Batus Inc., the American subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries of London, yesterday raised the price of its cash tender offer in an attempt to assure its acquisition of the big Chicago-based retailer.   Batus announced that it would offer $30 a share for at least six million shares, or 50 percent, of Field's common stock, up $4.50 from its initial offer, and $54 per for each of Field's preferred shares, an increase of $9.10.   Marshall Field's stock did not trade yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after the Chicago retailer asked for a trading suspension pending an afternoon meeting of the Batus board. The last trade was on Wednesday, when the stock advanced $1, to $25.50, after jumping $2.50 on Tuesday. In all, about a million shares changed hands in the two days as arbitragers and investors accumulated stock.

headline: LAND RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Somali Leader in U.S.  To Seek More Assistance
abstract: President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia arrived here today to seek more economic and military assistance from the United States.

headline: MEXICO DEVALUES PESO 30%
abstract: The Mexican peso was abruptly devalued by about 30 percent today after the Government announced it would no longer intervene on exchange markets to support the currency.   The move was surprising only in its timing since most bankers had forecast a major devaluation later this year. It was apparently brought on by a new flight of capital and mounting speculation against the currency.   The Bank of Mexico announced late Wednesday night that it would allow the peso to float freely until it found a level ''corresponding to current economic conditions.'' The central bank was ready to prevent a disorderly market but would not impose exchange controls, it said.

headline: TECK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reynolds Metals Loss
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company yesterday reported a loss of $21.1 million for the fourth quarter of 1981, compared with earnings of $33.5 million, or $1.72 a share, for the last quarter of 1980.

headline: MOODY SUSPENDS RATING ON 2 NUCLEAR PROJECTS
abstract: Moody's Investors Services Inc. suspended the credit rating yesterday on two controversial West Coast nuclear power projects, a move that effectively shuts them out of the credit markets and brings the projects one step closer to being terminated.   Borrowings for the construction of the two plants, Projects No.4 and 5 of the Washington Public Power Supply System, have totaled $2.25 billion, and termination of the projects could set off a legal battle challenging the methods used by all utilities to finance capital projects, analysts say.   A meeting is scheduled for today in Seattle during which the 88 Pacific No rth west utilities participating in the projects will indicate whet her they have enough money to forestall immediate termination.  But Wall Street analysts and members of the 88 utilitiesseriously dou bt that immediate termination can be prevented.

headline: Talking Business with Professor Domar of M.I.T. The Troubled Polish System
abstract: In decades past, advocates of capitalism criticized the inefficiencies of socialist economies, while Communists predicted the downfall of capitalist economies. More recently, comparisons of different countries' prosperity have been made, but little attention has been given to the relative merits of different economic systems.   The current economic problems in Poland raise the question of how important the form of the economy has been in determining what has happened to that country. Here, Evsey D. Doma r, Ford Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of T echnology, an expert in comparative economic systems, addresses that question.

headline: D'Arcy Names New Chairman
abstract: Alvin Hampel, who has long yearned to move formally from the creative side of the agency world to business side, is going to be doing it in a big way next Wednesday when he becomes chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York, which bills about $80 million. He will be replacing John Jay deGarmo, 57 years old, who has been chairman since D'Arcy acquired his deGarmo agency, with its $60 million in billings, in January 1980. Mr. deGarmo resigned.

headline: WARNER-LAMBERT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Foreign Worker Ban
abstract: Canada today banned the hiring of foreign workers in mines, on construction sites, in some factories and for non-specialized occupations to protect Canadian jobs in a sluggish economy. The ban, announced by Lloyd Axworthy, Minister of Employment and Immigration, was part of a $50 million program begun last month to minimize the impact of Canada's growing unemployment.

headline: TAIWAN'S EXPORT-LED GROWTH
abstract: TOKYO TAIWAN'S economy, buffeted by world oil price increases and severance of diplomatic relations with Japan and the United States in the 1970's, is bearing up well with the possibility of rapid growth in the early 1980's despite a world recession.  The Government imposed a sharp credit squeeze early in 1981 to control a domestic inflation induced by international oil pric e risesin 1979. But this has now been relaxed, and a new team of Cabinet ministers was put in charge of the economy la te last year to increasegrowth in 1982.

headline: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-A.T.&T.  Delay Given
abstract: Judge Harold Greene of Federal District Court here, who has charge of the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, granted permission today to the Justice Department to file by next Wednesday a requested statement describing the ''competitive impact'' of the proposed settlement of the case.   The report had been due today, but the Justice Department late yesterday asked for a postponement of the deadline.

headline: Wide Price Differences On Super Bowl Ads
abstract: There were a lot of people who were shocked when they heard that the CBS-TV Network was asking $345,000 for a 30-second commercial slot during the Super Bowl last Sunday. But considering the number of people being reached, the local CBS-owned and affiliated stations were asking even more.

headline: WHY LIONEL SOUGHT CHAPTER 11 SHELTER
abstract: The Lionel Corporation, which has concentrated on toy retailing ever since selling its well-known train business more than 10 years ago, was apparently forced into bankruptcy proceedings last week because of poor store locations, ill-timed acquisitions and marketing mistakes.   Lionel's management would only say that its problems were caused by poor Christmas sales. Industry analysts say, however, that there were other problems. Stewart Robbins, an analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., noted that Lionel's acquisitions were made at a bad time - just before the economy started to decline.

headline: COEUR D'ARLENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Restraint Toward East Is Affirmed by Schmidt
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that West Germany would hold to its policy of restraint and cooperation with the Soviet bloc despite criticism from some Western countries.   Speaking on the crisis in Poland, Mr. Schmidt said at a meeting of his Social Democratic Party in this village o utside Wurzburg in northern Bavaria:   ''We will not give up the policy of dialogue, moderation and cooperation with the East.''

headline: Texaco Executives Exchanging Posts
abstract: James W. Kinnear, a 53-year-old executive vice president of Texaco Inc., has been named to the additional post of president of Texaco U.S.A., the corporation's largest division, which is based in Houston. At the same time Annon M. Card, a 62-year-old executive vice president who previously held the presidency of Texaco U.S.A., will return to the Harrison, N.Y., headquarters to oversee many of the international activities of the company that Mr. Kinnear previously supervised.

headline: Kissinger Meets Dominican
abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry M. Kissinger met Saturday with President Antonio Guzman to discuss President Reagan's planned Caribbean basin development plan. Mr. Kissinger was accompanied by the United States Ambasador here, Robert L. Yost, and the designer Oscar de la Renta. Mr.  Kissinger and his wife, Nancy, have been staying Mr. de la Renta's villa.

headline: Steel Output Up 2.6%
abstract: Steel production rose to 1.788 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 2.6 percent from the previous week's 1.743 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. TRUCKING DECONTROL HELD BOON FOR CANADIANS
abstract: Both the Interstate Commerce Commission and Congress are looking into complaints by major trucking companies that Canadians are crossing the border to take advantage of easier American trucking rules resulting from deregulation while American carriers are deterred from entering the Canadian market.   Several Federal agencies have become involved in the dispute between the United States and its largest trading partner, including the Departments of State, Commerce and Transportation and the United States trade representative.   At stake, according to the trucking industry, is a substantial part of the vast export-import trade between Canada and the United States. Last year, $39.6 billion worth of goods and services flowed into Canada, while the United States imported $46.4 billion from Canada.

headline: LAKE SHORE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: British Official Resigns
abstract: Sally Oppenheim resigned today as Minister for Consumer Affairs for what she said were personal reasons. No replacement was announced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

headline: Florida Lets Banks Fight
abstract: Florida's House of Representatives today defeated a bill that would have made it illegal for an out-of-state banking company to own more than 25 percent of a Florida bank's stock.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Financial Corp. said it had raised its holdings in Penn Central Corp. to the equivalent of 14.2 percent of its common stock through the acquisition of 80,000 shares and options to purchase 195,000 shares.   * C. Itoh & Co., Toyobo Co. and Descente Ltd., three Japanese concerns, said they had increased their share of Munsingwear Inc. to 31.8 percent of the common stock outstanding, or 601,274 common shares, including 32,700 shares purchased between Sept. 14, 1981, and Dec. 14, 1981, at prices ranging from $14.25 a share to $15 a share.   * Curtiss-Wright Corp. said it had increased its holdings in Western Union Corp. to 9.2 percent, or 1,566,500 shares, through the acquisition of 198,500 additional shares for $6.6 million.

headline: Prices Rise In O.E.C.D.
abstract: Average inflation in the 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the O.E.C.D. said today.   Prices among the organization's members rose an average of fivetenths of 1 percent in December and 1 percent in January 1981.

headline: Plan to Buy Advent Ended
abstract: The Kloss Video Corporation said it had scrapped plans to acquire the Advent Corporation, a maker of stereo speakers and large-screen televisions that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code since last year.   Herbert Kloss, president of Kloss Video, said that ''we made a proposal to Advent but it wasn't possible to do it under the conditions we had set.''

headline: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

headline: Economic Scene; Looser Money, Less Inflation?
abstract: THE prospects for the American economy in 1982 are growing increasingly dismal. The securities markets have weakened, reflecting anxieties over rising interest rates. The Administration's policy makers have insisted that interest rates would come down with inflation, but the markets do not believe it. They foresee pressures on rates intensifying as the Government plans for growing budget deficits three years ahead - deficits that were supposed not to happen, as faster growth threw off enough additional revenue to pay for the big tax cuts.   At the same time, unemployment is climbing faster than expected.  The jobless rate, which was 7.4 percent when Ronald Reagan took office, reached 8.9 percent in December, and could hit 10 percent in the months ahead.

headline: More Belgians Idle
abstract: Unemployment in Bel gium reached a record of424,000, or 10.2 percent of the labor force, on Dec. 31, the Government reported today. It has predicted a further rise to 450,000in January.

headline: ISRAELI ARABS PREPARING FOR STRIKE AND PROTEST
abstract: Leaders of the nearly 600,000 Israeli Arabs are preparing for a general strike and major demonstration in northern Israel on Tuesday to demand an end to the Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and the formation of an independent Palestinian country.   While Israeli Arabs have in large number always favored the Palestinian cause, although not always its methods, this sentiment has until now been muted. With the coincidence, however, of the present unrest in the occupied territories and a date that for six years has been the occasion for demonstrations on behalf of Israeli Arab grievances, regional leaders have decided to join the two causes.   The date is called ''Land Day,'' the anniversary of a series of incidents in the northern Galilee in 1976 in which six Arabs were killed in clashes with Israeli security forces when they demonstrated against Israeli expropriation of Arab lands.

headline: HAIG, IN CAIRO, CALLS SIDES STILL FAR APART
abstract: After presenting the new American ideas for breaking the impasse in Palestinian self-rule negotiations to Israel and Egypt, Secretary of State Alexander M . Haig Jr. said today that despite ''som e progress'' the sides were still far apart.   Mr. Haig met for three hours this morning in Jerusalem with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other Israeli leaders, continuing their sessions from Wednesday. In the afternoon, Mr. Haig flew here and met for an hour with President Hosni Mubarak and later with Foreign Ministry officals.

headline: Business Loans by Banks Rise
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that business loans outstanding at large banks across the country rose $594 million in the week ended Jan. 6. Data on business loans extended by large banks are normally reported Friday, but were delayed last week because bad weather interferred with the gathering of statistics.

headline: Mitsubishi Denies Report on Smelter
abstract: Mitsubishi Light Metals Industries, responding to a statement by a Philippines Government agency, said it had no intention of setting up an aluminum smelter there.   The company, Japan's largest aluminum processor and fabricator, was commenting on a report by the Philippines Trade and Industry Ministry that Mitsubishi had expressed interest in replacing Reynolds International of the United States in a smelter project by transferring an existing mill from Japan.   Mitsubishi has cut production to 65,000 tons a year from a peak of 350,000 tons in 1978 by closing one plant entirely a nd reducing operations at another, a company spokesman said.

headline: News An alysis
abstract: Everything from auto license plates to government stationery proclaims this country to be ''free Nicaragua,'' but the reality is that its fortunes are dependent upon other countries, particularly the United States.   Its economy can be rescued only through the cooperation of the Western financial community, and political peace can be won only through an understanding with Washington.   It is an unhappy fact of life for a revolutionary leadership that fought under an ''anti-Yanqui'' banner and largely believes in Marxist analysis. But it is an accepted fact, and the poor state of relations with the Reagan Administration is a source of genuine despair and, at times, fear in Managua.

abstract: Human Rights Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space 3 P.M.

headline: MUBARAK, INSTALLING CABINET, STRESSES STABILITY
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak swore in a new Egyptian Cabinet today and ordered it to focus on internal calm and on national economic and social stability.   After the swearing in, Mr. Mubarak served as chairman of the new Cabinet's first meeting and told it, ''Public service should be based on objectivity, unselfishness, integrity, purity of behavior and thought, and avoidance of favoritism and graft.''   The last part of Mr. Mubarak's remarks was an allusion to a recent ethics court case in which a millionaire former member of Parliament, Rashad Osman, was convicted of corruption. He was ordered detained for a year, and the state sequestered his assets.

headline: Doner Settles Case With Ex-employees
abstract: W.B. Doner & Company, Baltimore, has settled out of court a suit it filed last November in which it sought to prevent employees who formed another agency from serving former clients. In the settlement with members of the new firm, Smith, Burke & Azzam, Doner received an undisclosed amount of cash.   The clients are the Roy Rogers division of the Marriott Corporation and Quality Inns Interntional.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Foreign companies must test Japan's new measures intended to eliminate import barriers before they know whether the Tokyo Government's actions do in fact open the Japanese market to their products.   Even before that crucial test, two things about the market-opening program are evident.  First, last week's lifting of 67 nontariff barriers by the Japanese Cabinet - most of them dealing with product safety requirements and quality control proced ures - will have little near-term effect on thebig trade surpluses that Japan is running wit h the United States and the European Economic Community.   Second, if the program is judged to be a meaningful step in opening up Japan's economy to foreign products, the payoff for Japan - in terms of easing trade tensions - is likely to be greater in the United States than in Western Europe.

headline: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31

headline: EXILE GROUP SEEKS TO OUST SANDINISTS
abstract: A group of Latin American exiles offered today to provide several hundred volunteers for any efforts by the Reagan Administration to disrupt the Nicaraguan Government.   ''We've been urging that this be done since our inception two and a half years ago,'' said Ellis Rubin, a lawyer who represents the Inter-American Expeditionary Task Force.   The group, also known as the Everglades Commandos, has been openly training exiles southwest of here for possible insurgent operations in Cuba and Nicaragua.

headline: Patents
abstract: A coin grader for use by collectors who are not expert numismatists was patented this week by Edmund J. Sobresky Sr. of Pottstown, Pa., himself an enthusiastic collector.

headline: Levels Steady For Gasoline
abstract: Supplies of distillate declined and gasoline inventories remained virtually unchanged last week, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.   For the week ended last Friday, supplies of distillate showed a normal seasonal decline, falling to 135.6 million barrels from 140.6 million barrels a week before.

headline: Chrysler Extends Rebate Program
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was extending its free maintenance and rebate program, which offers up to $2,000 on some vehicles, until April 10.   The program had been scheduled to end on Wednesday, but the auto maker's sales were off 34.9 percent in the last reported 10-day sales period, March 11-20, even with the current sales promotions.   The extension means that Chrysler will have run sales promotions for nearly six consecutive months.

headline: Dow Advances 4.75; Phone Accord Cited
abstract: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, with investor sentiment buoyed by news that the Justice Department had settled its antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The settlement calls for A.T.& T. to divest itself of its local telephone companies.    The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 4.75 points, to 866.53.  Trading was halted in A.T.& T. at 10:41 A.M., when the stock was up 5/8, to 58 7/8, and did not resume.  The response on Wall Street was positive. ''My opinion is that the settlement is bullish for the company,'' said Harry Edelson of the First Boston Corporation. ''If local service is separated from the long lines operation, A.T.& T. can compete mo re effectively.''

headline: RYAN INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITISH TROOPS IN KENYA FOR SPECIAL TRAINING
abstract: Among the thousands of visitors who occasionally visit Nairobi's nightclubs or shop-lined streets at this time of year are dozens of lean Britons whose disciplined manner contrasts with the casual amiability of ordinary tourists.   Even in civilian dress, they stand out as soldiers - in this case, members of Britain's Special Air Service. Now is the time of year when hundreds of them are brought to Kenya for intense training programs.

headline: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: HONDURA S DETECTS NO MAJOR ARMS SUPPLY TO SALVADOR REBELS
abstract: Despite United States charges that Nicaragua is stepping up arms shipments to Salvadoran guerrillas, no evidence is available here to indicate that the weapons are passing through Honduras, which borders on both Nicaragua and El Salvador.   The Honduran Army controls all border crossings from Nicaragua and patrols the border with El Salvador, but it says it has not intercepted any major arms shipments destined for El Salvador since late January last year, a few days after the Salvadoran guerrillas began an abortive ''final offensive'' to topple the United Statesbacked junta.   In the weeks before that offensive, documents captured from the guerrillas suggested that most weapons were reaching them from Nicaragua overland through Honduras. The crash of several light aircraft inside El Salvador also seemed to show that some arms were being flown to the rebels.

headline: President Elected, By Liberty Life
abstract: Stuart L. Lerner, 51 years old, has been elected president of the Liberty Life Assurance Company, a major life insurer based in Boston with more than $5 billion worth of life insurance in force. He succeeds Melvin B. Bradshaw, 59, who was appointed to the vacant post of chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer of the subsidiary of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.   ''The industry, almost without exception, has had a fantastic year in terms of new business, which was at levels higher than ever,'' Mr. Lerner said in a telephone interview. But he noted that the industry faced problems of change, one of them being the flow of funds from established insurance policies.

headline: Comment; HOW NOT TO BEAT LAST YEAR'S SALES
abstract: THE retailer's exhortation to the troops has always been, ''Beat l ast year!'' Maybe it's not emblazoned over employee entrances, but i t's there as a daily subliminal reminder, in the same way that it's i nvisibly watermarked on all internal-use retail store forms. And p erhaps now, the words lurk somewhere in computer storage, too.  Beating last year is based on a simple theory. The more sales that a store can generate, the more that profit piles up, providing the payroll isn't out of hand and the company isn't hemorrhaging bank interest.

headline: Savings Banks
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''A Plan to Save the Savings Banks'' (Feb. 28), almost every article on the plight of both the banks and the real estate business stresses the problem of the banks being committed to low interest mortgages while paying much higher rates to depositors.   We are reluctant owners of two houses.

headline: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ad Panel Speaker Sees Consumer Discretion
abstract: As keynote speaker of the 28th annual conference of the Advertising Research Foundation, Leo Bogart, executive vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, offered a scary prediction Tuesday - the future could hold a time when consumers, thanks to the wonders of telecommunications, could be asking for the advertising they want to see.   That means, of course, that they will not be asking for advertising they do not want to see.

headline: SENATOR INTRODUCES BILL ON TRADING RECIPROCITY
abstract: The chairman of the Senate's trade subcommittee today introduced legislation to reinforce the President's powers to withdraw trading privileges in the United States from countries that do not provide American exporters with reciprocal market access.   John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, who heads the Senate panel, joined a growing list of legislators who are sponsoring similar bills aimed at forcing down foreign trade barriers with the threat of progressive exclusion of foreign traders from American markets.   The Congressional moves began late last year with a Senate-passed rider to a communications bill that would specifically bar Japan from selling telecommunications equipment here to the extent that American companies are kept out of the same market in Japan.   Although Japan is not cited in other bills sponsored by at least a dozen legislators, the drive has picked up momentum with the recent report of a record $18.1 billion American trade deficit with Japan and with the dissatisfaction now being expressed openly by American trade officials at the latest of a series of liberalization steps by the Tokyo Government.

headline: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN-U.S. TRADE GAP $13.4 BILLION
abstract: Japan reported today that it had achieved a record trade surplus with the United States in 1981 of $13.4 billion, nearly twice as high as in 1980. American trade officials said they saw little likelihood that the surplus would recede significantly this year.   A Japanese emissary, Shintaro Abe, Minister of Industry and Trade, met with President Reagan and also with members of Congress shortly after the trade figures were announced in Tokyo. He said that Japan intended to meet the insistent demands of its foreign critics by taking dramatic steps later this month to open wider its home market to foreign goods, thus reducing its trade surpluses.

headline: Holders Tender Howden Stock
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Inc., one of the nation's largest general insurance brokers, said that its tender offer last November to acquire Alexa nder Howden Group Ltd., a London-based insurance brokerage, fo r more than $250 million in securities had been accepted by t he majority of Howden's stockholders.   Alexander & Alexander said that taking into account the Howden shares it previously purchased, it now owned or controlled more than 80 percent of the Howden shares outstanding.

headline: Poland Makes Debt Payments
abstract: Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citibank, acknowledged publicly yesterday that Poland had recently paid his bank some of the interest due in 1981 on the country's debt.   Mr. Wriston, speaking on CBS-TV's news program ''Face the Nation,'' also predicted that Poland would be able to meet interest payments due on its total debt of approxiamtely $26 billion, but had not paid all the interest it owed.

headline: Tosco's Shale Oil Plant Gets Another U.S. Loan
abstract: The Tosco Corporation said today that the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation had approved $105 million in federally guaranteed loans to help finance construction of the huge Colony shale-oil project in western Colorado for the next six months. Tosco said it would draw $3 million on April 1 and begin drawing the balance in July.   The authorization is the second for Tosco; the company has already drawn $83 million from the Federal Financing Bank against an earlier loan guarantee of $1.1 billion.

headline: UMET TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WALESA BABY IS BAPTIZED, BUT FATHER IS NOT THERE
abstract: Lech Walesa's daughter, seven-week-old Maria Wiktoria, was baptized before a huge crowd in a small wooden church outside Gdansk today, but the Solidarity leader was not released from internment to attend the ceremony.   A chair intended for him remained empty in front of the altar of the Church of God's Providence, while a crowd estimated at 7,000 filled the church and flowed onto the street outside, where the proceedings were broadcast by loudspeakers.   As the baptismal party left the church, the crowd shouted ''Solidarity! Solidarity!'' and ''Give us Lech back!'' Many held up V-for-victory signs.   There were no reports of any disturbances, and the police kept away from the church, which is situated on a former airstrip near a housing development. Only on distant approach roads could policemen be seen.

headline: STOCK TABLES
abstract: To the Business Editor: Great idea! Please do it!  DR. JOHN R. VIG Colts Neck, N.J., Feb. 7, 1982

headline: PIRACY IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA
abstract: On Sept. 25 Burton T. Kyle, director of the Office of Ship Operations of the Maritime Administration in Washington, sent out this advisory to international fleet managers:   ''Mariners are advised to use caution while transiting waters in the approaches to Singapore, and especially the Strait of Malacca in the vicinity of Phillip Channel, because of recent attacks on vessels by pirates.''   Stopping piracy, especially for Sin@gapore, now the second-largest port in the world and the third-largest oil-refining center, is crucial, since the city-state has based its economic plans in large part on the growth of shipping and refining, both of which are threatened if pirates are allowed to interfere with the orderly operation of shipping lanes or the safe anchorage of ships in Singapore's harbor.   Over the past year, there have been 29 reported incidents of piracy in the Phillip Channel, the narrow, five-mile sealane 13 miles south of Singapore, in Indonesian waters. The channel is the only passage for ships going from west to east through the Strait of Malacca into the South China Sea.

headline: SENATE UNCOVERS WASTE IN S.B.A.'s BONDING AID
abstract: Senate investigators said today that a Small Business Administration program, intended to help small-business and minority contractors, had lost millions of dollars because of lax managemment and fraud.   Investigators for the Senate Committee on Small Business said that a five-month investigation of the S.B.A.'s surety bond guarantee program disclosed that the agency had paid $178 million in claims in the last 10 years and that some organized-crime figures had profited from the program.   The investigators said they could not determine precisely how much of the money was squandered by some of the program's participants.  But one investigator said, ''It's certainly clear that, at a minimum, millions of dollars in taxpayers' funds have been lost because the S.B.A.'s lax management procedures have left the program vulnerable to waste and fraud.''

headline: World Bank Increases Its Charges on Loans
abstract: Directors of the World Bank today voted to increase char ges on loans to poor countries because of the squeeze onresources cau sed by austerity moves in the United States and other industrial co untries.   The directors set a so-called front-end fee of 1.5 percent on the face amount of new loans made by the bank.

headline: NATO Exercise Starts Today
abstract: A major command exercise of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is to start Monday with a scenario featuring anti-Soviet moves in eastern Europe, NATO sources said today.

headline: Saints and Sinners
abstract: To the Business Editor: Gary Sherbell's ''In Stocks, All the Saints and Sinners'' (Feb. 7) assigns Procter & Gamble a ''plus'' for promptly pulling a defective product off the market and Grumman a ''minus'' for the same thing - pulling a defective bus off the streets. As soon as the problem was discovered, we took full responsibility.

headline: MCGRAW-EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A FAST BY 53 BLACKS CATCHES CAPE TOWN OFF GUARD
abstract: Demonstrations outside South Africa's white Parliament are strictly forbidden, but for 17 days now 53 homeless blacks have been engaged in a protest no more than a stone's throw away and the authorities have seemed uncharacteristically hesitant about how to respond.   If the blacks were actually throwing stones, the answer would be easy. Instead, they have taken sanctuary inside St. George's Anglican Cathedral, which is adjacent to the Parliament building, and have vowed to fast there until they either die or win permission from the authorities to reside here legally with their families.   Those taking part in the fast belong to a larger group of Xhosaspeaking blacks who have spent most of the last nine months resisting efforts by the Government, which officially views them as illegal immigrants and foreigners, to expel them from Cape Town.   The contest of wills started last July when the police raided a hostel in Langa township, causing hundreds of so-called illegal blacks to flee into the surrounding bush where they soon established a squatters' camp. This was then followed by repeated raids and mass arrests, until finally the campsite was bulldozed and burned and the squatters deported to a supposedly independent homeland called Transkei.

headline: Reader Comment; BELL LETTERS
abstract: To the Business Editor: William C. McGowan's ''Comment: Ma Bell's Myths'' (Jan. 24) includes statements that as a career Bell System employee who has worked with the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Western Electric, New York Telephone and A.T.& T. I would rebut.   On the subject of cross subsidies: When I was a telephone installer in Harlem it was not unusual to take two days to install a single resident telephone. Installation charge at the time was about $5.  During the same period I could install four to eight phones in a downtown business office in two working days. The sidewalk public telephones, an essential public service, have never paid for themselves from the day they were first installed in New York City.

headline: ECONOMISTS EXPECT CUT IN INFLATION
abstract: A broad range of economists predict that February's decline in producer prices - the first drop in six years - will be reflected in consumer prices during the next couple of months as businesses sell off their inventories.   ''We might even see'' the Consumer Price Index fall, Lawrence G.  Chimerine, chairman of Chase Econometrics, said. A decline in the index, which measures the average of a range of consumer prices, would be the first in more than 16 years.   Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that the United States would not face double-digit inflation so long as the Federal Reserve Board maintained its tight-money policy. He added that the recession was nearing an end and predicted that the nation's economy would begin to turn upward in the next three months. (Page D6.)

headline: NICARAGUA READY TO TALK WITH U.S.
abstract: The Nicaraguan Government said today that it was ready to hold negotiations with the United States on all issues, including assertions of Sandinist arms shipments to Salvadoran rebels.   ''We have never accepted the U.S. charge of an arms flow through here,'' said Sergio Ramirez Mercado, a member of the three-man junta, ''but this does not mean that we're unwilling to discuss the point.''    Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said Monday that a condition for opening negotiations with Nicaragua would be Managua's agreement to end what he characterized as its deep military involvement in El Salvador. The Sandinist Government has previously said it could not accept that point as a condition because it was not playing a direct role in the Salvadoran insurgency.

headline: Bank of Scotland Issue
abstract: The Bank of Scotland Ltd. said today that it planned to enter the United States commercial paper market with an initial issue of up to $100 million. The bank, which is 35 percent held by Barclays Bank Ltd., said formalities had been completed for an issue in the near future.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Fidler Group has resigned the circulation marketing account of Business Week magazine, which is conducting an agency review.

headline: HAWKING ARMS OVERSEAS
abstract: AS the costs of sophisticated military hardware escalate, arms manufacturers are seeking foreign orders more than ever to raise their output and thereby keep unit prices affordable. This trend, defense strategists and industry analysts say, raises the disturbing question of whether the industrial powers will be able to afford to arm themselves in the coming decade without arming the rest of the world at the same time.   The size of the trade and the many new players in it are increasingly sparking political and economic interest. The world arms trade was valued at $30 billion in transactions last year and has been growing by about $5 billion a year since 1975, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, or Sipri, an independent agency that monitors the international arms bazaar.   But the most striking element of the rise has been in the cost of equipment. Today's XM1 tank, a heavily armed, 59-ton piece of hardware loaded with infrared devices and ele ctronic gear that would rival a jetliner's dashboard, costs about $1. 5 million. By contrast, the United States Army's standard World War I I tank, a lumbering hulk with relatively simple gear, sold for about $50,000 i n its day. The upward spiral in weaponry costs during the past 30 yea rs has beenfed by inflation in raw materials and labor coupled with t he everincreasing trend toward complexity in military equipme nt.

headline: Morgan's Earnings Up 35.4% in Quarter
abstract: J.P. Morgan & Company, the corporate parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter operating earnings soared by 35.4 percent, to $124.7 million, from $92.1 million in the comparable period of 1980, largely because of a jump in net interest income.   Compared with the $75.8 million earned in the third quarter of 1981, the increase was even more dramatic, up 64.6 percent.  Morgan, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, was the first of the nation's 10 largest banks to report fourth-quarter earnings.

headline: Reeves Brothers Gets Buy-Out Bid
abstract: Reeves Brothers Inc., a major producer of apparel fabrics, industrial textiles and foam produ cts, said it had received a $70-ashare le veraged buyout offer from a group of investors and current manag ement that would be valued at about $165 million.   Reeves said that the proposal, which would be managed through an affiliate of the Bankers Trust Company, is based on the contingency that selected executives would remain and invest in the proposed venture and upon execution of definitive agreements. The company said that its board had approved a study of the proposal and would reach a formal decision on its recommedation to shareholders as soon as practicable.

headline: PEOPLE
abstract: * Edward J. Abramson has been named advertising director of Bride's magazine.

headline: MANAGUA LEADER AT U.N. IS A MODERATE SANDINIST
abstract: When Daniel Ortega Saavedra was received by President Carter just months after he helped topple the pro-American Somoza regime in July 1979, Nicaraguans were surprised to see the former guerrilla in the White House - and astonished to see him smiling.   Of the nine young Sandinist commanders who run Nicaragua today, Mr. Ortega has the reputation of being the most solemn, the least given to light banter or irreverent jokes. And nothing, it seemed, merited more serious attention than what were regarded as the historical ''sins'' of the United States against Nicaragua. Neverthless, there was Mr. Ortega smiling in Washington.

headline: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WARSAW NOTEBOOK: 'END OF THE DREAM'
abstract: Five women were sitting in the treatment room of a cosmetics parlor Saturday, their faces piled with mud packs, wrinkle-erasing ointments and various creams. One remarked listlessly that tangerines were in the shops for the first time in a year.   ''Wonder which of our friends they come from,'' said a second, drawing out the word ''friends'' in heavy irony.  A third wondered when it would be possible to travel abroad again, so that she could leave the country for good. It was not, in the context of today's Poland, a non sequitur. For almost everyone, the combination of economic misery - despite the occasiona l tangerine - and oppressive restrictions of personal freedom under martial law has made everyday life just about unbearable. H undreds, no doubt thousands, now talk openly about one dream - going to the West.

headline: DEBT TALKS THIS WEEK
abstract: Richard B. Black, chairman of AM International Inc. since last February, resigned over the weekend, the office equipment company said today. Analysts termed his departure another setback for the debt-ridden company.   Mr. Black, who will remain an AM consultant for six months, said that he was leaving to avoid possible conflicts of interest that might arise from his suit against former officers, directors and accountants at AM.   Last week Mr. Black, contending that AM officials had violated securities laws by disseminating misleading financial information about the company before he took over, filed a $3 million suit in United States District Court in Chicago.

headline: World Bank Sets 3 Loans
abstract: The World Bank today announced loans totaling $131.7 million to South Korea, Brazil and Peru to support agricultural projects.

headline: India Seeking Loan for Mill
abstract: The Government of India is expected to raise a $1 billion, 10-year syndicated bank loan later this month, banking sources said here today.   The credit will be part of a financing program for the construction of an integrated iron and steel mill and rolling plant in Orissa state.

headline: SIGNAL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BELL'S BREAKUP SPLITS FAMILY
abstract: The first of four generations of Kincys in the Bell System - 17 people in all - went to work for the telephone company here on New Year's Day, 1898, not quite 22 years after Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone.   Ronald Kincy, one of the 17, can prove it by producing an old pay card for that date, showing that his grandfather earned $1.50 a day as a construction worker for what would eventually become the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, the largest operating company, by some measures, in the Bell System today.   Some time back, an office worker was cleaning out old files, came across the pay card, and asked Mr. Kincy if he wanted it as a memento. It's the kind of thoughtful gesture one family member might make for another, and in the case of Ma Bell, it is perhaps fitting.

headline: Dow Edges Up 0.38 As Volume Eases
abstract: Stock prices edged higher yesterday in cautious trading following Thursday's broad advance that marked the strongest rally in three weeks. Semiconductor issues were among the market's better performers.   The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.38, to 805.65, after the previous day's surge of 9.42 points. On the New York Stock Exchange, gainers led declining issues by 848 to 573 yesterday. For the entire week, the Dow climbed 8.28 points, thereby reversing its recent slump.

headline: A FRANCHISE BOOM IN PICTURE FRAMING
abstract: Ten years ago, owners of a print or painting would no sooner think of framing it themselves than they would of building their own car.  Framing was the work of artisans who alone knew the mysteries of mats and moldings.   Today, stripped of its mystique by ready-made frames and thousands of new frame shops, framing has grown into an industry with more than $1 billion in sales. Among those rapidly gaining ground are framing franchises, catering primarily to a do-it-yourself clientele.

headline: ISRAELI CABINET OFFICIAL, ON TRIAL, RESIGNS
abstract: The secretary of the Israeli Cabinet, who is on trial for giving sensitive information to a journalist, submitted his resignation today.   The official, Aryeh Naor, denied that his move was part of a deal to drop the case against him. But the chief prosecution witness, Ranan Lurie, a political cartoonist for The Times of London, said he had been told by the prosecutor that there was no need for him to come to Israel to testify.

headline: 17 Leftists Executed in Iran
abstract: Seventeen leftists, including a woman, were executed in three Iranian towns last week after being found guilty of armed rebellion and membership of opposition groups, the Teheran newspaper Ettelaat reported today.

headline: Pabst Brewery Closing Delayed
abstract: A Federal judge has ordered the Pabst Brewing Company to keep its Peoria Heights brewery open pending completion of arbitration proceedings between the company and its unionized workers.   United States District Judge Harold Baker granted a temporary restraining order sought by Brewery Workers Local 770 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents some 600 of the plant's 700 workers.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM TEXT OF A DECREE SIGNED BY A.T.&T. AND U.S.
abstract: Following is the text of the consent decree filed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department yesterday with the United States District Court in Newark:   Plaintiff, United States of America, having filed its complaint herein on January 14, 1949; the defendants having appeared and filed their answer to such complaint denying the substantive allegations thereof; the parties, by their attorneys, having severally consented to a Final Judgment which was entered by the Court on January 24, 1956, and the parties having subsequently agreed that modification of such Final Judgment is required by the technological, economic and regulatory changes which have occurred since the entry of such Final Judgment:   Upon joint motion of the parties and after hearing by the Court, it is hereby ORDERED, ADJUDGED, AND DECREED that the Final Judgment entered on January 24, 1956, is hereby vacated in its entirety and replaced by the following items and provisions: I -A.T.& T. Reorganization   A. Not later than six months after the effective date of this Modification of Final Judgment, Defendant A.T.& T. shall submit to the Department of Justice for its approval, and thereafter implement, a plan of reorganization. Such plan shall provide for the completion, within 18 months after the effective date of this Modification of Final Judgment, of the following steps:   1. The transfer from A.T.& T. and its affiliates to the B.O.C.'s (Bell Operating Companies), or to a new entity subsequently to be separated from A.T.& T. and to be owned by the B.O.C's, of sufficient facilities, personnel, systems and rights to technical information to permit the B.O.C.'s to perform, independently of A.T.& T., exchange telecommunications and exchange access functions, including the procurement for, and engineering, marketing and management of, those functions, and sufficient to enable the B.O.C.'s to meet the equal exchange access requirements of Appendix B;   2.

headline: State Clears Bank Sale
abstract: After four years of effort, a group of private Arab investors yesterday cleared the last hurdle necessary for their acquisition of Financial General Bankshares Inc., based in Washington, the only multistate bank holding company in the Eastern half of the United States.   Financial General owns two New York banks, the Bank of Commerce in New York City, and the Community State Bank in Albany. It also owns banks in Maryland, Virginia, Tennessee and the District of Columbia.

headline: Control Data Deal
abstract: The Control Data Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire a ''significant interest'' in the Centronics Data Computer Corporation, a Hudson, N.H., maker of computer printers. Control Data said that the deal would be made in conjunction with the NCR Corporation and International Computers Ltd., Control Data's partners in the joint venture, Computer Peripherals Inc. Under terms of the agreement, Centronics would issue stock to Control Data, NCR and International Computers in return for a cash investment by Control Data and the printer business of Computer Peripherals. Centronics reported revenues of $124 million for the fiscal year ended June 28, 1981.

headline: DEFICITS AND TIGHT MONEY VIEWED AS THREAT TO A 1982 RECOVERY
abstract: A moderate economic recovery is likely this year, but its prospects are threatened both by growing budget deficits and by the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, according to a forecast released today by the Congressional Budget Office.   Even with the recovery, unemployment will continue at high rates, the study said.  Based on its economic and spending assumptions, the Budget Office estimates that the deficit for the fiscal year 1982, ending Sept. 30, will be $109 billion. Without any further spending cuts or tax increases, the deficit would widen to $157 billion in 1983 and $188 billion in 1984, according to the projections.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Associated Madison Companies approved a previously proposed merger with the American Can Company in a stock and cash transaction valued at about $123 million.   * Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had been awarded a $100 million contract to supply pipe for a 320-mile portion of a multistate natural gas pipeline system that will extend from western Wyoming to eastern Nebraska.

headline: Delinquent Mortgages Up
abstract: Late payments on mortgage loans rose to a 17-year record last month as recession and high interest rates continued to squeeze household budgets, a savings and loan industry group said in a report scheduled for release Tuesday.   In February, payments on 1.21 percent of the mortgages held by savings and loan associations were considered delinquent, compared with 1.17 percent in January and 0.94 percent in February 1981, the United States League of Savings Associations said.

headline: REVIEW OF BELL CASE ON RATES IS URGED
abstract: A Long Island consumer advocate asked the state Public Service Commission yesterday to reopen the New York Telephone Company's pending request for multimillion-dollar revenue increases so that the impact of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's reorganization on the request could be evaluated.   But the commission chairman, Paul L. Gioia, said state law required the commission to decide the case by the first week of April. He said it was unlikely that the reorganization would affect the local company's rates in the coming year because the settlement with the Department of Justice gives A.T.& T. 18 months to give up its 22 local operating companies, including New York Telephone.

headline: BALANCING THE BUDGET- BY LAW
abstract: WASHINGTON IN what would surely be a delicious irony, it may be the fiscal policy of Ronald Reagan that drives Congress and the states to adopt a constitutional amendment ''requiring'' that the Federal budget be balanced.   Sponsors of such an amendment (it would also limit Uncle Sam's tax bite out of the national economy) hope for a Senate floor vote this spring. ''Some time in May,'' says an aide to the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, who manages the Senate agenda.   The White House last week began addressing the issue - substance, timing and tactics. President Reagan sympathizes with such an amendment but some of his senior staff have reservations about the one pending in the Senate. Whatever its support, however, it could prove difficult and perhaps impossible to enforce.

headline: POPE CALLS VOICE FOR SOLIDARITY IN POLAND VITAL
abstract: Pope John Paul II declared today that only the full restoration of the rights of Solidarity offered a way out of the Polish crisis.   ''Without such respect for the rights of man, the normalization of the life of society, development of economic life and safeguarding of culture in all its expressions remain impossible,'' the Pope told a group of labor leaders from various countries whom he received in a special audience today.   The Pope thanked the union leaders for having met here to express their concern over events in his country, ''where many of your colleagues, workers and the entire population are suffering very grave trials.'' The labor officials included representatives from Italy, West Germany, France and Belgium as well as a number of Solidarity leaders who were outside Poland when martial law was declared Dec. 13.

headline: A PLAN TO SAVE THE SAVINGS BANKS
abstract: WASHINGTON F OR 20 years, Representative Fernand J. St. Germain worked steadily to cultivate his political garden but rarely, despite growing seniority, did he find himself a place in the sun.   The people of Rhode Island's First Congressional District, of course, knew him as their man in Washington. He was the guy with the listed home telephone number who returned to Woonsocket each weekend and who liked nothing better than to drop in at the Ever-Ready Diner in Providence to eat franks and beans with his blue-collar constituents. They kept sending him back to Congress virtually without challenge.   In recent years the lobbyists and bureaucrats involved in banking and housing issues came to know Fred St. Germain, too, as he became an important legislative figure and subcommittee chairman. But except for brief periods, such as when he led an effort to tighten banking practices in the wake of the Bert Lance affair, Mr. St. Germain remained largely unknown.

headline: NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EVENTUALLY, MOST BALLOONS DEFLATE
abstract: Prices A question that inevitably arises in formulating strategies for financial management in the 1980's is inflation. We are all painfully aware of the prolonged, intense, and some say endemic inflation that has plagued the world economy in recent years.  This inflation has been both virulent and pervasive. It has nurtured a strong psychological bias of expectations that inflation will continue. The combination of past, actual, and expected inflation has influenced all economic decisions either to minimize the impact - or better yet - to take advantage of continued inflation.

headline: PROTECTIONISM: THE GATHERING STORM
abstract: AT the end of the 1970's, after international trade liberalization accords were successfully completed, it looked as if the everrampant forces of protectionism had been dealt a forceful blow.  Yet barely two years after the trade talks known as the Tokyo Round came to an end, nations are quarreling as they haven't since the 1930's over market access, discrimination, reciprocity, pricing - over the general principles of fairness in trade. And protectionism is on the march again.   - The Commerce Department, in response to vociferous complaints by the domestic steel industry, has filed proceedings against France, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Rumania, South Africa and Spain, accusing them of competing unfairly in selling steel in the American market.   - Seven American steel companies have filed for relief from lowpriced imports from 11 countries, mostly in Western Europe. They charge that those countries have subsidized their steelmakers, enabling them to ''dump'' products on the American market at prices below production costs. The petitions could lead to higher duties on the foreign steel and higher prices for American steel users.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Last Western Reporters In Uganda Are Expelled   NAIROBI, Kenya, March 1 (AP) - The Ugandan Government expelled the last two Western correspondents based in Kampala today without giving any reason, the journalists said.   Trent O'Keefe, 26 years old, of Sydney, Australia, and Jack Ritchie, 24, of Chicago, said they received letters signed by the acting principal immigration officer, A.M. Kyafulumya, advising them that their entry permits had been canceled and asking them to leave immediately.

headline: French Atomic Test Reported in Pacific
abstract: France carried out a nuclear explosion in the Pacific last Sunday in preparation for the construction of a neutron weapon, informed sources said today.

headline: TWO NATIONALISMS COMPETE IN DACCA
abstract: Using terms that reflect the fundamental split in this nation of 90 million people, Prime Minister Shah Azizur Rahman declared in Parliament this week that there should be no conflict between Bengali nationalism and Bangladesh nationalism.   His remarks were perceived here as yet another of the periodic appeals for conciliation between the large groups of people who respond with varying emphasis to the two great traumas that have shaped this country.   The so-called Bengali nationalists are those people who came to prominence in the struggle to carve a Moslem nation out of British India.   When that nation was formed in 1947 as Pakistan, the Bengali nationalists, often in league with the Urdu speakers of West Pakistan, became the ruling elite.

headline: A Roundup Of Account Activity
abstract: Last week ended with a lot of activity in the account area.  George Lois, who once helped contribute the Pontiac Choirboys to local advertising legend, now has the opportunity to make a similar contribution.

headline: BUSINESS FAILURES SPREADING
abstract: Lenny Rerek says sales at his wholesale auto parts shop were ''pretty lousy'' through the first two months of 1982. Unfortunately, he adds, lousy sales were not the biggest problem. ''Receivables are the real problem,'' he said. ''You sell people merchandise and they don't pay up within 30 days.''   Late in February, the cash-flow problem became a cash-flow crisis for his company, in Farmingdale, L.I. ''We predicted slack sales, and so we ordered less,'' he said. ''But how can you predict something like this?''

headline: Washington Watch; Services Gain Lobbying Arm
abstract: WASHINGTON WHAT do bankers, accountants, lawyers, doctors, retailers, insurance agents, data processors, engineers, stockbrokers and advertising representatives have in common? They are all part of that heterogeneous grouping known as the services industry.   For many years the service sector, as opposed to manufacturing, has been the principal engine for economic growth and employment.  Excluding government workers, services employ 50 million people, accounting for two-thirds of nonfarm private sector employment.  Again excluding government activities, services account for half the gross domestic product.

headline: Short-Term Rates Off Sharply
abstract: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday, encouraging securities dealers to raise prices and lower yields for longer-term issues.   By late in the day, the rate on three-month Treasury notes was 12.27 percent, down from 12.7 percent a day earlier and more than a percentage point below the 13.36 percent average rate at last Monday's auction. In the long-term bond market, the 14 percent Treasury issue due in 2011 was offered late in the day at 100 18/32 to yield 13.92 percent, up about two points, or $20 per $1,000 bond, from a day earlier.   Although the markets are facing a heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds next week, analysts said that prices rose sharply yesterday because of short covering by dealers.

headline: AUTOS: STUDYING THE JAPANESE
abstract: Until 1980, James E. Harbour was a little known executive of the Chrysler Corporation, with a gnawing curiosity about Japanese-style manufacturing. Today, he is probably the most-talkedabout auto consultant in Detroit.   For it was Mr. Harbour who, after months of research on his own time, proved that Japanese auto makers can build an average subcompact car for $1,700 less than their North American rivals.  Worse yet, he found, they can assemble the car in half the time.   Mr. Harbour delivered a 54-page report on his findings to senior executives at the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation in the fall of 1980. One company asked him not to publicize his work until it had time to study his analysis and consider adopting some of his recommendations. He agreed, and for a year he sat quietly, waiting for someone to act.

headline: EXPLOSIVE ON A FRENCH TRAIN KILLS 5 AND INJURES 14
abstract: A high explosive tore up the second coach of the Paris-Toulouse express tonight, killing five passengers and injuring 14 others, half of them seriously. The police said the explosion was caused either by a bomb, deliberately set off, or by explosives being transported clandestinely.   The explosion occurred shortly before 9 P.M., when the 15-coach train, traveling from Paris to Toulouse at 100 miles an hour, was 15 miles north of Limoges. Within two hours, more than 200 firemen, policemen and railroad and other rescue workers were on the scene, pulling the dead and injured out of the wrecked car.

headline: 2 HANOVER BANKERS GET DIFFERENT TITLES
abstract: John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and its main subsidiary, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, yesterday disappointed a lot of people who had expected him to name a No.2 man at the nation's fourth-largest banking organization.   Instead, Mr. McGillicuddy merely changed the titles of the two front-runners - Harry Taylor, 55 years old, and John R. Torell 3d, 42.

abstract: If you are waiting to see the act that Bozell & Jacobs Southwest will come up with to replace Doyle Dane Bernbach on the American Airlines account, you do not have long to wait.

As a result of the merger, General Portland is now wholly owned by a United States subsidiary of Canada Cement Lafarge.

headline: Alsands Wins More Time
abstract: The Alsands consortium said today that the Alberta and federal governments had agreed to pay operating costs of up to $8 million (Canadian) to keep the $13 billion synthetic fuels project alive through April.   It said that attempts to attract new investment had been ''very discouraging,'' but that the governments would keep the project going one month while new investors were sought.   Only three out of the original eight members of the consortium are left: Shell Canada Ltd., Gulf Canada Ltd. and the state-owned Petro-Canada.

headline: TEAM OF OBSERVERS FOR SALVADORAN VOTE ANNOUNCED BY U.S.
abstract: The State Department announced today that Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum would head an official United States delegation to observe the elections in El Salvador on March 28.   At the same time, the department said it was ''convinced that the electoral process represents an essential first step for a peaceful solution to El Salvador's political problems.''   In what appeared to be an effort to build up international support for the Salvador Government's efforts, the department said that the elections ''have been strongly endorsed within El Salvador by the Catholic Church and the nation's major peasant, labor, business and professional organizations and externally, by the overwhelming majority of members of the Organization of American States.''

headline: Around the World; 40 People in Bombay; Attack U.S. Consulate
abstract: A group of about 40 people attacked the United States Consulate in Bombay with gasoline bombs Thursday to protest American arms sales to Pakistan.

headline: ARMY-BACKED CANDIDATE IN THE LEAD IN GUATEMALA
abstract: The Government's Presidential candidate took a substantial lead today in incomplete returns from Sunday's elections. But charges of wide-scale fraud and misconduct were raised by two major parties.   Gen. Angel Anibal Guevara, the 56-year-old former Defense Minister who is backed by the Army High Command and the three-party ruling coalition, challenged the opposition to prove their charges of fraud and said their complaints were the traditional ones of losers.   It was believed that fewer than half of the 2.3 million registered voters had cast ballots. All four Presidential candidates are right of center, and all pledged during their campaigns to crush leftist guerrillas, who are reportedly boycotting the elections.

headline: DUARTE'S PARTY CAUGHT IN MIDDLE IN SALVADOR
abstract: Venceremos, the radio station of El Salvador's leftist rebels, recently interrupted its daily fare of heraldic calls to insurrection to give air time to some statements by Conrado Lopez Andreu, an improbable revolutionary spokesman. Mr.  Lopez Andreu is the president of El Salvador's Chamber of Commerce.   What brought the two sides in this country's violently polarized politics together was their common loathing for the group in the middle, the Christian Democratic Party.   Led by the president of the military-civilian junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Christian Democrats have taken hold of the center of El Salvador's political life and carry Washington's hopes in next Sunday's elections for a constituent assembly.   But at the same time, they have engendered such opposition from politically outspoken Salvadorans on both sides of the ideological spectrum that it is appears doubtful they can win a majority of seats in the election and open to question whether they could govern effectively if they did.

headline: Iraq and Iran Agree To Visits for P.O.W.'s
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced an agreement today between Iran and Iraq for reciprocal visits by families of military prisoners seized by both sides in the 16-month-old Persian Gulf war.   Visits would be organized by the Red Cross, a United Nations spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Chemical methods of storing thermal energy and recovering it when needed were patented this week by staff members of the Martin Marietta Corporation, Bethesda, Md. The general method involves use of ammoniated salts in two different solutions to retain and produce the energy.

headline: Bond Prices Decline Sharply
abstract: Prices of long-term bonds fell as much as two points yesterday, as securities dealers were deluged with sell orders from investors and speculators who decided to take the profits they had earned over the past three weeks.   Illustrating the trading pattern in the long-term bond market, the Treasury's 14 percent issue due 2011 closed at 103 3/4 to yield 13.47 percent, down from 105 7/8 and a yield of 13.17 percent late Friday.  As recently as Feb.9, the bellwether Treasury bond was offered at a price of 94 3/4 to yield 14.77 percent.   Short-term rates also increased. Rates on outstanding Treasury bills rose by more than three-eighths of a percentage point, while other money market rates increased by slightly smaller amounts.

abstract: * Artco Industries has proposed to pay $7.50 a share to all nonmanagement holders, subject to regulatory approval, in an effort to become privately held. Artco has 1.6 million outstanding shares and more than 500 shareholders.   * Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and Warren E. Buffett, chairman of Berkshire, said they held 16.84 percent of Handy & Harman common stock, or 2,318,400 Handy & Harman common shares, including 150,500 shares purchased between Jan. 22, and Feb. 4 for $2,292,075.

headline: Ogilvy & Mather Ad Wins $25,000 Award
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather's magazine advertising campaign for Paco Rabanne Pour Homme men's fragrance won the first $25,000 Stephen E. Kelly Award, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the Magazine Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.   Ogilvy was the only agency among the finalists to be represented by two campaigns.

headline: Foreign Reporters Ask An End to Censorship
abstract: The following dispatch was passed through Polish military censorship.   WARSAW, Jan. 7 (Reuters) - Foreign correspondents permanently accredited in Poland have asked Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the country's military leader, to end press censorship and allow journalists to work more freely.

headline: Union May Ask G.M. Talks
abstract: The United Automobile Workers announced today that its General Motors Corporation council would meet here next Thursday to vote on whether to revive talks, broken off Jan. 28, on concessions with the automobile maker.

headline: News An alysis
abstract: Almost from the day two decades ago when he started publishing his weekly Comments on Credit, Henry Kaufman has had an attentive following. But to be an analyst on Wall Street and to have a following is not all that unusual.   Indeed, it is only in recent years that Mr. Kaufman, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., has taken on a kind of aura, where his market analyses can be expected to send tremors through the stock and bond markets. It does not happen every time he speaks, but it happens often enough to make it more than a coincidence.

headline: BUSINESS TAX CUT AFFECTING LEASING APPEARS NEAR END
abstract: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today in effect halted one of the most disputed aspects of last year's sweeping tax cut: the sale of unused business tax credits that would have cost the Treasury more than $3 billion in revenue by early fall.   In an unusual action, he announced that he would move to repeal or alter the so-called tax leasing provision in the Economic Recovery Act of 1981, passed by Congress last August. He said the changes or repeal of this provision would be retroactive to Saturday.   ''Corporations entering into leasing deals after today do so at their own risk,'' the Kansas Republican asserted.

headline: Canada Paper Data
abstract: British Columbia is overtaking Quebec as Canada's leading producer of pulp and paper, according to industry statistics released today. According to the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, total pulp and paper production in 1980 was 6.4 million tons for Quebec, up from 4 million tons in 1960, and 6.03 million tons in British Columbia, up from 1.9 million tons. Overall production in Canada as recorded by Statistics Canada was 21 million tons in 1980, almost double the 10.4 million tons produced two decades earlier.

headline: U.S. RATES CRITICIZED BY E.E.C. AS TALKS END
abstract: Leaders of the Common Market asserted today that high American interest rates were spreading recession around the world and undermining hopes of reducing unemployment.   The charge was contained in a communique issued at the end of the Common Market's two-day semiannual meeting, and the issue appeared to be the only one on which the 10-nation European Economic Community could agree.   The organization's representatives, unable to forge a common position to present at their June meeting with President Reagan and the Prime Ministers of Canada and Japan, left for home today facing a new internal crisis precipitated by President Francois Mitterrand of France.   Mr. Mitterrand surprised and angered many of them by reversing himself and rejecting compromise proposals to end a dispute over reducing Britain's disproportionately large share of the Common Market's costs.

headline: U.N. Plans Parley on Elderly

headline: BONN CHALLENGES PHILIP MORRIS MOVE
abstract: Can West German antitrust officials undermine a purchase by an American company of a stake in a London-based company owned by a South African?   It may sound like a case in an international business law moot court, but, some think that could be the eventual effect of a decision today by West Germany's tough Cartel Office, if upheld.   The office condemned the purchase by Philip Morris Inc. of a share of the Britain's Rothmans Tobacco Holdings Ltd. as inimical ''in its consequences for the German market.''

headline: JAPAN AND U.S. SPAR OVER TRADE
abstract: The Governments of the United States and Japan clashed publicly today for the first time over persistent trade imbalances and what should be done to redress them.   The occasion was the visit here of a Japanese parliamentary delegation that is trying to determine how committed the United States is to pursuing a retaliatory course if Japan does not take further steps to open its market to American and other foreign goods.    Reports reaching Japan of exceptionally tough language used by Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige in conversations with the delegation prompted an unusual public exchange between Japan's Government spokesman in Tokyo, Kiichi Miyazawa, who is also Chief Cabinet Secretary, and Mr. Baldrige over the principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international trade charter. Under its rules countries give equal trading privileges to all signatories.

headline: Enterprise Zones
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''The Potholed Road to Enterprise Zones'' (March 7) argues that most urban cores are unsuited to the task of benefiting from the Administration's proposed ''Enterprise Zones.'' As a director of both the New York Public Development Corporation and the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, I must disagree.   In terms of land, the Bronx has hundreds of available industrial acres, assembled into sites ranging in size from a few thousand square feet to more than 70 contiguous acres. Municipally owned land will be made available at little cost for the creation of jobs.

headline: GULF STILL SEARCHING FOR OIL UNIT TO BUY
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation, which last year explored the possibility of acquiring the Marathon Oil Company, has expanded its search to acquire a domestic oil company, security analysts were told by company officials here today.   Gulf last summer arranged a $5 billion line of credit, which has not been drawn down to date and which analysts believe is still available for an acquisition.

headline: I.B.M.'S TYPEWRITERS MISS A STROKE
abstract: Armonk, N.Y. - I.B.M. dominates two markets - one is computers. The other one is the ubiquitous office typewriter. There, as in computers, the giant of Armonk is losing ground - not total dollar sales, it is true, but market share.   The International Business Machines Corporation has owned the office typewriter market ever since the machines first became electric. And in the strictest sense, the company still does. It has been so successful, especially with its Selectric line, that it is now the only American maker of heavy-duty typewriters and has almost 90 percent of the market.   But the tool the secretary uses to type letters and memos has been changing and is no longer merely electric. More and more, it's a computerized machine with memory and limited word-processing functions. And in this market for the so-called electronic typewriter, I.B.M. faces numerous competitors, some as sophisticated in computer electronics as I.B.M. itself.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * E.F. Hutton Credit Corporation said that it had signed a $30 million revolving credit facility with a syndicate of international banks headed by S.G. Warburg & Company.

headline: French Stock Trading Halt
abstract: France's economics minister, Jacques Delors, has told officials of the Paris Stock Exchange to suspend trading in the stocks of banks and companies due to be nationalized, a spokesman at the ministry said today.   Stockbrokers said later that trading in the stocks and bonds of the banks and corporations to be nationalized will be suspended through Wednesday and resume Thursday.
