headline: Harvester Talks
abstract: The International Harvester Company said that the United Automobile Workers union has agreed to meet the company here next Wednesday to discuss Harvester's request for a $100 million reduction in its employment costs up to Oct. 1, the expiration date of the current union contract. About 20,000 of Harvester's employees are represented by the U.A.W. The union said it had agreed to meet International Harvester representatives next week but had not agreed to reopen the three-year contract.

headline: Nkomo Urges Zimbabwe To End Detention Law
abstract: Joshua Nkomo, leader of the opposition Zimbabwe African Peoples Union Party, urged the Government today to end the practice of arrests without trial. The detention law was imposed by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe under emergency powers inherited from the former white minority Government of Ian D.  Smith.

headline: HAIG AND GROMYKO HOLD 'SOBER' TALKS ON RANGE OF ISSUES
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union for eight hours today and said afterward that differences over Poland ''cast a long and dark shadow'' over all East-West issues.   In a news conference, Mr. Haig sought to leave the impression that the discussions had been as chilly and confrontational as he and his aides had advised beforehand that they would be.   There seemed to be no agreement on any major issue, and Mr. Haig said he had told Mr. Gromyko that the United States would not agree to new negotiations on strategic arms reduction until ''conditions permit,'' meaning an improvement in the Polish situation.   ''All in all the discussions were very sober,'' Mr. Haig said.

headline: More U.S. Layoffs By Caterpillar
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that it would indefinitely lay off a further 2,500 employees in the United States and partly shut down several domestic manufacturing plants during April and May.    It said the latest furloughs would bring the total number of domestic employees on layoff to about 7,200, out of a total work force of 65,500.   Caterpillar said the employment and production cutbacks were needed to bring output in line with lower demand for its products, mainly earthmoving machinery and diesel engines.

headline: BEGIN IS REPORTED TO ASSURE THE U.S. ON LEBANON MOVES
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, in a letter toPresident Rea gan, has reassured the United States that Israel will not make atta cks in Lebanon unless there is a ''clear provocation'' from Palestin ian or Syrian forces, Israeli and Administration sourcessaid today.   The five-page letter was delivered by Ambassador Ephraim Evron to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. during a luncheon at the State Department Tuesday, department officials said. It was in reply to a recent message from Mr. Reagan to Mr. Begin expressing concern about American-Israeli relations, including American apprehension about a possible Israeli move into Lebanon that might violate the six-month-old cease-fire there.   Officials in Israel briefed reporters on some aspects of the letter, and sources in Washington familiar with its contents also commented. The overall tone of the letter was said to have been friendly, in keeping with a pronounced effort by officials in the United States and Israel to avoid further recriminations and to put relations back on a cordial basis.

abstract: The Polish Journalists' Association, suspended under martial law more than three months ago, was dissolved by the Government today, an official announcement said.   The official press agency quoted Warsaw's mayor, Gen. Mieczyslaw Debicki, as saying that the association, which backed the Solidarity union, ''undertook actions conducive to the dismantling of state and social institutions of public information.''

headline: STARTS IN HOUSING OFF IN JANUARY
abstract: Housing starts fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January after rising slightly in December, the Commerce Department reported today.   Builders began work on new homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 894,000 in January, down 44 percent from January 1981, just before the industry sank into one of its worst years ever.   The new report revised the December increase to 4.5 percent from the 13.3 percent reported last month. But the smaller figure was still a great improvement over big declines common earlier in the year.

headline: London Exchange Rescinds Measure To Halt Tin Losses
abstract: The world of tin is showing signs of exhaustion with the commodity's wild fluctuations in price since last July. Tin prices continued to fall today despite yesterday's announcement by an emergency meeting of the International Tin Council that member nations would contribute $180 million to help support the commodity's price.   The London Metal Exchange, meanwhile, acknowledged that a recent attempt to corner the tin market had given way to business as usual.  An emergency measure to limit tin traders' losses during a period of sharply rising prices was rescinded today at the regular Wednesday meeting of the exchange's managing commission. The exchange also dropped its temporary requirement that tin traders keep exchange officials informed of their positions.

headline: Steel Output Up 5.7%
abstract: Steel production rose to 1.68 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 5.7 percent from the previous week's 1.59 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: With the approach of elections in El Salvador that could be critical to the debate over increased American aid to that country, a gap appears to be widening between the Reagan Administration's analysis of the Salvadoran situation and the views of many moderate Salvadorans whom Washington's policy is ostensibly designed to support.   In Washington, an almost total preoccupation with the role of ''outside'' forces - Nicaraguan, Cuban or Soviet - has tended to cast the civil war as part of an East-West struggle important to the strategic interests of the United States.   In El Salvador, the perspective is different. Two weeks of conversations there with Salvadoran writers, artists, lawyers, business people and public officials leave a reporter traveling between Washington and San Salvador with the feeling that there are two El Salvador stories - if not two El Salvadors.

headline: India and Pakistan Agree To Set Up Panel on Ties
abstract: Foreign Minister Agha Shahi of Pakistan accepted an Indian proposal today to establish a joint commission on relations between the two countries, an Indian Government spokesman said.   He said the offer was made by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi at a meeting Saturday with Mr. Shahi, who is here to discuss a possible nonaggression pact between India and Pakistan.   Mr. Shahi reiterated Pakistan's ''firm resolve and profound desire to live permanently in peace with India,'' the spokesman said.  Mr. Shahi had talks with the Indian External Affairs Minister, P.V. Narasimha Rao, today and they will meet again Monday, before Mr. Shahi returns to Islamabad, the spokesman said.

headline: U.N. VOTES TO EXPAND ITS FORCE IN SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: The Security Council today approved the addition of 1,000 troops to its peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon.   The vote was 13 to 0, with the Soviet Union and Poland abstaining.  The Russians usually abstain on peacekeeping resolutions and do not contribute to costs because they feel that the United Nations Charter does not provide for such measures.

headline: The Postman
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Stuart N. Brotman, in discussing the Postal Service's involvement in electronic mail services (''Reagan Should Curb Big Mail, Too,'' Jan. 10) called on the Reagan Administration to impose certain restrictions that would sharply limit this agency's role in electronic activities.   For the record, I have long endorsed and urged the need for definitive legislation that would clearly spell out the Postal Service's role in electronics. I have repeatedly attempted to assure members of Congress, the Administration and certainly the telecommunications industry that the Postal Service has no designs on or intentions of participation in the business of electronic transmissions.

headline: U.S. Oil Executive Held Briefly in Beirut
abstract: Gunmen described as disgruntled job applicants kidnapped an American oil executive, a Lebanese colleague and their driver today, but the men were released unharmed seven hours later.   Thomas E. Anderson, 58 years old, of Norwalk, Conn., a vice president and managing director of the American oil company Caltex, was seized on his way to work.

headline: LETTER URGES WARSAW TO EASE RULE
abstract: A group of 18 literary, scientific educational and cultural leaders have sent a letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's Prime Minister, calling for an end to martial law and ''a speedy restoration of basic human rights in Poland.''   The letter, sent under the auspices of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies, urged the release of ''imprisoned writers, educators, labor leaders, students and others'' detained under martial law. The signers of the letter were: John Brademas, president of New York University Robert Silvers, editor of The New York Review of Books James D. Wolfensohn, chairman of Carnegie Hall Donald Barthelme, writer Frederick Seitz, president emeritus, Rockefeller University Barbara Tuchman, writer Michael Walzer, professor of government, Harvard University Irving Howe, professor of English, Hunter College Fritz Lipmann, Nobel Prize winner in medicine Joshua Lederberg, Nobel Prize Winner in medicine Rene Dubos, bacteriologist Christian de Duve, Nobel Prize winner in medicine Isidor I. Rabi, Nobel Prize winner in physics Isaac Stern, violinist Zubin Mehta, conductor Itzhak Perlma n, violinist Daniel Barenb oim, pianist Susan Sontag, writer

A.M.C., fourth in size among domestic auto makers, said that for all of 1981 it had a deficit of $136.6 million, narrower than its $200.8 million deficit in 1980.

headline: PEKING LEADERSHIP BEGINS STAFF CUTS
abstract: The Chinese leadership embarked on a long-awaited overhaul of its administrative apparatus today by whittling a dozen of its ministries and commisssions down to six and selecting slightly younger people to run three of the enlarged ministries.   The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, China's nominal Parliament, also approved a plan that will set an example for the country by trimming and reorganizing the highest level of government.   Under the new plan, the number of deputy prime ministers will be reduced to two from the present 13. The 98 ministries, commissions and agencies are being cut back to 52.

headline: FIAT LAYOFFS SET
abstract: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, said it would lay off about 40,000 workers from its car division for nine days, starting today, in a continuing effort to reduce unsold inventory. The production cuts affect all Fiat car plants except one, the company said. The company said earlier this year that stocks of unsold cars totaled 60,000, compared with a seasonally normal total of 40,000, making further production cuts inevitable.

headline: BRITAIN WILL BUY NEW U.S. MISSILES
abstract: The British Government announced today that it had decided to buy from the United States a costly and advanced new missile system for its nuclear submarine fleet so Britain would have an independent nuclear deterrent into the next century.   The Trident 2 missile system will cost $14 billion over 18 years, the Government said, and will replace Britain's Polaris missiles in its fleet of nuclear submarines, which will also be replaced.  It is the same missile system the United States Navy is to begin using around 1989, and the decision to deploy it in Britain was welcomed in letters released here from President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.

headline: Canada Price Rise in '81
abstract: Consumer prices in Canada rose by 12.5 percent in 1981, the sharpest increase in 33 years, the Government announced today. The increase in the Canadian rate was 2.4 percentage points above the 10.1 percent rate recorded in 1980, but below the 14.2 percent figure in 1948, the highest since World War II. The record Canadian rate was 18.2 percent in 1917.

headline: U.S. TO RETURN TO SEA PARLEY AT U.N.
abstract: After a prolonged review, President Reagan has said that the United States will return to the Law of the Sea Conference and will seek to relax the proposed curbs on mining the oceans' mineral wealth.   ''Most provisions of the draft convention are acceptable,'' Mr.  Reagan said in a White House statement issued Friday. But ''in the deep s ea mining area, we will seek changes,'' it said.   Last March, Mr. Reagan stunned other nations taking part in the eight-year-old conference when he said that the United States would no longer take part until it had carefully re-examined all the provisions in the complex draft code.

headline: SHIFT IN UNDERWRITING RULE ADOPTED
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a temporary change in underwriting procedures that some investment bankers have charged will severely undermine their traditional role in bringing new stocks and bonds to market.   The measure was part of a package of new rules approved today that will speed up and simplify the filing of information, which all corporations must do each time they try to market new securities.   The controversial change in underwriting practices, affecting only major corporations that frequently market new issues, was adopted by a unanimous vote for a nine-month period. It will become effective upon publication in the Federal Register, expected within a few days, but the commission said that eligible companies could change their underwriting practices immediately. The other new rules approved today by the S.E.C. will also become effective upon publication in the Federal Register, but they will be permanent changes.

headline: TALKS ON SECURITY ADJOURN IN MADRID
abstract: After 16 months of deliberations, the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe adjourned today for eight months with East and West at loggerheads over Poland.   Taking advantage of the last day of the conference, which is supposed to reconvene here on Nov. 9, both the Soviet Union and the United States and its allies fired parting salvos that reflected widely varying interpretations of the 1975 Helsinki accords that this conference was set up to review.   Calling the Madrid talks ''a stage of lost opportunities,'' the Soviet delegation, in a press statement, blamed ''the U.S. delegation and the delegations of those NATO countries that have supported the U.S. destructive obstructionist line.''   The Soviet statement, repeated in a closed session of all members, said the West was being led ''upon the path of cold war, the path of destroying everything positive that has been achieved over the years of detente, of the life of the process initiated in Helsinki.'' Clearly alluding to Poland, the Russians accused the United States of trying to dictate the ''internal and foreign policy'' of some nations.

headline: Matsushita Net Increases 14%
abstract: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company reported yesterday that net income rose 14 percent, to $378.3 million, or $2.65 a share, and sales increased 16 percent, to $10.62 billion, in the fiscal year ended Nov. 20, 1981.   The company attributed its record earnings to brisk sales of the VHS videotape recorders, sales of which doubled last year.

headline: BONN TO HONOR CONTRACTS FOR SIBERIAN GAS PIPELINE
abstract: The West German Government indicated today that it would do nothing to hinder West German companies from sidestepping the effects of American sanctions on the construction of a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.   According to a Government spokesman, the Cabinet was told by Count Otto Lambsdorff, the Minister for Economic Affairs, that the United States' request not to undercut its sanctions against the Soviet Union ''referred only to such American deliveries in which the United States is the prime supplier, and not a secondary supplier.''   The disclosure follows a decision last week by the United States to deny export licenses to the General Electric Company for the delivery of $175 million of components for the Siberian pipeline.   Though the West German spokesman, Kurt Becker, refused to apply Count Lambsdorff's interpretation to particular deals, it evidently meant that Bonn would not prevent companies from seeking other suppliers.

headline: Miles Chief Executive Adds Title of President
abstract: Theodor H. Heinrichs, 55, the German-born chairman and chief executive officer of Miles Laboratories Inc., will add the title of president on April 1. Miles, the health-care company best known for its production of Alka Seltzer, is a subsidiary of Bayer of West Germany.

headline: HER JOB: BUILDING STEEL MILLS
abstract: In the northeast corner of Italy, where most women concentrate more on polenta and chicken than cold-rolled steel, Cecilia Danieli has carved out an unusually successful career as the head of of Italy's leading builder of steel mills and steel-handling equipment.   The company she runs, the Danieli Group, with about 1,500 employees and revenues of roughly $100 million a year, developed the compact steel mills known in the industry as mini-mills.   These mills have revolutionized steelmaking and tilted the world steel market in the last two decades by giving scores of countries in Africa, South America and the Far East the me ans to produce steel cheaply and efficiently.   Though women have recently broadened their rights in Italy, and have long made a significant mark in the apparel and fashion businesses, the 38-year-old Mrs. Danieli, married and a mother of three children, is one of a handful who have reached the top in the male domain of heavy industry.

headline: No Headline
abstract: POLISH PANNEL SIGNALS INTENTION TO RESTORE CONTROL OVER UNIONS   WARSAW, Jan. 19 (UPI) - A committee of the military regime indicated today that labor unions would be strictly controlled in Poland in the future, signaling a return to the kind of Governmentrun labor organizations that preceded the birth of Solidarity.   The regime's Socio-Political Committee said that labor unions should be reborn ''on the basis of the constitutional principles of the socialist political order.'' In the East bloc, that has meant strict Government control over labor organizations.

headline: U.S. STEEL MOVES TO BUY MARATHON
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation moved ahead today with its purchase of the Marathon Oil Company.  The Bankers Trust Company, paying agent for U.S. Steel, said that it was making plans to put 50 people on overtime almost immediately so that it could begin issuing checks to stockholders in person and by mail on Monday morning. It became free to issue $3.7 billion in checks at 12:01 A.M. today, at the expiration of a deadline set by a Federal appeals court. The money will buy 51 percent of the Marathon shares.   The Bankers Trust announcement came yesterday afternoon, shortly after Chief Justice Warren E. Burger turned down the Mobil Corporation's final appeal to block U.S. Steel's acquisition of Marathon. Mobil sought time for a Supreme Court review of the antitrust rulings that blocked its competing bid for Marathon. Possibility Anticipated   Under typical Supreme Court procedures, even after Justice Burger turned down the Mobil appeal for an emergency restraining order, Mobil could have gone to other Justices in order of seniority.  However, anticipating that possibility, Justice Burger said that he had told other Justices of his decision and did not find any ''contrary views.''

headline: 145,000 IN POLAND FOUND TO VIOLATE MARTIAL-LAW RULE
abstract: The Polish authorities said today that a two-day police sweep had discovered as many as 145,000 people guilty of offenses, most of them apparently petty, against martial law rules.   The Polish Government's press agency, P.A.P., said the police had undertaken the operation to test the effectiveness of martial law in this nation of 36 million. They checked 51,000 warehouses, shops or factories, stopped 60,000 cars and raided 3,500 speakeasies known as ''melinas.''   Their findings, the press agency said, were that adherence to martial law regulations was ''not too good.''

headline: Energy Agency Studying Gas Prices
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has begun a study of whether the agency itself should raise the price of certain categories of natural gas, including ''old'' gas, from wells drilled before 1977, and whether it has the authority to do so.   The study is to lay the groundwork for possible further efforts to decontrol gas prices by administrative action if Congress fails to act on legislation to decontrol prices that the Reagan Administration is expected to send to Capitol Hill next month.   ''It's both a legal and economic analysis,'' the commission's general counsel, Charles Moore, said today. He added that, although the study was four to six weeks from completion, it appeared that the commission did have the authority to raise prices if it should decide to do so.

headline: REAGAN SEEMS CONFUSED ON VIETNAM'S HISTORY
abstract: President Reagan sidestepped a question today that sought reassurance that the United States would not secretly become more deeply involved in El Salvador's civil war, but in rejecting a reporter's suggested analogy to Vietnam, Mr. Reagan seemed confused about Vietnamese history.   After his last news conference a month ago, the President was criticized for his handling of purely factual matters and it seemed likely this could happen again. At one point in today's news conference, a reporter said that in the 1960's the Central Intelligence Agency had contrived a ''secret plan to get us involved in Vietnam in a surreptitious, covert manner,'' and asked if the President could assure the public that the United States would not be similarly drawn deeper into El Salvador.   Most students of recent Vietnamese history would disagree that such a ''secret plan'' existed, and Mr. Reagan also expressed disagreement with the premise of the question.

headline: SYRIA PUSHES HARD U.N. LINE OVER GOLAN
abstract: Syria insisted publicly today that, despite the prospect of a United States veto, it would press for a harsh Security Council resolution designed to isolate Israel for annexing the Golan Heights. But behind the scenes, and even in public, efforts were under way to negotiate a compromise that would avoid a veto.   Dia-Allah el-Fattal, the Syrian delegate, told reporters that ''the Arab group will push ahead'' with the stiff text it drafted.  The key part would call on all countries ''to refrain from supplying Israel with any types of weapons and related equipment and to suspend any military assistance which Israel receives from them; to sever all trade relations and suspend economic, financial and technological cooperation with Israel; to sever diplomatic and consular relations with Israel.''

headline: Saatchi-Compton Pact: Was the Price a Steal?
abstract: Thanks to all of the figures supplied by Saatchi & Saatchi of London to accompany the announcement of its deal to acquire Compton Communications of New York, the executives at other agencies that are engaged in the great acquisition race can do a lot of second guessing.   Some say Saatchi, a publicly held company, paid just the right amount. More think they paid relatively little considering the size of Compton. But Compton is privately held, so one can only speculate.

Hutton Group, two of the nation's largest brokerage firms, reported higher sales and earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981, with high interest rates helping to push up profits.   The earnings reports of the two firms reflect the generally lessrobust state of the stock market and the commodities markets in 1981.  Commissions, still an important revenue source despite the industry's diversif ication, declined at many Wall Street firms, including Merrill Lynch and and Hutton. Volat ile interest rates buffeted the debt markets during the year, an d many firms saw their profits from trading suffer.

In a joint statement issued after four hours of talks, they said that France and the United States would cooperate to improve controls over the export to the Soviet Union of computers and microelectronics, key elements in Moscow's military modernization.

headline: Advertising; How to Get A Product Known
abstract: AS irritating as it may be, Wisk's long-lived ''Ring around the collar'' campaign is still terribly effective advertising.  But James J. Jordan, the man who created it at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn some years ago, is convinced now that it could be improved.   He would add the name of the product and make it ''Ring around the collar? Wisk it away.'' Then it would conform to the new thinking of its creator, who is now chairman of Jordan, Case & McGrath.

headline: COCKPIT FIGHT REPORTED ON JET THAT CRASHED IN TOKYO
abstract: Investigators into the crash of a Japan Air Lines DC-8 in which 24 people died on Tuesday say there was a struggle in the cockpit only moments before the jetliner fell into Tokyo Bay 300 yards short of the main runway at Haneda Airport. It was also reported that the captain had been grounded for a year because of a psyc hosomatic illness.   The police, pointing to pilot error as the cause of the accident, said that one of the airliner's four jet engines was put into reverse thrust just before the crash, causing the plane to lose altitude sharply. The plane was carrying 174 people, incouding a crew of 8.

headline: Advertising; Campaign On Hotel Face Lift
abstract: TOMORROW, the beloved Barclay Hotel, following a $30 million facelift, will become the Hotel Inter-Continental New York to the muted drum beating of advertising supplied by Doyle Dane Bernbach and Smith/Greenland.   Although the target of this advertising will be that relatively small segment known as the upscale, frequent business traveler, the hotel - now part of a chain of 84 establishments worldwide - will be the first Inter-Continental using television advertising.   And a rather special spot it is, starring Sir John Gielgud in his first television commercial, according to Inter-Continental.   Created and placed by D.D.B., Inter-Continental's corporate agency, the commercial gets in a plug for the London and Paris hotels before focusing on what's new in New York, so it is as much a corporate ad as it is a specific New York promotion.

headline: VOTE IN SALVADOR GIVING PLURALITY TO DUARTE'S PARTY
abstract: Early results in El Salvador's elections indicated today that the moderate Christian Democrats had won more votes than any of the five other parties. However, their final total would not give them the majority needed to control the new constituent assembly.   The extreme right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance of Roberto d'Aubuisson, a former army major, was in what the United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, called a ''strong second position.'' The conservative National Conciliation Party, which ran El Salvador from 1961 to 1979, was in third place.   The outcome touched off a series of political meetings in the capital aimed at establishing a parliamentary coalition. The negotations are critical for El Salvador's immediate future because the new assembly will have the power to name an interim government, rewrite the country's constitution and call presidential elections in 1983.

headline: U.S. TO SELL $10 BILLION OF DEBT
abstract: The Treasury yesterday announced a $10 billion financing package for sale next week - a record borrowing and a vivid reminder to the credit markets that the Federal budget is deeply in deficit.   Prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly after the announcement and yields rose, mainly because the financing was larger than the $9.5 billion that had been widely forecast by securities dealers.   Among outstanding Treasury issues, three- and ten-year notes were offered late yesterday with yields of 14.66 percent and 14.53 percent, respectively. The outstanding 14 percent bonds due in 2011 were offered at 98 1/4 to yield 14.25 percent.

headline: MCI SEES BELL SHIFTING COSTS
abstract: William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation and one of the Bell System's most vocal competitors, warned today that the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company might attempt to shift its costs to c ustomers of local phone companies before a planned divestiture occurr ed over the next 18 months.   His charge, escalating a dispute over Bell System charges, came during a week in which A.T.& T. applied to the Federal Communications Commission to more than double what long-distance phone companies like MCI must pay for connections to Bell's local phone systems.   Mr. McGowan brushed off the filing as ''a nonevent'' that the F.C.C. was not likely to approve or even consider. But other companies with long-distance service that would be subject to higher connection charges say that their ability to compete against Bell could be severely cramped.

headline: Petrofina Sets Refund Pact
abstract: The Government has announced an agreement with American Petrofina Inc. under which the Dallas-based oil company agreed to refund $14.1 million in settlement of pricing violation accusations totaling $262 million.   Petrofina, which markets its gasoline in 25 states under the name Fina, agreed to pay the money to 400 wholesalers who bought its gasoline in 1974.

headline: SOLIDARITY AIDE BIDS TROOPS PUT CONSCIENCE FIRST
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.   The senior Solidarity leader still at liberty has appealed to soldiers and policemen to ''listen to their conscience'' and not allow themselves to be used ''as tools in the hands of the criminal authorities waging a war against the nation.''   The appeal was handwritten by Zbigniew Bujak, the 27-year-old leader of Solidarity's Warsaw branch, in the form of ''holiday greetings'' to Solidarity members and sympathizers and ''to all our friends in Poland and abroad.''   (The chairman of Poland's Council of State, Henryk Jablonski, called on the nation to preserve the ''sense of national accord'' that he said had grown out of the Solidarity movement. His remarks were made in a televised New Year's speech monitored outside Poland.  Page 4.)

headline: News Analysis
abstract: As the marathon Madrid conference on detente and human rights disbanded last week and diplomats packed their bags, there was an inevitable tendency to regard the meeting as a failure.   After 16 months, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, as the gathering is officially known, had done little to enhance the security of the 35 signers of the Helsinki accords of 1975 and had evinced more discord than cooperation between East and West.   Negotiations over a concluding document that might have strengthened the Helsinki accords - in such areas as family reunification, terrorism, journalists' working conditions and scientific exchanges - were fruitless, cut short by polemics over Poland.   Yet, as they departed, few diplomats who attended the meeting felt that they were the true authors of this impasse. Rather, as one Norwegian put it, ''the most dangerous international situation since the end of World War II'' had shaped, troubled and, finally, undermined the gathering.

headline: Central Poland Floodwaters Are Reported to Be Subsiding
abstract: Polish newspapers reported today that floo dwaters t hreatening the Plock region of central Poland were subsiding slo wly but that attempts to break up an ice jam on the Vistula River were proving unexpectedly difficult.   They said two icebreakers were brought in from the Baltic port of Gdansk.  The flood situation was stabilizing in other regions, except for the Gorzow, Konin and Szczecin areas, the newspapers said.

headline: WASHINGTON POST SELLS INSIDE SPORTS MAGAZINE
abstract: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its money-losing sports magazine, Inside Sports, to a small publishing concern that specializes in magazines for children and young athletes.   The buyer, Active Sports Inc., based in Bellevue, Wash., is the publisher of Sport & Athletes magazine, which formerly was called Young Athlete. Active Sports said the agreement to buy the troubled magazine was reached about two weeks ago.

headline: RUSSIAN ATTITUDE TOWARD POLAND HAS CHANGED LITTLE SINCE DAYS OF THE
abstract: CZARS By DREW MIDDLETON Military Analysis   ''The Poles must be made happy in spite of themselves,'' wrote Czar Nicholas I when he crushed the Polish insurrection of 1830, ''by taking from them the power to do themselves harm, by treating them like blind children, who take into their hands toys that might hurt them and others too.''   Analysts of Eastern European affairs contend that Czar Nicholas's words have significance today because they reflect a continuing attitude of Russians toward Poland and its people.   Invariably Russia has tried to make the Poles ''happy'' by the employment of overwhelming military force. Invariably force has succee ded at the outset. And, as regularly as the tides, Polish resistance to Russian domination has been reborn and has flourished.

headline: Economic Scene
abstract: THE President is giving ground so slowly on his budget and the huge deficits he is projecting that it is hard to be sure whether he is giving ground at all. At his news conference yesterday, President Reagan offered one of his favorite remedies for balancing the budget: an attack on waste and inefficiency. He said he would appoint a private-sector commission on cost containment. However, as though in recognition of the incredulity that might greet this standard ploy for rooting out scores of billions in waste, Mr. Reagan said this would represent ''the largest effort of its kind ever attempted.''   The one notable thing about his proposal was that he put the Defense Department at the head of his list of agencies to be surveyed for waste and inefficiency.

headline: U.S. WILL PRESS FOR MORE CURBS ON SOVIET TRADE
abstract: The United States signaled today that it was preparing to ask its Western allies and Japan for increased curbs on the shipment of high-technology products and oil and gas equipme nt tothe Soviet Un ion.   Officials said the request was expected at talks in Paris next Tuesday to consider a unified stand on trade curbs.  The Administration has apparently concluded that trade with the Soviet Union yields few benefits to the West A Polish official said it was difficult to say when military rule would be ended or detainees freed. Page A6. and has helped the Russians to improve their military capacity so that it is a threat to Western security. American interest in trade curbs has been given new impetus by the Polish crisis.

headline: U.S. EASES BAN ON SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICERS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in order to help negotiations on obtaining South-West Africa's independence from South Africa, has quietly eased a long-standing practice of not allowing high-ranking South African military officers into this country on official business, State Department officials said today.   The Department officials said that without any publicity, senior South African military officers have come to the United States in recent months as part of delegations that have met in private with Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, on the question of forming an independent nation, to be known as Namibia, from the territory of South-West Africa. This has been the subject of intense negotiations involving Western and African countries, as well as political groups inside and outside the South African-administered territory.   The most recent meeting with Mr. Crocker took place at the State Department on Feb. 22 and 23, the officials said. The leader of the South African delegation was Brand G. Fourie, the senior civil servant in the South African Foreign Ministry. He was accompanied, among others, by Lieut. Gen. P.W. Van der Westhuizen, chief of staff for intelligence in the South African defense forces, the officials said.

headline: Phillips Petroleum Elects President
abstract: C.J. Silas, 49 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Phillips Petroleum Company, based in Bartlesville, Okla. As president, he succeeds William C. Douce, 62, who will become chairman and continue as chief executive officer.  The management changes, effective April 1, will follow the retirement of William F. Martin, the chairman since 1974, at the age of 65.

headline: Rate Fears Depress Stocks
abstract: The stock market retreated again yesterday under the pressure of interest-rate worries, deteriorating technical indicators and a complete lack of group leadership.   The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.75 points, to 838.95, bringing its cumulative loss in the first eight trading days of 1982 to 36.05 points.   Volume slipped to 49.1 million shares from Tuesday's 49.8 million.  ''Basically, the stock tape shows no flair whatsoever,'' said Paul F. Mangels, of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. ''But if the Dow gets to near last year's low - 824.01, the close on Sept. 25 - we could see a bounce.''

headline: LTV to Settle Suit
abstract: The LTV Corporation said it had agreed to pay $7.75 million to settle a stockholders' class action suit that contends that LTV misstated its earnings and financial condition between 1974 and 1977 to inflate its stock value. Judge Patrick Higginbotham of United States District Court scheduled a hearing for May 10 to decide whether to approve the agreement in the suit, filed on behalf of more than 50,000 LTV stockholders.

headline: The President of Boeing Lobbies for Ex-Im Bank
abstract: Normally, Malcolm T. Stamper, president of the Boeing Corporation, is a man who avoids publicity and busies himself with making certain that the daily operations of the world's largest commercial airplane manufacturer are running smoothly.   For excitement, he jogs after work, and sometimes enters a marathon. He likes to recall, for example, that he finished in the middle of the 15,000 runners of the 1980 New York marathon.

headline: AN ALBERTA DISTRICT ELECTS WESTERN SEPERATIST TO FIRST PUBLIC OFFICE
abstract: Voters in Alberta today elected the first separatist to public office in western Canada.  The new member of the Alberta Legislature is Gordon Kesler, a 36-year-old oil scout, rancher and rodeo competitor. He is also deputy chairman of Western Canada Concept, a year-old political movement dedicated to taking Canada's four Western provinces - Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba and Saskatchewan - out of the 115-year-old Canadian Confederation into some form of independence or of association with the United States.

headline: Eckerd Halts Methaqualone
abstract: The Eckerd Drug Company, the nation's largest dispenser of prescriptions, announced that it would no longer sell methaqualone, a nervous system depressant, in its 1,209 pharmacies in 15 states.

headline: I.R.S. DEALT SETBACK IN TAX CASE
abstract: An appeals court has ruled that the Internal Revenue Service can be required to return property seized from a company that is seeking financial reorganization under the bankruptcy laws.   The decision, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, focused on whether a company that filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy act was entitled to the return of property that the I.R.S. had seized for delinquent taxes.   ''This question has created much conflict among bankruptcy judges and district courts throughout the nation,'' the appeals court observed in the 40-page decision, which it handed down on Tuesday in Manhattan.

headline: Jobless Rate 9% in E.E.C.
abstract: The symptoms of the continuing European recession worsened today with unemployment in the 10-nation European Economic Community hitting the 10 million mark for the first time since World War II.   Figures released by the Common Market's statistical office showed that 9 percent of the work force was unemployed in December, up from 8.8 percent in November.

headline: IRAN SAID TO GET LARGE-SCALE ARMS FROM ISRAEL, SOVIET AND EUROPEANS
abstract: Iran is receiving military equipment and arms worth hundreds of millions of dollars from Israel, North Korea, Syria, Libya, the Soviet Union and several countries in Western Europe to support its war against Iraq, according to Western intelligence sources.   This unusual collection of suppliers is reported struggling both openly and covertly, along with the United States, for influence over Iran's future and over the balance of power in the Middle East.   The arms they are providing enable Iran to continue the 18-monthold war against Iraq and may even permit it to prevail, with all of the implications that holds for the spread of Islamic revolution to other parts of the Persian Gulf. Arrangements Are Complex   According to documents - telex messsages, contracts and bills of lading - $100 million to $200 million in arms, spare parts and ammunition were delivered to Iran from Western Europe in the last 18 months. The intelligence sources said the documents indicated that about half of this was being supplied or arranged by Israel, and the rest by freelance arms merchants, some of whom may also have connections with Israeli intelligence.

headline: JOBLESSNESS: A GROWING SCOURGE
abstract: MOSCOW Unemployment, Soviet officials never tire of boasting, does not exist under the dictatorship of the proletariat. But the chronic waste and inefficiency of Soviet workers sometimes drive planners to mumble that a limited dose of joblessness may not, after all, be amiss.   Soviet law requires every man to hold a job - otherwise he becomes an illegal ''parasite'' - and employment bureaus are bound to supply work according to a man's qualifications. But the excitement of building Communism that was originally supposed to motivate Soviet workers has distinctly waned. Bonuses for overfulfilling plans have lost their attraction because there is so little to buy in the stores, and centralized bureaucracy has all but stamped out any incentive for inititative.

headline: WHITTAKER IN BID FOR BRUNSWICK
abstract: The Whittaker Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday a $668 million tender offer for the Brunswick Corporation, a major producer of recreational products.   Whittaker, which is based in Los Angeles, said that it would pay $320 million in cash for Brunswick stock and debentures in the first phase of its proposed acquisition. The manufacturer said that the second phase would involve an exchange of Whittaker stock for Brunswick. Whittaker valued the second phase at $348 million.

The first shipments of Levi's products are expected in May and June for back-to-school sales in the fall, according to a statement released by Sears.

headline: A RECORD YEAR FOR A CADILLAC DEALER
abstract: No one worries about sticker shock in George Principe's wood-paneled Cadillac showroom. While other dealers were fretting last year about the recession and slumping sales and buyers' preference for foreign cars, he and his six salesmen sold 996 new Cadillacs - more than ever before.   But the record sales have not completely protected Mr. Principe from the problems that have troubled Cadillac's poorer cousins within the General Motors family. The dealership's profits were held down by rising operating costs, including wage increases that followed a weeklong mechanics' strike last year.

headline: MOBIL GOES TO APPEALS COURT IN ATTEMPT TO BLOCK U.S. STEEL
abstract: The Mobil Corporation returned to a Federal appea ls court today to ask for an emergency order that would block the Uni ted States Steel Corporation from buying control of the Marathon Oil Company next week.   The appeals court did not act before closing for the New Year's holiday.  Mobil filed a new petition with the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit after Chief Justice Warren E. Burger on Wednesday rebuffed on procedural grounds Mobil's request for an injunction blocking U.S.  Steel's $6.3 bid for Marathon.   Mobil had sought to stop U.S. Steel from going ahead with the acquisition until the High Court could review lower court antitrust rulings that have stopped Mobil from proceeding with its own bid for Marathon.

headline: 6 Reprieved in Liberia
abstract: The Liberian head of state, Samuel K. Doe, reprieved six student leaders today who were scheduled to be executed by firing squad Friday for treason. Mr.  Doe, who was a master sergeant when he seized power in a coup in 1980, said in a radio broadcast that the students had been ''tied up in an unfortunate incident.'' The students were sentenced to death for breaching a ban on political activities.

headline: Dow, Led by Energy Issues, Gains 13.79
abstract: A brisk demand for oil shares touched off a spirited rally in the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average sprinted ahead by 13.79 points. The volume of 64.8 million shares, up from Tuesday's 60.1 million, marked the heaviest trading so far in February.   The Dow close at 826.77 was yet another display of volatility. On Monday, the industrial average had plunged 13 points, to 811.26, its lowest point since May 1980, amid investor worries about high interest rates, the recession and the darkening outlook for corporate profits.

headline: NICARAGUAN IS AT MEXICAN MISSION
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met today with the second-ranking member of the Salvadoran junta as the State Department continued to insist that Nicaragua and Cuba were directing the guerrilla operation in El Salvador.   But department officials were clearly concerned about the attention given Mr. Haig's dramatic announcement on Thursday to a House subcommittee that evidence of outside interference in El Salvador could be seen in the capture of ''a Nicaraguan military man'' helping to direct the insurgency.   Their concern was that the attention given the one Nicaraguan would detract from what the Administration regards as very compelling evidence, a view shared by both intelligence committees in Congress, that Nicaraguans and Cubans are deeply involved in the Salvadoran insurgency.   Reports from Mexico, confirmed late in the day by the State Department, said a Nicaraguan was inside the Mexican Embassy in San Salvador, having either eluded the Salvadoran police or having escaped from them.

headline: OFFICIAL SHAKE-UP REPORTED IN CHINA
abstract: The solicited resignations of over a dozen aging deputy ministers have produced the first tremors in a long awaited shake-up of China's bureaucracy.   Six ''veteran comrades'' from the Ministry of Coal Industry stepped down earlier this month in response to a call from the party's Central Committee for older officials to retire. Seven more from the Third Ministry of Machine Building followed by resigning to make way for younger men.   Their resignations, hailed as patriotic examples by the official press, fall well short of producing the kind of overhaul that Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang promised in a major economic report last month.  Mr. Zhao charged that the Government was so overstaffed that it frequently ''bogged down in endless debates and shifts of responsibility.''

headline: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose 0.3 percent in December. For all of 1981 the index, a rough measure of the inflation consumers will face in the future, rose just 7 percent, the smallest increase since 1977. The figures were welcomed by economists as a sign that inflation was subsiding. (Page 1.)   The teamsters' union agreed to major concessions in a tentative contract agreement with unionized trucking con cerns. (1.) Ford said it was asking the United Auto Workers for sub stantial sacrifices in fringe benefits in return for job protection and profit sharing.  (10.)

headline: Pabst to Acquire Pittsburgh Unit
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company announced a definitive agreement had been reached for Pabst to acquire the Pittsburgh Brewing Company.

headline: FOR CRAVATH, LIFE AFTER I.B.M.
abstract: Sixty years ago Paul D. Cravath, the patriarch of one of Wall Street's most prestigious law firms, described the qualities he looked for in the young men he hired.   ''Brilliant intellectual powers are not essential,'' he told an audience of Harvard Law School students. ''Too much imagination, too much wit, too great cleverness, too facile fluency, if not leavened by a sound sense of proportion, are quite as likely to impede success as to promote it. The best clients are apt to be afraid of those qualities.''   Cravath, Swaine & Moore has loosened and livened up considerably since then. But for the International Business Machines Corporation, represented by Cravath for 13 tortuous years, the attractions of the firm remain the same. The traits that Paul Cravath cherished - industry, precision, patience and perseverance -were responsible, they say, for the dismissal of the Government's case against them and their vindication in courts throughout the country.

headline: Lois, Pitts, Wins Simac Appliances
abstract: The maker of a home pasta-making machine has left Della Femina, Travisano & Partners and has taken up with Lois, Pitts, Gershon.  The company is the Simac Appliances Corporation, whose products include the Pastamatic line and the Il Gelataio ice cream machine.  The new agency says that the billings will be more than $1 million.

headline: THE HEAT'S ON MORGAN STANLEY
abstract: WHEN Morgan Stanley & Company, the most prestigious of investment banks, looks to its roots, it sees the industrial financier J. Pierpont Morgan, whose own American ancestry dates to 1636. An offspring of the House of Morgan, Morgan Stanley has grown rich as the banker to blue chip corporate America, with a client list that is the envy of Wall Street.   It earns a 20 percent after-tax return on equity. Each year, it either leads or is in the top tier of the numerous lists that rank Wall Street firms. In 1981, it appeared as lead manager on $11.76 billion worth of corporate stock and bond issues, taking the No. 1 slot by that measure for the third consecutive year. Its clients, including 15 to 20 of the nation's 50 largest companies, carry names like American Telephone, General Electric, Exxon and Du Pont.   But the world of Wall Street is changing, in ways that could threaten to crack Morgan's noble walls. New regulations, primarily the Securities and Exchange Commission's Rule 415, which allows corporations to sell securities directly to investors, pose a threat. Upstart competitors are hunting among Morgan's clients; Morgan has even bent its rule on being sole manager of corporate industrial issues. A retail distribution network, which Morgan lacks, is considered by many the key to growth.

headline: Japan's Jobless Rate Up
abstract: The number of persons unemployed in Japan increased by 120,000 in 1981, to 1,260,000, the highest level since World War II, the Labor Ministry said today. The figure represented 2.2 percent of Japan's labor force, the highest rate since 1950, when it reached 2.5 percent, the ministry said. In contrast, the unemployment rate in the United States was 8.9 percent in December.

Some members are worried that the Parliament has had little impact on the citizens of the Common Market countries. It was elected by direct election for the first time in 1979.

headline: ISRAELI PRESIDENT WARNS ARABS NOT TO STRIKE
abstract: President Yitzhak Navon warned Israeli Arabs today not to participate in strikes and demonstrations in support of protests on the West Bank.   At the same time, leaders of the Bedouin and Druse communities, as well as 31 of the 54 Arab local councils in Israel, declared that they would not follow the call to strike Tuesday issued by an organization supporting Arab land rights and backed by other Israeli Arab groups, many of them Communists or under Communist influence.   Tension on the West Bank continued with scattered protest action.  In the only reported act of violence, a member of the Kibbutz Gush Etzion, in occupied territory south of Jerusalem, was stoned while driving on the Jerusalem-Hebron road. Injured, he retaliated by opening fire, wounding one of his attackers. He was held for questioning. The extent of the injuries to both was not made known.

headline: SALVADOR TROOPS ARE LINKED TO THE KILLING OF 19 CIVILIANS
abstract: Armed men in uniforms routed 19 civilians from their homes in a San Salvador suburb early today, then shot them to death, according to relatives, who identified the assailants as Government troops.   The Salvadoran Army, in an apparent reference to the same incident, characterized the slayings as part of an operation to clear out leftist guerrilla hideouts.   Officials at a city morgue where the 19 bodies were taken said that the victims ranged from a 14-year-old boy to a 57-year-old woman.  Several of the bodies were found with hands bound behind the back with twine; they were clothed only in underwear.

headline: GREEK ARCHBISHOP IN A SCUFFLE WITH A BISHOP
abstract: A senior Greek bishop sai d today that he had been assaulted by his archbishop during a sto rmy session of the GreekOrthodox Church hierarchy.   The meeting Thursday ended with the church's refusal to accept the Socialist Government's plans to establish civil marriage and end the prosecution of adultery.   Bishop Amvrosios of Eleutheroupolis, one of the leading opponents of the Government's social changes, described Archbishop Seraphim's physical attack on him as an ''act of violence unprecedented in the history of the church.''

headline: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.4 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday reported a drop of $1.4 billion in the nation's money supply, a smaller decline than the $3 billion to $5 billion the markets had expected.   The figure for the week ended Jan. 27, however, reflected seasonal adjustments and benchmark revisions made by the Fed to its series of money supply data. Had these changes not been made, the money supply, as measured by M-1, which includes cash and money in checking accounts, would have shown a decline of $3.2 billion for the week, the Fed said.   ''The market was mildly disappointed,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at the Bank of New York. ''But these moves really don't say much because everyone is still waiting for more data about the seasonal adjustments.''

headline: SAVINGS BANK MERGER BELIEVED NEAR
abstract: In an unusual procedure, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is negotiating with groups of banks in its efforts to find a merger partner for the deeply troubled New York Bank for Savings, sources in Washington said yesterday.   It was expected that by this weekend the Federal agency, which insures deposits in savings and commercial banks, will narrow its choices to two of the groups, and that the final decision will be made by the end of the month, the sources said.   The New York Bank for Savings, which has its headquarters at 1230 Avenue of the Americas, has 19 branches, not including those of its divisions. The bank's assets total about $3.5 billion. Following a $34.7 million operating loss in the fourth quarter of 1981, its surplus - the amount by which its assets exceed its liabilities - dropped to $37.3 million, barely enough to get it through the present quarter if interest rates remain at or near present levels.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS

headline: POLE DOUBTS SPEEDY END OF MARTIAL LAW OR EARLY FREEING OF WALESA
abstract: The Government tried to dampen speculation today that Lech Walesa would be released from house arrest soon and that martial law would be lifted in the near future.   When asked at a news conference whether the Solidarity leader would be released within three weeks, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, a Deputy Prime Minister, replied, ''I don't know.''   He said talks with Mr. Walesa on the future of trade unions in Poland were continuing. Stanislaw Ciosek, the Minister for Trade Union Affairs, has met with Mr. Walesa '' several times,'' Mr.  Rakowski said . Mr. Walesa has been kept in isolation since martial law was impos ed on Dec. 13 and is said by officials to be at a villa outside of Wa rsaw.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: Interest Rates Climb Slightly   Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in a very quiet day, with most of the increase coming in the last hour or so of trading.  Low trading volume and a narrow range for prices were good signs, dealers said, that the uncertain interest rate outlook had caused many speculators and investors to curb their activity while waiting for more information about the economy.   By late in the day, three- and six-month Treasury bill rates had increased about an eighth of a percentage point, to 12.85 percent and 12.9 percent, respectively.

headline: Poland Criticizes Conference
abstract: Poland has prot ested Western plans to discuss its internal problems during the East -West Conference on Security and Cooperation next month, the East German press agency said today. The agency said that Poland argue d that discussion of Polish problems would contravene the Helsinki accords.

headline: Advertising; Another Change At J.W.T.
abstract: IN another major management change, Walter J. O'Brien, head of the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., will be moving east to become president of the company, replacing Greg Bathon, who has resigned the post.   The announcement came Friday after the di sc losure that Marie Luisi,the highly respected head of Thompson's JWT S yndication and spot buying, had been suspended as a result of an audit that found improper record-keeping in the syndication un it.   Don Johnston, chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Company and the JWT Group, the holding company, said in a telephone interview Friday that the management change, which occurred at a board meeting on Thursday, was unrelated to the suspension. Although he declined to give any of the details of the audit, he did say that it was internal, and that whether the authorities would be notified depended on the outcome of the investigation in progress. Mrs. Luisi's lawyer was quoted last week as saying that his client was not guilty of any wrongdoing.

headline: 41 Tanker Scrappings
abstract: The continuing worldwide oil glut means that more than 41 very large crude carriers, the largest category of oil tanker, are likely to be scrapped during 1982, the International Association of Independent Tanker Owners said here today. In 1981, 41 such tankers, an average of 11 years old each, were scrapped, the organiz ation said.

headline: ASSAD SAID TO BE IN CONTROL DESPITE REBEL UPRISING
abstract: The bitter fighting between thousands of army troops and insurgents barricaded in the city of Hama does not appear to have posed an immediate threat to the regime of President Hafez al-Assad, Western diplomats here said today.   The Syrian authorities say they have regained control of the city, seized hundreds of weapons, including mortars, machine guns and rockets and arrested scores of dissidents, mostly members of the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood, an underground group that has been conducting a terrorist campaign against the Government.   The Government has said that it plans to reopen the road to Hama, sealed off since the uprising began on Feb. 2, on Sunday.  Diplomats and other analysts of Middle Eastern affairs noted that the fighting did not appear to have spread beyond Hama to other major cities, particularly Homs and Aleppo, two cities that have been the scene of clashes in the past.

headline: Gannett Gains 14% in Quarter
abstract: The Gannett Company, a media conglomerate that publishes 85 daily newspapers, said today that it had earned $54.6 million, or $1.01 a share, in the fourth fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, up 14 percent from the $47.9 million, or 88 cents, posted for the period a year earlier.

headline: Market Place; Margin Calls: Ominous Rise
abstract: THIS telephone call is as welcome as a visit from an Internal Revenue Service agent and may be even more devastating. The call is from a broker, who wants more money from the customer or else one or more of the customer's holdings will be sold.   The customer has maybe two or three days to come up with the funds. Margin calls like these are going out in near-record numbers, touched off by the weakest market conditions since April 1980, when a squeeze of the market in silver reverberated in stocks and sent them sprawling, driving margin debt to $14.14 billion in October that year.

headline: GAS SERVICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Personal Finance; THERE'S SOMETHING BETTER THAN AN I.R.A.
abstract: I T'S like an Individual Retirement Account, only better. It cuts your income taxes, allows you to put away more money than with an I.R.A., but still lets you get your hands on the funds in an emergency - without a penalty.   It's called a salary reduction plan, and it's one of the hottest new developments in employee benefits.  ''They literally put I.R.A.'s in the shade,'' says Philip M. Alden Jr., a vice president with Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby, a New York employee benefits consulting firm.   Essentially, the arrangement allows workers to defer as much as 10 percent - sometimes more - of their salary each year, and to then put that money into a company profit-sharing or savings plan. With an I.R.A., by contrast, workers can only contribute a maximum of $2,000 a year.

headline: New Editor Takes Over At Times of London
abstract: Charles Douglas-Home was appointed editor of The Times of London today, ending a week-long wrangle over the management of the newspaper.

headline: Levine, Huntley
abstract: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver last week became the agency for the Entertainment Channel, a pay-cable entry that is due out this spring. The client is a joint venture of Rockefeller Center Cable and RCA Cable.

headline: 600 Troops Leave Ulster
abstract: Six hundred British paratroopers, sent to Northern Ireland after the slaying of a Protestant politician by the Irish Republican Army in November, have been withdrawn, the army said today. Regular British troop strength in the province is now 10,500.

headline: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

headline: Business Conditions; RELIEF FOR CEREAL STOCKS
abstract: After two consecutive years of declining world cereal stocks, this year's expected record crop should go far to swell inventories, economsts at the International Monetary Fund say. They anticipate a 1981-82 world cereal crop of 1.5 billion tons.

headline: TO WHITE EXILES, THERE'LL ALWAYS BE A RHODESIA
abstract: Technically, there are no Rhodesians left in the world, since there is no Rhodesia. But white immigrants who are streaming into South Africa from Zimbabwe cling to the name and to racial attitudes that sometimes seem to put them to the right of most local whites.   ''I'm a Rhodesian; I'm definitely not a Zimbabwean,'' insisted Robin Ross, a farm machinery salesman. But the Rhodesia that he and other recent immigrants still inhabit is a memory and a state of mind, not a place. A used-car salesman named Ed Johnstone, whose showroom in downtown Johannesburg is bedecked with Rhodesian regimental flags and a brass plate proclaiming it to be the ''Unofficial Rhodesian Embassy,'' summed up the attitude.

headline: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRANCE PLANS A SECOND HIGH-SPEED RAILROAD
abstract: France, already enjoying the world's fastest passenger trains operating at 160 miles per hour between Paris and Lyons, is now planning a second high-speed electric line.   French National Railroads gave its approval last month for construction of a new 219-mile route out of Paris to connect with existing trackage to western and southwestern France. Early Government approval is expected, and completion is planned by 1988.   High-speed electric trains began operating late last September over completed sections of the new line connecting Paris with Lyons, 264 miles to the south southeast. In less than two months, the orange-colored streamliners had carried one million passengers, or twice the number in the corresponding period in 1980 on the old line.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Libya Says U.S. Fighter s Buzzed a Jetliner   BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 3 (AP) - Libya's Government radio said today that two United States jet fighters buzzed a Libyan jetliner over Greece.

headline: People
abstract: * John M. Pope appointed to vice president of marketing for the consumer products division of the Western Publishing Company, a subsidiary of Mattel Inc.   * Robert P. Holton appointed publisher of Marine Engineering/Log magazine, and a senior vice president of the publishing company Simmons-Boardman Publishing Corporation.   * Richard G. Kuhl has been appointed vice president/new products in the Boyle-Midway division of the American Home Products Corporation.

headline: Fed Backs Thrift Unit, Bank Ties
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board and the Government agencies that insure deposits in savings institutions have begun establishing the legal machinery needed to enable commercial banks to acquire troubled savings institutions, Frank O'Brien, a Federal Reserve public information officer, said yesterday.   Such acquisitions would represent a change in present laws that prohibit banks from establishing out-of-state offices that take deposits from consumers. In addition, the Federal Reserve does not allow commercial banks to acquire savings banks or savings and loan associations within a state.

headline: BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Cuban Offer to Nicaraguans
abstract: Cuba is offering 400 scholarships to Nicaraguan children to study on Havana's Isle of Youth in the next school year, according to a Managua radio broadcast monitored here Wednesday. The children, who must be no more than 15 years old, will join 1,200 other Nicaraguan students in Cuba, the radio said. More than 26,000 children from Africa and Central America have been educated by Cuba in the last four years on the Isle of Youth.

headline: Police Lieutenant Slain In Guatemala Ambush
abstract: A police official who was expected to be replaced by the new junta has been killed in an ambush, the police have disclosed.

headline: OCCIDENTAL OIL GETS CHINA MINE CONTRACT
abstract: The Government today gave formal permission to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to study the feasibility of developing what could become the world's largest open-pit coal mine.   An agreement signed by Armand Hammer, Occidental's board chairman and chief executive officer, with the China National Coal Development Corporation envisions the exploitation of an area in Shaanxi province that would produce 15 million tons of coal annually in its first phase, with output eventually tripling.   The Pingshuo open-cut mine, about 300 miles west of Peking, covers an area of nearly 14.7 square miles and reportedly has proven reserves of 1.4 billion tons of coal, which is more than double China's total coal production last year. More Than 2 Years of Talks   The accord signed today followed two and a half years of negotiations in which Occidental successfully outbid other competitors for the right to present a detailed plan for Pingshuo.

headline: CONSUMERS GLASS CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31

headline: AM International
abstract: AM International Inc. said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had almost no net worth at the end of its fiscal year July 31, 1981. The graphics equipment and information processing systems manufacturer, formerly the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, said that it was almost $250 million in debt and that a recapitalization of the company was likely to be required if long-term stability was to be restored.

headline: Tobacco Lobby Opens Cigarette Campaign
abstract: This week, just as the Surgeon General issued especially strong new warnings against cigarette smoking, the Tobacco Institute, the Washington-based lobbying organization of tobacco product manufacturers, began an estimated $6 million defensive magazine advertising campaign.   There are nine ads in the campaign, all created by Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.

headline: AMERICAN WELDING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNESCO PARLEY ON THE PRESS OPENS WITH U.S. OPPOSING MANY PLANS
abstract: An internationa l conference aimed at finding practical ways to strengthen journali sm and communications indeveloping countries began here today, with t he United States strongly opposed to a series of proposals tha t would increase government control of news.   The conference, the second session of a Unesco-backed International Program for Development of Communications, is the result of an American effort to channel a protracted and often bitter debate over a ''new world information order'' toward specific projects that would help the free flow of news.   The Reagan Administration is unwilling to provide any direct financing for a program controlled by third world governments and is instead proposing projects supported by the American private sector.

headline: POLISH CHIEF PLANS MAJOR ADDRESS TO OUTLINE CHANGES IN ECONOMY
abstract: In a major address to Parliament on Monday, Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski is expected to present programs for economic and eventual political changes, but the Polish leader is not likely to end martial law, well-informed Polish sources said today.   They said the general, who heads the Government, the Communist Party and the Military Council of National Salvation, is also likely to call for a ''social dialogue'' with all responsible, patriotic forces. The formulation excludes Solidarity leaders, most of whom are in detention and who are regarded as extremists by the Government.   The speech is regarded as General Jaruzelski's most important since martial law was imposed Dec. 13. It comes at a time when the military authorities are under pressure to present a program to lead the country out of crisis.

headline: POLAND PAYING INTEREST DUE IN 1981, BANKS SAY
abstract: Poland yesterday paid up all the past-due interest it owed for 1981 to one major New York bank, and other leading banks said payments have been quickly flowing in for the past two weeks.   ''As of yesterday, payments were coming in rapidly,'' said Ray V.  Toman, a press officer of the Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, which is believed to have lent more money to Poland than any other American bank.   ''We've been substantially brought up to date,'' said a spokesman for a leading New York bank with a relatively large exposure in Poland. Except for the Bank of America, no bank was willing to be named.

headline: Tin Price Below $12,775
abstract: For the second consecutive day, the price of tin metal today closed below $12,775 a metric ton on the London Metal Exchange.   The metal closed at $12,761.30, up $41.06 on Wednesday's official close.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Adams Drug Co. announced the retirement of Samuel Salmanson as chairman and secretary of the company. He will continue as director.  Charles Salmanson, vice chairman and treasurer, was named chairman and treasurer. Jerrold Salmanson was named secretary.

headline: SYRIA ASSAILS U.S. STAND ON GOLAN
abstract: Syria charged the United States today with encouraging Israel to destroy chances of peace in the Middle East by vetoing a United Nations Security Council resolution on sanctions.   Syria had led an Arab drive for sanctions against Israel because of Israel's decision last month to annex the Golan Heights, which was captured from Damascus in 1967.

headline: ENDERS AND CHILEAN CHIEF MEET
abstract: The Under Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs, Thomas O. Enders, met with President Augusto Pinochet today to discuss the political turmoil in Central America and human rights in Chile.   The meeting came amid moves by the Reagan Administration to resume weapon sales and military aid to Chile's military Government for the first time in five years.

headline: Henderson & Friedlich Gets Muzak Account
abstract: Henderson & Friedlich is going to be doing advertising and market promotion for Muzak, the tuneful subsidiary of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. The previous agency was Van Brunt & Company.
