headline: Pabst Is Closing Illinois Brewery
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewery, said that it would begin closing its Peoria Heights, Ill., brewery in early January.

headline: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: PUBLIC ORDER DISCUSSED
abstract: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish and the Russian by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:   Internees Noon Friday   (6 A.M. Friday, E.S.T.) The state of security in the country and the state of public order provided the main subject of the meeting of the parliamentary commission for internal affairs and the administration of justice, which met under the chairmanship of Zygmunt Surowiec. Part of the session was attended by the Speaker of Parliament, Stanislaw Gucwa.   A report was delivered by First Deputy Minister for Internal Affairs Boguslaw Stachura. To begin, he informed the deputies that peace was reigning throughout the country. He also said, among other things:   The leadership of the state, especially since February 1981, made many attempts to prevent the dangerous trends that became apparent during the post-August renewal. Despite economic difficulties, the authorities undertook efforts aimed at improving public supplies.  The destructive activities of the extremists sought to paralyze these initiatives. In the first 10 days of December the specter of civil war began to emerge with force. The 10-12 December meeting of the Solidarity national commission left no ill usi ons as to the intentionsof the enemy. The country faced the threat of a general strike as well as the danger of people being brought on to the streets on the anniversary of the events of December 1970.

headline: THE YEAR OF THE ACCOUNTANT
abstract: SOME people on Wall Street have their own name for the new tax law.  They call it the ''Accountants' Relief Act,'' and they're not far off. The radical changes that Congress enacted last year in the nation's tax system is translating into big business for accountants this year, when those provisions take effect. And 1982 shapes up as the year of the accountant, if there ever was one.   ''Accounting flourishes when there is change,'' said Henry Gunders, co-chairman at Price, Waterhouse & Company, which ranks No. 4 among the elite Big Eight firms that dominate the accounting profession.  Russell E. Palmer, chairman of Touche Ross & Company, the No. 8 firm, added that ''1981 was our best year ever. And 1982 will be even better.''   The accounting business is bursting not only in the Park Avenue towers where the leading firms are based, but also in the offices of certified public accountants throughout the land. Greater demands by municipalities, businesses and individuals for more precise information of all types, particulary more accurate financial information, have made the accountant a much sought-out individual.  Everybody seems to need accountants. ''You have much more complex problems that you are dealing with,'' explained William L. Raby, chairman of the Federal tax division of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. ''It's not enough to be somebody who knows a little about taxes. That's becoming dangerous.''

headline: Hi-Shear to Join With Raybestos
abstract: Hi-Shear Industries and Raybestos-Manhattan Inc., two suppliers to the aerospace industry, announced today that they had reached agreement in principle to merge into a new unit through an exchange of stock.   Raybestos-Manhattan, based in Trumbull, is a manufacturer and marketer of energy absorption and transmission products, fastening systems and other specialized materials.

headline: British-French Perfume Venture
abstract: Two British companies and a French concern announced in New York that they planned to merge into what would be one of the world's largest fragrance and flavor producers, with annual sales of $200 million.

headline: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Armenian Group Ends Attacks on French Sites
abstract: An Armenian guerrilla group said today that it would suspend terrorist operations against France because the French authorities had promised a fair trial and political prisoner status for four Armenians jailed in Paris.

headline: LIBYAN LEADER'S VISITS UPSET ALGIERS AND TUNIS
abstract: The weeklong visit to Algeria and Tunisia by Col.  Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, which ended here Sunday, has generated con cern and puzzlement in both countries, according to the officials and Western diplomats in Tunis and Algiers.   The Algerian Government of President Chadli Benjedid was reported to be upset over an announcement by Jana, the Libyan press agency, that Algeria and Libya had reached agreement on ''steps'' toward a merger into a unified Islamic Republic. This agreement, the agency said, was reached during Colonel Qaddafi's five-day stay in Algiers.   Algeria had long resisted such a merger, although its leaders - notably the late President Houari Boumediene - have said on various occasions that in principle the proposed Islamic Republic was a good idea. Colonel Qaddafi has said that his ambition is to fashion an Islamic state that would consist of Libya, Tunisia and Algeria.

headline: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UP FOR A SECOND MONTH
abstract: Prices that farmers get for raw products increased by eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Agriculture Department reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly rise - the first such occurrence in more than a year.   Nevertheless, the overall average of farm prices was 7.6 percent below the level of a year ago, officials said. The January price rise was revised to 3.1 percent from 1.6 percent, the first increase since December 1980.

headline: DUARTE SAYS PRESS AND POLITICIANS HAVE EXAGGERATED THE LATIN CRISIS
abstract: The President of El Salvador's junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte, said Saturday that the crisis in Central America was being blown out of proportion by the international press and by some United States politicians.   The international attention, he said, is harming the ''little countries,'' including Nicaragua and El Salvador.  In a four-hour interview, Mr. Duarte made these other points:   - If his Christian Democrats win the elections scheduled for March 28, they will become a ''legitimate government,'' which can more forcefully deal with violations of human rights. Mr. Duarte is confident that he will become President of the country, not just the junta.   - While emphatically rejecting any negotiations with the leftist rebels as a way of ending the fighting, he said he would encourage them to return to the country and participate in building a democracy. But he will not allow them to have any positions in the Government, he said. He also said he would not share power with the ''extreme right.''

headline: Philippines' Strongest Quake In Five Years Causes Injuries
abstract: The strongest earthquake in the Philippines in more than five years caused some damage and injuries today.

headline: Rockefeller Said to See Hope for Angolan Ties
abstract: David Rockefeller, on an African tour, says his visit to Angola could help toward normalizing relations between Angola and the United States, the official Angolan press agency reported today.   Mr. Rockefeller, a director and former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank and a strong advocate of United States recognition of Angola, told the agency after visiting oil installations in northern Angola that his trip was essentially commercial.

headline: DOW FALLS 7.61 POINTS, TO 807.55
abstract: The stock market was pounded anew in very heavy trading yesterday with computer and other technology issues coming under particular pressure. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 7.61 points, to 807.55, the lowest close in almost 22 months.   Volume swelled to 74.3 million shares, the fourth-busiest session ever on the New York Stock Exchange. Wednesday's turnover of 70.2 million shares had been the seventh-heaviest trading in Big Board history.   Data General, a computer manufacturer, was a factor in the broad market selloff as its shares responded to management forecasts of a decline in earnings in the March quarter. It plunged 10 points, to 33 3/4. This compares with a record price of 87 3/4 in 1980.

headline: Egyptians Are Warned O f Economic Sacrifices
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak said today that his economic goals would require sacrifices and he cautioned officials not to undermine the Government's credibility with exaggerated promises.   In a half-hour address on television, he dwelled on the faltering economy and said new steps had to be taken within ''a social framework that is quite clear.''

headline: 11 Killed, 20 Injured In Alps by Avalanches
abstract: A series of avalanches that swept down the slopes of the French Alps today in a sudden spell of warm weather killed 11 people and injured 20, the police said.

headline: SAUDIS CUT OIL OUTPUT; GASOLINE PRICES FALLING
abstract: SAUDI ARABIA CUT oil output to its lowest level in more than four years.  The country now will pump 7 million to 7.5 million barrels a day, trimming 500,000 barrels from production.  Gasoline prices have fallen at least 2 cents to 3 cents a gallon in less than a month because of the worldwide surplus of crude oil.

headline: U.S. STANCE ON NICARAGUA ANGERS PARIS
abstract: Officials here reacted angrily today against what they interpreted as an effort by some Washington officials to magnify the significance of France's agreement to sell arms to Nicaragua.   They heatedly denied published reports that the projected shipments included offensive weapons that could be used by guerrillas in El Salvador.   A senior aide to the French Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, said that a statement attributed to the State Department spokesman supporting such reports was worrying. It indicates, he said, ''that there are people in Washington who are trying to make trouble between us and the United States.''

headline: EX-OFFICER OUSTS GHANA'S GOVERNMENT AGAIN
abstract: Jerry J. Rawlings seized power in Ghana for a second time today, overthrowing the civilian Government that he had resigned in favor of two years ago.   In an emotional speech broadcast on Accra radio, Mr. Rawlings accused President Hilla Limann of taking the West African nation ''down to total economic ruin.''   Recalling that he had voluntarily stepped down as Ghana's leader in September 1979 after Mr. Limann and a civilian Parliament were elected, Mr. Rawlings said in his speech that the two years of President Limann's rule ''have seen nothing but repression.'' 'A Pack of Criminals'   ''They were a pack of criminals who bled Ghana to the bone,'' Mr.  Rawlings, who is 34 years old, said of Mr. Limann and his associates.  He said in his radio broadcast that ''several soldiers'' had died in the fighting involved during his coup today. But Mr. Rawlings offered no further details.

headline: Gold Mining In Modern Era
abstract: EVEN when refined gold commands a mere $315 an ounce, the prospect of raw gold can quicken pulses. Last Friday the shares of Franklin Consolidated Mining sparkled, reaching 1 7/8 bid, up from 1 1/2 bid a day earlier. Volume was surprising for the over-the-counter market: 37,200 shares. The excitement over this obscure gold mining company reflects interest in its century-old mine to the east of the Continental Divide near Idaho Springs, Colo.   Franklin has spent the last 10 years constructing a mill and an assay facility that management says cost more than $1 million. When Franklin begins milling operations this week, it will mark the firstfull scale production at the mine since the 1920's.

headline: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: McGregor Campaign
abstract: McGregor Brand, which does not make anything but does license its well-known name to sportswear manufacturers, is going to be doing some marketing for the first time and has retained the Saxon Communications Group for help.

headline: Dow Off 1.52 as Rates Climb
abstract: Rising short-term interest rates sent the stock market down moderately yesterday in accelerated trading. A few of the specialsituation and transportation issues registered the largest declines.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout most of the session, closed down 1.52 points, to 845.89.  In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored advancing issues by a 9-to-5 ratio. Turnover expanded to 48.9 million shares from 45.1 million the day before.

headline: I.B.M. Computer
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new mo del of its Series 1 line of small computers.

headline: INVESTMENT UNIT SET BY CHASE
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank is planning to establish a new subsidiary for its investment banking activities that would be comparable in size to Bache Halsey Stuart Shields & Company, one of the nation's 10 largest securities concerns, the bank said yesterday.   Under the plan, which is to be formally announced today, Chase will merge all its securities trading and capital market activities, domestic and international, into a single subsidiary of the bank.   The company will not enable Chase to enter new fields at present because it, like the bank, will be subject to the Glass-Steagall Act that limits the types of investment banking activities in which commercial banks may engage; most importantly, underwriting corporate securities is prohibited.

headline: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHINESE TRY TO QUELL RUMORS THAT DENG'S POWER IS FADING
abstract: Several Chinese officials and editors sought today to dampen speculation that China's 77-year-old leader, Deng Xiaoping, had lost authority through an internal power struggle. Speculation about the future of Mr. Deng, w ho was last seen in public on Jan. 12, followed a remark about hi m made last Saturday by a Deputy Prime Minister, Wan Li.   Mr. Wan told visiting executives from the Reuters news agency that Mr. Deng had withdrawn from daily decision-making to a ''second line'' of officialdom. This remark has not been reported in the official Chinese press.

headline: Charity
abstract: To the Business Editor: Stephen L. Slavin's Jan. 3 response, ''Charity (Cont.),'' to our Dec. 27 letter, ''Bergmann's Coercion,'' fell victim to a typographical error.   Our letter said that 80 p ercent of the 5,47 1 organizations registered in New York State had fund-raising costs of less than 15 percent and ''these organizations raised $1.7 85 billion, which was 72percent of all money raised within the states .'' In translation, that became $1.7 million.  JOHN J.  SCHWARTZ President American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel New York, Jan. 5, 1982

headline: Beatrice Must Sell Part of Fiberite
abstract: The Justice Department announced that it had reached a settlement to end an antitrust suit filed by the Carter Administration to block the merger of the Beatrice Foods Company and the Fiberite Corporation.

headline: Turkish Ex-Chief to Be Freed
abstract: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, who is serving a three-month jail term for defying a military ban on public statements, will be released Feb. 1, his lawyer said today. Mr. Ecevit was jailed Dec. 3 after a martial-law court found him guilty of violating a decree aimed at gagging former politicians.

headline: Publisher Goes To CBS Unit
abstract: Since Geo magazine was sold out from under him by Gruner + Jahr, most of adland has been wondering where Peter G. Diamandis, 50-yearold frequent publisher and occasional agency man, would turn up next. The answer is CBS Publications.

headline: ROLLINS BURDICK HUNTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Spanish Police Seize Terrorist Arms Cache
abstract: Antiterrorist police seized five tons of weapons and explosives belonging to the Basque E.T.A terrorist organization today and arrested two presumed members of the group.   The police said the cache held ''practically all'' of the weapons belonging to E.T.A.  A police spokesman said the Central Antiterrorist Brigade obtained information on the weapons f rom two E.T.A. members arrested Sunday when policeme n freed the father of the Spanish singer Julio Iglesias,kidnapped by E.T.A. Dec. 29.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO ACQUIRE F.&M.
abstract: Shearson/American Express Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the F.& M. Corporation, the parent of a Seattle securities firm, in a cash and stock transaction valued at $76 million.   Shearson/American Express said it had offered 1.1 million shares of its common stock, worth about $48.5 million, and about $27.5 million in cash for F.& M., whose principal subsidiary is Foster & Marshall Inc., an investment banking firm.

headline: U.S. Lets Home Savings Acquire Six Small Units
abstract: The nation's largest savings and loan association was given permission today to broaden its base and acquire five small savings and loan institutions in Texas and one in Illinois.   The Home Savings and Loan Association of America, based in Los Angeles, completed its second interstate acquisition in less than a month with the help of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Home Savings is the principal subsidiary of H.F.  Ahmanson & Company.

headline: Bankeno Mines Bids for Merland
abstract: Bankeno Mines Ltd., a dormant shell corporation controlled by Turbo Resources Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas producer, said today that it had offered to acquire all outstanding shares of Merland Explorations Ltd. of Calgary in a deal valued at about $260.6 million (United States).   Turbo, an energy exploration and production concern that already owns a 50 percent stake in Merland, said Bankeno's share-and-warrant offer would equal or exceed the $13.30 (Canadian) a share that Turbo paid for its Merland stake last summer.

headline: BANK, THRIFT MERGE IN MINNESOTA
abstract: The Marquette National Bank of Minneapolis, in the nation's first merger between a commercial bank and a thrift institution, announced yesterday that it had acquired the ailing Farmers and Mechanics Savings Bank of Minneapolis. The move will create the fourth-largest commercial bank in the city, with deposits of more than $1.1 billion.    The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which helped arrange the merger, said Marquette had won Farmers, the state's only savings bank, in a bidding contest with three other Minnesota banks and nine from other states.

headline: Economic Scene; The Outlook For Volcker
abstract: WILL Paul A. Volcker serve out his term, which ends in August 1983, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board? And will the Administration replace him as chairman thereafter?   With worries mounting in financial markets at home and throughout the world over the conduct of United States monetary policy, in the face of huge looming Federal budget deficits and the threat of another rise in interest rates, Mr. Volcker's tenure at the Fed will play a crucial role in affecting the future o f the domestic and international economy and the political fortu nes of President Reagan and the Republican Party.   Immediately, there appears to be little prospect that Mr. Volcker will leave or be put in a position by the Administration where he would feel compelled to resign. That possibility existed before the White House made it known, three days before Christmas, that President Reagan intended to appoint Preston Martin, a California businessman, as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board to succeed Frederick H. Schultz, whose term expires at the end of this month.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES RISE SHARPLY
abstract: Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday and caused securities dealers to revise upward the yields that will be needed to attract buyers for three- , 10- and 30-year Treasury issues scheduled for auction this week.   At the Treasury's regular weekly sale of three- and six-month bills yesterday, average rates were more than a percentage point higher than the prevailing rates for similar issues as recently as last Friday.   Three-month bills sold at an average rate of 13.85 percent, up from 12.58 percent last Friday and 13.36 percent a week ago, while six-month bills sold at an average of 13.846 percent, up from 12.7 percent last Friday and 13.53 percent a week ago. Six-Month Bills Rise   Adding a quarter of a percentage point to the average of the sixmonth bill rate, banks and savings institutions may pay a top rate of 14.096 percent on new six-month savings certificates starting today, up fro m 13.78 percent for the week ended yesterday.

headline: 13 Woolco Stores to Close
abstract: The F.W. Woolworth Company, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, said it will close 13 Woolco discount department stores in three states by July 4, idling about 900 employees.   ''They had not been operating up to Woolworth's operating criteria; they were not profitable,'' said Joseph Carroll, a Woolworth spokesman.

headline: Strategic Arms Talks Urged by U.N. Chief
abstract: Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to resume their negotiation on limiting strategic nuclear weapons.   The Soviet-American talks now being held here on limiting mediumrange missiles in Europe are a ''step forward'' in the field of nuclear disarmament, the Secretary General said in a message to mark the opening here of the 1982 session of the 40-nation Disarmament Committee.

headline: CORPORATE FINANCIAL STRAINS
abstract: At no time since World War II has the financial position of the nation's corporate sector been so weak. It is not so precarious, financial experts say, that a widespread collapse is imminent, although it is possible that Braniff, International Harvester or one or more of the other major companies already in financial straits could go under.   What concerns analysts most is that a broad range of American companies have left themselves little cushion against adversity, be it high interest rates, a prolonged recession or a crisis of confidence in the financial markets.   For most corporations, having a margin of safety is simply a matter of having enough readily available funds to pay their bills in the near future, no matter what happens to earnings. Financial analysts call this liquidity, and it is this measure of future solvency that many believe has gotten dangerously low in recent years, particularly in an era of soft earnings and seesawing interest rates.

headline: E.E.C. Assails U.S. Policies
abstract: European Economic Community finance ministers today voiced alarm at the impact of United States policies on the world economy and said the message would be conveyed to Washington later this week.

headline: Pentecostals in Soviet Get 2d Room at Embassy
abstract: Two families of Pentecostalists who have lived for three and a half years in a cramped basement room of the United States Embassy moved into a second room today, doubling their living space.   Pyotr Vashchenko showed guests into a 15-foot-by-9-foot room that was formerly the embassy's barber shop. Mr. Vashchenko, his wife, Avgustina, and their daughters Lyuba and Liliya will move into the carpeted room.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE MITTERRAND JUGGLING ACT
abstract: In a side room at a hotel here, just before plunging into a crowd of French residents who had eaten a 60-foot buffet lunch while waiting for him, President Francois Mitterrand reflected on the two-day visit he was about to end.   ''The only new thing,'' he said, ''was that I said the same thing.'' In Israel, where his visit broke a 15-year-old tradition of official French aloofness, Mr. Mitterrand coupled warm words for the Israelis with an assertion that the Palestinians were a people with the right to a state. Earlier, in visits to Egypt, Algeria and Saudi Arabia, he coupled warm words for the Palestinians with the assertion that Israel was a legitimate state with a right to security.

headline: Three of 10 Complaints Result in Ad Changes
abstract: Only three out of the 10 complaints resolved in February by the National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus ended with the dropping of either an ad claim or advertising. All seven of the other advertisers were able to support their claims.   The three were Aamco Transmissions, whose agency is Calet, Hirsh, Kurnit & Spector; the Kroger Company, the supermarket chain whose advertising is done in-house, and Pacer Lubricants, whose agency is Brown & Koby.

headline: Reagan's Latin Talk Is Planned Tomorrow
abstract: President Reagan will present his development plan for the Caribbean and Central American region in a speech Wednesday to the Organization of American States, the organization said today.   The speech on what the Administration has called its Caribbean Basin initiative, a trade and aid package, will be delivered at noon to the Permanent Council of the O.A.S.

headline: BANK TRIES TO TURN MARKET FORECASTING INTO SCIENCE
abstract: At Chemical Bank, specialists are trying their best to make real estate a science. The result is a new set of predictions for what is likely to happen in commercial and residential real estate in 15 cities across the country. In the real estate industry, where analysis of market conditions has traditionally been based in large part on intuition, Chemical's work will surely stir debate.   Computer analysis and forecasting reports have become an essential part of every business, and experts besides those at Chemical are trying to apply more precision to the vagaries of real estate. But Chemical says it has developed an unparalleled econometric model for making its forecasts of supply and demand for office buildings, shopping centers, stores, warehouses, and multifamily and singlefamily homes.

headline: 76 in Sicily Accused Of Drug Trafficking
abstract: Michele Sindona, the Sicilianborn financier, and 75 others accused of being Mafia heroin traffickers were ordered to stand trial today on charges of criminal association, trafficking in illegal drugs and other crimes.   Giovanni Falcone, the investigating magistrate, said heroin traded through Sicily to the United States had made the group about $600 million.

headline: Canada's M-1 Advances
abstract: Canada's narrowly defined money supply, M-1, rose $526 million to $23.42 billion in the week ended March 3, the Bank of Canada said today.

headline: SYRIANS REPORTING KEY ROAD IS OPEN
abstract: The Syrian authorities said today that they had reopened the main highway running through the embattled city of Hama, but that troops were still rooting out die-hard insurgents from narrow alleys and underground catacombs in the ancient quarter.   The Government characterized the battle as a ''mopping-up operation.'' The traditionally rebellious, fundamentalist Sunni Moslem city has been sealed off since Feb. 2, when a Government security force attempting to raid a suspected stronghold of the underground Moslem Brotherhood was wiped out, sparking a general insurrection.

headline: FULL STUDY ORDERED ON PHONE PACT
abstract: Judge Harold H. Greene today ordered a fulldress public review of the Federal antitrust settlement that frees the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to enter new businesses after divesting itself of its 22 local operating companies.   Judge Greene, in a seven-page order, outlined procedures for getting information about the settlement to the public and repeated an earlier statement that he would not approve the two-week-old agreement until he determined it was in the public interest.   First, he set aside an order issued by Judge Vincent P. Biunno in Newark on Jan. 11 approving the settlement as a modification of an earlier consent decree that has limited A.T.& T. to regu- A shift in depreciation policy that would raise phone rates won F ederal approval. A.T.& T. announced management changes to prepare f or its sweeping divestiture. Page D3. lated telephone businesses since 1956.  Legal authorities said that Judge Greene had the right to vacate an order by another Federal district court judge because Judge Biunno had given Judge Greene full control of the case in transferring the consent decree to Judge Greene's jurisdiction last week.

headline: LONDON LOSES BIT OF HISTORY IN BILLINGSGATE
abstract: They sold the last fish at Billingsgate market today, and London will never be quite the same.  Billingsgate is one of the few markets whose name entered the language. Its fishmongers and porters in dirty white aprons were so famous for gutter language that ''billingsgate,'' says Webster, means ''foul, vulgar, abusive talk.''

headline: Professor Director
abstract: To the Business Editor: As a member of the editorial board of The Nation, I was of course delighted to learn in ''Professor Director'' (Jan. 17) that we have as distinguished a reader as Dean Richard R. West of the Amos Tuck School of Business Management at Dartmouth. His criticism of the discussion of the relationship between the academy and society at the American Writers Congress, unfortunately, rests on an excessive simplification of the argument.

headline: NO SUPPORT BY JAPAN OF AID PLAN
abstract: The Japanese Government does not endorse a plan proposed last week by a Japanese-American businessman for private industry in Japan to provide $10 billion to finance job-creating projects in the United States.   Nor does there appear to be support for the idea in industry and banking circles here. The plan was presented earlier this week at the winter meeting of the National Governors Association in Washington by Kaytaro Sugahara, a wealthy 72-year-old Japanese-American businessman.

headline: Safeway Net Up in Quarter
abstract: Safeway Stores Inc., a leading grocery retailer and food processor, said today that its fourthquarter profit rose by 13.6 percent but that its full-year earnings fell by 4 percent.   Safeway also announced plans to close by March 27 its Omaha division, which operates 70 stores in eastern Nebraska and western Iowa, because of continuing losses there.

abstract: In addition to Del Monte, Young & Rubicam, which has been serving the Gannett Company as corporate ad agency for two years, has also been named to do advertising for USA Today, Gannett's proposed national newspaper scheduled for publication in the autumn.   Young & Rubicam, which also is the agency for Time Inc., and its Time, Fortune and Discover magazines, will be promoting both circulation and advertising for USA Today.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ruled that an illness suffered by Judge Inzer B. Wyatt ''makes it medically impossible for him to continue to participate in the remaining deliberations.''

headline: KAISER ACCEPTS OFFER BY HILLER
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement in principle for an investment group headed by Stanley Hiller Jr. to acquire most of the company for about $350 million in cash.   The Hiller offer, which includes a bid of $55.25 a share for 83 percent of the company's common stock, follows bids that the group had made last year of $50 and then $52 a share. These were rejected by Kaiser's management.   Edgar F. Kaiser Jr., a former chairman of the steel company, is believed to have encouraged the cash offer in order to sell the 17 percent stake held by the nonprofit Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The so-called umbrella theory, under which the Soviet Union would come to the aid of East-bloc countries with debt problems, has lost much of its validity, Hans Friderichs, a spokesman for the management board of the Dresdner Bank, said in an article released today.   Dresdner bank is due to act as agent bank on the $2.4 billion rescheduling agreement for Polish commercial bank debt, which has been delayed by the imposition of martial law and the failure of Poland to repay all outstanding 1981 interest obligations.

headline: SQUATTERS IN SINAI EVICTED BY ISRAEL
abstract: Israeli troops began removing militant Jewish squatters from Sinai today as permanent residents announced that they would leave peacefully as soon as the Government paid them compensation.   Soldiers surrounded the settlement of Hatzar Hadar in northern Sinai at dawn. They then moved into the abandoned houses occupied in recent weeks by about 60 protesters, including children, whose leaders opposed the return of the region to Egypt.   Reporters at the scene said the militants announced Tuesday night that they would resist. They erected barbed-wire fences, burned tires, dug trenches and filled them with water. When the soldiers grabbed the squatters, most apparently resisted passively; some pushed, pulled, kicked in the air and tried to wriggle free.

headline: Comment; HOW TO GET OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY
abstract: IT'S called O.P.M., or "other people's money" and the search for it takes up a substantial part of most businessmen's time.  The idea is to get someone else to give you money to use as you see fit.  If you make a profit with the money, you then give back only that portion that represents what you borrowed, plus interest.  However, it is pleasant to contemplate as well that if you lose it all, you are free to go bankrupt, wipe the slate clean, and start again with more O.P.M. for still another venture.

headline: Red Brigades Attack Army Depot in Italy
abstract: Four Red Brigades guerrillas overpowered 13 guards at an army depot near here today and made off with arms in the Brigades' first action since police raids this month after the rescue of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier.

headline: JAPAN SEEMS TO TAKE ON BIGGER DEFENSE ROLE
abstract: Last week the Japanese Cabinet approved a budget for 1982 that includes a 7.7 percent increase in military spending.  The rise, which will bring the amount of money spent on the nation's armed forces to $11.8 billion, was th e first increase in military expe nditures as a percentage of the national budget since 1956.  ''I personally feel it was rather historical,'' said Tadashi Ogawa, an official in the Finance Ministry. ''The rate of increase in defense spending in 1980 was a little higher than that of education for the first time in 10 years. It was almost equivalent to that of social welfare in 1981.'' But the official went on to warn that there would be only ''very small, modest increases'' in military expenditures from now on.

headline: Business Conditions; FAILURES ARE SPREADING
abstract: The pace of business failures, which last year reached levels not seen since the early 1960's, has accelerated during the first two months of 1982.   Through the week ended Feb. 28, more than 3,500 companies had gone out of business, a 55 percent increase from the same period a year earlier, according to statistics from Dun & Bradstreet, the business information and service company.

headline: TAKEOVER BILL SIGNED IN FRANCE
abstract: France's industrial nationalization bill, the biggest Government takeover of private industry since World War II, was signed into law today by the Socialist Prime Minister, Pierre Mauroy.   Five major industrial groups, 39 banks and two financial holding companies were nationalized under the law at an estimated cost to the French taxpayer of $7 billion.

headline: Stocks Mixed; Dow Up 0.67
abstract: The stock market's attempt to continue its recent rally ran out of momentum yesterday as prices ended mixed in slower trading. The main casualties were some of the technology issues, which have been hardhit recently because of lower earning estimates.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 0.67 point, at 805.56. In the previous two days the Dow had risen 9.42 points after having dropped almost 45 points in the preceding six sessions.

headline: U.S. and Hungary Will Grant Reporters Multiple Exit Visas

headline: Careers; Retiring Workers Get Tuition
abstract: BACK in 1976 the International Business Machines Corporation announced a bold new program, offering tuition dollars to employees approaching retirement. The money could be used to finance training for a second career or even a hobby.   Coming before the fast-paced inflation of today that is leading many older people to second careers, it was a pioneering effort. In 1978 Pitney Bowes also started a preretirement education program.

headline: Swissair Plans A-310 Delays
abstract: Swissair plans to invest 2.5 billion Swiss francs, or $1.33 billion, between 1982 and 1985 on aircraft fleet renewal, according to its planning director, A.  Bernhardsgruetter said.   However, a stagnant market for European airline seats means Swissair will not expand its fleet of 50 aircraft to 55 in the period as planned and will now delay delivery of some Airbus A-310 models on order, he added.

headline: SADAT'S DEATH GIVES TOURISTS PAUSE ABOUT EGYPT
abstract: The horse and buggy, its brass fittings gleaming in the sunlight, sits with a forlorn driver for hours near the Happi Hotel waiting for a passenger.   The other night a belly dancer, Miss Ahly, undulated in a nightclub with only a handful of customers to view her twitching hips.  Out on the glittering waters of the Nile, near the first cataract of the great river, only a few graceful feluccas - small, narrow vessels with lateen sails - moved silently through the water with a scattering of tourists aboard. Many more were moored to piers waiting for customers. Normally at this time of year, Aswan is full of tourists taking advantage of the warm weather, the flawless blue skies and the joys of an easygoing oasis filled with water and greenery and with the desert visible in the distance.

headline: Around the World; Britain Said to Withhold Files on Two Defectors
abstract: Government files on two Britons who defected to the Soviet Union in 1951, Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean, are being withheld by the Foreign Office even though they are eligible for publication, British newspapers reported today.   The documents, which many believe could shed new light on the defections of the two men, were due to be published under a rule that allows Cabinet minutes and other secret Government papers to be made public after 30 years.

headline: Czechoslovak Author Loses Citizenship While in the West
abstract: Jiri Grusa, the Czechoslovak author, has been stripped of his citizenship while on an extended stay in the West, a Czechoslovak Embassy spokesman confirmed today.   Exile sources in Vienna said that Mr. Grusa, 44 years old, spent six months in a Czechoslovak jail in 1978 after his novel ''The Questionnaire'' was published in West Germany. They said he was granted a two-year exit visa in December.

headline: NEWSPAPER ADS UP
abstract: A weakening economy did little to curb demand for advertising space in newspapers last year. Preliminary figures from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau show that revenues in 1981 hit an all-time high of $17.4 billion, up 12.3 percent from a year earlier.

headline: DESPITE DIVISIONS AND CRISES, ITALY AVOIDS DISASTER
abstract: After a century of national unity, Italy is still two countries. The north, with its industries and technology, is part of Europe - ''the southern tip of the Ruhr,'' a Milanese industrialist said only half facetiously. The largely rural south is part of the underdeveloped Mediterranean third world. Naples and Palermo evoke Alexandria, not Hamburg or Le Havre.   The north-south issue is the oldest and most fundamental of Italy's unresolved problems. These problems are so numerous and of such variety that foreigners, though not Italians, often fear the ultimate catastrophe - the collapse of the country's institutions or the breaking apart of its social fabric.   A cartoon in a leading French magazine some time ago showed the Italian boot spinning madly around Europe in imminent danger of being torn loose and flung either south into the third world, east into the Soviet orbit or perhaps s imply into the void of outer space.

headline: 2 SCANDALS HAVE ALL MOSCOW ABUZZ
abstract: The arrest of a flamboyant circus performer known as Boris the Gypsy has set off a major scandal here that has led to the arrest of the country's top circus official. It has also led to the discovery in the official's apartment of diamonds and foreign currency worth 1.2 million rubles, the equivalent of nearly $1.7 million, according to Soviet sources familiar with the case.   As foreign reporters here learned of the case, word reached them of another development in the nationwide crackdown on corruption that the Kremlin started last year. Soviet and Western sources reported that the retired general who headed the bureau responsible for issuing emigration permits, Konstantin I. Zotov, was dismissed last month for his failure to halt subordinates who were selling the permits at black market prices said to run as high as 3,500 rubles, or more than $4,700, more than 15 times the official fee.

headline: Mubarak Sends a Message
abstract: Gen. Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, the Defense Minister, left unexpectedly for Washington today with a message to the Reagan Administration from President Hosni Mubarak that ''concerns armament agreements,'' a military spokesman said. He declined to give details.

headline: COLOMBIA CALLS FOR A NAVAL FORCE TO CUT OFF SALVADORAN REBELS
abstract: President Julio Cesar Turbay Ayala of Colombia called today for an inter-American naval force to block the flow of arms from Cuba and Nicaragua to guerrillas in El Salvador and other Latin American countries.   He said the force should be created by the Organization of American States under the 1947 Rio Treaty, which calls for mutual defense of the Western Hemisphere against outside intervention. He accused the Soviet Union of trying to undermine governments in the region through Cuba and Nicaragua.   The official request to create the force would likely come from El Salvador, the country where outside intervention is clearest, the President said. He predicted that the proposal would receive the necessary two-thirds vote of O.A.S. members.

headline: DOZIER TELLS OF 42 DAYS IN A PUP TENT
abstract: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier spent his 42 days of captivity in the hands of Red Brigades terrorists constantly chained to a steel cot in a pup tent under the never-extinguished glare of an electric bulb.   The only way in which the 50-year-old officer, who was held in a Padua apartment, could guess whether it was day or night was when one of his guards changed the bare bulb that hung over his head from white to blue. General Dozier said he assumed that the blue bulb indicated nighttime and was a concession on the terrorists' part to make it easier for him to sleep.   ''The period was really characterized by excruciating boredom,'' General Dozier said today at a news conference at the American military base in this northern Italian city.

headline: ROSENTHAL RE-ELECTED IN CHICAGO
abstract: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade tonight narrowly re-elected Leslie Rosenthal to be chairman of the nation's largest commodities exchange in one of the biggest and most heated exchange elections in recent memory.   The controversial Mr. Rosenthal, who is the general manager of the commodities trading firm of Rosenthal & Compa ny, defeated Ralph Goldenberg, an independent trader who was the choice of the exchange's nominating committee by 105 votes -659 1/2 for Mr.  Rosenthal and 554 1/2 for Mr. Goldenberg.   ''It was the biggest election we've had in a long time, said Robert Wilmouth, president of the Board of Trade. ''It was the intense competition and the contrasting style of the two men.'' He attributed Mr. Rosenthal's victory to his reputation for ''innovation.''

headline: THE GLOSS FADES FROM MAGAZINES
abstract: ''Nothing's going to save these magazines. Nothing. I can tell it by feel, by the heft of the magazine - lay a copy on the doorstep and the wind blows it away. Not that I'm against your trying to save it.  Go ahead. It's like someone in your family dying, you have to try to save him...'' ''The View from the Fortieth Floor,'' Theodore H. White   NOT only in Mr. White's 1960 novel do able men and women strive to heal ailing magazines - and grieve when their efforts fail. This winter, too, there is pain and sickness in the magazine industry.  Inside Sports, a young magazine with unexpectedly heavy losses, is being sold off by its disappointed owners - sharing the fate of Attenzione and Home. Other magazines, running the gamut from Penthouse to Ms. to Consumer Reports, have been losing readers, revenues or funding.   The Ladies Home Journal and a whole covey of other traditional women's service magazines have been losing advertising for a year. In the uncertain economic climate, even so eminent a publisher as Dow Jones & Company decided to kill a planned new magazine, the Wall Street Journal Magazine, after putting out a prototype issue. The growing casualty list includes Ambiance, American Girl, L'Officiel, Next, Panorama, Quest/81 and Talk.

headline: Schmidt Plans to Meet Mitterrand Tomorrow
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany will visit Paris on Wednesday for talks with President Francois Mitterrand.

headline: SETTLERS PROTEST SINAI COMPENSATION PLAN
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet's decision last week on compensation for settlers evacuating Sinai has begun to encounter opposition, both from settlers who think the money is insufficient and from politicians who think it excessive.   Settlers from Yamit, a town on the Mediterranean that is part of the swath of Sinai to be turned over to Egypt in April, reacted favorably at first to the award. But after studying the detailed figures, they renewed their opposition and at a news conference today. they threatened violent resistance to the withdrawal if the compensation is not increased.

headline: ASTRONOMERS SCOFF AT SOOTHSAYERS PREDICTING WORLD WILL END TODAY
abstract: Despite widespread rumors, the world is unlikely to end today as a result of an unusual alignment of the Sun, the planets and the Moon, known as a syzygy. Astronomers do not expect anything unusual, except for the fact that all of the other planets will be visible at the same time from the Earth,   Because the nine planets will be on the same side of the Sun in a relatively rare configuration, all will be observable, some with the unaided eye and some with a telescope, shortly before dawn today and tomorrow.   Far from being in a straight line that also passes through the Sun, Earth and Moon, as some people have been led to believe, the planets will be scattered across the sky. Of the planets that can be seen by the unaided eye, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn, visible through most of the night, will be closest to perfect alignment.

headline: Pakistan Decides to Preserve Its Ban on Political Activity
abstract: President Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq and his Cabinet decided today not to lift a 28-month-old ban on political activity.

headline: Sudan and Chad Agree T o Normalize Relations
abstract: The Sudan and Chad agreed today to normalize relations and set up a ministerial committee to insure Chadian rebels do not use the Sudan as a base.   In a joint statement issued at the end of three days of talks, President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan and President Goukouni Oueddei of Chad said the committee would handle matters of mutual interest.   The withdrawal of Libyan troops last month from Chad eased relations between Chad and the Sudan. Mr. Nimeiry had charged that the Libyan troops next planned to move into the Sudan.

headline: Italian Police Find Red Brigades Hide-Out
abstract: The police found personal belongings of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier in an apartment used by the Red Brigades as a hide-out during his abduction, the authorities reported today.   The hide-out was discovered several days ago, but the news was kept secret in the hope that Red Brigades members would drop by, the police sources said.

headline: Around the World; Death Toll in Lebanon Said to Be 2,100 in 1981
abstract: More than 2,100 people died as a result of v iolence in Lebanon in 1981, about 700 more than in the previous year , security sources said today.   The dead included more than 500 people killed during violence between Palestinian commandos and Israeli forces in southern Lebanon and in Israeli air raids against Beirut last July.

headline: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANS SELECTED
abstract: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation today selected five projects in five states to compete for multimillion-dollar Federal subsidies to develop synthetic fuels.    The projects, survivors of a lengthy process that began with 63 candidates, now enter into final negotiations over terms under which the subsidies would be granted. Most of the five, representing a range of technologies and resources, are expected to eventually get the subsidies.   The proposed plants would be in Memphis; Gillette, Wyo.; Breckenridge County, Ky.; Creswell, N.C., and West Pittsburg, Calif.

headline: IN A TROUBLES POLAND, JEWS AGAIN SEEM TO BE MADE SCAPEGOATS
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by the authorities there since Dec. 14.   The Christmas issue of the official Communist Party newspaper in the northern city of Szczecin carried a lengthy article on Jews.  Since 1947, it said, Jews have created trouble in Poland.

headline: CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Can Company said it had agreed to acquire a 25 percent stake, or 1,754,320 shares, in the Associated Madison Companies, and will buy 69.3 percent, or 490,000 shares, of convertible preferred stock, for an aggregate price of $38.7 million.   * Apple Computer Inc. said that it would spend $25 million to expand its manufacturing and test plant in Singapore.   * Blount Inc. said a joint venture in which it is a 45 percent partner had received an additional $230 million contract for work at a university academic center in Saudi Arabia. Separately, the company said that a subsidiary had signed an agreement with the Hotel Corporation of the Bahamas to design and build a casino and other structures at a value of $33.4 million.

headline: WHO'S TRYING TO CORNER TIN?
abstract: Since last July, a shadowy group of speculators has spent as much as half a billion dollars buying up huge quantities of tin. Their evident attempt to corner the market has since raised the price of this normally plentiful metal more than 25 percent - to as much as $7.60 a pound in London yesterday -while the prices of other commodities have sagged under world recession.   Commodity traders have been startled by such high prices at this time. Governments, manufacturers and the governors of world exchanges have been investigating the scheme, pooh-poohing it, taking steps to undercut it, asking how much more the speculators can spend and, generally, filling the narrow world of big-time tin with the shrewd and wild gossip that attends every such manipulation.   On the floor of the London Metal Exchange, where much of the world's tin is traded, the prevailing rumor is that the Malaysian Government lies behind the gigantic purchases, which have amounted so far to 20,000 and perhaps even 30,000 tons of soft, shiny, useful, unglamorous tin.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Ashland Oil Co., Ashland, Ky., announced that Robert E. Yancey Sr. is retiring as president.   * E.G. Bowman Co. has elected John L. Procope chairman and Herm M.  Wille vice president of marketing and director of sales.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES UP SLIM 0.4%
abstract: The Producer Price Index for finished goods continued to rise at a subdued pace in January, despite the sharpest jump in food prices since the 1980 drought, the Labor Department reported today.   The index for finished goods, the most important of the three producer price indexes for measuring roughly future inflation in consumer prices, rose four-tenths of 1 percent, or slightly less than the average for the preceding three months. The January rise, when compounded, was equivalent to an annual increase of 5.3 percent.   The Reagan Administration was quick to seize on today's report as further evidence of dwindling inflation.

headline: JAPAN DETAILS EASING ON IMPORTS
abstract: Japan today detailed the measures it would take to open its markets to more foreign goods. The measures are part of its response to increasing pressures from the United States and Western Europe, which are suffering high unemployment while running huge trade deficits with Japan.   ''Japan realizes that its prosperity depends upon the prosperity of the United States and Europe,'' said Masumi Esaki, a former Minister of International Trade and Industry and chairman of a special committee of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party charged with easing trade frictions. ''Therefore, we are determined to do all we can to maintain the free-trade system.''

headline: Business Conditions; ENERGY PRICE EFFECT
abstract: Energy conservation has been a persistent theme of the past eight years, but a recent study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development shows that the push to use energy more efficiently has taken years to develop and was strongest when real price increases were passed on to energy users.   In the 1982 Economic Outlook, O.E.C.D. analysts found that energy intensity - a ratio of energy usage to economic production - declined 3.7 percent in 1973-76 and 7.9 percent 1978-81 among the seven most developed economies.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Comsat, Washington, has named Robert W. Kinzie vice president, satellite systems and technology of Comsat General; Edmund Bartlett 3d, vice president, finance and administration of Comsat General; Don R. Owen, vice president of earth station programs of Comsat General, and Stanley L. Shubilla, vice president of finance and administration of Comsat World Systems division.   * GTE Lighting Products, Stamford, Conn., has appointed James F.  Cosgrove vice president of research and engineering.

headline: Hanna Mining Net Off 66.4%
abstract: The Hanna Mining Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 66.4 percent, to $4.2 million, or 47 cents a share, from $12.5 million, or $1.39 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues dropped 28.6 percent, to $62.3 million, from $87.3 million.

headline: Market Place; Strategists' Viewpoint
abstract: SINCE the fourth quarter of 1980, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has embraced the disinflation theme as a main prop of its investment strategy, says Burton Siegel, research director for this major brokerage house.   ''Regardless of what is going on in the world,'' he reiterated this week, ''disinflation - or lower levels of inflation - is here to stay for 1982 and certainly into 1983.''   Does this imply a vigorous economic recovery when the current slump is over? Not in the eyes of Mr. Siegel. ''Once we get out of this recession,'' he declared, ''the recovery will be the slowest since the end of World War II.''

headline: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; C.E.A.'s Use Of 'Plonking'
abstract: THE late Stephen Potter, famous as the discoverer of Gamesmanship (''the art of winning at games without actually cheating''), also made important but less noticed contributions to economics, which he called ''the plonking science.'' By plonking he meant the uttering of trite and obvious ideas in a heavy, pompous manner.   Mr. Potter discovered two basic ploys used by plonking economists.  The first (Economic Approach A) relies on ''a little wild incomprehensibility.'' A still-useful example comes from Mr. Potter's 1952 book, ''One-Upmanship'':   ''If you want to influence the general liquidity situation of banks and public,'' the economic plonker begins, pretending to expect a reply. ''If you do,'' he quickly goes on, ''I think you're forgetting that the Bank of England's discretionary action on the cash basis took the shape of dealing in Treasury Bills, the market rate of discount on which could and did fluctuate.''

headline: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
abstract: * Anacomp Inc. is offering $50 million in 13 7/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due January 2002 at a price of 85to yield 16.45 percent, to be sold through a Shearson/American Express Inc. group.   * Connecticut Natural Gas Corporation is offering 700,000 shares of common stock at a price of $17.75 a share, to be sold through a Blyth Eastman Paine Webber group.   * Hydro-Quebec is offering $200 million of 16 5/8 percent debentures, Series EQ, due 1992 at a price of 99.75 to yield 16.67 percent at maturity, to be sold through a First Boston group.

headline: Bonn Predicts Rise in G.N.P.
abstract: West Germany's gross national product is expected to grow by 1.5 percent in 1982, after having dropped by three-tenths of 1 percent in 1981, the Government said today in its annual economic report. The relatively optimistic forecast is based on expectations of a revival in world trade.

headline: Around the World; Syrian Chief Said to Fo il An Attempted Coup
abstract: A Kuwaiti newspaper, quoting Jordanian sources, said a group of Syrian Army officers had failed in an attempt to overthrow President Hafez al-Assad. Syria denied the report.

headline: Hitachi Sets Texas Plant Expansion
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. will expand facilities at its plant in Dallas to triple capacity by the middle of this year.  The plant, operated by Hitachi Semiconductor America Inc., assembles about 300,000 of the 16- and 64-kilobit random access memory, or RAM, chips a month, it said.   Industry sources noted that American semiconductor manufacturers had recently renewed calls for import curbs on Japanese chips and said that the expansion was being undertaken in the light of such calls.

headline: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MCLOUTH STEEL WINS PAY CUTS
abstract: Blue-collar employees of the struggling McLouth Steel Corporation have accepted pay concessions that will mean a $1.14 average hourly loss, a United Steelworkers of America official said.

headline: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BIC PEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: For the first time in more than a decade, serious doubts are being expressed about the soundness of the North Atlantic alliance's strategy in defense of Western Europe.   Forward defense is the essence of this strategy. This means that with sufficient warning of Soviet aggression, all allied troops in West Germany would move forward to the frontier areas. An increasing number of professional soldiers in Europe believe this strategy is unwise. U ntil recently their misgivings have been muted, but several factors, amon g them the possibility that American troops now in Germany might be needed for operations outside the NATO area, have forced re-exa mination of the basic strategy.

headline: SEOUL UNITY OFFER REFUSED BY NORTH
abstract: North Korea today rejected South Korea's latest proposal for reunification, insisting that United States troops be withdrawn from South Korea first.   In response to a plan announced Friday by President Chun Doo Hwan, North Korea said, ''To our regret, it cannot be considered a 'proposal' worthy of any positive significance.''   The North Korean press agency, in announcing the rejection, transmitted a speech by Vice President Kim Il, chairman of a North Korean committee for reunification, calling for acceptance of North Korea's own plan to end the 36-year division.

headline: Careers; Executive Perspective In Schools
abstract: IN-RESIDENCE programs are being widely used at graduate schools of business to introduce students to business leaders. At the same time, the programs provide the executives with an interesting experience, sometimes tinged with nostalgia.   Programs vary. Some schools invite retired executives, some working ones. Cornell asks a recently retired executive for a full semester on campus, where he serves as a kind of visiting professor.  Dartmouth asks executives to spend a week or so, while other schools invite them for a few days.

headline: AUTO PRICE CUT SOUGHT BY DEALERS
abstract: Consumers now look at cars more as transportation appliances than as an expression of their success in life, and this has made them more practical and intensely price-sensitive.   That is the consensus that emerges from discussions with auto dealers attending the annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association here. The group has once again urged auto makers to convert their current rebates into permanent price reductions to stimulate sales.   ''People see cars as things now,'' said Hugh Greer, owner of a Toyota-Subaru dealership in Wappingers Falls, N.Y. ''They come in and say, 'I'm going to keep this thing for 10 years.' There aren't many people anymore who plan to trade in their car every two or three years.''

headline: SOCIAL DEMOCRAT WINS A BY-ELECTION IN GLASGOW
abstract: Roy Jenkins, the 61-year-old former president of the Common Market, won a seat in Parliament this morning.   Mr. Jenkins, a Chancellor of the Exchequer and Deputy Prime Minister in past Labor Governments, scored a solid victory in Thursday's by-election in the Hillhead constituency in Glasgow.   He ran as the candidate of the year-old Social Democratic Party, in alliance with the Liberal Party, and he is expected to be named leader of the Social Democrats and of the alliance within six months. He would become Prime Minister if his party can defeat the Conservative Party of the incumbent, Margaret Thatcher, as well as the Labor Party.

headline: Hartford Unit In Deposit Bid
abstract: The Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Association, confronted two weeks ago by a near run in which more than $9 million was withdrawn by nervous depositors, today began to try to lure back its customers.   As one incentive, the savings and loan association said it would refund penalties that were incurred by customers' premature withdrawal of certificates of deposit.

headline: PRODUCTIVITY OFF 6 1 2% IN PERIOD
abstract: Productivity for all private business, including farming and nonfinancial corporations, fell a revised 6.5 percent in the fourth quarter from the level a year earlier, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.   But, it increased 2.5 percent in all of 1981, the highest yearly figure since 1977, according to preliminary data released by the bureau. Preliminary figures had shown a 7.2 percent decline in the fourth quarter.

headline: Prospects
abstract: OPEC's Last Waltz?   Times have never been worse for OPEC. Oil prices keep slipping, economists keep pushing back estimates of the strength and timing of recovery in major consuming nations, and the cartel's own revenues are falling sharply. So the OPEC gathering in Vienna this week is likely to be a critical and cantankerous one.   Much of action may take place before Friday, when the session formally begins, says Philip Verleger, an oil analyst with Booz Allen Hamilton. In order to defuse bickering about future production levels, Saudi Arabia, which has cut ouput by roughly 3 million barrels a day in the last 12 months, to 7.5 million, may announce more cuts as well as a price drop of around $2 a barrel. However, those steps may not be enough, Mr. Verleger says.

headline: Advertising; Agencies Seek Sears Account
abstract: WASTING no time, Sears, Roebuck & Company, which said Tuesday that it would consolidate its three apparel accounts at one agency, began talking to Chicago agencies yesterday in its Chicago headquarters.  The account - for women's, men's and children's clothing - comes to $30 million.   One of the agencies was Foote, Cone & Belding, which had the women's apparel business, as well as tires and batteries, and is the only incumbent being invited to pitch for the collective business.

headline: TWO BANKS DOWNGRADE POLISH DEBT
abstract: The Marine Midland Bank of New York and the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia reported yesterday that they had placed their loans to Poland in the category of ''nonperforming assets.''   The banks, the first in the West to announce such action, thus officially confirmed to their shareholders that Poland was not paying interest as originally scheduled. But the two institutions did not write off their loans, which were well below $100 million, as losses.    In fact, bankers said, the fact that these loans were put in the ''nonperforming'' category and not listed as losses indicated a belief that the loans would eventually be repaid. Bankers Remain Sanguine   The accounting steps reflected an attitude that is widespread among American bankers with loans to Poland. Although they have been frustrated in their attempts to collect overdue interest payments, the bankers say the situation does not threaten the basic soundness of the international banking structure or the soundness of any individual bank.

headline: Excerpts from testimony, page A6.
abstract: The Reagan Administration made clear today that while it was willing to enter into talks with Cuba on issues in the Caribbean basin and Central America, it did not believe such an approach in itself would solve the region's problems.   Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, told a House panel that mere talks would not suffice to ease tensions. In a Senate committee hearing, Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. said the United States would not ''accept that the future of the Caribbean basin be manipulated from Havana.''   While the two officials testified, diplomats here and in Mexico City confirmed that a special State Department envoy, Gen. Vernon E.  Walters, met with Fidel Castro for four hours in Havana earlier this month to discuss Cuba's relationship with Nicaragua and with the insurgents in El Salvador.

headline: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canada-Peking Pact Signed
abstract: Canada and China signed an agreement today setting up a 1982-83 cultural exchange program, the New China News Agency reported. The program covers the arts, journalism, broadcasting, television, film, publishing, sport, the humanities and social sciences.

headline: INDIA FACING TOO MAN ENDANGERED RHINOS
abstract: With the still-endangered great Indian onehorned rhinoceros increasing in numbers, India is considering moving about 60 of them from their main sanctuary in the northeastern state of Assam to other parts of the country.   To naturalists, the reasons are ecological, but to activist university students who have led a two-year campaign in Assam against unrestricted settlement in the state by people from neighboring Bangladesh, the proposed transfer is an attempt by the central Government to deprive the Assamese of a tourist attraction.   At the start of this century there were reported to be only a dozen of the animals in India. Now there are said to be more than 1,400.  Sharad Gaur, an education officer of the World Wildlife Fund, said the rhinos had multiplied faster than expected in the last decade and the concentration in Assam's Kaziranga preserve had reached ''the saturation point.''

headline: 3,000 More Layoffs Set by Caterpillar
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced today that it planned to lay off 3,000 more workers, raising the number of United States employees on indefinite layoff to 10,000, because it expects lower 1982 sales.   The maker of heavy machinery, tractors and earthmoving equipment said it now expects 1982 physical sales volume - the dollar volume of sales without the effect of price changes -to be moderately lower than 1981.

headline: REAGAN AND VOLCKER IN TALKS
abstract: President Reagan and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, met Monday to discuss monetary and budget policy, Administration officals confirmed today.  No details of the conversation were made public.   ''It was a good meeting,'' said one Administration official who asked not to be named. The official said that the meeting covered a broad range of economic issues, including monetary policy and budget deficits. But, the official said, the main reason for the session was to reinforce the ''personal relationship'' between the two men. The two last met in December.

headline: NEW FROM SILICON VALLEY: THE WINCHESTER DRIVE
abstract: SAN JOSE, Calif.  W HILE the rest of the electronics industry is bracing to weather the recession, one young business has made an extraordinary debut, one that its partisans compare to the first months of the calculator and digital watch booms of the early 70's.   Like lots of new technology, the product involved does not sound like much. It's called a micro Winchester drive, or rigid micro disk drive. A micro Winchester is a memory storage device for personal computers that uses a 5 1/4-inch metal memory disk. It is both a challenger and a companion to the so-called ''floppy'' disk drive, itself only 10 years old and the memory device now used most often in personal computers. Just since last January, almost 30 companies have announced their entries into the Winchester drive market, according to John Trifari, West Coast ed itor of Mini-Micro Systems, a computer trade magazine.  And during on e particularly busy week last November, at least six companies ope ned their doors for business.

headline: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITED STATES STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADORANS ARE ACCUSED OF MORE MASSACRES
abstract: Guerrillas and villagers in San Vicente Province say that Government security forces murdered a total of 124 people in this Salvadoran hamlet and two nearby hamlets in January, but the charges could not be verified on a visit to El Campanario today.   Facts were hard to ascertain here, and there was evidence only of tragedy: 14 human skulls, bloodstained clothes, including a little girl's yellow dress, and several female scalps with thick black hair, one still adorned with an ornamental comb.   A United States Embassy spokesman said that an investigation into the reported massacre began this morning in response to the charges made by people living in the area and publicized over the weekend by a church-related human rights organization.   The spokesman said that all serious charges of human rights violations are investigated by the embassy, which is required to report such violations to the State Department.

headline: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Federated to Buy Twin Fair Stores
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest retailer, has agreed to buy Twin Fair Inc.'s 14 discount department stores in western New York for an undisclosed price, Twin Fair announced.

headline: Funds Curb Sought by Fed Member
abstract: A member of the Federal Reserve Board, Lyle E. Gramley, urged Congress today to authorize the Fed to impose reserve requirements on money market funds to the extent that they are used for transaction, or checking account, purposes.   But Mr. Gramley told a House banking subcommittee that he does not believe money market funds and other financial innovations developed in recent years have so far become a serious problem for the Fed in its managing of the money supply.

headline: Sony in French Deal
abstract: The Sony Corporation said today that it would invest 141 million francs, or about $23 million, to build a video cassette production facility near Dax in southwestern France.  It said the factory, which would be its second in France, would start operating in the summer of 1983 and should produce around 10 million video cassettes in the first year and 15 million in subsequent years.

headline: Product Introductions Increased in December
abstract: New product introductions rose to 121 in December from 116 during the same month in 1980.

headline: Bond List Unavailable
abstract: A schedule of bond offerings for this week was not available because of the New Year's holiday.

headline: HAIG, ON EVE OF NATO TALKS, SAYS HE WANTS UNITY ON SOVIET SANCTIONS
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States would press its allies at a special NATO meeting here Monday for agreement on a framework for imposing sanctions against Moscow if the situation in Poland is not ''remedied in the immediate future.''   Mr. Haig, speaking at a news conference aboard his Air Force plane flying to the first emergency foreign ministers' meeting in the history of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said that the United States also intended to ask the allies for a statement condemning Soviet involvement in the Polish situation.   Mr. Haig's comments about what he expected from the alliance went beyond what he had said in Washington last week after President Reagan had met with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany. Then, Mr. Haig indicated that the United States would not press for economic sanctions against the Russians - something opposed by Bonn at this time - and seemed satisfied with the NATO meeting limiting itself to a statement holding Moscow responsible for the Polish crisis.   Mr. Haig said he was concerned that the Western allies not soften their response to the events in Poland by what he called ''the phony moderation'' of the Polish leadership in recent days.

headline: REMARKS BY SANDINIST
abstract: Following are excerpts from remarks to the Security Council by Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of the Nicaraguan junta, as translated by the Nicaraguan Mission to the United Nations: The U.S. Government has entered into a period of meetings with representatives of the Mexican Government. After a round of meetings with the Mexican Foreign Minister, Don Jorge Castaneda, Mr. Alexander Haig made public a five-point proposal aimed at initiating conversations with Nicaragua following the elections scheduled for March 28th in El Salvador.   The mere fact that the United States makes public a willingness to negotiate with Nicaragua on the basis of these points could be considered an encouraging element; but it turns out to be contradictory because, as I have been demonstrating throughout this exposition, the aggressive and destablilizing actions against Nicaragua by the U.S. Administration have been dramatically on the rise.   The five points announced by Mr. Haig do not constitute a global approach to search for and find realistic solutions. The proposal fails to take into account the fact that the fundamental problem of the Central American crisis does not consist of the never-proven allegation that arms are reaching the Salvadoran revolutionaries via Nicaragua while, on the other hand, the United States is supplying arms, airplanes, helicopters, advisers, technical support and hurried military training to the Salvadoran army.

headline: Patents; Other Uses For Teller Machines
abstract: WASHINGTON A VETERAN inventor, with more than 200 patents, proposes that automatic bank teller machines be used to transfer funds to program the operation of postage meters in offices. Luther G. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was granted a patent this week for apparatus to issue cards that the meters will accept.

headline: 5 Are Stabbed in London
abstract: Five people were stabbed Friday night in clashes between young blacks and whites in a London housing project, the police said today. One of the five, Diana Duberry, 16 years old, was reported in serious condition at a hospital. A Scotland Yard spokesman said the fights broke out after bricks were thrown through windows of a disco in the Hackney district of East London.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MARCOS TO VISIT SAUDI ARABIA TO EASE MOSLEM-REBEL ISSUE
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos is scheduled to visit Saudi Arabia this month for the first time. It is a country with which the Philippines has been developing close ties.   The three-day visit will give him an opportunity to reply to charges that the predominantly Christian Philippines is not doing all it could to resolve peacefully the decades-old conflict between Christians and the five million Moslems in the southern part of the country.

headline: MID-CONTINENT TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Some Withdraw DeLorean Suits
abstract: A major threat to the insolvent DeLorean Motor Company was lifted when some creditors withdrew court petitions that would have forced the company into liquidation.   One such creditor was Tony Scott, owner of an engineering company that builds precision parts for the car.

headline: Market Place; How Nike Sets A Fast Pace
abstract: NIKE Inc., which did not exist 20 years ago, has become a major factor in an industry that has stymied a lot of companies: marketing specialty shoes. Part of Nike's secret is that, unlike many other shoe enterprises, it does not spend a lot of money on factories.  Instead, Nike buys its shoes from South Korean and other foreign manufacturers.   A superior product and the low-capital approach have produced soaring profits for the Oregon-based company. Philip Knight, who founded Nike in the mid-1960's, was on the track team at the University of Oregon. While there, he wrote a paper about imported track shoes.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 30, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on the situation in Israeli-oc- cupied territories at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Conference on the Law of the Sea - 10:30 A.M., 3 P.M. and 8 P.M. headline: French Steel Output Off
abstract: French output of crude steel in 1981 fell 8.2 percent from 1980, to 21.27 million tons, the steel producers' association said today.

headline: Fiat Raising Prices 3.5%
abstract: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, announced today that it would raise prices of its automobiles by an average of 3.5 percent on April 2.
