headline: Head of Optical Concern
abstract: John Lawrence, 70, a former head of Dresser Industries and chairman of Recognition Equipment Inc., a manufacturer of optical character recognition equipment, has been temporarily named president and chief executive officer of Recognition Equipment. He succeeds Jay Rodney Reese, 55, who resigned from the company, which is based in Dallas.

headline: WEST GERMANY, TOO, IS FACING A CRISIS OF THE CITIES
abstract: For many West Germans, this city has a cruelly dismal reputation as just another Ruhr town, a workaday place in a valley of smoke and smog and sweat.   The assumption is wrong, an old cliche. Gelsenkirchen, although no Alhambra, looks clean and cared-for, and it feels friendly. But the city itself, like dozens of others, is in deep trouble, a situation that undercuts the widely held assumptions about postwar West Germany.   The crisis of the cities that is developing means that cuts in social services, education and leisure expenditures are for the first time being considered in the light of debt and poor economic prospects. Just as the accepted notions of the 1960's and 1970's about the strengths and stability of the West German armed forces, labor unions, press and academic worlds seem less certain, so does the idea that West Germany has built an indestructible shell of prosperity and soc ial welfare.

headline: No Headline
abstract: COMMUNIQUE BY THE COMMON MARKET   BRUSSELS, Jan. 4 (AP) - Following is the text of the communique on Poland issued today by the foreign ministers of the European Economic Community:   BRUSSELS, Jan. 4 (AP) - Following is the text of the communique on Poland issued today by the foreign ministers of the European Economic Community:   The Ten utterly disapprove of the development of the situation in Poland.  They have noted the declarations of the Polish leadership of its intention to maintain national independence and to re-establish in the near future liberty and the process of reform as well as resuming the dialogue with the various elements of the Polish nation.  Unhappily, the Ten must note today that, contrary to these declarations, what has taken place has not been dialogue but repression bringing with it violations of the most elementary human and citizens' rights, contrary to the Helsinki Final Act, the United Nations Charter and the Universal Declarations of Human Rights.   The Te n the refore appeal urgently to the Polish authorities to end as soon as po ssible the state of martial law, to release those arrested and to resore a general dialogue with the church and Solidarity.

headline: Correction
abstract: Because of wrong information supplied by Arthur Anderson & Company, the value of a 10-year charitable lead trust that provides a charity with income of $8,000 a year from the securities funding the trust was incorrectly stated in ''A Way to Give a Lot, for Less'' (Dec.  20). The value of that gift today is $58,880, and would have reduced 1981 taxes for someone in the 70 percent bracket by $41,206.

headline: SMITH KLINE INCREASES 19.9%
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, hurt by foreign currency exchange translation, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 6.2 percent, while sales fell 9 percent.   Union Carbide, the nation's third-largest chemical company after E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Dow Chemical Company, said that earnings in the latest quarter slipped to $139.8 million, or $2.04 a share, from $149 million, or $2.21 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales of the concern fell to $2.43 billion from $2.67 billion.   Net income in the fourth quarter included an after-tax currency loss of about 30 cents a share, compared with a currency gain of about 16 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 1980.

headline: A.T. & T.'S NET IS WORLD RECORD
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its net income for the year rose 13.7 percent, to $6.89 billion, or $8.55 a share, the highest profit ever reported by any company in the world.   The increase, almost twice the 7.2 percent improvement that the phone company registered in 1980, came to a large extent as a result of higher phone rates.   The 1981 profits compare with $6.06 billion, or $8.17 a share, earned in 1980. These numbers were restated slightly to reflect an accounting change.

headline: Mitterrand to Meet Reagan Next Week During U.S. Visit
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France will meet with President Reagan in Washington on March 12, the White House announced today.

headline: Sales Fall in Canada
abstract: Retail sales in Canada fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December, to $8.11 billion (Canadian), seasonally adjusted, after a 4 percent rise in November, Statistics Canada said today.

headline: Payment to Times Co.
abstract: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had received a partial prepayment from the sale of its Australian and New Zealand magazine operations.

headline: PRESSURE FOR BUDGET CHANGES
abstract: There is a widespread feeling among top corporate executives that President Reagan must - and eventually will - compromise with Congress in its demands for spending cuts and tax adjustments that would help close the $91.5 billion budget deficit projected for 1983.    A re-evaluation of some of the basic elements of the President's economic program, they say, is essential if the recovery promised for late 1982 is to be either substantial or sustained.   ''When there is enough at stake people will compromise, and there is enough at stake now,'' remarked Edward F. Gibbons, chairman of the F.W. Woolworth Company. ''We are at a point where people have to be sensible. The interest rate situation is becoming intolerable and unless we do something about the deficits causing that situation, any recovery will be anemic and short-lived.''

headline: HAIG BACKED IN OUSTER OF OFFICIAL
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has won permission from President Reagan to replace a highranking S tate Department official after demanding White House support on th e matter, according to well-placed Administration sources.   The President has given Mr. Haig the authority to replace the official, Myer Rashish, as Undersecretary for Economic Affairs with his deputy, Robert D. Hormats, currently Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, the sources said.   The sources said that Mr. Haig sought White House authority for the move before his trip today to Europe for a meeting of North Atlantic Treaty Organization foreign ministers after reports that the Administration had not supported his threat to dismiss Mr. Rashish.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Citicorp said a rate of 15.94 percent was set at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commerical paper, compared with 15.421 percent last week.   * Continental Illinois Overseas Finance Corp., a subsidiary of Continental Illinois Corp., announced a $100 million Euronote offering due 1989, with a 15.75 percent coupon rate, to be sold through a Morgan Grenfell group.   * Standard & Poor's Corp. said it had added Ethyl Corp. and the State of Rhode Island to its weekly Creditwatch list of entities whose securities may be subject to ratings changes.

headline: Pentacostal Fears Draft
abstract: A 19-year-old Pentecostalist Christian taking sanctuary at the United States Embassy said today that Soviet officials are trying to draft him into the army, a move that could complicate his attempt to emigrate to the United States. The Pentacostalist, Timofei Chmykhalov.

headline: SOUTHERN METHODIST NAMES BUSINESS DEAN
abstract: Roy A. Herberger Jr., 39, will join Southern Methodist University on June 1 as dean of its Edwin L. Cox School of Business. The Dallas position has been vacant since November 1980, when Alan B. Coleman, 53, resigned. Mr. Coleman is now president of the Foundation for the Southwestern Graduate School of Banking at S.M.U.   ''The actual teaching methodology I'm not going to fool with,'' Mr. Herberger said. ''What I first intend on doing is taking a look at how the business school can help Dallas and the northeastern part of Texas grow. I really want to make sure that we're in sync with that community.''

headline: MACY POSTS 5.1% GAIN IN QUARTER
abstract: R.H. Macy & Company, the first of the nation's major retailers to report earnings in the most recent fiscal quarter, said yesterday that net income increased 5.1 percent and sales advanced 10.4 percent.   The company said that the latest quarter was affected by numerous markdowns as well as high interest costs, but that operating expenses ''had been held in line.''   Macy's said that net income in its second quarter, ended Jan. 30, rose to $62.3 million, or $3.78 a share, from $59.3 million, or $3.67, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose to $935.5 million from $847 million.

headline: Poland's Debt Extended
abstract: A group of Western banks agreed today to allow Poland more time to repay interest that came due last year, a spokesman for Dresdner Bank said. The move postpones from today to early April a signing date for the agreement rescheduling payments of $2.4 billion in interest and principal that came due in 1981. Poland failed to meet a Feb.15 deadline for repaying the remaining 1981 interest, estimated at $50 million to $75 million.

abstract: Shareholders of the Reliance Group Inc. voted overwhelmingly yesterday to approve the offer by Saul P. Steinberg and his family to take the major, New York-based insurance holding company private.  Earlier, a similar offer was approved by shareholders of the Leasco Corporation, a computer leasing concern.

headline: G.M. Cutbacks To Idle 60,400
abstract: The General Motors Corporation announced plant closings and production cutbacks for various periods over the next four months that will put 60,400 employees out of work, 5,400 of them indefinitely.

headline: PPG OFF 41.6%
abstract: Nabisco Brands Inc. said yesterday that strong gains by its bakery and domestic foods divisions helped lift earnings 14.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981.   Sales, however, slipped 1 percent owing to the effect on international results of the strong United States dollar and lower prices for the company's high-fructose corn syrup.   The company said that net income in the latest three months rose to $86.1 million, or $1.36 a share, from $75.4 million, or $1.19 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales dipped to $1.57 billion from $1.59 billion.

headline: British Output Down
abstract: Britain's industrial output fell fourtenths of 1 percent in January, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Government reported today. Some of the January drop was attributed to wintry weather and strikes.

headline: Market Place; Home Lending In California
abstract: LOS ANGELES THE mortgage market is alive - but not particularly well - in California. Even so, the Financial Corporation of America here is aggressively lending to home buyers, unlike most of the state's thrift institutions.   The management of this financial services holding company reasons that home buyers will take mortgages as long as the monthly payments are within their means. To get them there takes some doing, inasmuch as the company's savings and loan association currently gets 17 1/4 percent for mortgage money.

headline: POLAND REPORTED PAYING DEBT UNAIDED BY SOVIET
abstract: Administration economic officials said today that the Soviet Union, contrary to speculation, had not been making international debt payments for Poland, but the Polish Government, from its own resources, had managed to pay since mid-December $100 million in overdue interest to Western banks. Robert D. H ormats, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affa irs, and Marc E. Leland,   Poland expects to reach agreement with Western banks next week on rescheduling its loans. But the Polish Government is worried about the suspension of talks with its 16 creditor nations. Page D3.

headline: INCREASE IN RATES IS EXPECTED
abstract: Short-term interest rates are widely expected to rise in late March and April in tandem with large increases in the nation's money supply, but analysts disagree about whether the higher rates and money supply surge will be temporary or long-lasting.   ''When an event like this money supply bulge is so widely anticipated, the difficulty is to know to what extent it has already been discounted in the financial markets,'' commented Richard Scott-Ram, an economist at the Chemical Bank. He estimated that short-term interest rates would rise slightly in April but would be reversed in May. Overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market might rise to an average of 14 3/4 percent in April, up from 14.48 percent in the week ended March 24.

headline: Teledyne Files Harvester Plan
abstract: Teledyne Inc. disclosed that it planned to raise its stake in the financially ailing International Harvester Company to more than 15 percent.   Teledyne and its subsidiaries currently own 11.8 percent of Harvester's common shares and about 1.3 million of Harvester's nonvoting Series C convertible preferred shares.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Teledyne said it planned to acquire the additional shares in the open market, by private purchase and or by converting Series C preferred shares.

headline: REAGAN PROPOSES OWN PLAN TO CUT MISSILES IN EUROPE
abstract: President Reagan announced today that the United States had presented the Soviet Union with a draft treaty that proposed the elimination of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.   The draft treaty, which is based on the ''zero option'' plan endorsed by Mr. Reagan over two months ago, was introduced on Tuesday during the negotiations on limiting medium-range nuclear arms in Europe, according to a White House spokesman. Those talks began last November in Geneva.   ''I call on President Brezhnev to join us in this important first step to reduce the nuclear shadow that hangs over the peoples of the world,'' Mr. Reagan said in a statement released today by the White House.

headline: British Blow Up a Car
abstract: The police blew up a suspicious automobile found parked today on the route along which Queen Elizabeth II was to drive to Buckingham Palace with Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman. The route was changed. A Scotland Yard spokesman said tests later showed there had been no explosives in the car.

headline: Demonstration Is Halted In a Yugoslav City
abstract: The police said today that they broke up a demonstration Sunday night by several hundred people in Pristina, capital of the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo, where nine people died in Albanian nationalist riots last spring.   Communist Party leaders in Pristina issued a statement today saying the demonstration was ''the most serious endangering of public peace and order since the spring riots.''

headline: FAFCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STUDY BY BONN FORESEES TROUBLE FOR THE MILITARY
abstract: The West German armed forces, generally regarded as the strongest component in Western defense outside the United States, have entered a period of difficulty and possible decline, according to an official study prepared for Defense Minister Hans Apel.   The 100-page report to Mr. Apel on the West German military over the next 20 years was made 16 months ago by the ministry's planning staff but came to light only recently. It says that ''additional data will not change the trends.''   It warns that a web of financial, personnel and political problems has created circumstances in which it is incr easingly questionable if West Germany can fully maintain over the n ext decades its commitments to NATO, its force levels and the advanced technological status of its fighting units. Assumptions Being Questioned   For more than two decades after their creation in 1955, the armed forces seemed to reflect basic assumptions about the stability and economic strength of the young West German democracy. Now, as assumptions about the country's prosperity and the immutability of some of its institutions -the cities, the labor unions and the press, for example - seem less certain, so do the standard, almost reflexive, views of the armed forces.

headline: British Court Blocks Appeal O n Rights of Canada's Indians
abstract: The Court of Appeal refused today to grant Canadian Indians permission to appeal to t he House of Lords, Britain's court of last resort, in their lega l fight for land rights.   The decision followed the Court of Appeal's rejection Thursday of a request by Albertan Indians that Britain guarantee their land rights, granted 200 years ago when Canada was a British colony.   The court ruled that the Canadian Government had the responsibility for honoring the obligations.

headline: Chrysler Gets Pension Delay
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union has agreed to give the Chrysler Corporation until September 1984 to pay its $187 million pension contribution for 1980, the two sides said today.   The deferral, which has the authorization of the Internal Revenue Service, will save Chrysler about $93 million during the first three months of 1982.

headline: HAIG AND MEXICAN DISAGREE ON FLOW OF SALVADOR ARMS
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda of Mexico met in New York yesterday to discuss the situation in Central America. But they disagreed over the issue of Nicaraguan arms shipments to leftist insurgents in El Salvador.   After the two-and-a-half-hour meeting, Mr. Haig told reporters that a failure to deal with the Nicaraguan concern was the principal weakness in the peace plan advanced last month by President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico.   Mr. Castaneda described the current arms flow from Nicaragua to El Salvador as ''fairly small and unimportant.'' Halting it, he said, depends on United States concessions, among them a less belligerent attitude toward Nicaragua.

headline: 13 Die in Peruvian Floods
abstract: Thirteen people died Friday in Cuzco Province as a result of natural disasters caused by heavy rain. Five people were killed by a flood in Cirialo and eight by a landslide in Ninabamba.

headline: Around the World; Military Air Crash Kills 53 in South Korea
abstract: A military transport plane crashed into South Korea's highest mountain on a military exercise, killing all 53 people aboard, the Defense Ministry said today.

abstract: The Xerox Corporation announced an average price reduction of 25 percent on three of its low- to mid-volume copying machines and increases in service contract rates for all its copiers and duplicators.   Xerox officials said that, effective Jan. 1, the United States price of its 4000 model copier was cut to $10,995, the 3400 to $10,995, and the 3450 to $13,995.

headline: Patents; Method Developed For Marking Diamonds
abstract: A method of ''fingerprinting'' diamonds and other crystals has been patented by staff members at the Research and Development Center of the General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y. Patent 4,316,385, granted Robert C. DeVries and Roy E. Tuft this week, explains that natural diamonds, synthetic diamonds and cubic boron nitride can be marked without damage to their external appearance.  A beam of ions (charged atoms) is used to mark the diamond's interior with an invisible pattern.

headline: INSURANCE EXECUTIVE CHOSEN TO HEAD S.B.A.
abstract: President Reagan has chosen a California civil engineer and insurance executive to head the Small Business Administration.  James C. Sanders, the nominee, is 55 years old.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * FCB International, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, has acquired an interest in Gnomi Advertising and Marketing in Athens.

headline: Advertising
abstract: THE young man from the client's office was chatting the other day with the young man from the agency's office about the difficulty in reaching the audience they were both trying to attract: ''high networth individuals.''   John A. Laurino, the young man from the client's office, defined the target group as persons with at least a million dollars in liquid assets. Real estate does not count.

headline: THE PLUNGE IN PENNY STOCKS
abstract: Only 15 months ago, Denver's penny stock market was riding the crest of the Rocky Mountain energy boom. So many new brokerage firms had crowded along 17th Street, the main downtown thoroughfare, that the area came to be known as ''Wall Street West.''    In the last six weeks, however, the city's over-the-counter market has been on the skids. Six of the almost 30 brokerage houses trading in the offerings of small, untried oil companies have gone out of business - three as a result of court-ordered liquidation following inspections by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers.

headline: Indian Legislators in Melee
abstract: Legislators punched and kicked each other in a 15-minute free-for-all in the Rajasthan State Assembly today.  The altercation took place after the Speaker had called for a vote on a report by the state's Business Advisory Committee and opposition lawmakers objected, demanding further debate, the United News of India reported.

headline: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Jan 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Loan for Mexican Bank
abstract: Banco Nacional de Credito Rural, the stateowned Mexican agricultural bank, has arranged a $400 million eightyear loan with tougher terms than Mexican borrowers had negotiated late last year, bankers said today.

headline: ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IRAQ MAKES OVERTURE TO END WAR WITH IRAN
abstract: Iraq has made a new overture to end the 18-month-old war with Iran.  With his troops apparently unable to make further military gains, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sent a special envoy to Guinea with written proposals for President Ahmed Sekou Toure, head of a nine-member Islamic mediation mission.   Arab diplomats here said the Iraqis were apparently demonstrating some flexibility.  The envoy, Hamid Alwan, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, told the Gulf News Agency, which is based in Bahrain, that the new proposals were ''important'' and that they could bring about a ''farreaching result in fixing responsibility for the current conflict.'' He declined, however, to disclose the contents.

headline: SANDINIST DEFENDS MILITARY BUILDUP
abstract: One of the members of the Nicaraguan junta said today that the military buildup here was ''exclusively defensive'' and that the United States was making charges to the contrary to justify a possible intervention.   The Sandinist official, Sergio Ramirez Mercado, conceded in an interview that the country had expanded its armed forces and that garrisons were more scattered than when Nicaragua was ruled by Anastasio Somoza Debayle, but he disputed charges from Washington that 2,000 Cuban soldiers were at the side of the Nicaraguan troops.  ''There is not a single foreign soldier in Nicaragua,'' he said. Seeking Nonaggression Pact   ''When Mr. Haig is saying every day that they are going to bomb us and attack us and blockade us, how can they then turn around and ask us not to defend ourselves?'' he asked.

headline: AUTO CONNCESSION IMPACT DEBATED BY ECONOMISTS
abstract: Business economists and forecasters are sharply divided over the extent to which the wage concessions made by workers at the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation will be adopted by other sectors of American industry.   Many experts argue that the concessions agreed to by the United Automobile Workers will obviously have a powerful ''demonstration effect'' for other businesses throughout the economy, thus toughening the bargaining stance of managers elsewhere and leading to widespread worker ''givebacks.''   Others contend, however, that the impact of the widely publicized settlements will be limited by the fact that both the wages and the business conditions prevailing in the auto industry were exceptional - a circumstance that has undermined thetraditional trend-setting role. Unions Created Major Gap   ''I doubt it will have much impact on other sectors of the economy,'' said Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford. ''The United Auto Workers and United Steelworkers of America have managed to create a major gap between their own compensation rates and the average for manufacturing wages. They succeeded in pricing their labor out of the market relative to both American and foreign competition.

headline: Advertising; Chemical Bank Sets Campaign
abstract: CHEMICAL BANK will break a new worldwide corporate advertising campaign tomorrow with the theme ''Chemical Takes You Beyond Tradition.''   It is the first effort from N.W. Ayer, which replaced Marsteller last March as the corporate agency. It will not affect ''The Chemistry's Just Right At Chemical,'' coming out of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, the product agency for four years.

headline: TECHNOLOGY MAGAZINES' SPURT
abstract: When Bernard A. Goldhirsh was a hard-working engineering science major at M.I.T., he wrestled with the problem of bad vibrations on military vessels.   Now, 20 years later, Mr. Goldhirsh is the publisher of two new magazines about technology, and he is betting $4 million in start-up costs that the publications will stay afloat. This time, he reports, the vibrations are fine.   ''More and more, the business of America is becoming technology,'' and the magazines ''are on target and on budget and doing well,'' said Mr. Goldhirsh, who also puts out the small-business magazine Inc.

headline: Soviet Buys More Corn
abstract: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 200,000 metric tons of corn - nearly 7.9 million bushels - from the United States for delivery by Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: Cuisine Files Chapter 11 Bid
abstract: Cuisine Magazine, which moved to New York from Chicago last year, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act yesterday, calling higher operating costs here the cause of its troubles.   ''During the past year, Cuisine transferred its operations from Chicago to New York and therefore incurred substantial costs,'' said Christopher Bullen, executive vice president of the company.

headline: Around the World; South Korean Chief Ends Curfew Restrictions
abstract: President Chun Doo-hwan today ordered the lifting of curfew restrictions in force since the end of World War II.

headline: South African Premier Calls for Party Congress
abstract: Prime Minister P.W. Botha called today for the first national congress of his National Party since 1968.  Mr. Botha said the Federal Council, the party's national executive group, decided unanimously at a meeting in Cape Town to hold the congress July 30-31 in Bloemfontein, capital of the Orange Free State.   The decision came 10 days after 16 ultra-rightist party members broke away over race policy and formed the Conservative Party of South Africa.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Donate Pay
abstract: Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, the Israeli Chief of Staff, has started a program under which soldiers are donating a day's pay each month to help defray military costs. The money, which is distributed by the Israel Security Fund, a public body set up in September 1980, is being used to teach illiterate recruits to read and write, expand training programs and develop new weapons.

headline: SCHMIDT FRUSTRATED BY REGIONAL PARTY VOTES
abstract: Three Social Democratic regional party conventions passed motions on security and nuclear weapons issues today that disavowed or contradicted the programs that won a vote of confidence for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in Parliament on Friday.   The regional groups' actions, compounded by a new spate of charges and countercharges in the Government coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats, undermined the impression of stability that Mr.  Schmidt said he sought to create by calling the confidence vote.   The confidence motion dealt mainly with the Government's new program of economic stimulants, but it specifically included the Chancellor's foreign and security policies as well. As a result, the balloting in the regional conventions, summoned to prepare for a national party convention in April, had the character of gestures of dissatisfaction with Mr. Schmidt's leadership.

headline: NLT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * Jerry Harmon has joined Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising as executive vice president and director of creative services.   * James D. Johnson, a senior vice president of the Marschalk Company, has been elected to the board.

headline: British Banks Cut Rates
abstract: Britain's four major banks cut their base lending rates to 14 percent from 14 1/2 percent today, a day after the Dutch and West German central banks cut the rates on loans they make to commercial banks. The four British banks, National Westminster, Barclays, Lloyds and Midland, cut their rates after the Bank of England made funds available to them at lower interest rates. The West German central bank cut its rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent, and the Dutch central bank cut its rate to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent.

headline: Business World; New President Named At Sonat Subsidiary
abstract: Sonat Inc., the renamed Southern Natural Resources Inc., has appointed N. Thomas Williams, 48, president of its Southern Forest Products subsidiary, based in Birmingham, Ala. At Southern Forest Products, which has more than 800,000 acres of timberland and operates paper mills, he succeeds Ronald L. Kuehn, 46, who, as previously announced, has become president and chief operating officer of the parent company.

headline: Heavy Stock Trading In I.B.M. and A.T.&T.
abstract: Heavy volume marked trading in the shares of American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday. But their performances were below the expectations of many analysts who had predicted healthy advances.   ''While A.T.& T. managed to score modest gains, it was a terrible day for technology stocks and telephone stocks in general,'' said Harry Edelson, a vice president at the First Boston Corporation. ''A lot of the computer stocks are going to have a poor fourth quarter to report, and there's some bad news ahead in the technology group.''

headline: Advertising; Changing From Meat To Media
abstract: THE Mickelberry Corporation, with roots that go back to 1893, appears to be doing something that other companies have tried and failed. A noncommunications company, Mickelberry has been successfully acquiring ad agencies for almost 10 years. That is a singular achievement, according to the American Association of Advertising Agencies.   The man who took this company from processed meats and baked goods and into advertising agencies and printing companies is James C.  Marlas, a 44-year-old Harvard cum laude graduate and lawyer, who discovered agencies almost by accident and seems pleased with the results.

headline: No Headline
abstract: 1981 U.S. AUTO SALES FELL 5.3%   DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) - Sales of new American-made autos in 1981 fell 5.3 percent, to the lowest sales level since 1961, as the Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation today reported their final sales figures for the year.   The three other domestic manufacturers had issued their final figures on Tuesday.Ford said its United States car sales in the final reporting period of December, which had nine days this year and eight days in 1980, were down 34 percent, to 26,361 cars in 1981 from 35,547 in 1980. A.M.C., which reports sales monthly, said its December sales fell 19.3 percent, to 7,741 from 9,594 in 1980.   Sales for the end of December were reported on Tuesday by the General Motors Corporation, which had a 15.9 percent decline, the Chrysler Corporation, which had a drop of 36.7 percent, and Volkswagen of America, which had a gain of 21.2 percent.

headline: McLouth Creditors Extend Deadline
abstract: Major creditors of the ailing McLouth Steel Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest steelmaker, have agreed to allow the company to continue full operations through May 15 and partial operations through June 18 while the company searches for a buyer. The previous deadline set by creditors was today.

headline: Italian Layoffs Suspended
abstract: The Italian Government asked Montedison to suspend moves to lay off about 2,000 workers next month because of excess capacity.

headline: Heublein Backed On General Cinema
abstract: A Federal court order cleared the way today for Heublein Inc., the international food and beverage company, to buy more stock in the General Cinema Corporation. The two companies have been engaged in a takeover battle.
